This is where this story gets even more intensed...where we find Caden  seems to stop at nothing to win Syd back....however, there seems to be a interest growing with Den's brother Morgan who has always been best friends with Syd.  Now what do we have now...a 'love triangle?  I will say that in this read many times Syd got on my nerves with how she dealt with her life situation when it came to Den, but as the story continues we do see some changes as we see the story where this friendship between Syd and Morgan turns into something much more.  Now, we have such a dangerous situation brewing  due to the fact that Den doesn't seem to want to take the word no from Syd. What will happen as Syd and Morgan try to hid there feelings from their friends and family? However, it seems to me that if Syd had put her foot down earlier  ...but anyway...this is where I say you must pick up the novel to see how this author will bring it all out to the reader.  Be ready for an interesting read with so many twist and turns from denial, accidents, hot sexy sex, and more that will keep your attention turning the pages to see what is coming next.  The main characters as well as the secondary ones were all developed,defined, well portrayed and oh so well believable giving the reader a true forbidden romance read only leaving in the end the answer will Sydney finally get the happiness she so deserves?I will be really looking forward to this authors second series 'Edge of Scandal # 2'...'His All Night.'I received a copy through NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

Title:  Under the CoversAuthor:  Claire BostonPublisher:  Momentum BookSeries:  The Texan Quartet # 3Reviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating: FiveReview:"Under The Covers" by Claire BostonWhat I liked about this novel...I loved this sweet love story about Elle and George.  Now to make this story complete  I will have to add Elle's son Toby because he really makes this story so cute.  We find Elle had left a controlling and abusive ex boyfriend... taking her son and determined to move on with her life. Now Elle has a opened up a business and is doing OK with he son...meets George and will a friendship will come from it?  We find that Elle has been hurt too many times in her life by that ex... so will she be able to trust George?  I really liked how this author brings on this situation...with George slowing down a bit with Elle as she was able to meet his family and  friends who had assistanced her several times as it was needed in her cafe/book store.  I will say at this point this author really has some wonderful secondary characters who were well developed, defined, well portrayed and believe characters that will keep you turn the pages in this series ...and a couple I did not like [Ex boyfriend and his Mom].  As the story goes on we find that Elle will find her past has not been left behind...for her in law and ex boyfriend will come back into the picture.  How will Elle be able to face this situation?  With Elle not wanting to have in commitment to George what will come of this?  What will happen as George tries to win her and the heart of her son?  I don't want to spoil it for you other than say you will have to pick up this good read to see how it will be brought out to the readers. .Even though this is a third series...I believe 'Under The Covers' can be read as a standalone.I received this copy from the publisher via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

Title:  Secrets at Maple Syrup FarmAuthor:  Rebecca RaisinPublisher:  Carina UKReviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating: FiveReview:"Secrets at Maple Syrup Farm" by Rebecca RaisinWhat I liked about this novel....This was another one of this author's great novels that I did enjoy reading.  It was so interesting to know that Lucy's mum who was suffering from a long term illness wanted her daughter...  something special for her daughter.  So, we find Lucy on an adventure for a year...ending up in Ashford, Connecticut where her life would be changed forever.  Why was that?  Lucky was there to live her life to the fullest for one year not  worrying of her sick mum. It was there in Ashford that she meets some wonderful people....even that moody Clay who she persuaded  to give her a job as a 'farmers assistant' on the Maple syrup farm in which he had inherited.  I loved how this author was able to bring the readers back to Ashford, Connecticut which was the home of the famous 'Gingerbread Cafe' that if you are a reader of this author novels you will know all about that cafe... meeting up with many old friends..like CeeCee, and Lil to name a few.Yes, "Secrets at Maple Syrup Farm'  is of many secrets that will be dealt with in this read, however, .  I was happy to say I was able to guess a few of them early in this well written read.  The storyline will keep you turning the pages till the end because you will not want to miss anything. The heroine in the read really loves her mum and wanted to obey her but for me I found it so hard to do what Lucy had done...and that was obeying her mum wishes.  The hero, Clay...well I was able to catch what may have been his secret from what this author presented this story... still it was a good read in how this author presented it all to the reader.  I don't want to give too much away other than to say pick up "Secrets of Maple Syrup Farm" and see how well this story is brought out.  Questions will be answered...Will Lucy decide on the trip to Paris...for a career as an artist or stay in Ashford?  Will their be something for Lucky in Ashford besides wanting to be that artist?What else I liked about this novel...There was definitely a learning process of how maple syrup is made that this author covers so well in the read and I don't want to leave out all of those good baking descriptions that the ladies of the Gingerbread Cafe turned out as well in the foods you can use with maple syrup.  I will say there were a few recipes that were new to me to what you could use maple syrup in!I will say that it will be interesting to see what more may come of Lucy, Clay and her mum that only this author can do so very well especially in the small town of Ashford....what a great place to live.

Title:  Break Your HeartAuthor:  Rhonda HelmsPublisher:  KensingtonReviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating:  FourReview:"Break Your Heart"  by Rhonda HelmsWhat I liked about this novel....I found this  novel of  "Break Your Heart was a sweet New Adult read dealing with a 'African American heroine and a Asian American hero that turned out to be a sweet read especially for the New Adult readers.  The story line was right on point all the way from the beginning of the read to the end. This story of if Megan [student]and Nick[professor] who become involved. The characters were all well developed, defined, well portrayed and yes...believable that help to keep this read right on chart.  It was very interesting to see how this student was going to handle all that was put in front of her and even so with that 'professor.'  The author even worked other problems into this read that will keep the reader turning the pages to see what will happen next.  So, from a infatuation with a professor to life with family [mom issues]...we are given a read that with imply some secrets that will come out.  Will this heroine be able to handle it all?  Will Megan be able to 'silence the noise around her and listen to what her heart is telling her?  And omg that hero Nick was simply off the chart...loved that 'Terminal Tower scene.'  This is where I will say you will have to pick up this read to find out will Megan and Nick be able to make it and get what they want in the end.I received an advance copy from NOR in exchange for an honest review.

Title:  It's YouAuthor:  Jane PorterPublisher:  BerkleyReviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating: FiveReview:"It's You" by Jane PorterWhat I liked about this novel....I really like how this author was able to give the reader such a good story of healing as it was for Ali especially after she left for Napa after the death of her mother and untimely death of her finance Andrew, who had committed suicide in Arizona.  Truly life for Ali had been 'turned upside down.'  Now she was in Napa looking after her father due to falling and injuring his arm who now lived in a retirement community.  Would she be able to find some peace after all of her painful memories that had haunted her from Arizona? It was in Napa where  Ali opens up to new friendships and trying to decide what would be best for her life now that she is alone and feeling very angry.  What will happen after Ali meets a cantankerous old women named Edie who lad lost her husband in W W II?  I liked how this author was able was able to let one see that there are some many pains and losses in our world. This history was indeed interesting!  From meeting Edie why would a journey to Berlin give Ali answers about not only Edie but herself also?  Who would have known that both of these women had endured tremendous emotional pain.  In the end  would there be a way for Ali to heal and yet not forget?  I liked how this author was able to show through another person story how Ali will be able to find the courage she needed to want to live again.  I found the characters were beautiful written being so well developed, defined, some humor and so believable giving this story such a heart wrenching detailed story that I wasn't able to put down until the end...often finding myself tearing up at parts of the read.  Be ready for a good story of personal growth and self discover....also there is a backstory from a Edie's diary...but I don't want to spoil it for you...only to say you will have to pick up the good read to see for yourself what that is about."It's You" was a  well written story by this author that told two stories of two women of different generations that showed raw powerful emotions.  For Ali.... love and loss, recovered from heart break and healing  to being able to  pick up the broken pieces of the heart and the strength to make some new choices and hope again. I will go farther in saying that this is one novel that will stay with you long after you have read it.

Title:  Reservations for Two [Two Blue Doors #2]Author:  Hillary Manton LodgePublisher:  WaterBrook PressSeries: Two Blue Doors SeriesReviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating: FourReview:"Reservations for Two" by Hillary Manton LodgeWhat I liked from this novel...This story was about Julietta and Nico with  them opening up a a new place...Two Blue Doors restaurant.  There will be some problems with trying to find suppliers for the restaurant.  Now, why was that?  Along with this there seems to be some mysteries that will come up front and center as Juliette's  mother will be diagnosed with ovarian cancer and is not doing well with her treatments and then there is a long distance romance.  I felt the story started up a little slow but it does pick up and the reader will be presented a good read by this author that is told is first person narrative by Juliette. I wish I had read the first novel...'Table by the Window' first because I did have a little problem understanding some of the story and some of its characters.  However,  as I continued to read on  I did find this read somewhat captivating that did keep my attention till the end.  This was quite a interesting read where one could see this family pulling together, the inclusion of  history of written old letters between Juliette's grandmother, Mirielle and her sister that dealt with love from WWII France. Be ready because the reader will also get some surprises, happiness, sadness, drama, humanity, hope, illness, family relationship issues,long distance love,  traveling, suspense, mystery of family secrets, some new romance and even some heartbreak of a break up romance.  Then what puts the icing on the cake of this novel  .... the reader gets some very good recipes that you will be left wishing you could be there...tasting it all. I liked how this author was able to weave these unique recipes[especially those chocolate chip cookies] into the plot of this story...very well done. If you are interesting in recipes, food and cooking ... you will love this novel.  Also I enjoyed the quotes that began each chapter that dealt with food or cooking. If you are interesting in Now, in saying all of that I will say it would be best to read the first series, then this one and then the reader will be more than ready for the conclusion of the 'Two Blue Doors'series..'A Table By The Window' to get the rest of this intriguing story by this author.I received a copy through NOR  in exchange for an honest review.

Title:  Sex Becomes HerAuthor:  Regina ColePublishser:  KensingtonSeries:  Sexy # 1Reviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating: FourReview:"Sex Becomes Her" by Regina Cole....I found this novel had a very intriguing erotic story...giving the reader a little bit of it all from  Eliza finding true love, forgetting about what had happened in the past with that horrible  relationship, and in the end finding someone ...doing what she  wanted  do when it came to exploring her identity of sex.Eliza was living in a small mid western town,  a chemist when rumors are spreaded about her reputation from her ex boyfriend..Tyler[broadcasting her fantasies and secrets desires] and definitely a prick. Then Eliza meets Chandler who was a divorced ..meeting  by bumping into each other at the airport and then finding themselves at the same wedding in Hawaii.  From here this story really picks up  when these two meet and explore the fun with their chemistry being off the chart.  But why will Eliza keep feeling like she was 'damaged' when all she wants is happiness. I liked how this author tells this story from both Eliza's and Chandler's POV.  Be ready for plenty of drama as well as twist and turns, and even some other issues to be maybe  divulged that will keep you turning the pages in this read. Will these two people go their separate ways or will they get their HEA? And what was this secret Eliza was holding on to through most of the story?  I did also enjoy that Chandler was ....well I don't want to spoil it for you...so you must pick up this well written story to find out.The author really gives the reader some interesting characters, however, there were some some secondary characters that I wasn't to sure about seeming a little off a little ..like Gregory, Sabrina and Stacey but you will just have to pick up this read to see for yourself what you may think of them..  In the end this author will give you one a story that will be the an example of a women's sexual liberation in an adult relationship that will be a held up due to 'respect, understanding and open communication' giving Eliza the self confidence to believe she had value.  I did notice that this author left the reader wondering just what would 'Sex # 2 be about?  In that this wasn't a cliffhanger I guess I will be left to wonder!I received a copy through NOR  in exchange for an honest review.

Title: Ever After  Author:  Jude DeverauxPublisher:  Ballantine BooksSeries:  A Nantucket Brides Trilogy # 3Reviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating:  FiveReview"Ever Ever" by Jude DeverauxWhat I enjoyed from this read....I liked this well written story that kept my attention from the start all the way to the end of this good story which happens to be  the third in this Nantucket Brides Trilogy.  This was quite a interesting story of how a family member can betray you.  I am not sure I wouldn't have taken the road at the end that this heroine took concerning here step sister  but I guess it turned out for the best.  It was a blessing for Hallie to have met Jaime in Nantucket and what a mess he had been through but with Hallie's help will something come of this connection?This will be quite a interesting read about that step sister of Hallie's [what a messed up person she was] and  those hunky Taggert  and Montgomery men!  Indeed from all of the characters that are presented in this story were simply off the chart...well developed, defined, portrayed and so very believable. Some  of the characters you will like while others well...you will have to pick up this read to see for yourself who they are.I loved how this author was able to bring in those 'meddling ghosts' that  will  surely keep your attention  just waiting for them to show up.  And let's not leave out those beautiful weddings that took place.  Now to get it all  from what happens to Hallie  that gets her in , her crazy acting sister, Branden, meeting Jaime and much more you will have to pick up "Ever After" and see for yourself how well this author brings it all out for the reader.

Title:  How To Marry a Royal HighlanderAuthor:  Vanessa KellyPublisher:  ZebraSeries:  The Renegade Royals # 4Reviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating: FiveReview:"How To Marry a Royal Highlander" by Vanessa KellyWhat I liked about this novel..I loved this historical romance story of Alec[Alasdair Gilbride] and Edie[Eden Whitney].  I will say I laughed so hard at some of the bantering that went on in this novel with Alec and Edie but also especially that of Edie's mom.  I was able to catch some of Edie's feeling for Alec quite early in the read, but was quite surprise at a lots of the twist, turns and drama in this read that was so very interestingly presented by this author. The characters were all off the chart well done...being well developed, defined, portrayed, engaging and so very believable. I also liked the way this author was able to give the reader one hot steamy highlander romance story as the heroine and hero are brought together in their lively interaction throughout the read.  Who knew that a horrible kiss and being snubbed by the ton would cause such a uproar that would force Edie to have to leave London for the Highlands. And that there would be plans by Edie's mom to start some  match making for Edie.  I found this read  not only fascinating and entertaining with a good depth, a great plot but also a well paced read that will definitely keep your attention all the way till the end.

Title:  Sea Glass SunriseAuthor:  Donna KauffmanPublisher:  ZebraSeries:  The Brides of Blueberry Cove # 1Reviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating: FiveReview:"Sea Glass Sunrise" by Donna KauffmanWhat I liked about this novel....I really enjoy reading to first series of 'The Brides of Blueberry Cove.'  The two main characters were very interesting to read about being of career decisions and family issues.  Hannah McCrae was homein Blueberry Cove, Maine for her brother's wedding, after her job and personal life in DC had gone up in smoke.  It was on her way home Hannah gets involved in a car accident after running a four way stop sign...their she meets Calder Blue who stopped to help her and this lovely story begins.  Calder was in town to see about a job on the town's waterfront and also trying to resolve a decade of feuding between two separate factions of his family...'The Blue's.'  I loved how this author was able to get Hannah and Calder together that will involve them in land issues involving semi dangerous residents and much more as they are drawn together  in this very interesting story.  And in saying that I will say I enjoyed how this relationship developed between  Hannah and Calder. The chemistry was off the chart..hot and steamy!  Let's not leave out those secondary characters especially Hannah's sisters  that will put a smile on your face being well developed, portrayed, and believable helping to give the reader a story that will keep your interest in this two plot story that even has some mystery in it.  Be ready for a good read about a old family feud with some crazy and some humours town people and you have it all..."Sea Glass Sunrise."

Title:  Hot Summer NightsAuthor:  Lisa Marie PerryPublisher:  Harlequin KimaniSeries:  California Deserts DreamsReviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating:  FiveReview:"Hot Summer Nights" by Lisa Marie PerryWhat I liked about this novel...Wow, what a well written story that this author gives the readers. I found this story was somewhat predictable however there will be some twist and turns that will really will  have the reader do on the edge of your seat wondering what is coming next.  I found "Hot Summer Nights" a contemporary romance about [Gabrielle]Gabby and Geoffrey.  I loved how this author brings these two people together..with Geoffrey thinking Gabby was a waitress instead of an executive chef of this resort. Now why was that?  With Gabby trying to do it all  but will she be ready for what Geoffrey wants to offer her?  What was it about Gabby that Geoffrey was so intrigued with?  Will she be able to handle these feelings that she has for Geoffrey or will she keep herself in the shell that she seems to have been in for quite a while? I found the characters in this read were for the most part well developed, defined and believable giving the reader a interesting read.  Truly friends like Gabby has with Robyn, and Kimberly really added to this wonderful story and I will not forget the some of the staff employees.  I will say I didn't care for Gabby's family at all and that is all I have to say about that!By the time I got to the ending  of this read I was however left wondering is there more to come of this story especially after the strange phone call that was received?  Well, I guess we will just have to wait and see!I was gifted this read for my honest opinion.

Title:  Bliss SummerAuthors:  Cheris Hodges & Lisa Marie PerryPublisher:  Mill and Boon KimaniReviewed By:  Arlena DeanRating: Five"Make You Mine Again" by Cheris HodgesWhat I liked about this novella...I liked this short romantic novella.  It turns out to be just what the title said..."Make You Mine Again." For that was just what happened for Jansen and Bradley.  I loved how this author gave the reader a interesting story with some many secrets with twist and turns, however when it all came out and each one of these main characters were able to listen to each other....well you will have to pick this one up and see for yourself how well it comes out.  Yes, the story was somewhat predictable, however, you will be given an  interesting well written story that will keep you turning the pages till the end.  and then we have....."Unraveled" by Lisa Marie PerryWhat I liked about this novella....Now, this short story was really some read.  You talk about mean spirited classmates that seemed to have it out for on Ona.  I love how this story was presented..with a "reunion trip turning out to be an erotic-theme cruise" for these classmates.  Now how did this happen?  However, I loved how Ona was able to some much needed help from that 'blond-haired, silver-eyed Riker Evan. My feelings went out for this heroine because she really went through a lot to achieve making this cruise a good one but will that happen with all the bitterness that seems to be around her from some former classmates.  When Ona thinks that she will have one friend with her on this trip...well, I will stop here and say you will have to pick up this well written read and see how this will all come out. What will happen when all of the secrets and lies comes out in this 'Unraveled' story?  Will Ona as well as Riker  finally get someone to love and be accepted for who they are?I was gifted this from the author for my honest review.
A quick humorous read, with just enough witty honesty to make it a frank and practical guide to surviving menopause from the husband's perspective.

A man with Aspergers decides he needs a wife, and sets about securing one with scientific finesse - creating a detailed questionnaire to eliminate any unsuitable candidates.  He gets side-tracked from the Wife Project by the Father Project - a quest to discover the biological father of Rosie, a girl who had unwittingly filled out his survey.The story structure had a good rhythm and the hero is quirkily unpredictable yet with breathtaking single-minded logic.  I suspect the novel was written with a screen play in mind, as I think it could easily be transferred onto the screen with few changes to the story; plus there were a few iconic visual scenes that are ready to go.Highly recommended if you have a friend or significant other who favours logic over emotion - Big Bang Theory fans will enjoy seeing a Sheldon-like character actively seeking romance.

Even though I knew all the tragic facts of the Father's Day murder of three small boys, I was not prepared for this heartwrenching insight into how the tragedy destroyed so many people. Before the tragedy, Cindy Gambino was a bright, energetic and bubbly woman who thrived on domestic order and motherhood; throughout her relationship with Robert Farquarson, she had been exasperated by his lack of involvement with their babies and his lack of initiative in contributing to the household in other ways.  Eventually she ended the relationship, but was careful to support his relationship with their three sons.The death of her sons completely destroyed her in a way I could not comprehend through media coverage of her facing the endless trials and anniversaries with her new partner and their two subsequent children. This book chronicles Cindy's destructive dependence on pain killers and anti-depressants simply to face the day, and how she lost her complete sense of self.  Somehow she managed to hold on to her fledgling romance with Stephen, although the book paints the painful contrast between their life as a grieving couple and what could have been if they hadn't both been shattered by this tragedy.Every time Cindy seems to find new strength and purpose, she is knocked down again by her own grief and the slow-moving legal process.  While she started out devoutly believing her husband's innocence, the truth gradually dawns upon her that he killed their children to destroy her. With every page, I just want to tell her not to let him win.  In the background, we see the peripheral victims of the tragedy - Stephen and his children who also lost three children when the boys were murdered; the heartbroken school community who create a memorial garden for Jai, Tyler and Bailey; and the friends and family who can't resist taking sides in a long-past divorce battle, making their judgement about who was to blame for the failure of Cindy and Robert's marriage.Robert himself is a shadowy figure who lurks in the background with no good answers for his actions before or after the tragedy.  His revenge is diabolical - he not only killed their three children, he destroyed Cindy so she could feel no love or joy in her new life without him. Just as he had never helped much with their home or children, Cindy was unable to contribute much to her new home - she no longer cooked or bothered with housework, and she struggled to nurture her two boys with Stephen. It seemed to me that Robert's revenge was to turn Cindy into a version of himself, and I hope she can fight back to preserve her new family and find peace with the future and her own identity as a grieving mother with two living children and stepchildren who need her.This is a heart-wrenching book that clearly outlines the physical and emotional toll of grief beyond the initial tragedy.  It also gives a good account of the court case and the evidence that convicted Robert, and kept him in jail despite various appeals. Hopefully now, his victims will find some measure of peace.

Life on Scribbly Gum Island is a mixture of serendipity, tradition and mystery, starting with the famous and lucrative Munro Baby Mystery - what happened to Alice and Jack Munro, who disappeared from the small island leaving a newborn baby girl?  Connie and Rose, the two young girls living on the island with their father, had found the baby and alerted authorities to the mystery - now elderly women, they have made Scribbly Gum Island into a lucrative and appealing tourist attraction, with the star of the show Baby Enigma, the abandoned little girl that they raised, and who is now a grandmother herself. Every year, they celebrate the Anniversary of Alice and Jack's disappearance with an island festival.When Connie dies, she leaves her house to a relative stranger, triggering a reassessment of the Munro Baby Mystery amongst the family. What really happened to Alice and Jack Munro?  How has their disappearance - murder? abandonment of their baby? - become the catalyst for an annual celebration?Different family members have their own interpretation of the mystery. Enigma's granddaughter Grace is a unique and important character as she gives an unsettling insight into post-natal depression - she understands why Alice might have simply walked away from her baby. Enigma herself glories in the celebration being all about her.  As an elderly woman, she confides that as a child she'd been afraid her real parents would show up and she wouldn't be special any more.When the truth is finally revealed, it is both surprising and logical, and immensely satisfying. And the reader knows that while this family has focused on the mystery of Alice and Jack, they've missed a few shocking incidents in their own family history.

In this latest chapter in the Tudor saga, glorious King Henry has receded into a bloated tyrannical child-king, fretfully trying to make sense of his marital history while his latest wife acts as his nurse. The story is narrated by Kateryn Parr, who sets aside her own hopes for marriage with her lover, to become Henry's last queen.  While Gregory can only speculate about the thoughts and motives of these colourful historical characters, she does it superbly within a carefully researched historical context.Kateryn is haunted by her predecessors and tries to avoid their fatal "mistakes" yet she also finds that a living queen cannot compete with the dead Jane Seymour, mother to Henry's only living son. She even finds it difficult to deal with Anne of Cleves, who had graciously side-stepped marriage with the King, and was now a favoured member of court.  In a double irony that Tudor lovers will appreciate, while Henry's previous wives were obsessed with delivering a healthy male heir, Kateryn is portrayed as terrified of becoming pregnant to Henry, because another failed pregnancy would humiliate the King, endangering her life.While Kateryn navigates these challenges and becomes a loyal loving step-mother to Henry's three motherless children, she also makes her own significant contribution to the era, translating religious passages into English.  Gregory's examination of the changing church and attitudes to education, particularly for women, is extremely illuminating.  Kateryn also takes the role of Regent when Henry is away at war, competently managing the country in his absence - a formidable task for a young woman who has only previously run a small estate.  There are also interesting glimpses of the man Henry could have been if he hadn't been gluttonous for power and for food - a man who respected higher education for women as well as men; a man who was prepared to make changes to the Church.Kateryn's secret love story runs as a recurring thread throughout the book, the lost passion between the lovers creating a dramatic contrast to the sordid sickly business of intimacy with King Henry.  This is an excellent finale to the saga of Henry's wives and I'm glad to learn more about Kateryn's achievements as a writer and a Queen. Overall, the book conveys the frighteningly precarious nature of life with despotic and fickle Henry - when a dearly beloved wife or friend can be banished or destroyed at any moment.

I love any slice of Mitford, and this book is no exception.  Jessica "Decca" Mitford writes a commendable companion piece to her sister's fictional stories about the legendary family.  Here you learn the inside story of "Jassy" who saved up her running away money from the time she was a little girl and then suddenly took off one day to America, leaving her aristocratic family reeling.  The extraordinary thing about the Mitford family is how closely truth and fiction run together.  Just like Jassy in Nancy's stories, Decca did revolt against the perceived meaningless boredom of secluded privileged family life until she abruptly eloped to France with her cousin Esmond (a young cousin of Winston Churchill).  Life was certainly no longer boring - the young couple swung between poverty and parties with their well-to-do friends, coming up with many get-rich-quick schemes along the way, some clever, some downright dishonest. After a family tragedy and with war looming, they moved from London to America where they continued seeking their fortune.This is a great story in its own right, but when you balance this book against other books by the Mitfords and about them, you will pick up a few undercurrents.  Like most teenagers, Decca's view of her family was fairly jaded and distorted, but even as a mother of adult children (when she wrote this book) she did not balance her unfair appraisal of her mother or her upbringing.  Older sister Nancy pointed out that Decca seemed to have researched her childhood using Nancy's fictional novels, and in a few cases presents Nancy's ridiculous stories as fact, while failing to work with any original content of her own. While Decca presents her parents as rigidly incapable of respecting any other viewpoint, she has the same failing - she never acknowledges how hurtful or frightening her actions were, and she cannot explain the inconsistency of her hatred of her sister Diana (a Hitler supporter) with her passionate love for her sister Unity (a Hitler fanatic).  To be fair, it would be difficult for any Mitford to negotiate all the passionate political allegiances of any member of the family.  And while Decca rages against her family's impassive attitude to war (based on her observations in the mid-thirties, written decades later) she fails to acknowledge that while she skipped off to America, Nancy worked to help Spanish refugees and their mother took Jewish refugees into the family home while nursing Unity who was permanently incapacitated after a failed suicide attempt.In a family of eccentric and funny people, during a time of polarising political beliefs and social change, Decca comes across as the family member who is always pushing for an argument and always needing to be in the right.  One unintentionally funny anecdote is her unswerving admiration for her husband Esmond who wrote letters from America to cousin Winston (Churchill) advising him about war policy. Decca says she doesn't know if Winston read the letters, but it showed how intelligent and insightful Esmond was.  Yet neither of them showed much intelligence and insight when they caused an international incident by eloping to Europe during the Spanish Civil War while Decca was still a minor. Despite her criticism of her family, she did continue to live by the upper class creed that "If I don't like something, I will insist you change it" which served her well as the pioneer of muck-raking journalism and helped her make a difference amongst her poverty stricken neighbours who didn't have that kind of self-assurance... but wasn't so congenial on the family front.

When I read Anne Frank's diary as a teenager, I could relate to her as a person and I could understand the tragedy of her death, but I could not comprehend the horror and fear of the situation forced upon her family.  This book really brought home the cruel terror of forcing people into hiding simply because they were born into a certain religion.  I could also see for the first time, through Miep's eyes, how precarious the hiding place was - while the Franks and their friends hid upstairs, people worked downstairs during the day and any sudden unexpected noise would have attracted attention.Miep fills in a few blanks in the pages of Anne's diary - she tells of the day she was working at her desk and looked up to see the German officers storming upstairs, and then the hideaways being marched down again, blinking and shuffling on their way to the concentration camp.  She records how she found Anne's diary in the chaos, and hid it in her drawer, knowing she was implicating herself in the "crime" of hiding the Franks. Anne's father came home and resumed his place in the business, but when they finally understood that his wife and girls were not returning, Miep gave him Anne's diary.Miep describes herself as an ordinary woman living in extraordinary times, but she must have had an extraordinary level of courage, nerve and moral fibre to show such commitment and loyalty in the face of danger. Just as Anne's diary inspires us to be courageous and creative in the face of difficulties, Miep's story inspires us to have the courage of our convictions.

I love James Herriot's writing style and also his tenacity as he looks after the creatures great and small in the little Yorkshire town of Darrowby.  His character sketches are hilarious but never cruel and within the humour, you can see how much love and caring he has for animals. While he puts a humorous gloss on life - and the breathtaking scenery and delicious food are beautifully depicted and easy to envy - it's clear that life is tough in the 1930s.  Even disregarding the war looming in the background, a simple car journey is hazardous without windscreen wipers and negotiating a rough winding road punctuated by vicious wire bound gates.  And nobody could envy the three am cow midwifery!My only criticism of the omnibus version is that some stories are missing, so the story arc of James and Helens' courtship is fairly rushed compared to the single book versions. It is worth starting with the single volumes and if you like the style, keep collecting them!

In this thinly veiled autobiographical novel, Nora Ephron's counterpart Rachel Samstat has a passion for cooking, so recipes punctuate the storyline - she describes the recipes for her sadness, her joy, sharing - and as an aside, discusses the various merits of which fruit pie to make if you're only going to throw it at your husband anyway.In between cooking up a storm, Rachel's story is witty, heartbreaking and poignant.  With their marriage in ruins, she gives birth to their second child and for a little while the parents are united together... but only as parents, not as husband and wife. Her caustic one-liners are beautifully balanced and memorable - if you read carefully, you will pick up a few lines that made it into the When Harry Met Sally screenplay.The movie starring Meryl Streep and Jack Nicholson does not match up to the book - from what I remember, Meryl blamed Jack for this, but I just don't think the movie script meets the bitingly witty standard of the original book.

Poor Adrian - he can't take a trick.  His skin is bad, his parents have complicated romantic lives, the family is short of money, he's bullied at school and he is in love with Pandora Braithwaite - but worst of all he is an unrecognized intellectual with craving to write poetry, and a panoramic knowledge of the Norwegian leather industry. The BBC won't publish his poems (but at least they are immortalized in the published pages of his diary) and nobody wants to hear his discourse on the Norwegian leather industry.While the books are very, very funny, I can't help feeling sad for Adrian as well - his pompous diary entries demonstrate how much he wants someone to appreciate his talents and individuality, but his parents are heartlessly pursuing their own lives and don't have time to give him the attention he needs. He is a classic teenager, indignant that nobody will appreciate him, and incapable of analysis or self-criticism - it is the type of book that reads differently at different stages of your life.

Margaret "Peggy" Mitchell created the iconic Scarlett O'Hara and recreated the world of the Confederate South - but who was the woman behind the sweeping passionate saga? The Road to Tara shows how Mitchell was shaped by her childhood in Atlanta, Georgia, hearing bitter passionate stories of the Civil War (which ended in defeat decades before she was born) and also by her fiercely feminist mother, who taught Peggy that when the world falls apart all you have to rebuild is whatever is in your head, and whatever is in your hands.  While Peggy always felt she failed to live up to her mother's expectations, she certainly did shape her destiny through the stories in her head, and the ability to craft these stories into a unique and compelling novel. This book shows how Mitchell's life was the inspiration for Scarlett's fierce single minded scramble for security, despite the pull of nostalgia - certainly Mitchell's mother would have approved of how Scarlett rebuilt her world using her head and her hands.  Ironically, Edwards points out that unlike her heroine, Mitchell could not cope when her own world seemingly fell apart, when she was overwhelmed by the fame and attention triggered by the publication of Gone with the Wind.Edwards also reveals the men behind the fictional counterparts, Ashley Wilkes and Rhett Butler.  While the inspiration for Ashley remains a shadowy, brief cherished romance in Mitchell's life, the man who inspired Rhett Butler will be an unhappy shock for dedicated GWTW fans. Mitchell's first marriage was violent and unhappy, due in part to her husband's alcoholism, and there are several disturbing parallels in the romance of Scarlett and Rhett.This is a "must read" for any Gone with the Wind fan - you will love reading the samples from Mitchell's journalism days, and you will be fascinated by the glimpses into her childhood where she sat on the knees of elderly Confederate soldiers who were only young boys when they marched away to war.  You will see how Scarlett's fierce independence was a response to Mitchell's sense of inadequacy, and you will have a greater insight into Scarlett's attitudes to flirtation and sex.Best of all, you will "witness" the writing of Gone with the Wind - how it started as a hobby, then became an all-consuming obsession, only to be abandoned whenever the author had a fit of panic about her ability to write.  In today's world of laptops and digital copies, you will wonder how Mitchell ever managed to compile a highly detailed book with dozens of characters and spanning 12 years, by stuffing chapters into different manilla envelopes.  You will read of the magical moment (any author's fantasy) when a publisher came knocking on Mitchell's door looking for manuscript, and found himself with a suitcase full of manilla folders containing a future bestseller. And he was hooked by the very first page.

Every day, Joe's mother goes to wake him up, only to find... a lion or a pig or some other creature in Joe's bed. By Sunday, [spoiler alert!] she finds Joe himself in bed, and they have a lovely day together.This book has been a favourite with all four of my children - it is a great one to read and re-read from the age of 2 to 6, as you can see your children develop an understanding of their own imagination.  A 2 year old will wonder where Joe goes every day when the lion/ mouse/ monster/ king etc tries to fit into the daily routine, while a 6 year old will know that Joe is pretending to be these wild and independent creatures.Joe on Sunday is a simple read-aloud story, with a great rhythm and vocabulary, so you will enjoy reading it to your child, who will soon pick up on the pattern of the story and maybe even learn the days of the week.  The bright, humorous illustrations complement the story beautifully.This book is not easy to find now, so I recommend snapping it up while you can and making it a permanent fixture on your bookshelf.  After years of reading it to my own children, I love introducing other kids to Joe, so I can see whether they think Joe "goes away" or if he is just pretending.

I love reading historical fiction and biographies based on the Tudor era, and I've often been curious about the mysterious disease "sweating sickness" that struck such fear during this period.  Claire Ridgway explains the symptoms and treatment of sweating sickness, which is extremely interesting from a modern perspective - whatever it was, it clearly caused dangerous dehydration, and the Tudors didn't have many treatments for that. For best results, stay completely still for 24 hours, under light covering and taking sips of warm drink.  Whatever you do, don't fall asleep. There are some herbs and specific beverages recommended in the text, if you are interested in purchasing the book.Ridgway also looks at possible triggers for sweating sickness, although most of the theories can only be speculation as the disease disappeared as mysteriously as it appeared.  The book is an extremely short read, but it is crammed with well-referenced information from primary sources such as Tudor written records and modern scientists. An excellent addition to your Tudor library!

I was curious to read this because I have looked at Natalie's blog intermittently, and she seemed to switch between sponsoring products to worrying that she can't write what she likes because of her sponsors - so I wanted to read what she had to say when she was free to express herself without a sponsorship deal.  Hmmm.First of all, this book is a very poor endorsement for her publisher who clearly did not bother to hire a proofreader to untangle all the convoluted passive sentences and spelling errors - even of brand names!  I'm also a little dubious about her decorating advice as demonstrated by the pictures of her home, which is overflowing with oddments and objects.  Natalie's signature style advice is: "When in doubt hang some antlers on it" and she is true to her word as you can see by the morose corpses in the background of each image.  "... the kind of decorating decision that separates the men from the silk flowers. I ve brought so many dead animals into our home ... we have become a sort of halfway house for forgotten bulls eyes."With a shudder at the poor creature hanging on the wall, I flipped over to to the next tip, which seemed more my taste: Doilies.  Natalie states that "a paper doily is the difference between chocolate chip cookies for the neighbors on a flimsy paper plate and chocolate chip cookies for the neighbors on a pretty, flimsy paper plate."  Isn't this a lifestyle book?!  Why is she entertaining guests with paper plates?There are other mystifying chapters, such as "On Being the Boss of Your Own Poops" and "What would Meg Ryan Do?" - Now I love Meg Ryan movies and I'm sure she is an admirable person in real life but I don't really know enough about her to answer this rhetorical question, let alone use it as a life compass.  According to Natalie, Meg Ryan would tell me to take care of myself.  Regarding the poop chapter I have nothing to say. Another chapter is entitled "On Being French" where Natalie reveals that she is not French but she thinks she should be.  So maybe it should be called On Not Being French.On the last pages, I discovered that Natalie Jean hadn't completely freed herself from the domination of sponsors - every object featured in the book is mentioned faithfully in the "Resource" section, along with retailer/ supplier information.  For your convenience she has indexed these entries according to object, such as "For my feet" in case you want socks just like Natalie Jean.  I'll have to check first to see what Meg Ryan is wearing on her feet.

Faberge's eggs - intricate, opulent mementos of domestic intimacy - epitomized the last decades of the Romanov dynasty. Nobody except the Tsar of Russia could have commissioned such magnficent jewelled works of art, yet many of them were made to commemorate private celebrations and special places. When the Romanov empire crumbled and the other treasures were dispersed, even the new Communist leaders sought to preserve Faberge's eggs. Ironically the eggs emerged to symbolize the capitalist age of the 20th century, as millionaires collected them like unique trophies of wealth.This book traces the eggs from the earliest inspirations of Carl Faberge and his first Imperial commission to create an egg for Tsarina Marie, as a memory of her childhood. It follows the royal family tradition of a new egg for Marie from her husband the Tsar every Easter for the rest of his life; and how their son Nicholas continued the tradition, commissioning one egg for his wife and one for his mother each year. Faber examines how Faberge designed the eggs to reflect significant historical events in Russia as well as special memories for the Imperial family throughout Nicholas' reign - up until the last unfinished egg of 1917, that Nicholas never saw although he did receive a bill addressed to Nicholas Romanov after his abdication.The story of the eggs did not end with the fall of the Romanovs. Faber traces the fate of each egg, including what is known of those that are missing, and we see how they captivated royalty, con artists, entrepreneurs and millionaires throughout the twentieth century. There are plenty of amusing and poignant anecdotes, such as the millionaire Malcolm Forbes who was determined to "beat" the Kremlin's score of ten Faberge eggs. When he finally collected his 11th egg, he told reporters that his search wasn't finished because most people do buy eggs by the dozen. And after his death, his sons respected his wishes and released the eggs onto the market, so someone else could have the fun of collecting them.The book is an excellent companion piece for anyone who has been fascinated by the Romanov dynasty and its downfall... for anyone who loves reading of intricate and costly works of art... and for anyone who wants to read a simple creative history of the twentieth century from a unique perspective.

While this case received a great deal of media coverage, the book brought the personalities to life with empathy and detail.  Simpson does an excellent job at presenting everyone's perspective in a polarizing case.  Most importantly of all, she presents Tina Watson as a real three-dimensional person, when all we have known of her from the media is the terrifying silhouette of a prone diver at the bottom of the ocean contrasting with the glowing bridal photo of eleven days earlier.So did Gabe Watson intentionally kill his bride for insurance money - or did his negligence and inexperience contribute to her death?  Should the dive company take any responsibility?  My opinion shifted several times while I was reading this book, which describes Tina and Gabe's romance, his attitude to her family and friends, and Tina's early health problems and her relative inexperience as a diver. Whether you decide Gabe is innocent or guilty of causing Tina's death, his behavior towards her family is inexplicably cruel and inexcusable.  When all they had left was a grave to grieve over, he repeatedly removed their flowers from Tina's grave and had her body exhumed and buried elsewhere.The other puzzling issue for armchair detectives is the 16 different versions Gabe gave about what happened during the 7 minutes he and Tina spent underwater, before he emerged alone while another diver swam desperately to retrieve her from the ocean floor.  Why couldn't he give a consistent, plausible account for his actions?  Simpson starts the book with a simple yet thorough description of diver training, so readers can see that Gabe's explanations do not make sense and he did not act appropriately under the circumstances.A compelling human tragedy, and a beautiful tribute to a woman who died too soon and is still mourned by her family and friends who have too many unanswered questions.

Dedicated Tudor fans will love this biography of three background figures in Henry VIII's England - his niece Margaret Douglas (daughter of his older sister Margaret); Mary Howard, who was Anne Boleyn's cousin and married Henry's illegitimate son, Henry Fitzroy; and Mary Shelton, another relative of Anne's and briefly Henry's mistress. If you have read Phillipa Gregory or other historical fiction from the period, these names will be familiar to you as shadowy background players - Soberton gives them substance and personality, so we can see their strength of character, their talents and their achievements. We can also see the hazards of being too close to the throne of a paranoid king, who saw every marriage as a threat to his dynasty.One flaw in the book was that the three stories were intertwined in each chapter, making it difficult to follow which Mary we were talking about sometimes. This might be a fault of Kindle formatting, not breaking the text when necessary.

The narrator is a single man who longs to be more sexually experienced, although he struggles to forge meaningful relationships.  The solution?  He decides to infiltrate the world of swingers.  For Daniel, to be accepted into this tribe is the sexual equivalent of a commoner being accepted into the Royal Family or Jane Goodall being accepted by the chimps. His single status is a huge obstacle in his path, as of course most swingers are happily married couples who don't trust anyone who might upset the balance of harmonious partner-swapping.After a slow and heartbreaking start, the author reveals all his secrets in a unique and comprehensive etiquette guide to sexual interaction and basic courtesy. The book is an entertaining read for anyone curious about this choice of lifestyle - the etiquette guidelines would also be useful for anyone negotiating the dating scene. One bonus star maintaining and expressing his respect for women while discussing sexual habits in depth. His grandmother would be proud of his good manners, although she might not be comfortable with the circumstances.

When Alice loses the last ten years of her memory, she finds herself navigating life and divorce as a highly organized mother of three, while caught in her identity as a 29-year old pregnant woman, deeply in love with her husband.  It is so easy to identify with her dilemma and readers will unconsciously be looking back a decade to contemplate how they have changed.  Alice learns the blessing and curse of memories, as she craves the forgotten moments with her children, but enjoys a more harmonious relationship with her bewildered husband who tells her that she won't like him so much when her memory returns. Alice has the luxury of examining all her relationships as an outsider, so she was apologising a great deal for things she couldn't remember.... At one point, I wondered how the "past" Alice could really have transformed into the "present" Alice but when the puzzle pieces fell into place, her character was logical and consistent. One of the most valuable points of the book was Alice's realization that every person in a relationship contributes to its success/ failure... and sometimes you all have to make peace with that to move on.This book is a great lesson in what to remember, what to forget and what to value - while the conclusion was perhaps one chapter too long, it was bitter-sweet and satisfying.

I was very interested in reading this book after seeing it promoted on a historian's website, as I felt this was a great historical perspective to examine.  Even in my history class at school (in the 80s!) our teacher talked about how childbirth and lack of contraception affected the role of women in society and we looked at Henry VIII's wives and daughters from that perspective. So this book seemed like an anachronism to me, and I was disappointed that the author's argument was undermined by historical inaccuracies and wildly personal opinions.  For example, she questions why we don't condemn Mary 1 of England after her treatment of the "rightful" Queen of England, Lady Jane Grey.  For one thing, I've heard Mary condemned on many grounds (such as her religious persecution) but I've never heard a serious historian claim that Lady Jane Grey was the rightful Queen of England.  I'm sure someone could make up a strong argument for this premise, but the author did not bother - she simply stated that Mary executed the rightful queen of England, and for some confusing reason, this was tied into the slut-shaming argument.While the author condemns historians for judging women of history for their sex lives, I was puzzled to pick up a consistent implication that sex is generally a power play.  For example, she talks about Cleopatra meeting Caesar for the first time, saying that Caesar was a "world weary and promiscuous 52 year old Roman who had seen it all and slept with most of it. Cleopatra was a 21 year old exiled ruler who was probably still a virgin.  She wouldn't have known how to seduce a man like Caesar even if she had been willing to try."  The phrase "seen it all and slept with most of it' is about as sexist and demeaning as you can get, but I was also amused at the assurance that a promiscuous 52 year old and virginal 21 year old, who both happened to be strong assertive leaders wouldn't have been attracted to each other, and the young girl wouldn't have known how to act upon it even if she had found him attractive.  Did the author consider that these were two like-minded people who were actually attracted to each other and acted upon it? I also don't understand Kramer's one-sided debate about Cleopatra being promoted only as the bad girl/ good girl when she quotes enough historians to support the argument that she was a strong and effective ruler in her own right. Another bizarre claim was that before Anne Boleyn was married, she was a victim of the "slut if she said yes, and a bitch if she said no" attitude.  Anne's romantic affairs up to and including Henry VIII are fairly well documented, and I've seen no evidence to support Kramer's claim that she had problems negotiating sexual terms before her marriage.  When she managed to snare the king, she was certainly called a whore and accused of witchcraft and other powers to "catch" him, but I don't see how that fits in with Kramer's claim about her pre-marital life. Kramer claims that even "in modern discourse, Anne Boleyn continues to be either pilloried as a whore or upheld as an angel" and she quotes unnamed "history buffs" who call Anne "a piece of work" who "deserved to die." I'm not sure who these history buffs are, but I can't believe they have the authority to be quoted in a serious historical work.A few other niggling issues - she uses the word "slut" as if it has meant the same thing for centuries, but the meaning of the word has actually changed fairly recently.  Secondly, until the mid-20th century, ineffective contraception and the risks of childbirth had a powerful effect on attitudes to women's sexuality, and it is only now that women can take control over their biological destiny that attitudes have relaxed.  I can't see anywhere in Kramer's book that she addresses this part of the equation.I feel this could be a rewarding historical angle if it was tackled by a historian who could dispassionately chart how attitudes had changed, using valid historical references to support her claims. This book could certainly be strengthened with clear references to historians and an acknowledgement that attitudes have changed in historical texts over the centuries.

This was a childhood favourite, and I was thrilled to find this copy on Kindle. Warm, nostalgic, funny and inspiring, Katy's story is an excellent choice for anyone who loves Anne of Green Gables, Little Women, or Laura of the Little House.In the beginning, Katy is really, really naughty, in an impulsive endearing way - clumsy, inspired and heedless of consequences.  While the first few escapades end with a few tears and bruises, she finally does some real damage - choosing to ignore her aunt's orders not to play on the new swing.  She falls, and "bruises her spine", so she is unable to walk.  Her father, a doctor, sees no option but to leave her in her bedroom and hope for the best.  Katy is shattered, and confines herself in the dark, crying constantly, until a wise cousin sets her on the right path.The author, Susan Coolidge drew on her own childhood when her publisher asked her to write a comparable story to the current best-seller Little Women.  Personally, I prefer Katy and her siblings, because there are no dark undertones and being good does not involve painful sacrifice or submerging your true personality. It looks like a wholesome healthy childhood with plenty of loving guidance. I can't see Katy's father telling the children to give away their Christmas breakfast! The book is humorous and light-hearted, and the moral is not too heavy handed, because Katy really doesn't have a choice about being less impulsive and more patient. The family dynamics are true to life, sensitive and funny.  Your heart will break for poor sensitive little Elsie who doesn't belong with the older or the younger group of children and always feels left out.There are also a few interesting historical insights: once Katy is injured, she is stuck in her room with no options to go outdoors, and no physiotherapy to keep her muscles from wasting.  Also, the story is set in Ohio, yet Katy's family are "Westerners" which puzzled me (I'm not from the US!) Later in the series, when Katy's sister goes to Colorado, they start referring to themselves as "Easterners", so there is some insight into the growth of America during the 19th century.In comparison to the other classics, Katy also has the most delicious food than any other 19th children's heroine.  While the other books make the food SOUND delicious, I've always privately wondered if I'd want to eat with Laura or Jo or Anne.  But Katy's meals are tempting and delectable.Some commenters have complained about the format of this Kindle version - it must have been corrected since then, as my version was well laid out, easy to navigate and with no discernible errors.

This is closer to a novel of manners than a murder mystery, as a group of childhood friends are reunited in their 70s when a box containing two skeleton hands is found in their old play area.  An early scene in the book reminded me of The Famous Five, with the older people sitting around being interviewed by a policeman about what they had noticed while playing all those years ago.While the reader already knows the identity of the victims and the murderer, the friends have no idea... they are each more preoccupied by the impact of their reunion. Alan Norris starts daydreaming about his first love, Daphne, who is dazzling and glamorous in contrast to his dull and predictable wife Rosemary; Michael is steeling himself to meet his 99-year old father, who abandoned him as a child. The other couples are facing the inevitable health decline of old age, but one of the beautiful aspects of this book is that all the characters are still learning and growing and participating actively in life. None of them are defined by their age, even though their adult children and grandchildren are quick to dismiss any unpredictable behaviour as "Alzheimers".The strongest and most engaging thread in the story is the "love triangle" between Rosemary, Alan and Daphne.  This story makes a few surprising twists and turns, ending with a satisfying and believable conclusion. While I always enjoy Rendell's books, The Girl Next Door has a fresh and original style, and the intriguing, deceptively simple plot is handled with skill.

There's a toilet metaphor in the title, but I'll leave that for another reviewer...Once I sat down next to this woman in a pub who spent the next two hours telling me horror stories about her love life, and rationalizing about how all these horrible men treated her badly because they were secretly in love with her.  The fact that some of these men were in long-term relationships with other women didn't shake this theory.  Reading Quin Woodward Pu's book "The Plunger Syndrome" plunged me back into that dark drunken night, so long ago. She likes the word "I", doesn't she?!Well, it's reassuring to see that Quin Woodward Pu has managed to modify her sentence structure,  but the general structure is still as bewildering as her previous efforts.  In the first section she switches rapidly from an anecdote about a man who "dumped" her after two dates, to an anecdote about being raped.  Both these anecdotes served to show how Pu prefers creative individual ways of dealing with conflict - when she was raped, she didn't do the boring sheep thing by calling the police; instead she called the man's wife.  When she was dumped, she called her lawyer.  My admiration and respect for Ms Pu's creative individuality shot skywards, even though I struggled to figure out the connection between the two events.While these two anecdotes seem to suggest that the men in Ms Pu's life take what they want and run for their lives/ wives, the title of the book is The Plunger Syndrome. Ms Pu wants to educate the world about men who are "plungers" - when they meet a girl with Ms Pu's creative individuality, they plunge into a fantasy of a deep long-lasting relationship. This was certainly very educational to me - I always thought men who talked about marriage or romantic mountain-climbing trips to Nepal on the first or second date were BS artists, not plungers.  I thought they were after sex, and they were on a mission to make as many wild, romantic extravagant promises as it would take to seduce me. Maybe I don't have Ms Pu's creative individuality.Sometimes men lie to get what they want.  Sometimes they start out liking you, then decide they're not interested in seeing you again. Sometimes there is an interesting funny story in this chain of events... but not this time.

Wendy Bright just wants to go to school like other kids, but her father is a warlock and thinks school is a waste of time.  When he starts casting spells on her teacher, Wendy needs to use all her magic powers, with the aid of her 14 kilobat spell cruncher to keep school going. But when her father casts one spell too many, Wendy discovers that her teacher has a few powers of her own.This is a delightful hilarious read-aloud story for pre-school and early school age children.  Wendy is resilient and determined in the face of two very stubborn adults.

This is the story of two brothers who discover a box of treasure they can't open.  They argue over the treasure until Herbert pushes Harry overboard.  Herbert spends the rest of the story stranded alone while he desperately protects the "treasure".  Meanwhile Harry makes it to shore and goes on to have a loving and fulfilling life.For adults and older children, the lesson is obvious.  An abstract treasure is not worth sacrificing family, companionship, warmth, security and comfort.  For children under the age of 6, the moral of the story is lost behind the dazzling word "treasure". They see Herbert crazy and alone, hugging the box with the treasure in it, but they will insist that he's happiest because he has the "treasure". I think this moral belongs in a more complex book for older children.

I would highly recommend this as an excellent story for any little people who have just "welcomed" a new baby at home, as it takes an original angle to all the "new baby sister/ brother" stories.This is one of those fantastic illustrated stories, where kids relate to the story immediately, while the adults can follow the plot from an adult perspective. Cuthbert is perfectly happy being an only child with parents and grandparents all to himself. But then he ends up with 4 baby sisters who snatch all the attention away from him.  Cuthbert does his best to win back some attention from parents and grandparents - my kids love the way he says "Bumble boo bum" while everyone croons over the babies.  When he is ignored and put off, he resorts to his imagination, and calls for a BAD boy to play with him.Well Cuthbert gets more than he bargained for when three pirates answer his call.  But when the pirates upset the babies, Cuthbert realizes where his true loyalties lie, and he comes to accept his place in the family. My children have all loved this story, and my youngest daughter even asks me to read her story in bed, like Cuthbert's mummy.

One of the keys to great writing is when the "villains" are also endearing and engaging.  Monstrous Lady Montdore is an incurable snob with one dream - to see her beloved only daughter Polly marry spectacularly well... maybe even to the Prince of Wales.  But when Polly finally makes her choice, Lady Montdore is horrified and vows never to see Polly again. So who does she decide to marry?This ends as a twisted kind of happy ending love story, as Lady Montdore discovers the love of her life, but remains famously blind to his true nature.This plot is set against the busy noisy hilarious chaos of the Radlett family, modelled on Mitford's own eccentric upper class family. Uncle Matthew roars and blusters but he still sets Fanny's criterion for manhood; Uncle Davy is diverted from his health to make excellent observations about various family members and dull, quiet narrator Fanny is the central point where all these colourful eccentric characters converge.I love this book and The Pursuit of Love, but all Mitford's other books are not so razor-sharp unfortunately.  However, her family is as fascinating as they seem in these semi-autobiographical novels, so I would recommend reading some of the Mitford biographies available if you want to know more about this family.

This story alternates between three perspectives, Cecilia, the relentlessly "perfect" wife, mother and Tupperware queen; Rachel, so buried in grief for the loss of her teenage daughter years earlier that she cannot bond with her still-living son; and Tess, who thought she was happily married right up until her opening statement in Chapter 2.These women only know each other superficially, and do not realize how their interlinking lives connect them to a tragedy in the past and a disaster looming in the future. One character, Connor Whitby, is linked to all of them - they all have very different views of what sort of person he is, and he proves to be the eye of the storm, a catalyst for disaster, several times over.As a veteran of school-mum politics, I recognized and related to all the female characters at some point.The plot was intricate and believable, and it had me thinking, "What would I do in this situation?"  How do you change gears into high drama while you are focused on your children and the trivial tasks of everyday life?I recommend this book for anyone whose life is currently defined by the school run and canteen duty.  It is funny, intriguing and heartbreaking with a satisfying conclusion. If you have started a book group with your fellow school mums, I'm sure you will have some colourful conversations about the characters in this book!

This is the story of a high-profile Australian tragedy - a recently separated father drives off the road into a dam, and manages to escape out of the sinking car, leaving his three small sons grappling to undo their seat belts in the dark cold water. Only the father survived.  Robert Farquharson claimed he had blacked out during a coughing fit, losing control of the car.  But the physical evidence showed that the car had turned sharply and cleanly into the dam at a regular speed, without skidding or spinning out of control.Garner's opening cry, "Let this be an accident" is echoed throughout the book, by court watchers, family, witnesses and most heart-rending of all, Cindy Gambino, the mother of the lost boys and estranged wife of Robert.With a compassionate, non-judgemental eye, Garner looks at the evidence and wonders how we judge a person guilty - is it the evidence, or is it the character of the accused? As she watches Farquharson's strong maternal sisters support him, Garner quotes a legal friend who says "If I was appearing for him, I'd try to make his family see that loving him doesn't mean they have to believe he's innocent."The style of this book is melodic and mournful, yet the evidence is clearly represented and easy to follow, so readers can make their own balanced assessment. If you enjoy this book, you will also be interested to ready "Have you seen Simone" by Virginia Peters, as she uses a similar style to tell a true crime story.

I have been looking for a Kindle version of this beloved book, and was very happy with this one.  There were a few formatting issues that bothered me, but at the end of the book I found a note from the publisher asking readers to report any issues... so hopefully they have been ironed out now!The Exclusive Bonus Features at the end of the book proved to be a summary of the book's history, a list of characters with limited explanation about their role in the book (not so useful) and a list of Civil War battles with notes about their context in the book (quite interesting, but disappointing to find it after the war was over!) So if you are reading this edition and curious about the characters or the battle history, skip to the end for these notes. (I was secretly hoping for photos, but no such luck!)Before you read this book, it is a good idea to do a little Wikepedia level research on the Civil War.  This story is completely and infamously from the perspective of the Southerners who persisted in believing the slaves were happy being slaves and felt like "family" with their white owners.  Considering the O'Hara family had about 300 slaves, and 3 stayed loyal to the family after the Yankees won, this is probably a statistically accurate account of how many slaves saw their white owners as "family".  There are some ingenuously racist statements, such as the time Scarlett told a Yankee woman that she wouldn't consider white servants... to enjoy GWTW, you have to see it as a time capsule, and remember that the economy of the time was based on slave labour to keep the cotton crops flourishing. Margaret Mitchell fails to mention Lincoln's assassination, but his untimely death had something to do with the chaos of Reconstruction, when there was no good economic model to replace the slave labour one.I read and re-read Gone with the Wind throughout my teens and twenties, and I'm now coming back to it after many years.  The characters and scenes remained so clear to me, but still I came up with some new insights about this classic story.  When I first read GWTW, the term "narcissistic personality" wasn't so common, but now I see that Scarlett O'Hara is the most impeccably drawn narcissist in literature.  She only cares about the people she can't have, discarding them as soon as they show any interest in her (including her own son, who she only seems to notice when he's having fun with someone else); she drifts into boredom when other people talk about their problems, including the old lady who told of how she watched her mother being murdered by Indians.Yet because the book is so completely from Scarlett's perspective and she's living through such difficult times, we relate to her completely.Mitchell did an incredible job of juggling an enormous cast of characters and keeping them all memorable so the stories within stories are easy to follow.  Some characters like Tony Fontaine only appear briefly every few hundred pages, but you know exactly who he is and understand exactly why he acts as he does.Even though I'd hate to know Scarlett in real life (unless I needed financial support after a war), you have to admire the way she tackles each challenge so single mindedly, whether she has to lie, steal, cheat, kill... or even pick cotton once the slaves are gone.  I know sequels have been written but there is no decent sequel for this story.  She will always be a self-centred narcissist, craving whatever she can't have.

What happened to Tegan Lane?  A young Australian woman, Keli Lane, showed up at a Sydney hospital 9 months pregnant. She claimed she was planning a home birth but couldn't contact her midwife.  Staff delivered her healthy baby girl and gave her the paperwork to fill in - Keli filled in some of it, naming the baby Tegan Lee Lane.  Mother and baby had no visitors, and a few days later they left the hospital quietly, without being formally discharged.  A few hours later, Keli was at a wedding with her boyfriend, as if nothing had happened.  When she attempted to adopt out another baby a year or so later, a sharp-eyed social worker picked up that Keli had had three babies, yet only two were accounted for, and Keli's double life imploded.Keli Lane is probably one of the most composed and enigmatic women to ever face a murder trial. With no body, no witnesses and no crime scene - and for years, no known victim - authorities took years to pin Keli down to a murder charge.  This book helps the reader walk alongside Keli, using her own words as well as the recollections of friends and transcripts of taped phone conversations, to give some insight into why a healthy young woman with a steady boyfriend would use adoption - and worse - as birth control. With unflinching, but non-judgemental insight, Chin gives us an opportunity to question why and how Keli Lane found herself in this situation.The most intriguing aspect of Keli Lane is that she never confided in anyone throughout three pregnancies. It's probably understandable that she didn't turn to her parents or ex-boyfriend when she decided not to keep her baby, but less comprehensible that she didn't confide in a girlfriend, or even a friend's mother.  Having set her mind on adoption or abortion, she cleanly removed several babies from her life without anyone in her circle knowing. With Tegan, however - the second of three children to be born - she was stuck.  She missed the time frame for abortion and she knew from experience that the adoption process was emotionally draining and time-consuming, especially when you are lying to social workers about the natural father's involvement.Keli wants the world to believe that the only person she ever confided in throughout three full-term pregnancies was the man who fathered Tegan during a one-night-stand, while they were both in committed relationships with other people. This man was prepared to accept custody of Tegan without any necessary paperwork or a blood test to prove paternity.  And he has the same passion for secrecy as Keli, having managed to raise Tegan under the radar of the biggest missing person search in Australian history.She spins lies that reveal a great deal about her attitudes, and that also shove the blame for her decisions onto other people.  By far the cruellest story Keli tells is that she hid her pregnancies because she feared her parents' disapproval.  Personally, I think this young woman in a rocky relationship with dreams of athletic glory, actually disposed of these babies through abortion, adoption and murder in secret, because she knew her parents would have encouraged her to keep a baby.  The simple truth is, Keli did not want to have a baby.  In one tragic note of truth, when she knew the police were after her, she realized she would be separated from the one child she did keep and raise.  She told a friend in a taped phone conversation that she had finally figured out she was meant to be a mother. But it was too late.

The Going-To-Bed book has just enough humour to keep it memorable, while still being soothing and reassuring at bed time.  Gently stepping through the bedtime routine in impeccable rhyme, the kids themselves will rock and rock and rock to sleep as they meet the rhythm of the story.

This was an interesting story, and worthy of a true crime novel. I would recommend this book to readers who enjoy a wide range of literature including true crime.
