For readers who only like true crime, the style might put you off. I would recommend you read the sample first to see if you enjoy the style, before buying the book.  I enjoyed the style of this book, which was an original and unusual one for a true-crime story - I felt as if I was reading the biography of a 19th century writer, rather than the typical news reporter true-crime style.  The style, the setting and the characters all gave the story an olden-day feel, as if this was a turn of the century crime, but it actually took place in 1987.  A wealthy eccentric couple disappear abruptly and the local Jersey police are convinced they were murdered by one or both of their sons... but without the bodies, the investigation stalls.The book opens with Roderick breaking down in guilt years after the crime, and then veers neatly into the parents' past with a rather contradictory account of the boys' upbringing and characters.  One part of the book jarred with me - Roderick's brother Mark is described by his aunt as thoughtful and loving, sending flowers to his sick mother, when not all young men would have bothered... but only a few pages later, he is described as having a cold and hostile relationship with his mother.  It is natural for relatives to have a more mellow view of relationships than other observers, but I think the author should have addressed these inconsistencies directly, rather than just recording completely different perspectives without comment.While the old-fashioned biographical style engaged me during the earlier part of the book, I don't think it was a suitable style for describing the police investigation, which could have been narrated in a more direct, newspaper style. Once the crime was officially solved, I think most readers will still be asking: "Was that really what happened?"  A few key pieces of evidence didn't seem to get a fair hearing in court.

My kids have my copy of this book from when I was a child, and they love the story as much as I did - pirates and talking animals are a winning combination!  I'm a little dubious about the moral of this story though... while the pirates were portrayed as evil, violent thieves, it was Dr Dolittle who sailed away into the sunset with all the treasure, leaving the pirates to their fate.  When we read this book together as a family, we talked about Dr Dolittle being not much better than the pirates!

If you get depressed at the social isolation and hopeless eccentricity of Rendell's usual heroes, you will be relieved to meet John Creevey, who starts the story as typically painfully shy and unassertive with only a handful of friends but gradually becomes a little tougher, a little more observant and a lot more assertive.  It is rare for a Rendell hero to come out of his shell and improve his life, but by the end of this book there are a few hints that John might resolve some of the tragedies of his life and find love again.John is distracted from his own heartbreak by a series of coded messages that he believes are the communiques of a criminal gang.  Once he learns how to decode the messages, he decides to send a message of his own...  He never discovers that this "criminal gang" are actually schoolboys playing an elaborate and sophisticated spy game; and he never finds out what happened with his message.Fourteen year old Charles Mabledene is the polar opposite of John Creevey.  Angelically beautiful with robotic efficiency and absolutely no morals, he is ambitious to move into a position of power in this schoolboy gang, and he demonstrates disconcerting talents for uncovering information. He proves to be the most chilling character in this book of "strange men".I found John's story more engaging than the parallel plot of the schoolboys with their secret gang.  Their schemes seemed either too meaningless or too impossible for me to engage with them properly, although I am quite convinced that highly educated school boys of that age would enjoy these kinds of spy games. The two worlds collided when Charles took up John's "assignment" not knowing the message was planted. Without giving away the ending, I think this could inspire an excellent sequel - I'd like to know what one particular character was up to, twenty years down the track.

Vicky Soteriou had everything she wanted - a lavish lifestyle, an adoring husband, three beautiful children and a lover she could manipulate to do anything... With a destructive taste for conflict and excitement, she gambled away her future by convincing her insecure drug-addled lover Ari to kill her husband so they could be together.  As her husband fought for his life in hospital, Vicky realized the police were closing in on Ari, so she quickly and neatly confessed to her involvement in order to minimise the damage.  Another bad gambling choice.While Vicky orchestrated the central event - her husband's attempted murder - her voice and perspective are mostly silent in this book, as she did not speak publicly in court or otherwise after her first disastrous incriminating police interview.  But the voices of those around her - Chris, her devastated husband, her lover Ari, her blindly loyal parents and her bitter in-laws - all paint a picture of a woman who sees herself as above the consequences of the actions she instigates.  Her sister could not understand why Chris's family were so vindictive when Vicky "just made a mistake".  She managed to convince her parents that Chris was somehow responsible for the attempt on his own life, and she was the victim of a "conspiracy". The police who interviewed her were astounded when she asked to go home after confessing to attempted murder.Her self-centred confidence would be comical if it wasn't for the scarred and damaged body of her ex-husband, her confused and devastated teenage daughter, who is now estranged from Chris, and the two little twins who are growing up without their mother.  It is a great consolation to me that Vicky is deprived of designer clothes, cocktail parties, nail polish and thrice-weekly hair appointments throughout her incarceration.  A fantastic quote from her parents gave an insight into her upbringing: at Vicky's murder trial, her parents noticed a strange woman sitting next to Chris and they were outraged.  At a break in the proceedings they accused him of leaving a "rose petal" for a "cactus"!  Maybe they should have put some of that energy into teaching their rose petal right from wrong.Chris Soteriou has emerged courageously from the tragedy as a stronger and wiser man, with two small children to raise, a loving woman to support him along with his fiercely loyal family.

We were lucky enough to see author Craig Smith read the Wonky Donkey live, playing the guitar at the same time, and my story-reading skills pale in comparison.  But my kids still love this book for its clever alliteration and great illustrations.Some negative reviewers have said this book pokes fun at disabilities, but my children have an affectionate respect for The Wonky Donkey and I'm happy to see a book where the characters are not "picture perfect."

Bertie has some dreadful habits that horrify his family, who all scream out "No Bertie! That's dirty Bertie!" every time he's caught out. But Bertie also learns for himself (as we see from the pictures) why these habits are considered "dirty".My daughter discovered this book at pre-school and when I offered to buy her a special story to commemorate finishing pre-school, she asked for this one.  The whole family thinks that Dirty Bertie is hilarious and "No Bertie! That's dirty, Bertie!" has become a household catchphrase.If you're happy to giggle at a picture of a bottom or if you think it's time to discuss WHY nose-picking is dirty, this is the book for you.  Some negative reviewers of this book have said it teaches bad habits, but I actually found that my kids were interested in talking about why Bertie's habits were so dirty, and why we don't do things like that. Don't mean to brag but I'm happy to report that none of my children have been licking the dog's face or weeing in the garden since reading this book. If your child is indulging in anti-social "dirty" habits, this is a great way to tackle the problem with good humour and helpful illustrations.

My children and I love reading this story about the catering dilemma when a tiger shows up for tea and you need to feed him.  He eats/ drinks everything including ALL Daddy's beer!  If only they'd had some tiger food in the house...I find this book really captures childrens' imaginations as they try to work out what they would do in this situation.  There are also quite a few valid and intelligent questions, such as how can you drink all the water out of the taps? Why would a tiger prefer Sophie's sandwiches to Sophie herself? Would a tiger get drunk from drinking beer?  (Some of these questions are from older kids than the intended audience...)This whimsical old-fashioned story has a European feel with the landscape and clothing - there is also something decidedly old-fashioned about the family structure with Daddy at work all day (and the "Ta-da!" pose when he arrives home from work), but this does not detract from the story for me.  If it bothers you, you can talk about how family dynamics are different now, although careful not to spoil the magic possibility that a tiger could possibly come to tea.

I loved this book when I was little so it was very exciting to find a copy of it for my own children - and they love it as much as I did!  Harry is given a knitted jumper from the children's grandmother, and he HATES it.  So with a little coercion, he manages to lose it... and there is an amusing twist when the children find out what happened to it!

Elizabeth is a difficult character to pin down - unlike Anne Boleyn or even Margaret Beaufort or Elizabeth Woodville, it's not so easy to give the White Princess a modern context because what modern woman finds herself in this situation? She is the eldest daughter (and presumably eldest surviving child) of the King of England, so she should be queen.  She's seen her younger brothers disappear, spirited away by someone who wants the throne badly enough to kill innocent children... that would be enough for most people to decide they are quite happy to forget about ruling England.  Elizabeth takes the middle ground - she marries Henry Tudor, victor at Bosworth and solidifies his claim to the throne, then steps back into the shadows so he can rule England.  Did she have more influence than we know about? Was she haunted by her brothers? Why was she so flirtatious with her uncle? Was she so determined to be queen she would have married ANYONE???  We will never know and we can only wonder...I think the flaw in this story is that Phillipa Gregory really wants us to believe that Perkin Warbeck could have been the missing prince from the tower.  But this just isn't plausible to me.  Even the most stoic queen would have cracked under this pressure and embraced her brother.  For me, the only realistic reason Henry would have allowed Perkin in court was to prove he wasn't really the prince. There is also a beautifully sad historical account in Alison Weir's biography of Elizabeth going on a pilgrimage during her last pregnancy, visiting all the significant places of her life in the months between Arthur's death and her own death.  I'm sorry Philipa Gregory didn't use this as the basis of her story as it was quite powerful and speculative.Elizabeth's choice to be a background figure must have been a choice to some extent as only one generation on, her daughter in law Katherine was a strong consort, and of course in the next generation, her grand-daughter and namesake became one of England's greatest rulers...

I bought this book for my daughters in 2006 when our third child was due, and now my youngest child (age 5) still loves having it as a story.  It is an easy enjoyable story to read aloud together, with engaging characters.  While Amy, the oldest is confident and excited about the new baby, Ben, the younger child, is a little unsettled with the inexplicable changes whirling around him although he enjoys helping prepare the room for the baby.  The illustrations are beautiful and the storyline sets up some realistic expectations - Mum will get tired easily and you can't go to the hospital with her!  Ben is sad and confused when she disappears and feels as if "everything is changing".  But the book also offers some helpful tips for how parents can guide their children gently through the experience of meeting the baby.  The baby has a present for its siblings and Ben is allowed to choose the name (from a list, read out loud by Dad).  Even now that our family has finished the "baby phase" my kids loving the special memories associated with this book.

While other protagonists in the Cousins War series are obsessed with gaining or retaining the throne, the King's Curse is narrated by Margaret Pole, the daughter of George Duke of Clarence and the niece of Edward IV and Richard III.  If you have read The Kingmaker's Daughter, you know about her tragic childhood - her mother died young, her father disappeared into the tower for treason, and her maternal aunt, wife of Richard III died broken-hearted before the Battle of Bosworth.Margaret and her younger brother survived all this, and at the beginning of The King's Curse, she is married and banished to the country out of the new king's sight.  Her brother is not so lucky, banished to the tower as a punishment for being born too close to the throne.Margaret doesn't seem to have any ambitions to regain the throne for herself or her family.  She is happy with minor royal responsibilities, such as looking after the new Spanish princess Katherine who comes to England to marry Arthur Prince of Wales.  While she suffers indignities and injustices under Henry VII, she chooses to pursue a rewarding country life, looking after her lands and her people. Henry even stifles this ambition when he drives her into poverty after her husband dies.  Then Henry VIII becomes king and he does not seem to have his father's craven mistrust of Margaret's heritage.  She is welcomed back to the palace where she attends the beautiful young queen Katherine.  When Katherine gives birth to her first son, Henry asks his beloved cousin Margaret to raise this new prince.But the baby prince dies and the new king becomes obsessed with his own failure to sire an heir to his throne.  He tests his power to the limit, violently defying his subjects, his advisers, his loyal wife and even his God as if a tantrum could get him a son. Meanwhile Margaret quietly nurtures her family of four boys and a girl, so they become powerful and influential members of court without ever admitting how close they are to the succession.Over the years, during Katherine's downfall and the rise of Anne Boleyn, Margaret has to do some fast talking to protect her family and her lands, without being accused of treason.  She narrates the horror of Henry's reign, describing a brutal tyrant who would not listen to rational argument and executed good men simply for disagreeing with him.  She also describes the disastrous effect when Henry dissolves the monasteries, which worked as England's social security system, offering shelter and support to the sick and poor.Margaret is pragmatic, with a fierce desire to live.  Her death is one of the defining moments of Henry VIII's reign - he executed his cousin, the woman who had helped raise him, had raised his daughter Mary and whose sons had supported him without ever hinting that they had a comparable claim to the throne.  He executed her when she was in her 60s without a trial - her death is legendary because she fought back when the executioner swung his axe.Most books about Henry VIII focus on his personal life rather than the life of citizens during his reign - this book is the exception because even though Margaret is a peripheral member of the royal family, she describes how Henry's obsession with absolute power affected the country. This book brings home the arbitrary brutality of Henry's reign and shows the far-reaching effects of allowing certain favourites to seize land and treasures from the monasteries.  It's maddening not to be able to tell Henry to concentrate on his own beautiful daughters who were both there, and both non-threatening successors to the throne. After reading this book, I wonder if the desire for a son was more about proving his manhood than securing the throne for future generations.An enjoyable and thought-provoking read for a long time Tudor fan!  While this book might end The Cousin's War, I could see some threads towards future books - I'm guessing I'll see Reginald Pole and Princess Mary again!

Jemima's tale is an old-fashioned allegory, warning young women to beware of foxy gentlemen who show an unnatural interest in their eggs.  Jemima is a little gullible and trusting, restless to leave the farm, and a "very bad sitter" - in short, she's a girl looking for trouble. The foxy gentleman is quick to size her up and take advantage.The book is perhaps one of the few child-sized Greek tragedies, as Jemima goes to so many lengths to protect her eggs, trusts the wrong person and then just on the verge of rescue, the eggs are lost anyway.  The allegory goes perhaps one step too far when Jemima's rescuers accidentally gobble up her eggs. As the central moral of the story is recognizing "stranger danger", it's a little too ironic that the friends should cause the tragedy. All the characters are three-dimensional adult personalities transcribed into animal form and the story has an undercurrent of menacing violence that might bother some parents.However, small children will not see past the exquisite water colour illustrations of the farmyard animals, so you can enjoy this book together and talk about the mistakes Jemima makes and the lies the foxy gentleman tells... We can only hope Jemima doesn't make similar errors of judgement in the future.

Emily Brown is a little insensitive in this book, as she forges ahead with her adventures, not considering that her companion's elephant mummy might need a little reassurance that everything is alright.  But then, in a twist, the little elephant friend starts missing Mum... who is not available (she's at work).The moral of the story seems to be that when kids are busy, they are free to ignore their mothers; but it is very sad and worrying when Mum is busy or unavailable.  I'm sure young children will relate to this theme beautifully.  My 5yo daughter and I had some lovely in-depth discussions about Emily Brown and her actions.Not as good as "This Teddy Bear Belongs to Emily Brown" but still lovely.

I was mesmerised by Levin's book and wondered hypothetically how the plot could have been transposed into a movie.  My husband said: "I think there was a movie called "A Kiss Before Dying" - but I don't know why you want to watch it."  He was right on both counts.The plot is so painfully contrived, it turns itself inside out and becomes meaningless.  Dillon's only characteristic seems to be a sycophantic fascination with his father-in-law and a hypnotic fascination with trains. But Sean Young's performance is truly spectacular in its awfulness.  Drama students should watch it as an object lesson in how NOT to deliver lines.Surely no other actress has ever managed to deliver the lines: "He killed my sister;" and "Yes, I'll marry you," with exactly the same facial expression and emotional affect.  Did she even read the script?

This book has elements of classic mystery writing, although its various subplots don't seem to merge neatly.  The opening is intriguing - a man is truffle-hunting with his dog, when the dog produces a human hand from an old ditch.  It turns out the ditch was dug 11 years ago, and numerous witnesses display uncanny memory skills as they recall what they were doing the day the ditch was dug, the unusual t-shirt on a passer-by, and the conversations they had about the ditch being refilled again.My favourite plotline was of the devoted husband and father who left home to attend a funeral 11 years earlier and never returned...  This loving blameless man had one innocent secret, and as we can guess, it was this secret that triggered his disappearance.  Coincidentally his daughter is going public in her search for the father who never came home, just as the hand emerges from the ditch...  while this is contrived, it's a little more satisfyingly within the rules of mystery writing than all those impressive feats of memory.  This story dovetails with the story of a local author who has one outstanding success to his credit, and two (!) cackling wives pushing him to churn out more novels.The other main plotline had no connection with the rest of the story - Rendell must have it in her contract to discuss social issues, and she tells a terrifying and compelling tale about genital mutilation of young girls.  If Dora Wexford started the story not knowing what female circumcision is, she certainly knows by the end of the tale, as Rendell describes the procedure repeatedly in painful graphic detail.  If you're squeamish, skip those bits - they don't affect the outcome of the mystery.

This is a brief and succinct account of the investigation into the death of Anni Dewani, a Swedish woman of Indian descent who was shot dead during her honeymoon in Capetown.  Her husband Shrien Dewani claimed their car had been hijacked, and he had been thrown out of the car.  Within 3 minutes, Anni was killed and a few valuables were stolen.As police investigated the suspects, they drew a connection between the gunman and the hired driver of the vehicle, and from there, drew a connection between the driver and Shrien Dewani himself.  Did Shrien hire his driver to arrange the murder of his wife?  Police soon discovered that the bridegroom had a bizarre motive for the crime - but meanwhile, an investigative reporter started asking himself: How easy is it for a tourist to arrange a hired killing within a few days of landing in Cape Town?  Not that easy, apparently.It is not the author's fault that this book ends with an unsatisfying lack of completion.  At the time of writing, Shrien Dewani was in an English mental health facility, fighting extradition back to Cape Town, so he had never had his account of Anni's death tested in court.  But it is still an excellent and balanced summary of the different perspectives of the case - perhaps one day, the legal system will come to an official conclusion about why Anni Dewani was killed.Most importantly, Hammer includes emotive interviews with Anni's family, giving her a personality and a "voice", as well as giving voice to the family's heartbreak. The evidence is set down so the reader can decide independently which is the most plausible explanation.

This is an excellent tale of discovery and identity for anyone who has been adopted, and even for anyone who questions the role family plays in shaping identity.  Suzanne Chick grew up believing that her mother had died in childbirth and her father was a soldier killed in the war, a story of romantic finality that wasn't actually true.  Her adoptive mother finally admitted that Suzanne's birth mother had been unmarried and was probably still alive.  Suzanne didn't start searching for her birth mother until her own daughters were grown.  She soon discovered that her birth mother was a well-known and prolific writer, Charmian Clift, but that Charmian had died many years earlier.Suzanne "meets" her mother through Charmian's writing, and through the work of a biographer working on a book about Charmian's life. Charmian's writing leads Suzanne to have more questions about the past, but not all can be answered.  Most harrowing of all, she learns about the tragic lives of Charmian's other children, the two sons and daughter born from her marriage to novelist George Johnston (author of My Brother Jack).I've heard this book hits on all the adoptive child's fantasies - my birth mother is famous/ I was the lucky one because I was adopted - and I think this is probably correct.  There is a fairy tale quality to this story, a sense of triumph over tragedy, as Suzanne fits the missing pieces of her identity into place. It doesn't end this way for all adopted children seeking birth parents - Suzanne's brother (also adopted) was inspired to seek his own birth mother after observing Suzanne's journey.  He received a blunt letter in the mail denying contact.  Suzanne is the lucky one.

At first reading, I felt this was a raw and very honest account from a woman who truly believed she was doing something good for someone else, and was caught up in the emotion of giving away her own child.  There is some very good thought-provoking insight from psychologists and experts about what Whitehead was going through and she had an excellent ghostwriter who helps to keep the story seeming balanced.BUT the more you read, the more you realise how manipulative and self-centred Whitehead is. My take on the story is that she was seeking out her own surrogate father because her husband wouldn't have any more kids.  Mary Beth had her children very young and she was probably ready to do it all again as an older, experienced mother (she was still only in her late 20s). So she hatched a scheme to sign up as a surrogate, get pregnant then cry for the baby.  No wonder she was angry when the Sterns expected to pick up the baby!!When the sperm donor/ surrogacy scam didn't work, she had an affair, got pregnant and left her husband to start a new family.

This has great surge protection and can accommodate two of those brick type plugs.  Nice on/off switch and lights to indicate it is grounded and protection is on.However, this is a very confusing device.  There are four plugs that are so-called energy saving.  There are no instructions as to how they work from what I could see on the box or in it.  Apparently you need to have something plugged into the 'master' outlet and if THAT device is drawing power the rest of those controlled devices will get power.  Okay, sounds good.  But how is someone to know that?  And what happens if that master outlet device gets turned off or even unplugged?  The rest of the devices on that side get the power cut.  I don't know how much energy you might potentially save, but to me that is not worth the potential pitfalls of having something you need get turned off with no warning.  This to me is not a good thing.  Essentially for me those four outlets are not going to get used.  So I have a huge device for four outlets.Keep that in mind when considering something like this.

Fall is in the air, if not in the temps.  This product just wreaks fall.  What a delightful smell.  And it tastes quite nice.  Of course there might be more sugar than you would like in this, so read the label and decide.This is a HUGE container.  It says the shelf life is 9 months unopened, but once opened it drops to 30 days.  I doubt a couple of people using this daily for normal coffee drinking will make a big dent in this.  So keep that in mind.  It seems geared to a restaurant operation more than a home kitchen.The pump is very sturdy and does a good job.  Be careful how much you use, a little really does go a long way.Not bad, but keep the limited open shelf life in mind.

You get what you pay for with this.  Feels cheaply made.  And the surge protection is very, very minimal.  DO NOT use this to protect anything you value.I am quite disappointed with the build quality for this product from a company I would expect more from and have come to rely on.Spend a bit more and get better protection.

This is indeed a very compact heater.  It can sit on top of a desk easily, but I prefer it on the floor.  Looks very attractive and should fit into most decors.  Very simple operation.  An on/off switch and a three way switch.  The middle position is for air only.  One is for full heat at 750 watts and the other is half heat at 375 watts.  Most heaters are pumping out at full heat at 1,500 watts, so this is half that, which is fine for your feet, etc.The fan is a bit louder than I would have preferred, but after a while you get used to it.  The case is cool to the touch and has a nice little indent to assist in carrying it around or moving it.  It also has a very effective tip over switch that works very well.  And once it gets back on level ground it begins to work again.All in all a very nice personal heater AND fan to circulate the air in the room.

This clock is very compact and ready to go out of the box.  Plug it in and the time is set.  All I had to do is use the DST switch in the back (great idea for those twice a year times).The display is large enough to see during the night.  You can easily set two separate alarms and change the snooze option, which is a nice feature.  You can also install a battery to back up the settings in case of a power failure.The clock is very compact and works well.  And it has two USB ports.  Though I would have preferred them to be in the back of the clock, not the front.  But they are nice options.All in all a great product.

This is really easy to use.  In fact, you can end up using more than you intended to with the way this comes out, which is a bit of what happened to me.  So be careful.It does go on easily.  And it seems to be working.  I have had female dogs using the grass at the edges for doing their business and have had brown spots as a result.  Seems to have helped.We shall see how long it lasts.  So far so good.

This is a super convenient hub. Very lightweight. And very compact.Once I plugged it into a UBS port on the computer it took seconds to glow blue that it was hooked up. No problem being recognized. If you plug four cables in it will get wobbly so be forewarned. You might need to weigh it down. It is lightweight. That makes it perfect for traveling with a laptop. The cable is not very long so that could be a problem.  But for a laptop it's just perfect.All in all it's a great USB hub.

This is a super convenient hub.  Very lightweight.  Though it comes with a power adapter you don't need to use it unless you are connecting power absorbing devices.  I tried it out with a number of things plugged in and it worked just fine.  No need for the ac adapter.  Though it is nice to have in case.  If I set this up in one place I will probably plug it in to have that extra power.Once I plugged it into a UBS port on the computer it took seconds to glow blue that it was hooked up.  No problem being recognized.  If you plug four cables in it will get wobbly so be forewarned.  You might need to weigh it down.  It is lightweight.  That makes it perfect for traveling with a laptop.  The cable is quite thick, so I will substitute another lighter one that I have if I take it with me.All in all it's a great USB hub.

I have used both arm and wrist blood pressure units.  This one from a great company is very, very compact.  Much more so than other wrist units I have had.  And it comes with a compact and sturdy travel case.  The case is nice but you can save even more room by wedging this between some clothes.  It folds up super small.Well, all well and good, but it has to do the job, right?  That it does and very well.  It is super, super quiet.  The quietest one I have used.  When you put in on and turn the start button on it helps guide your wrist position for the best reading.  But, be quick, because after a few seconds it will begin the reading even if not in the best position.  The display is very crisp and clear.  You easily set the date and time (follow the instructions).And the best part is that you can synch your readings to a phone app.  Once synched you can emailed them to yourself or your doctor.The accuracy is great.  This is a great product and superb for traveling.

This is a wonderfully sounding bluetooth speaker with lots of versatility.  It is heavy, so don't think you can throw it in your luggage and take along on a trip.  Well, you could, but I wouldn't take up that much space and weight.  There are other options for that.Make sure you read the instructions.  Once you do, set up and pairing was a snap.  The battery gauge only works when it is turned on, which is not the case with other things I have owned.  It takes a while to charge up.  But then again it lasts and lasts.  And you can charge your phone or tablet which is a great feature.The sound, well, it's simply awesome.  I was holding it and felt it vibrate at the bass notes.  Quite impressive.  Very nice stereo separation.You can also answer your connected phone and use it as a speakerphone.  It sounds fine.  But like all these type products the caller can hear you are on a speaker.It is pricey.  But it is a quality product.  I have it in another room and am playing some things from my computer through it and it sounds great.  Of course, if others are around you need to move it closer to where you are.  You can use it outside on the deck.  It won't be flying around.  Did I say it was heavy.  You could use it as a paperweight.All in all this is a great product and sounds just great.  Make sure you want to spend this much money on something like this.

What an excellent keyboard/case.  I have used lots to these in the past and I have to say this is the best one yet.Once you put the iPad in and line it up the keyboard comes alive.  A light flashes to tell you it's now connected.  The keys feel, well, just great.  I typed on it for a while and unlike some other keyboard/cases/folios this one felt natural, like a regular keyboard.  No guessing where the keys were either.  Everything worked just great.And the really nice thing about this one is that you can fold it over and the iPad can be used easily in one hand.  Of course it is a bit bulky but not as bad as you might think.You can also recharge an iPhone while using it.  A nice touch to top off or especially when you are run down and don't have a charger handy.All in all this is one great keyboard that is one of the lightest ones around, works well and feel natural.

I have used WD-40 for ages.  So I was very intrigued at this formulation.  Will it last long-term, up to a year, who's to say at this point?  But I suspect it will.  Why do I say that?Well, the product smells like the WD-40 I know and love, so that's a start.  But I did notice when I applied it it had a bubbly effect when it hit the bolt, etc.  Interesting.  Like it was digging into the little unseen crevices.Also, it seems to have a bit more consistency, adhering and not as drippy.I do believe it will have staying power.  But since I just used it on spreader bolts, fence gate locks, outside bolts, I can't attest to how long it will hold up at this point.  But for now it seems to a different variation of the formula which makes me hopeful.  So far so good.

I would suggest you look elsewhere for file folders.  These are just fair.  They are flimsy.  Have no body.  The color is, well, not pleasant to look at.And then there is the packaging.  While they came in a sturdy cardboard container, they were shrink-wrapped so tightly that the corners were bent.  When I took them out many of them could not get back into a straight position.  Who wants brand new bent/curled file folders?They function fine for a light job.  That's about it.  If you have lots of papers to put in they don't hold up.  Very flimsy.Save your money and look elsewhere.

Well, Turbo Tax and Intuit have been in the news quite a bit of late.  And now they are giving people money back.Well, I used the Deluxe version last year and had to pay to upgrade along the way because of some features it did not have.  Now they have cut even more from the Deluxe so I bought the Premier.  Amazon has great prices on this (though I got a free copy to review).The Premier edition works well for my particular needs and as usual walks you through the process.  It can get a bit confusing and difficult to go back to a particular spot, but that would be true with any software tax program.  The ability to e-file is nice for Federal and state and this version includes one state download.  But you have to pay to file your state electronically.One issue that I have encountered over the years is that when you file a second state return, which I need to do for income in a different state, I needed to include a copy of my other state tax return.  That did not get included in my e-file.  If I am paying extra (a lot extra) to e-file another state, why would they not include ALL the forms that are required?  I have pointed that out to Intuit.  I don't plan to do that again.The program imports a lot of info which saves time.All in all I am pleased.  I haven't finalized things yet, just did what I could, but so far it is pretty typical.  I knocked off stars because of the up-selling.  I was all set to buy the Deluxe and discovered that it no longer did what it did last year.  And then I recalled how I had during the course of using it last year had to upgrade anyway for some financial importing features that actually saved me time to do and ended up being worth the extra money.Don't expect a lot of customer support from them and don't pay attention to their guarantees.  Had an issue one year when they miscalculated and I had to pay interest.  To get the guarantee refund, etc., they wanted me to go through so many hoops that would have taken so much time it wasn't worth it.  I essentially had to recreate the file.  They would not accept their own electronic file I had on my computer.  Go figure.  Made no sense.But, overall I have been pleased with them.  Like I said, I knocked off stars for their come from behind change in product and up-selling.

This is a very classy looking, solid soap dish.  Goes on the tile very easily and holds a typical bar of soap well.  Not your typical way of installing and I think it holds up well because of that.Takes water well and shows no sign of wear.If you don't mind the bronze look or if it fits in well with your decor then you will be happy with this rugged looking, easy to install and soap friendly dish.

What a nice, compact and efficient stapler.  It sits very nicely on my desk top either horizontally or vertically.  Takes up a lot less space than my other stapler did.It works as advertised.  Staples up to 40 sheets without a problem.  I used regular staples at first, then switched to Optima staples and noticed a difference.  So, if you get this, get the right staples.  By the way, it does NOT come with any staples.  Big mistake, in my view.  They should have included some staples to get started with a blurb about using the right ones.The staple backs lie flat which helps when you have stacks of stapled items.  It avoids that bulge at the stapled corner.  Also, this uses about half a strip of staples.  Being so compact there is no way to have had it use a full strip.  The only disadvantage is that you will refill it more often.  Very little effort is needed to do the job.All in all a great little handy stapler.

These are a bit different that the ear plugs you might buy  They are rigid and come in a small little case.  They essentially just block your ears from outside sound... more muffle the sound.  Don't expect to hear a lot of difference.  I used them on a plane the other day and while it did help a bit, it wasn't a lot.  That being said, it was better than nothing and did help muffle the engine noise.These are not easy to get in and out of the case.  I spent more time than I would think I should have getting them in and out.  There must be a better way to do that.Once out of the case they are easy to hold and maneuver.  And it takes a bit of turning to get the right fit to block the sound around you.  Well, as much as it can.Again, don't set your expectations too high.  They are easy to travel with, easy to handle and do help a bit.  If you are looking for earplugs that are reusable then these should fit the bill.

This is a very nice stroller.  Easy to fold up and open.  Works well and has a nice screened area at the top which when uncovered (easy to do) let's you peak in and see what is going on with your little one.  Easy to maneuver and lots of onboard storage.Some issues I had were the instructions (as with a lot of so-called instructions) were not clear.  At one point it referred to a picture that was so small and unclear you couldn't figure anything out.  Why is it so difficult for people to write instructions in a clear, concise and simple manner.  They should actually give the instructions to someone and see if they can figure things out.Another issue was the horrid smell from the folding top.  It went away after quite some time.  But it left me wondering about any potential effects that could have long term.  In this day and age the use of this plastic/whatever material that produced such a horrible smell should be rethought.The instructions say you don't need tools.  Well, I needed a hammer like item to get those little cotter pins inside the wheel hub to attach the rear wheels.  My finger did not have the force needed to get it through the axle hole.The stroller works easily and the braking system is simple and quite effective.I knocked off a star for all of "my issues."  Otherwise it's a great stroller that you will enjoy using (once the smell goes away).

I have lots of these type chargers.  This is a pretty heavy duty one at 9000mAh.  It took a while to charge up.  Came totally discharged which I have not experienced before with this type of product.  But once it got charged it stayed charged.The light isn't all that bright.  I didn't find any instructions in my package and it took a while to figure out how to turn it on.  You push the button, the lights show your charge level, you push the button twice to get the light to go on.  At least that's how it worked for me.Both slots are 2.1 which is good.It's not big or compact.  I have others with more power that are more compact.  This one isn't bad, just not one that I would carry in my jacket pocket.  Maybe in a travel bag.All in all it's a good portable charger with plenty of power to charge a phone and a tablet with ease.

This is a super product.  What a quality made set of bits.  I have lots of them around and often have trouble keeping them in the drill shaft or keeping them from making things worse than I want or need.Not these great bits.  They stay put and they make starting the drilling easy because almost not noticeable is a small little protrusion that get the hole started right where you want it.  This in and of itself is a great feature.  The bits are super quality and stay put in the drill shaft.After my experience with them they will be my go to bits.  You may pay a bit more, but you really are getting your money's worth with this solid product.

This charger is not recognized by my droid turbo as a valid quick charger.The phone sees it as an AC charger, and pulls the same amount of current like any other 1 amp or higher standard charger, but does not charge like a QC charger should do.I only own one QC type device and am unable to test with other devices to see, but my phone sees every other QC type charger i've tried, including a car charger from this brand, as a QC charger and quick charges with them.As a standard rapid charger, it works just fine. Small size, well put together and solid.I would have preferred finding one with folding prongs, but thats a minor gripe.Update: After about 2 weeks of use, it no longer works at all.Returned to amazon as defective.Would suggest finding another option.

I have a life proof case for my turbo for days im Working and need rugged protection.This case is on there the other days.It's sharp looking, protects well, I trust the d30 material and tech 21 brand,  ive had their cases on many phones over the years.
Meets and exceeds requirements for my job, comfortable, sized well, fits right.One star off because,  like many similar pants,  th fabric can be scratchy.

My Droid Maxx was restarting and freezing so I finally convinced myself it was time to replace it.I really wanted the grey and orange limited edition,  but needed the extra storage space, as the phone is primarily a work device.The Turbo is a worthy successor to the Maxx.Ita been out a year and there are many long good reviews,  so I won't get into detail,  but I really like this phone.

Pros : good protection.  Rugged. I trust it to keep my Droid Turbo well protected at work. Does not add a lot of bulk or weight to the phone.Cons : it muffles the sound badly from the speaker and earpiece. Why the heck didn't they put a vent on the top like the did the bottom for the mic.

Stuck to my life proof for my Droid Turbo.Took a little bit to get used to using it, but after a few days I really like it.Also like the versatility and the added accessories.Price was high, but if it lasts as long as the phone and case,  which I expect it to, its worth it.
Really nice charger. Quick charges my Droid Turbo perfectly. Good price too.
Very comfortable soft fabric, breathes nicely,  which is rare for a FR shirt.Meets the requirements for my job, and not annoyingly hot when I'm in the field.
Absolutely fantastic. Adds a good amount of protection without much bulk or added weight.I've come to trust life proof on my tablets for work and home.
Works just as well as OEM. Good replacement for the full size antennas.
I had putchased a symmetry for my lady's iphone6, and it was pretty nice, so I figured that i'd probably get one for my iphone 5.Just as nice, works pretty well. I like it.

Did not immediately fit the phone. Slightly warped and would not attach properly to one side. Snug to the top and bottom, and i doubt the phone will fall out of it without effort.Its my experience with TPU cases, after having them on several phones, that it will eventually stretch and fit right, especially if the phone gets warm from charging or the sun.Not worried about it. This phone is due replacing very soon anyway.

I havent bought a scanner in a long time.Technology has changed a bunch since the early days.Normally, i have one or two radios in the truck with scan capability, and that met my needs.I'm on a temporary assignment in the mountains of colorado, and wanted a base station scanner to use in my hotel room to hear both work frequencies an surrounding areas.This one met my needs, since i didnt really need any digital scanning for now.Holy moly! I like this thing.So far, i've programmed in 10 county fire dispatch channels, and its searching for their tone-out information by itself.Waiting on a USB to Serial adapter to arrive to be able to program the rest of my channels.its a pretty hefty unit, well built, nice screen, easy to manipulate the controls.Pros i've found so far:1. Comes with 3 types of power cords. Home/Cig plug/hard install car wiring.2. BNC vs older "rca type" plug3. GPS capable4. Preprogrammed per state5. Software programmable6. 10 channel fire tone out scanOther people have reviewed the 15x pretty well, so i'll leave this review by saying:-You're going to want to computer program it.-You need to find a better instruction manual online.-You will probably like this scanner.
Simple, light, inexpensive compared to their other products, but it works.
Identical to the one that came with my Moto X.Works perfectly, same quality as I expected.A good spare to pick up.

Man, these shoes are awesome. Wish i got them sooner.I've worn them thru heavy snow, frozen mud, slippery spring mud, grass, and all around.They arent too hot, which was a mild concern of mine for summer wear.In the cold weather, they're amazing, even though the leather is thin and not all insulated.Laces are nice and thick, no complaints there.Soles have lots of traction.When these wear out, i'm sticking with the brand.
I bought the cheapest color, since i was going to sell the tablet anyway.Fits my stream 7 just fine, all the cutouts are correct, and the magnet is really strong and keeps it closed.
Fit fine, install was easy, doesnt interfere with normal use, or either of the otterbox cases i use.

I normally wear carhartt medium-tall in their outerwear, but I tried on a similar vest of theirs in store, and found a medium would work for me.I love the color. Big fan of burnt orange, and this darkened, weathered orange looks great.Warm. Fuzzy inside. Like it a lot.I'm working in northern colorado, where they do not believe in summer. I didnt pack anything heavy, so I ordered this vest. Perfect for my needs.As others have said, the zipper can get stuck. Its a matter of just working it up and down a bit until it breaks in. Some lube may help.

I have two identification cards for work. One is your standard goverment CAC/Identity card, the other is a simple RFID card to open doors.I wanted a holder that-Open face so that the plastic doesnt get scratched up-Holds two cards on opposite sides-Easy to slip the cards out to use them, but holds them securely.-A bonus would be RFID blocking for one side, but not the other.This item is PERFECT for my needs.And, I found out, that if i peel off the metallic foil on the REAR side (the side that i want the RFID to work) then it actually lets that card transmit its ID.  I wont get into the technical reason why, but with one side missing its foil, one card is blocked, and one card reads.Its PERFECT for you Government types with separate key cards for ID and doors.Even though its 10-11 bucks, i'll probably buy several more in other colors for my co-workers.

Designed for original iphone 5. Not for 5c (size is slightly off) or 5s (covers touch sensor)iOS 7 and up can cause an issue with swiping the notirications from the bottom, as the plastic is in line with the bottom of the screen.
Purchased to protect my son's ipod. As usual, otterbox's quality is superior.

Bought them to try out how grippy they were.Texture is grippy and acceptable, but the latex smell was more then usual latex gloves.In addition, they hold up poorly when stored in vehicles.Would not reccomend for field or medical use.Bought 2 boxes, ended up giving them to a mechanic friend who likes them.
Generally, their transparent plastic ones tend to break, but havent had a problem with these yet.Color is pretty, girlfriend likes them.
We purchased several of these used rugged phones for our field employees. Cheap, easy to replace, worked fine, and ESNs were clear for activation. We use a sprint reseller for service.

Clip these things to dog's collars for increased safety while walking, and to be able to find the dark colored dogs while out in the desert at night. Batteries are locally replaceable, and they stand up to the abuse you'd expect.
My son was obscessed with the titanic, so he bought himself this keepsake coin as a present. He really likes it. Copper coin, good quality.
I prefer these to the purple brands my agency buys, specifically because of the texture on the fingers, increases grip in wet or greasy conditions. Buy them out of pocket every few months.
My company uses a MVNO that resells sprint service as our phone provider. We needed rugged phones for use in the field. These were cheap, hard to break. Exactly as described and clear for activation.
I like these, no switch to fail, decently bright, multiple light levels, good price.Keep them on keychains and on zipper pulls for emergencies.

Started having corruption issues soon after purchase. even with updated firmware, its not completely reliable. Seller refunded a portion of my purchase price in lieu of shipping the damn thing back to china.Good concept, poorly executed.Stick to major brands with a US warranty.
Installed in the rear of a 2008 1/2 ton silverado when I replaced the differential fluid.Fits properly and has a good seal.Works better then using RTV which may leak or ooze

I'm an investigator who works in the field. These are my go-to notebooks for field notes.Since my notes are subpoena-able, i am prohibited by policy from using spiral bound notebooks.These work well, fit in my uniform pockets, and hold up pretty well in the field.
Perfectly fine for using on a vest or somewhere that you'd want quick access to medical information if you're incapacitiated.

Took an educated guess on size. I'm 6 feet, 150 pounds.Intended on wearing over a sweatshirt or light jacket.Fits well. Good quality material as i've come to expect from Carhartt. You get what you pay for.Color is nice, curious to see how color and material hold up after first washing, hopefully it gets a little softer with age, its a little bit stiff now, but thats not a dealbreaker.Comfortable. i only wish the pockets were lined, they're just canvas flaps sewn on the outside.

Installed under the bumper on an existing hole in the frame on a 2010 Ford Escape with deeply tinted windows, Wired to existing reverse light. Provides additional light for reversing. Really nice, bright, a great flood pattern.I did seal the lens with a thin bead of clear silicone for additional water reistance.Will update in the future if there are any issues.

Worked as expected, and a little brighter then anticipated. Installed in a chevy silverado, install took a few minutes, just replaced the oem bulb. Had to bend the clamps a bit, as they were loose.If one doesnt light up on install, then rotate it 180 degrees. These are polorized, unlike OEM bulbs.
Worked and fit as OEM. Acceptable replacement.

Sealing flap didnt exactly close the opening as well as I planned. Also, didnt get as much compression on a coleman sleeping bag, but that was more a fault of the material of the sleeping bag then this thing.
I've worn it for two seasons on duty. Very comfortable, rugged, nice design, looks sharp and professional.

We recently received our grey headboard for our guest bedroom, and like the other reviewers were pleasantly surprised at how nice it looks. We paid under $100 and definitely got our money's worth, it's exactly as a headboard should be, and takes all of 1 minute to assemble since you just attach the legs to the board. I had a slight issue with attaching the legs to the frane, the included bolts were like a mm too big for the slots, but using a drill I was able to push it through anyways. It's a little wobbly attached to the frame, but I dont see how it'd be different than most any other headboard attached to the metal frame. I would actually recommend if possible just bypassing the frame and attaching it to the wall, just need to get the screws to do as such, I will be doing that at a later date but for now, it works fine.It is cushioned, but could stand to be slightly more cushioned but is still more comfortable than having your head hit the drywall. The grey is more of a true light  grey, the pics they posted have a greenish tint but the piece itself does not have a blue or green tint.Overall, this piece was about the same price as doing it DIY, but saved the hassle, and looks professionally made.

Don't know why that one review is so anti-flavored protein, but yes, this has other ingredients in it, as many protein drinks do. It doesn't hide the ingredient list, its right in the product description, and the list is pretty short (and some of them can be very, very long). Also, the "serving size' is suggestion only, and you can get far more than 28 servings out of this. I usually use a single scoop (24g protein), so that's 72 servings for around $50 (I got it on sale, so the price varies).It mixes well, the strawberry is alright, artificial tasting, but not too bad if you pair it with milk. Since I don't use a fridge at work, I put about 4oz milk in my blender bottle along with several ice cubes, they melt and bump up the liquid to around 8oz for a serving by the time I have it after my afternoon workout.Overall, its protein, if it fits your budget and/or is a good price, there's no reason to not consider this brand.

Its expensive, even overpriced for the amount, but its a good mix of natural oils, so I can't fault the product in the least. You could of course just use Olive Oil and have similar effects for a cheaper price, but you'd have to do a bit of legwork or have a rich stock of oils to duplicate this formula.You can use this anywhere, doesn't have to be for a beard since again, its just a bunch of vegetable oils. If you suffer from dry skin or hair, you can use this after taking a shower since your natural oils will have been stripped by soaps and warm water. Or you can use lotion, which is likely even cheaper but not as "natural". Keep in mind even as a "natural" product, people can still have reactions to it, but its a good option to try since natural sources of oil tend to be less problematic than certain chemicals used in lotions and creams (also note that oils can clog pores if you're already naturally oily, I wouldn't use oils, but this is for dry-skin sufferers to try).

Overall, this light has great spectrum, it absolutely works for plant growth, but this is a VERY focused beam. Light intensity decreases exponentially the further away it gets, so you really don't want this more than 3 inches from your plant, which leaves around a 3 inch spread. For many plants, this means it basically will get at most two leaves in a canopy, and you'll get very upright growth with no spread depending upon the plant.This bulb is ideal for a sprouting, cutting, or very small and/or immature plant, but if you're looking to grow or over-winter most plants, you'll need something with far more power and spread.The light is still working great almost a year later, however, when you unscrew it from the light fixture, the top of the bulb comes unscrewed on mine at least. So, rather cheap materials, but hey, it's still functional and works great for bringing a cutting to a teenager when used alongside foil. I do DWC, and also take my own cuttings, so I use this as an intermediate when my adult plants are still flowering, and my cuttings are getting a little antsy to get out of their dome, I pop them in a bucket with basket lid, have a clamp light with this LED ove the plant and surround the plant with that reflective bubble wrap insulation, works very nicely.

Works as advertised, feels of pretty good quality overall. The wire gauge and jacket could stand to be a little thicker, but I have it crossing power cables (perpendicular, of course) with no noticeable interference over a 20' run so that's a fairly good sign of proper shielding. I'm using this cable for a LFE subwoofer but the fidelity seems fine even with bass-heavy music. I'm also used to heavy-duty A/V cables since I work with A/V equipment, but this is an good consumer product at a good price. Unless you're looking for a mobile cord (as in, heavy duty jacket for A/V equipment that will get knocked around a lot), there's really no reason to spend more than this, you're getting OFC wire with seemingly good shielding (important if running near power cords), gold-plated connectors (doesn't matter much to connectivity but prevents oxidation), and seemingly well connected connectors.

So far so good, I haven't had it installed for too long, but I'm the type who will come back and alter a review if it ever leaves me less than satisfactory down the line, but I can't speak for longevity yet.However, the Joy Bidet was very easy to install, just turn off the water to the toilet, connect the T to the toilet tank, connect the hose from the wall (water source for the toilet), and connect the hose to the bidet, reinstall the seat, turn back on the water, and you're done. No plumbing experience required, these bidets are very simple to install, although I would recommend a crescent wrench for installation of the pipes (don't over-tighten and crack the plastic parts though) and a screwdriver for the toilet seat. The only somewhat difficult part was putting the toilet seat back on while getting it aligned properly, but that could very well have just been how our toilet was designed.The bidet itself works very well, the pressure is perfect for our house; in comparison, we also have a Luxe Neo 180 bidet, and the pressure on that thing is crazy, you have to be very careful not to hurt your button back there. The advantages the Neo 180 has are that it looks a little nicer, and has a "woman" nozzle as well which is directed slightly more forward (as a side note, this is also advantageous for guys who get sweaty down there, a little awkward to use but it works). The Joy Bidet's really only flaw is that it looks rather clinical. Not really a deal breaker, just would look nicer with some nicer printed text and maybe a chrome knob or something like the Luxe, but we'll make do where we're making doodoo.This was a steal for the price, and for those who haven't used one before, this is not only more sanitary, it also lessens the amount of paper waste. You still use TP to pat dry afterwards, but trust me guests are often intrigued and enthused by it, not at all weirded out.

I loved everything about these bulbs, but they are apparently very cheaply made. One is still going strong, but the other has developed a very rapid and annoying flicker while on (meaning it lights up and shuts off very rapidly when it should just be on). Have tried in another fixture that works fine with the other bulb, so I know its the bulb itself. There's not much else to be said about these; they work, they had a fair and even amount of light, it just looks like there's a 50/50 chance of them working properly, hence the 50/50 on my rating.

I've purchased and installed two of these wall mounts, they work fantastic and are worth every penny. The primary reason for installing the mounts was to free up shelf space for center channel speakers, but an added benefit is this also secures them to the wall for earthquake-safety reasons (living in California, everything should be earthquake prepped).Installation is a breeze for those with handy-man/DIY experience. For those without said experience, this is still a rather easy project to tackle, but I'd say two people should be utilized if you are inexperience (so someone can hold the mount while being fastened, and so you can have a helper to load up the TV on the bracket). Both mounts were installed by myself, since I've done this a few times, the last one I purchased took approximately 5 minutes to put up. The only real difficulty comes from making sure the TV/mount are in the spots you want them to be. I'd rather make sure to just hit the studs and adjust furniture accordingly, but if you need to install between studs, the standard procedure is to install a sheet of plywood to the wall that is fastened to the studs, then install the mount on the plywood.The hardware included might not be the greatest, but I've had zero issues with it so far. These mounts are pretty darn secure, I'd feel safe with pretty much any TV being mounted with these. I have a 42" plasma and a 55" LCD mounted with these ones (I also have other mounts, usually its either Cheetah or VideoSecu, both are solid brands of comparable quality, get whatever is cheapest with the desired features). The dual-arm or articulating mounts are much better for actually swiveling a monitor or TV around, its a nice smooth motion (the one-arm mounts usually need to be 'locked' for them to not be wobbly, which means they don't swivel easily).I'm sure the more expensive mounts have cool features and all, but ultimately, this does everything I need in a mount: its solid, swivels nice and smooth, and was fairly easy to install, not much more I can ask for.

Is the flavor good? Yes. Is it worth even remotely close to the cost they are charging? I'm afraid not. I suppose if you're a complete jerky snob then maybe the extra cost is worth it, but since I wasn't paying attention when I ordered (my fault, just ordered it when it was on sale), I didn't see this is only a 2oz bag. The entire package is 200 calories, that's how small amount you are getting. If you can find Alien Fresh Jerky local, then I'd recommend that over this, as the cost/flavor ratio is far more reasonable (and it is pretty good jerky as well). Or of course there's always Oberto natural, which is a little tougher but tastes about as good for way less cost.

Excellent product, as others have said, nice metal build, very high quality. The bracket gives this the option to either be hung, or attached to wood via screws (not included). I currently have the Back to Roots AquaFarm to grow herbs in it, and sunlight through the window just wasn't cutting it. So I got this light which I have screwed into the wall, approx 6 or 7 inches above the aquafarm. I have plenty of plants thriving, although this light could stand to be brighter (its plenty bright for its rated capacity, but keep in mind if growing multiple plants they will want even more light). This LED flood light is also nice because it disperses the light better than most LED grow bulbs.For those new to using LEDs for growing, this light should be plenty for starting sprouts or growing herbs, and it should be adequate for a lone larger plant, but don't think you can get one 20W LED grow lamp and suddenly stick 3-4 tomato plants under it and expect them to thrive.

I never got a chance to use the California Blade or whatever it is others are talking about, so I can only compare my experience with this blade to my previous methods of drying the car. I've gotta say, it's not perfect, but I fully endorse every person who washes their car to keep this in their 'toolbox'. In fact, it's worked so well, I have two, one to keep in both my cars!So let me explain about the product first: it's merely a 1/4" silicone 'blade' on a plastic handle, and works similar to any other squeegee like you've used at any gas station. But, this one is designed for the entire vehicle, hence the thicker and longer blade. And it works really well for the most part; its only flaw comes with curves and uneven surfaces, which most cars are bound to have. But think about it, on those large flat surfaces, do you not get a lot of water buildup? Does this not require an annoying amount of towels or chamois to dry? Well, one method for those who wash their cars at home is to use the squeegee as much as they can, then go back over with a microfiber towel (recommended Meguiars microfiber towel)Now, for how I use it is slightly different than most, but I think it's a good method and others might appreciate. Here in CA, water is somewhat of a big deal, so I don't really wash my car at home as much as I used to. But, I commute a lot, so my car looks like garbage within a few days (I also live near fields, so my car is constantly caked with dust and bugs). So, I use a DIY car-wash place that recycles the water, and I do this every week on both vehicles. Paying for car-washes would be quite expensive, but I only pay $2.50 each time, doing soap, clear-coat protectant, rinse, and spot-free rinse. It's super helpful to find a spot-free rinse. But 'spot-free' is only mostly-spot free (it still makes a huge difference though, we have such hard water in our area). I then use this wiper-blade to remove the excess water, and then touch up slightly with the microfiber towel on certain spots. Because the towel only gets slightly damp and not soaked, I don't have to worry about washing/drying it all the time. The Wiper Blade is silicone/plastic, so there is no cleaning or drying! Just use your finger to remove excess water, and its dry! Then I keep both in the back of the trunk, ready to use for next week. Our cars look great and clean (most) all the time, our cars are protected (wipers also are less prone to scratch your coat on your vehicle), and we're helping to conserve water at the same time. Obviously you'll still need to apply wax/detailers/etc at some point, but most quick-detailers should give good results with a quick spray through after each wash, and then waxing only needs to be done on a semi-annual basis, and this regimen works well for those who aren't super into detailing their vehicles, but still want it to look nice and clean on a regular basis, on the cheap I might add.

First, let me say the pros about these bulbs:+Affordable+Look goodThe cons:-Takes 1 second to turn on after flipping switch-Bad CRI, definite green hueOK, so basically, the bulbs look excellent in our fixture; I had recently installed a face-down fixture in our bathroom to replace the ugly track-of-bulbs builder grade garbage. Since I put in a nice new fixture, the curly-q CFLs looked noticeably more ugly sticking out of the half-globes. So I decided to look into a bulb that looked better, and these absolutely hit the spot, they look great in the fixture. They were also an excellent price for LEDs (although energy-wise, about on par with the CFLs they replaced).On the negatives, they aren't 'instant-on', and this is in two different fixtures on different parts of the house that worked fine with CFLs and incadescents, but they take about a second after flicking the switch to turn on. Figured I'd mention it since that was a huge gripe about CFLs originally (which have come a long way). The other major negative is the CRI isn't listed that I can see anywhere on the packaging, but it's gotta be very poor. They put out a noticeable green hue, I think it looks gross. I can deal with excess blue, and excess yellow is common in CFLs, but the two combined to make the excess green hue just looks gross to me. I've asked others and they don't seem to mind it, so I know its just me being a picky-pants, but still, I couldn't stand to light up something important like a living space with this color.So for a guest bathroom and a rarely-used office hanging lamp, they will do, but I'm unsure if I will order more or not when I replace our master-bath fixture. The bulb shape is excellent, obviously its very lare so you must have an accomodating fixture, but for the fixture it went in they look great. Just wish the color output and turn-on speeds were a little better.

This isn't my first USB stick drive, but I've gotta say I'm pretty impressed with the case design on this guy. Most of the USB sticks I've had tend to have either rubber or plastic casing, making them prone to damage if you're like me who uses them very frequently and also uses them with their daily key set.I've found no flaws with this case design, fits beautifully on a keyring, is quite small (without being 'tiny' to easily lose), and seems very durable.The only 'issue' is the write speed is quite low; I saw one review state they were getting 15mb/s transfer speeds, but in my real-world usage, it seems to average just above 7mb/s transfer speeds. Still acceptable, especially for my usage of this particular device, but it quite a step back when I go from my speedy USB 3.0 sticks with their 70+ transfer speeds to go to something with a tenth of the speed. I use this particular device in my cars to store music on (wanted something with a durable keyring so I could hookup a 'quick connect' to it, as I alternate between vehicles throughout the week to spread the wear and tear on vehicles). So, it sucks when I need to load it up completely with the full 30GB of music, as that is a little slow (approx 20 min or so), but otherwise it's worked fantastic. For this one, durability was far more important then speed, and it's been excellent in that regard.If you want speeds, look into the USB 3.0 sticks, they put 2.0 to shame. Also, it seems other brands have copied this design, so I guess just look for the one that's cheapest, but you won't go wrong with this one, and it's at a pretty affordable price.

Got these at a great price, currently just have a 40 and 25-pounder, will likely order lower weights for my wife (will be price-comparing to local stores for the smaller ones though).They are solidly made, good size, not really any negatives that I can list. I had no chipping on mine, nor stickers or anything that won't come off, mine just had a tag with the little zip-tie type things on them, so I think many of the complaints others had are probably being rectified.Mine was also shipped in a box within a box, the outer box was ripped to shreds but the inside box containing the actual product was great.These are solid cast-iron, the only thing that can really happen to them is the paint can chip off (they can also break your stuff, but that's user error). Thus, the only improvement I would say would have been nice to have seen is to have moreso a vinyl/rubber coating on them, as the paint is just a high-gloss enamel that does nothing other than appearance. Its slightly slippery, but being that I do intentionally rotate them in my hands I think it's a good amount of slickness to them. I think these are great and love the price that I paid for 'em, just kinda keep your eye out for when they go on sale and you should get a great deal.

This isn't going to be a popular stance here as this set for some reason has a solid 5 stars, but man this is the biggest joke in the Naruto series. Now, if you're like me you'll still watch them, but first off what is with this Scooby-Doo nonsense going on? Seriously, the plot of the first storyline is straight out of an episode of Scooby-Doo, complete with masked mystery men and hologram projectors to scare off those "meddling kids". I mean this is just insulting, as the rest of the Naruto series definitely tip-toed that line between being an adult anime, but this is a straight saturday-morning kids show. Seriously, Kakashi friggin stands there and has some weak ninja throw stars at his back, doesn't even attempt to evade them, and then Naruto just runs past enemies and they somehow all fall down defeated? Just...wow, what a joke. Sloppy animation, poor storylines, zero character development, and Naruto's voice-actor (English) got very sloppy here as well. The other voice actors were still spot-on, just no real amazing dialogue scripted for them.And the case is still in the cruddy box set that is very easy to have damaged in shipping with no extras. So yeah, even if its not popular I'm going to rate this as I really feel, which is that it is merely OK. I still recommend buying it and the price is great, but lets not kid ourselves into thinking this is 5-star worthy either.

Having purchased this on a lightning deal, I can say that this product's strongest assest is its cheapness. Unfortunately, that's really its only strength.This product does not mix well at-all; I have to use a blender bottle just to mix the stuff, attempting to mix it with a spoon leaves half of it sitting on top of the water or in clumps.The flavor is overly fake-sweet. The fruit punch even smells somewhat like licorace, but then tastes like cotton candy gone bad.I don't really "feel" much after taking this product. Well, my stomach makes some grumbles (no cramping or anything really negative though) but thats about it.All of this is in contrast to C4, which I do now strongly recommend after seeing what its competitors are like. I hated the cost of C4, so figured I'd look at an alternative; don't get me wrong, its better than nothing if you really really don't want to spring for something better, but I can only give this an unenthusiastic recommendation. I personally can't wait until its gone, I will be sticking with C4 unless I find a better alternative.

First, for those who don't know much about the show, Naruto obviously follows the story of a young ninja-in-traning named Naruto. But, the show is much more than that and follows closely the lives around him as well, all fellow ninja and ninja in training, in a time/world where ninja are the primary military power for the neighboring villages.The show starts off a little quirky, and of course has its usual anime quirks, but has some of the greatest character and plot development I've ever seen. The tip-toe the line as the themes and issues dealt with are often very adult, but also encapsulates it and presents it in a manner that makes it ok for most ages. At times the show can be filled too heavily with filler, simliar to Dragonball Z, but I would also say most of the time keeps a pretty decent pace aside from a few tangent storylines. Overall though, I'm friggin addicted to this show, and once you get halfway through the first season it really begins to build up immensely. Vol 2 is amazing, but still Vol 1 I think is necessary to build up to it and begin the journey.The price is pretty excellent; I'd love for there to be a better 'normal' way to watch these dubbed, but hulu only has subbed, so the DVDs are the best method (there are of course websites, but many have bad quality). You get a heck of a lot of episodes for the price, although you'll find you end up addicted so when all is said and done be prepaired to dish out some dough!The biggest letdown is the packaging. Its nothing special, and that I'm A-OK with. However, two of the boxsets were in bad shape, one of which I had to return. And yes some of that is shipping, but it's also just really really really cheap boxes. The discs even seem more like a cheap DVD printer than a high-quality production. I mean the content's perfect quality so no worries there, but Viz obviously got a super-cheap company to produce these DVDs. But Amazon's great with returns so if you do get a busted one like I did, just make sure to exchange it. They work perfectly fine for normal usage, they just aren't super quality for shipping or constant usage.

I remember when I got this years back from my parents; I'm always into the latest gizmos and whatnot, so I thought this was more or less a joke. I was appreciative of the gift of course, but never thought I'd seriously use it. However, after several frustrating moments with several electronic studfinders, I finally pulled this little guy out of my bag. Within seconds I had what I needed; the magnet's so powerful it stuck to the wall hands-free so I could very easily mark the location. This is now my go-to studfinder.And the built-in level is far more handy than you'd think.Normally I'd give far lengthier reviews, but there's really nothing else that can be said about this. It works with very strong magnets. There's no batteries or electronic components to go bad. It's insanely durable. And it just works. That's really all that can be said about it, but it's completely worth the cost, every handyman should have one.

***Update 12-15-2013***I try to keep up with my reviews, and I'm not above correcting any previous remarks should my opinion change. I've added a star, as the pump seems to have gotten quieter and is now quieter than the Keurig we also still have. We are thinking that we will keep the Tassimo and return the Keurig, as the Tassimo does make good specialty drinks, almost coffee-house grade, so it's nice for a weekend treat as they are still quite expensive. I still recommend and will continue to use our Senseo machine, not only is it smaller/quicker/quieter, the cost per cup is by far the cheapest of the bunch, and if you only want coffee it's a great way to go. The big hangup for us is the senseo doesn't create a bunch of trash where both the Keurig and Tassimo do. If you want cappuccinos and other espresso drinks, the Tassimo's the way to go. And just a hint, this is a great item to use coupons that a certain BB&B store gives out regularly...****This isn't going to be a popular review, but I'm not sure why on earth the other reviews are so generous to this machine.
