This is a real review, and no this isn't complaining about it breaking down, this machine is just really not that great for the reasons I will go over within.So to start off, we purchased the Tassimo T20 on sale for black friday, and we got a great deal on it, much lower than the current asking price. We purchased some Gevalia Carmel Macchiatto coffee from the same store (BB&B) and took it home to try it out. We currently have a cheapie $15 Hamilton Beach Senseo machine and figured this would be a significant upgrade since I had always liked Keurig since trying them out years ago.So first impressions, the machine feels fairly solid, the snap lid feels sturdy, all good there. However, some immediate issues I didn't care for: bad instruction manual on super cheap/raggedy paper that was hard to read (you're going to burn through massive plastic containers, don't try to act like you care about the environment using cruddy paper), and within it says DO NOT use vinegar to descale the machine and you must buy a special cleaner from Bosch. The Keurig we eventually also purchased to compare said specifically to use vinegar, guess which method is cheaper? We've used vinegar in our Senseo, not that it even has a scaling issue like these other machines do (I'll go more into this as well later).OK, so those are minor/petty issues admittedly, so long as the machine works great we're all good, right? OK, first, the Tassimo is the LOUDEST machine we have in our house short of our washing machine when it gets off-balance. It literally shakes the entire counter and causes our dogs to bark with how loud the pump is (and concerns me if they're using such a poor quality pump how long it will last). The Keurig is also loud, but still quieter than the Tassimo T20 by far (the senseo being a drip machine is completely silent...).Next up was loading the machine: it's not rocket science, pretty straight forward, but has way too many steps surrounding the machine beyond simply loading the machine. See, you can only load a disc when the light is on orange, again straight-forward. However, it has a mind of its own on when it wants to go back into standby mode. It regularly sits on the green-coffee symbol, and after brewing it has some ridiculous "manual" mode where you like hold the button or press it repeatedly for extra water I guess (I really just wanted a normal cup of coffee at this point...). The symbols also don't make sense in my opinion, green tends to mean "ready to go" as in the time you mess with the machine, not "don't touch, but we're green lighted". They really need to reverse the symbols, have a "red" for when it's brewing and green when it's ready to be handled.OK, absurd little light symbols aside, at least loading the machine isn't difficult. Oh, but the pack you bought is mostly little milk containers for some reason? Yeah, so you put those in first (or whatever the specific "recipe" calls for), and then you get to wait like 30+ seconds after its down doing a glorified frothing of milk to finally have the machine go back into the orange so you can open the top to finally put in the coffee disc. Finally, you have your coffee.Admittedly, it does a decent job of brewing. But you know what else does a decent job of brewing with less confusion and takes about the same amount of time? A friggin espresso machine (which we also have). And the espresso machine isn't going to cost you $1.50/cup either.Look, the machine brews a decent cup of coffee or espresso, that much I can admit to. However, I just think the darn thing is radically impractical, obnoxiously loud, and ridiculously expensive on a per-cup basis. If you want normal good coffee, the Senseo still wins our heart which is surprising as it's a cheap piece of junk, but it also takes up no counter space, is so easy to use a child could do it, and takes less than 30 seconds to brew a cup with no wacky prep or maintenance. If you want variety, the Keurig wins although it's pricey, but the k-cups are significantly cheaper (although not quite as good as the Tassimo, admittedly). If you want espresso and good coffee, save your money for a real espresso machine. With the amount of learning it takes to utilize the Tassimo you can learn a basic espresso recipe such as a carmel machiatto, and you won't be paying a heavy premium for frothed milk either.

This was my first Brother printer; I've been wanting to try out the Brother brand for a while, as they've made decent and reliable small business printers for years (at least as far as I know of them). It seems they're really pushing into the consumer territory, and with the major manufacturers (HP, Canon, etc) all having their various failings, now might be the best time to switch to a different brand.Overall, let me just summarize at the top that this printer is functional, does everything it should quite well, except the print quality is pretty mediocre and the plastic paneling is very very cheap.Now, that may sound like I'm unimpressed with the printer, but that would be wrong. I think the cheap paneling isn't that big a deal so long as you treat it with care, just don't go and plop something heavy on top or else you'll probably obliterate the thing. My previous printer was a Canon MX700, and the plastic was very thick on it and the printer lasted for years (but scanned pretty poor quality). I don't have kids or anything that might break the printer so I'm not too worried, and for a personal printer it should be fine, I just wouldn't have it necessarily as a printer for a whole small office due to its brittleness.The print quality gets the job done, but I wouldn't expect even high quality prints of documents (that are meant to show to prospective clients for example) and certainly wouldn't even attempt photo printing. But, if you need high quality color documents, FedEx Office/Kinkos/etc are always there, and WalMart/Costco will print photos that will blow away all but the highest end printers (which would cost thousands, I know I used to work for Costco's photolab and now work in digital media). In fact, the printing of this machine reminds me of the old color dot-matrix printers (even makes that irritating "rrreerrr" noise as the print head moves back and forth). Speaking of noise, its pretty quite, but does make that high-pitch noise as the print head moves around, but its pretty muffled and certainly acceptable.Other pros of the machine include its rich feature set (duplexing, ADF, wireless, etc). The wireless worked easy for me; I did have to install software from the CD and it installed some irritating taskbar software with popups for updating (didn't remember seeing that listed through the install prompts). I like the paper tray being within the machine in the front instead of paper sticking out the back like many consumer machines, and the print cartridges are really easy to replace as the door is located in the front of the machine (no having to prop up the lid to change cartridges).Like I said, the cons aren't really a big deal nor a deal breaker, just don't expect this to be a shared frequent-use high-quality printer. It fits its niche quite well, and for all of its cheapness it seems intelligently designed (like my Civic, cheap parts but also designed to run forever). I'm satisfied with it for the price, and have no problems recommending it to people needing a cheap all-in-one printer for their personal use.

There's only one flaw with this case, and that is the primary case doesn't cover the top or the bottom of the phone. If you primarily use the holster this may not be a problem, and even if you don't use the holster it may still not be a problem, but figured I'd point out it's one flaw. I know it's a flaw because that's how I've broken my phone previously; while gorilla glass is very strong and scratch resistant, it is still glass and is prone to shattering if dropped in the right way. The rubber cases actually provide better protection in my opinion than the hard shells because of this: they absorb more of the impact.So, that's the one major flaw, but I don't think it needs to be a deal breaker, and I still love the case overall.The kickstand can be a little tough to pull out, particularly if you have weak fingernails, but if you work it one side at a time it pops out without too much difficulty. The kickstand itself has been great, and the primary reason I purchased this case (I actually didn't care about the holster). The kickstand works well in either portrait or landscape mode.The holster is a lot better than I thought, and is actually one of the best holster-designs I've ever used! it slides in and out smooth as butter, yet isn't so loose that it will fly out on it's own. The clip mechanism is easy to operate and has a spring; I've used holsters without a spring mechanism and they can be tough to actually clip onto a belt or pocket. The holster also protects the front of the phone completely, and is inlaid with a felt material.The case fits everything well, has holes in all the necessary locations, is a snap to install or remove, and (since I jog with my phone in my hand) reduces the likelihood of hitting the volume buttons accidentally without impeding your ability to push them when you want to.Overall, a great bargain for the $6 or so price most sellers are asking for! Certainly feels like a case you'd pay $30 at Verizon for!

The Butter Chicken Curry by Kitchens of India is one of their best tasting products (many are really good however) in my opinion. The paste is easy to work with, but there in lies what I think is the best opportunity: because this is just a paste, you are also free to modify and create your own recipes as well! If you want to add coconut milk, go for it!The way I personally cook is to first marinade the chicken in oil and lime (so it gets broken down), then cut and flash grill it on a cast-iron grill pan while sprinkling curry powder on top, then toss it into a pot to simmer with this spice packet, and while that's simmering I also grill onions, garlic, bell peppers, and some either jalapeno and/or red pepper which I also dust with curry powder, and then I add them to the pot. Finally I let everything simmer for a few minutes, then serve and it is spicy and delicious (if you want it slightly less spicy forget the hot peppers). This not only stretches the dish, it also stretches the amount of sodium (it is rather high in sodium) across bigger portions, and also adds tons of vegetables.I love this paste though, I can make dishes that taste better than many of the local Indian restaurants (too many just toss in the chicken and cook quickly, it gets rubbery cooked that way).So overall the spice packet is great for making various kinds of curries (including the traditional butter chicken curry), it does have some heat on it's own, but do watch out for the sodium in these packets. Also, enjoy!

So first, I'm not really a tea fan, but the Yogi Green Tea Rejuvenation has a pretty decent flavor in my opinion, and my wife who actually likes tea really liked this flavor. In comparison, we had originally ordered Lipton Green Tea Bags, Superfruit Purple Acai with Blueberry, 20-Count,  Boxes (Pack of 6) since it had a 20% coupon, and even at the reduced price there's no way I would recommend it. I was shocked at how little tea was actually in each packet for starters, two bags couldn't even flavor an 8ounce cup!So, I looked around, and liked Yogi's response to a critic's claims, they have organic tea leaves and that's a big deal to me; I like to purchse organic produce when possible, but didn't even make the connection that they might be spraying down their originating plants (Camellia sinensis). After receiving my order, I really think we made the right choice.The tea bags where stuffed pretty full, having almost 3x as many tea leaves in each bag as the Lipton bags, so that alone makes the slightly higher price justified. Each bag is plenty for a small cup. The flavor is pretty good, like I said I'm not a tea person, it's almost like it needs a squirt of orange or something, but still a little dab of honey I'm certainly OK with it. The tea is fairly mild and smooth, but not in a watery/unflavored sort of way like the Lipton tea.So, I strongly recommend this brand, I look forward to trying out other flavors but as for now this will certainly be my mid-afternoon tea; the caffeine amount is perfect so I can go work out, but not so much that it keeps me up at night.

So to give up a soda addiction, I've recently switched to teas. I'm not really a big tea fan, but having tried a few Tazo teas with just a bit of honey or sugar added I was growing to somewhat like it. When I saw this Lipton tea had a coupon, I decided to go for it, since I like Green Tea anyways.Well, this is just disappointing. First, the packets contain a very very small amount of leaves, as in around 1/8 of the bag was filled with leaves. Second, they don't really have any smell, and even just making a small (around 7oz) cup with two bags still barely had any flavor. And worse, the flavor that was there was kinda disgusting. I tasted like a hint of minty-like flavor with some bitter...I don't know, trash-water flavor? I mean seriously, it was just gross. I've tried it on multiple occassions, and my wife who likes tea a lot more than me commented on how flavorless it was.Will not be buying Lipton again if this is what they've become; Tazo may be overpriced but I've never had an experience with them like I have with this tea.This is one of the very few one-stars I've ever given, but I really feel this deserves it. It's cheap, but even for cheap it's still not worth it.***Update 8/27/13***So we decided to try Yogi Green Tea Rejuvenation, Herbal Tea Supplement, 16-Count Tea Bags (Pack of 6), and while it is a little more expensive, each individual bag had more than double the filling of tea leaves, in fact closer to triple the amount, meaning only one bag is actually needed for a normal sized cup. Plus, it tastes much much better. We contacted Lipton about this flavor, and never received a response, I guess they're OK with trash-flavored tea with their name on it. We won't be trying Lipton products after this fiasco, this stuff just gives me nightmares thinking about, it really was that bad.

I'm not sure why Consumer Reports is getting so much flak in the reviews, because they still are a great starting point for many larger (and occasionally smaller) purchases. Of course you shouldn't ONLY trust Consumer Reports, but for things such as cars and appliances they are usually really good and thorough in their reviews and somewhere in their top selections lies a winner. Even when I bought my Civic previously, they ranked it high but for some reason stated the Ford Focus was the "car to buy" at that price point; still, if you actually read the reviews you can come to your own conclusions. They try to be objective, but choosing a "best of" tends to come down to subjective points and its up to you, as the consumer, to decide which factors are most important.Since my car purchase, I had unsubscribed from them for a few years (just didn't have any major purchases in the pipeline, so I didn't need it), but since re-subscribing I actually find their articles to be better written then previously. Like I said, you still need to make your own decisions, but if you follow most of their reviews and guidelines you'll at least land in the general vacinity of what you need and avoid some major catastrophes as well. And yes, I'm quite technically savvy, and use this as a starting point, but if you aren't savvy you'll be far better off going with a CR recommendation then you will over just believing what advertisers promote.And yes a PC magazine might be better at reviewing PCs, but again, as somewhat who works as a computer tech for major organization, they're pretty darn biased as well (my personal recommendation is that the brands don't mean anything unless you're a major organization with a service plan, they're all made with the same parts produced in the same factories; best to look up specific models and read reviews on Newegg or Amazon instead and take those with a grain of salt).Anyways, I recommend Consumer Reports, but I do wish they were slightly cheaper to subscribe to. I also will state that, as someone who watches a lot of TV, I appreciate many of their articles on "As Seen on TV" products, since I'm often curious (most are garbage, but every once in a while something decent comes along).

On my android phone, I use Hide It Pro, and it works beautifully; the application name is "hidden" by calling itself "audio manager", and hiding files is quick and easy. The same application is available for Kindle Fire, but it doesn't work quite the same way as it does on my phone. If you only have a very small amount of files (like 2 or 3) you wish to hide, it may be better, but each file needs to be "sent" so it takes like 7 button presses and a little bit of wait for every single file. I also tried another file hiding application (File Hide Expert), and that also didn't work as I wanted.This application, Smart Gallery, isn't perfect by any means, but you can tell its got a good foundation and does what it should for the most part. Hiding an entire folder is easy to do, there are options for changing the password type (swype or pass code) and it is quick and doesn't seem to be glitchy like the other apps on Kindle Fire were. The developer has also added some "how to" notes for each page, and it's not terribly complicated to use either. There is some clunkiness however; the password doesn't prompt you to set it up/change it, you have to go to settings yourself (top right corner), and the GUI isn't the best around either. That being said, I'd take a little bit of clunkiness for an app that doesn't seem to be as glitchy and actually functions as it should unlike the others I've tried. The only other thing I'd like is if it were to do like the "Hide It Pro" app and change its name/icon after installation and have a "secret" way to access it.I wouldn't hide like sensitive info with this obviously, just trying to make it so if I pass around my K Fire people don't see EVERYTHING I have; kinda lame the K Fire doesn't allow a little more customization, but at least I found an app that works good enough in the meantime!

Originally I had a little Fender amp, I believe it's the Fender Frontman 15g, for my practice amp. And it's not a bad amp or anything I suppose, but the sound was somewhat inconsistent, it had a lot of hum, and I just wasn't a fan of the sound. I've been out of practicing guitar, and while waiting around I stopped into a guitar center and passed by these amps with one of their salesmen playing it. On a whim, I listened and loved it, purchased it, brought it home, plugged it in, and am really liking it!This amp is larger than the Fender, but it's still a great practice-size amp unless you're in very cramped quarters. Its not super light where I'd lug it with me everywhere (unless that were my job of course), but that's to be expected for an amp like this. I've heard tons of smaller amps, but I really think this size is ideal for practicing on (just the dispersion alone seems better than a smaller amp, even though I play with the amp pretty low on the volume scale). This can also go fairly loud if needed.I do notice I have a little more hum than when I listened in-store, but that could easily be my guitar (Epiphone Les Paul '56 Gold Top), but it's certainly manageable on this amp (unlike the Fender, which I brought back out to compare). I've gotta say I also think this amp is pretty freaking cool to have the effects built-in! I'm not really an effects guy, despite having about 7 pedals; I think they're awesome, I just don't like having to bring them out and hook them up to just diddle for a few minutes on the guitar, so it's great to have them built-in! Huge time/hassle saver. And they sound pretty darn good too! Obviously not as versatile as a true pedal effect, but great for practicing.The only odd thing is the "clean" setting had effects enabled; even after doing a factory reset, they were enabled again, but I like that you can easily store your own settings. Just change to the settings you like, then hold down the button, and like setting a radio station in your car its stored instantly! I think that's pretty awesome, but I'm used to old-school amps I suppose. But anyways, it's nice to instantly switch between clean settings, crunchy settings, to heavy distortion settings just by pushing a button. Playing clean on this amp (which is what I do most often) sound amazing, it has great clarity; just plucking a few strings sounds like music coming from this little box, it's pretty cool. It does take a little getting used to with the effects and the knobs, but once you spend a few minutes, look a few things up in the manual or online, it's actually rather straight-forward.I don't regret the purchase in the least, this little amp is impressive and well-worth the asking price IMO. It's actually made pulling out my guitar and practicing a fun experience.

I didn't order these online, as the Meeks near me had this for $6 and couldn't pass them up since I lose almost as many pruners as I break. They looked solid in the packaging, and after testing them out, I've gotta say that out of the package they're one of the best pruners I've ever owned. Everything is solid/heavy-duty, short of the brands that cost 3-5x as much. The pruners are sharp, and have a lot of metal in the head. That also makes them slightly heavier then say Fiskars. I'd recommend a Fiskars product if you suffer from something like arthritis, but the nice thing about these Bond pruners is they cut through thick woody specimens with ease. Those who deal with Wisteria in a sunny climate know it can be rather invasive, but I can easily cut through multiple shoots at a time to keep it in check. The blade is sharp, and the spring is nice and strong. I also like the pouch and haven't had an issue with them tearing, although I mostly just use my pant pocket anyways.Compared to the Corona, Fiskars, and various other cheapies I've purchased lately, these Bond pruners are far superior. The comparable Coronas look like they'd be as good, but I bought their 5/8" pruners which were garbage (broke right out of the package, company never replied either).The only potential downside I see is that they are made in China, which likely means Chinese steel, which also means it may be more prone to rust (tends to have higher impurities). Basically that just means wipe 'em down after use and don't leave sitting outside for them to get wet; who knows, they could be fairly rust-resistant, but that seems to be a common problem with Chinese imported hand tools. I have no problem with them and bring them inside anyways (otherwise I'll misplace them and lose them).  The other minor issue is occasionally the locking mechanism seems to get in the way if you go snipping away blindly (probably because I use them more like hedge trimmers than delicate pruners). They have a noticeable amount of grease on them (good thing), so I'd say you should probably grease them yearly to keep them nice and springy. I have noticed they don't hold an edge all that great either; still good for cutting thick stiff branches, but takes some work on other items (or just needs to be sharpened).These are just plain clippers that work very well.

So I just received my pair today hoping this would be better quality than my other tools. My other pruners include Fiskars, Avon, and various other cheapies. I figured this time I'd buy something a little bit higher in quality, but still didn't want to break the bank. Can't say I'm impressed however.I opened up the box, and yeah, nothing special, which is exactly what I was wanting. Just a standard workhorse set of pruners. I take them outside, and with the first few snips the spring mechanism was already not working properly (I had to "assist" it to get it to spring back). So I snip a few more branches, all around 1/4" or so in diameter. Now the spring mechanism is busted completely, and the locking mechanism is no longer working properly either.So, I guess I just got a bad pair, but for it to break that quickly doesn't exactly send loads of confidence on the brand. I sent a message to Corona to see how they respond, and that'll be the deciding factor on whether I'll give them another chance or not.And yes, bought through Amazon directly, and they have the Corona engraving on the tool so unlikely it's a Chinese knock-off.***Update 4/19***So I haven't heard a response back from the company, so I've just decided to return it. I bought some cheap/small Fiskars instead, which the lock mechanism already detached for a minute, but was an easy fix and otherwise functions perfectly. So I guess I'll stick with them instead; I'm sure I just receieved a bad product, but I also never got a response from the company so I'd rather not deal with it. If you are going to buy the Corona Pruner, I'd recommend trying the 3/4" instead of the 5/8", the way the 5/8" is designed seems to be more prone to errors.

I can't say how it happened, but within the past year and half these pantry moths had become one of the largest pests in our area. For anyone that has dealt with pantry moths, you know how annoying they can be when their population begins to explode. Our garage was filled with them, everywhere I'd look, every box I'd open would have these little moths.So, finally this year I decided to look up traps for them, and sure enough found these Catchmaster traps with good reviews. I set two up, one inside the house and one within the garage, and within the first night the indoor one had caught 2 moths and the garage had caught around 10. Fast forward to about 3 weeks later and the garage one no longer had any available surface space it was so filled with moths! I've gotta say, I'm not sure what people were expecting when they complain these don't last more than a few months; they are disposable traps, they aren't intended to be a year-round product.All in all though, I'm happy, these things really work. When I opened up the next package and put two more in the garage, there were already moths jumping in the trap before I had fully set it up!

I have not even played the game yet, but feel compelled to write a review solely based on the delivery method of this game for PC users.  Although I understand that most applications are shifting to download method versus CD/DVD/BluRay, the fact is that it should be discounted when compared to the console versions that do come with a disc.  Why should I have to pay the same price just to receive an empty box with a download code, and then use my internet connection/time to download it?  Not to mention that if something should happen to my computer, I have no disc to reinstall.  Yes, if it happens anytime soon I can probably reinstall it by downloading it again (more time), but what happens in the distant future when I want to reinstall this game and it's no longer available to download?  And why is only the PC version a download code?  The consoles can all download full games as well -- why pick on/cheat just the PC gamers?I'm hoping this game lives up to the previous version which I enjoyed so well.  If it does, I may come back and adjust my rating appropriately, but I don't think I can ever give this game (no matter how good it may be) a full 5-star rating with this whole download-only thing just for PC gamers.

I am actually surprised there are no other reviews for this product, because it's quite excellent.  Personally, I needed a pouch type case like this because I use a mount/holder in my car that's custom made for the Nexus 6 so it cannot have even a thin case on it or it will not fit.  What's nice about this case is that the screen is protected.  Most cases do not offer any protection for the screen at all.  The pull tab to get the phone out of the case is a nice system/feature.  The quality of the leather/stitching seems excellent -- I hope it lasts.
This does not fit a pug well at all, and I don't see the helmet fitting any type of dog.  Without the helmet, the costume is useless and no one will know what your dog is supposed to be.

I was pleasantly surprised about the differences in the item pictured and what was sent.The center glass piece is not connected with rubber tubing -- it's a solid piece of glass.  The only caveat to that change is that they didn't include a center pipe clamp.  I'm not terribly confident that the center pipe won't break because of that lack of support from a clamp, but it seems to be pretty sturdy.The base is also not a triangle -- it's a rectangle, which I feel will be a lot more sturdy.We are using this for my son's 8th grade science fair experiment.  We were just going to go with something homemade, but this will look sooooo much more "professional", and also put the focus more on the experiment rather than the apparatus used in the experiment.  I feel it will result in a better grade/score.  At first it seemed a little on the price side (even those others here on Amazon were significantly higher priced), but when you add up all the supplies, time spent finding, buying, and assembling it, it's actually probably the better deal.  I also just don't really have the time to fabricate one of those from scratch.  I firmly believe this a right tool for the best job scenario.I highly recommend it if you need one

Original 2-star Review:The costume is actually pretty good, but unfortunately it arrived missing one of the two plastic hoops that make up the mouth and the one that was there was split/broken.  Of course, now it's too late to return this one and get a replacement that isn't broken, so I'm stuck paying full price and still having to rig something to make the costume usable for my child for Halloween.Incidentally, I'd recommend getting one of those green one-piece suits to wear underneath this as it doesn't come with a real shirt, gloves, pants, etc.  Basically it's just the pot and the mask, but it's still a great costume.So, costume is actually recommended, but the vendor, Blockbuster Costumes, I would steer clear from them.Edit:  So now that Halloween is over, I had to come back and report that this costume was a huge hit -- everyone loved it.  However, I have to take credit for a lot of that because I modified it rather significantly.  Like I stated above, mine did not come with a hoop in the lower jaw, so I added some plumbing tube from the hardware store and it worked great.  I also stitched the two jaws more together in the corner of the mouth which looked a lot better.  I also added a hoop of plumbing tube around the "rim" of the pot so it kept its shape a lot better and actually looked like a pot instead of skirt.  A green one-piece leotard was worn under it.  My son said it was a little difficult to see out of it, but I showed him how the face covering just velcro'ed in place, so he could uncover and recover his face as he wanted.Overall, great costume, but I'm still steamed that I had to pay full price for one that was broken and missing parts.  But the costume was such a success, that I decided not to have the costume take a hit because the seller has lousy quality control, so I changed the review to 5-stars, purely for the costume.

This is an excellent flood light for decorating during the holidays.  I'm currently using it for Halloween, uplighting a 15' tall ghoul, and setting it on dark purple or blue or even using the strobe function makes the Halloween decor look awesome.  I'm probably going to buy a second one for use at Christmas, so that the entire front of my house will be well lit. If you have a smaller house (or smaller front face to your house), you could easily get by with just one because it's very bright with a rather wide angle beam.It's probably bigger than you might be thinking it is.  In fact, it's huge.  I have laptop computers that are smaller.  I guess that can be good or bad depending on how you're using it.  I don't actually mind the size, but was surprised about how big it actually is.The remote works fairly well, but it has very limited range as others have said.I know this has been asked/answered several times, but there seems to still be conflicting answers -- it definitely retains the last settings in memory, even when powered off with a timer or just unplugging it.

Worked perfect, just as advertised!  Make sure you check the model numbers for the both the PS3 and drive.  I would've bought the wrong drive if I hadn't checked. Replacement process is fairly easy if you're used to working on PCs and other electronics.  My kids are so happy now that they can play their PS2 games since their PS3 fat is back up and working!

My family really likes this type of case for their iPads and Android tablets.  I usually buy the Poetic brand version of this style of case, but they haven't been holding up too well, ending up with the plastic corner pieces cracking/breaking, etc.  This Fintie version seems much more durable, as well as more form-fitting, completely covering and therefore protecting the edges.  The material it is made out of also cleans up better than the "leather" versions.  The autowake feature works very well, too.Just a word of warning -- this case is NOT going to really protect any tablet from accidental drops, even from a short height. After replacing the screen on my son's iPad 3x, I attempted to move him to a nerf style case to better protect the device from accidents, but those cases render the iPad almost unusable.  In the end, he went back to the case and he just needs to be more careful.  But think of this case as more of a scratch protection than drops or any other moderate impacts.

Very nice chair for $100!  It's a little smaller in the seat than my previous chair, which was a bit of a personal disappointment, but I'm a pretty big guy (6'3", 235lbs) and I still have plenty of room in this chair.  The material on it gets a little hot after sitting there a while, but I think that would happen even with real leather.  It was also relatively easy to assemble.

I was very disappointed to discover that this router does NOT play nicely with the Verizon FIOS G1100 modem/router that I have with my FIOS service.  There's no way to make the Asus my primary router and no way to make it be an AP.  You may want to consider a different router if you have FIOS service.

All I'm going to say is that when we took three of these posters (for my three boys) to get framed, the employee tried to buy these posters off of us.  Simply put, these are cool, and anyone remotely into gaming would love it.

First of all, I have to commend Bissell for even attempting a product like this.  Why?  Because of SUS (Stupid User Syndrome) that is typically rampant in both floor steamers and vacuum cleaners by themselves.  SUS is amplified x2 when combining these two products.  I don't understand why quite a few people here find direct manufacturer replies to these reviews as suspect.  I find it to be excellent customer service!If you read through the 1-star reviews, the majority of them say the Bissell Symphony worked perfectly the first few times/months they used it, but then it stopped performing well.  Guess what, people?  You have to maintain your housecleaning tools!  I own three different vacuum cleaners, two different steamers, one hard floor scrubber, and one carpet cleaner.  After every time that I use any of these, I thoroughly clean them.With my vacuums after each time that I use them I remove hair and debris from the power brushes, I wipe out the inside of the dirt cup with a wet paper towel, and generally clean the entire outside casing.  Every two or three times that I use the vacuums I clean the filters as directed in the operator's manual.  About every six months or so, I actually remove the hoses and run water through them to remove any built-up dust, and then allow to drip dry.  These are all things you must do or every vacuum is going to fail over time.  If you don't want to do this, then I suggest you revert back to a broom and dustpan, as they don't require any maintenance.  Have fun with that!With my steamers I only use distilled water.  The reason why stares at me every few months when I get a shower -- all of my shower heads in my house are crusty with mineral build-up because most city water is ridiculously hard.  You should be doing the same thing in all devices in your house that produce steam -- steam cleaners, steam mops, clothing steamers, irons, etc.  There's no place for those minerals to go when tap water is converted to steam, so it stays in the product and affects performance. Usually you can resolve this by running a cycle or two of diluted vinegar/water through it, but it's just better, easier, and usually cheaper or about the same price to simply use distilled water.  You should especially use distilled water when the manufacturer specifically recommends it.  Not doing that is, frankly, SUS (Stupid User Syndrome) and definitely not the fault of the product or manufacturer.Also, a lot of the complaints seem to be centered around cleaning up heavy messes.  This isn't a shop-vac or an industrial steam cleaner -- it's more of a regular, routine cleaning device.  If your home is really so filthy that this device cannot clean it, then you probably need to either clean more often or switch all you devices over to industrial/commercial models that are made for cleaning the apparent restaurant/hotel level of filth that you seem to be encountering.  I have pets, I have children, I have women in the house with long hair, and I've never encountered messes that my consumer home appliances couldn't clean or maintain.Now, all that being said, the Bissell Symphony works just fine for me, even after months of owning/using it.  Does it vacuum as well as my dedicated vacuum (Shark Rotator Liftaway Professional)?  No.  But even a Dyson vacuum doesn't clean as well as my Shark does, so I really didn't expect this product to either.  I expected it to clean as well or better than my Hoover Lynx cordless vacuum (which is an excellent cordless vacuum by the way), and it does do this.The Bissell Symphony does steam just as well as both of my other steam mops (if not actually better because the steam starts faster), and it is nice to not have to vacuum the whole floor first.  Admittedly, if I want my home to be as thoroughly clean as I can possibly get it (like I do once or twice per month), I vacuum the whole house with my dedicated vacuum and then steam mop all the hard floors with a dedicated steam mop.  However, between these ultra-thorough cleanings, the Bissell Symphony does an excellent job of maintenance cleaning, and because it's combo device, I can get it done in roughly half the time.  My time is valuable -- so it's nice for housecleaning to not take as long every time.  There are several problem areas in my home -- by the guinea pig cage, under the bar stools, and under the dining room table.  I usually hit those areas (and only those areas) with my Hoover Lynx cordless, and then just use the Bissell Symphony on the entire floor.I originally rated the Bissell Symphony 4/5 stars because I feel there is room for improvement on both the vacuum and steam mop sides.  I do feel that if this item was improved it would most likely cost a lot more than it does, so given the price/performance ratio, I feel this is overall a very good product to excellent product as-is, which would probably get it more like 4.5 stars, so I rounded up.

I bought this card for a Core I3 based gaming machine for my sun.  He mostly plays Steam games as well as Minecraft, and it handles those exceptionally well.  It's also very capable of playing the latest Call of Duty titles at rather high settings with great performance.  Just make sure you pair it with a nice, fast monitor, because I tried to skimp a little on the monitor and ended up having to switch it out for a better performing one.  The colors were bleeding/blurring a lot, and I was initially worried it was the graphics card, but it wasn't.  The new monitor (only $15 more) works much better when paired with this GPU.  Good  dollar value, too.

Wouldn't you know it, as soon as I bought this the wife ended up with a nail in the tire of her vehicle, so I was able to test this out when I had to top off some air in the spare tire.  My wife has a Toyota 4Runner with big 20" wheels, too, and this pump made quick work of about 10-15lbs of air.  I was initially annoyed that a compressor with these specs didn't allow for using a cigarette lighter plug to power it,, but it's honestly not bad to hook it up directly to the battery, and it easily reaches all the way back to the rear wheels on my Toyota Sequoia SUV.  Very powerful, and ridiculously quiet.  As soon as I heard how quiet it was I figured the performance would suffer, but not so at all!  Definitely the best portable compressor I've ever owned, and I've owned about 1/2 dozen different ones over the years.

This is a great, lighter-weight blazer that's perfect for dresswear in a warmer, humid climate like Florida where I live.  This blazer with a nice pair of linen slacks, a guayabera style shirt (untucked), and a pair of nice dress sandals and you're set!  Nice and dressy yet comfortable.  Great jacket for "formal dining" on cruise ship vacations!

I was a little worried about these shoes when I purchased them, mostly because they're not real leather.  Now that I have them in-hand and actually wore them all day to a college graduation (that involved significant walking distance from parking), I don't know if I'll buy a pair of real leather sandals again.  These are soft as butter with a really nice insole and tread that provides ample arch support, no blisters, and all-day comfort.  They look really nice and dressy on, too.  I live in Florida, so I can't always do the full suit approach to dresswear, but a nice lighter weight linen suit or blazer/slacks, and untucked straight tail guayabera style shirt, and these nice dress sandals and I'm set.  Also excellent for dining on cruise vacations, etc.

I love these shirts for semi-dressy events.  Perfect with a nice pair of linen slacks and some dress sandals.  I'm not a huge guy, but I'm big, tall, and a lot of my height is in my torso.  I like the way Cubavera adds some torso length to their big/tall sizes, but not too much.  It fits me perfect for throwing on a nice linen blazer over it without the shirt tail hanging under the blazer in the front or back.  I reside in Florida and it's just too hot/humid to do the full suit for dresswear all the time.  This is a very nice alternative and still looks dressy.

I'm currently on a quest for a stakeout pole (SOP) for my kayak.  I have several homemade ones (using a garden stake as well as PVC).  The fiberglass on this SOP is a little more "chaulky".  It's also a non-standard size pole (diameter) so it's difficult to add a stainless steel point to it.  At 6' it's also a little on the short side.  The water I typically fish is very shallow, but there are frequently times where 6' just isn't enough. The rubber handle is very easily marked/marred.  Also the anchor shackle is not very useful since it's so high up.  Unless you're in 5-6' of water, attaching a lead to the shackle is going to pull the anchor to the side and out of the ground.  It's better to attach the lead so it slides up and down the pole depending on the depth of the water (you want the lead to be at water depth).I'm probably going to end up with an 8' Wang Anchor, which is a lot more expensive but includes a stainless steel tip and a better handle.  There's also a DIY one available (Google catfish stakeout pole), but to be economical you really need to organize a group buy, which makes the initial front money somewhere around $350.Overall, this is pretty good SOP, but I think there are better ones out there.

I bought my first one for a new computer build for my son, but I liked it so much that I immediately purchased another one for my other son's computer.  This mouse just has an excellent button feel, shape, etc.  Normally I would just buy a Microsoft Comfort Mouse 6000, but for some reason they're now $130??!!  I'm glad they were that price though, because I would've never found this one. About the only negative I've found is that there's no way to customize the thumb buttons.  I would prefer for one of the thumb buttons to be a magnifier. I'm currently looking for a 3rd party utility that can do this function, but other than that this is a perfect mouse!

I tried this tea in a cafe when on vacation recently and was so happy when I found it on Amazon after returning home.  Due to health problems, I recently gave up all caffeine, including coffee and sodas, but I've found myself needing a slight caffeine pick-me-up, and the relatively low amount of caffeine in tea does the trick.  I really like the flavor of this tea.  I tried both the regular and tropical versions, and I like the fruity-ish flavor/scent of the tropical the best.  Neither versions are bitter at all, even if accidentally over steeped.  And just like it says on the package, you can easily share one teabag across two cups.  Two Leaves and a Bud have definitely found a new customer!

I haven't had a chance to really use these yet, but I did test them/try them out and they seem like they're going to work perfectly.  Previously, I was just using some 1/4" rope, and I think these rachets will do a much better job.  Like others have said, the actually ratchet part is TINY, but seems to work very well.  The carabineers seem to be rather heavy-duty for their size, and work a lot better than the "S" hooks that the other Malone ratchet systems uses.  Not terribly expensive either.

I've only been using it for about 5 days now, but I'm very impressed with this dashcam, especially for the price.  Everything has been working perfectly with no problems at all.I chose the capacitor rather than battery model because I reside in Florida where electronics are typically baked quite nicely through the windshield in the Florida sunshine.  The black bezel was nice, too, so it's not so "advertised" that you have a camera on your windshield -- it definitely blends in a lot more.Apparently this camera now comes with a different mount than that what the online reviews typically show.  This new mount swivels nicely for almost infinite adjustment, and it seems to lock down pretty securely.  .Another thing that most reviews I've read claim is that you cannot use a Class 10/UHS microSD card in this camera, but that's the only card I had available and it's been working flawlessly.  My firmware in the camera is dated September 2014, so perhaps that's something the manufacturer fixed with a firmware update.As the photo shows, I mounted mine behind the rearview mirror next to my radar detector (which is actually mounted to the mirror stem).  I then ran the included power cord around the windshield and installed a 12v receptical under my dash using a fuse tap/"add-a-circuit".  Everything looks really clean and uncluttered, with no cords showing or hanging down in front of the windshield.  I can still see the screen just under the mirror to check on it from time to time, but once you configure it to your preferences, the camera pretty much just runs itself.  When you start up the car, the camera powers on and starts recording, and then stops recording when you shut the car off.Overall, a very nice dashcam at a price that's difficult (if not impossible) to beat.

Seems to still be the most stable, go-to OS for PCs at the moment.  I've worked a little with Windows 8 and I just don't care for it.  I'm hoping that Windows 10 will be more like Windows 7.  I was a long-time holdout on Windows XP for the same reasons.  When it just works and is reliable, why mess with it?  That's now what Windows 7 64 bit is to me -- my new XP.

I used these for a system rebuild and they're working great.  I actually had problems with the motherboard not booting because I didn't have these DIMMs pushed all the way into the socket (oops....noob mistake),  Decent price and more than enough memory for a Windows 7-64 bit system.

I used this processor along with a new motherboard to upgrade a previous Pentium Duo system I built a while ago (that's now being used by my kids), and I'm actually very impressed with the performance.  I have a custom i7 system for myself (I do a lot of gaming and video editing), and was going to go with the i5 processor for upgrading the kids' PC, but the high price of the i5 put a stop to that.  For the high price of the i5, I might as well go with an i7, but the i3 is ridiculously cheap and for the medium level gaming that they do on the PC, it does a great job.  They mostly use consoles for gaming, so it really wasn't necessary for them to have an i7 processor.  I have this i3 processor on an Asus  B85M-G R2.0 motherboard with an older Asus Radeon 7850 graphics card and 8GB of RAM with Windows 7 64-bit, and it's now a very nice, extremely capable system.I have no regrets at all going with the cheaper i3 versus i5/i7 processors.

Working fantastic so far.  I used this motherboard to upgrade an old Pentium Duo system where the onboard network card failed.  It was time to upgrade to a more modern processor anyway (i3).  The upgrade went very smooth -- I basically replaced all the major internal components of the system and the whole process (including new OS install) was literally done in just a couple of hours.  I am a 20+ year career network engineer, but hardware upgrades don't usually go this smoothly.Minor caveats would be that the motherboard doesn't seem to be entirely micro ATX formfactor, because I replace another micro ATX board with this one in the same case, and the screw holes for the case aren't all in the correct area for this new motherboard, even though they were for the old one.  The case is just a generic mini tower, so it's not like I'm trying to re-use a proprietary Dell or HP case or something.  It works, but there's just not as much support as I would like, and it was a minor issue when pressing on the motherboard to install the CPU, heatsink/fan, and RAM.When i first turned on the system, it wouldn't boot.  I immediately thought I had a DOA motherboard, but then I remembered to go back to the basics and make sure everything is seated properly and check all the wire connections.  Turned out that I didn't have either RAM DIMMs pushed all the way in (probably because I was worried about the motherboard flex from the lack of screws).  I felt like a noob, but was glad something so simple solved the problem.  After that, everything booted up perfectly.This is my second Asus motherboard, and so far i would highly recommend them.  I have this micro ATX one now for my kids' computer, and for my full-height tower computer, I have a full ATX motherboard by Asus, which has been working perfectly for a year now.

Love it so far.  It replaced an Lexmark X8350 All-in-one printer that just croaked on me out of the blue (it was rather old).  I love that ALL of the functions of this printer -- printing, scanning, faxing, etc. -- are all available wirelessly to every PC that's connected to it.  There's also some limited functionality with Android/iOS devices.  It prints fast, relatively quiet (a bit of "clunking"), ink colors are really, including in printed photos.  Anything that I initially felt to be a caveat has all turned out to be learning curve differences between this Epson printer and my Lexmark (which again, I had for a very long time and was very used to it).  Some things that didn't seem to work right (perfect example is the rear paperfeed) worked fine after I read the instructions and figured out how it was supposed to work.  About the only lingering caveat is the XL (high capacity) ink cartridges are not readily available in my local stores, but even that isn't a really big deal because with a little planning ahead, I can order directly from Epson (with free shipping) for the same price that they're listed at in the local stores (when they're in stock).  It's just a really nice, modern printer that is a nice upgrade to my old Lexmark.
This is a great bobble-head -- a lot more detail than usual, even compared to the others in the Guardians of Galaxy series.  Can't wait for the Baby Groot to come out!

Very cute figures.  Came upon these by accident when browsing Amazon, and they're the perfect addition to my youngest Minecrafter's collection.  These are TINY, so note the size in the description so you won't be disappointed thinking they're the usual size for action figures.

Very cute figures.  Came upon these by accident when browsing Amazon, and they're the perfect addition to my youngest Minecrafter's collection.  These are TINY, so note the size in the description so you won't be disappointed thinking they're the usual size for action figures.

Very cute figures.  Came upon these by accident when browsing Amazon, and they're the perfect addition to my youngest Minecrafter's collection.  These are TINY, so note the size in the description so you won't be disappointed thinking they're the usual size for action figures.

Very cute figures.  Came upon these by accident when browsing Amazon, and they're the perfect addition to my youngest Minecrafter's collection.  These are TINY, so note the size in the description so you won't be disappointed thinking they're the usual size for action figures.

I'm actually pleasantly surprised by these.  They stay in place well for exercising/activity, but definitely try the different size earbuds and clips until you figure out whatever fits your ears the best.  I do wish the neck cord was a little bit longer so it draped around the neck more, because if you turn your head too far to the left or right, it tends to pull. The controls aren't very easy to use, especially the single button for power, play, pause, etc.  You can't really operate that button with the headphone in your ear because you have to press it so hard that it feels like you're going to bust an eardrum.  The sound on these is pretty good, better than what you would typically expect for such inexpensive headphones.  No, they're not Bose, so you have to manage your own expectations.  Like others have mentioned, it doesn't come with any sort of charger -- just a USB charging cable.  You can use your phone charger, PC USB port, etc.  The charge quickly and seem to hold the charge for a quite a while.  One of the other things that surprised me in a positive way about these is there is no delay when using them to watch movies on my tablet.  Usually with wireless headphones there's a delay.  Overall, especially for the price, I would highly recommend these if you're looking for inexpensive, good, wireless headphones.

This one is no different than any of the other switches (most of which I've also tried) -- it doesn't work.  I get no audio through any of the devices.  I've replaced all the cables, tried all three devices in different orders, even tried it on a different TV, but it's all the same result -- no audio.  The peripherals I'm attempting to connect are a late model Sony Smart BluRay player, a Roku3, and a Comcast Genie Client all hooked up to a Panasonic 42" Plasma HDTV (which is admittedly old-ish, but I've also tried it on a month-old Vizio HDTV.I've now given up on a remote controlled HDMI switch.  I'll just keep using the manual GE HDMI "puck" style switch that requires me to get up and press a button to change the input.  It's just 2014 -- why should I expect to be able to use a remote control?  (sarcasm)

I'm a career network engineer, and I cannot get this device to reliable produce audio from any of the three devices connected to it.  I've tried all new HDMI cables, I've tried all the devices (Roku3, DirecTV Genie Client, Sony BluRay Player), each device by itself, various combinations of 2 devices, and the only time I get any audio is randomly from the Roku3, but even that is completely inconsistent.  The manufacturer admits that some devices/TVs are simply not compatible.  There really needs to be a compatibility list in the description.  Otherwise, it's a crapshoot as to whether or not it will work with your devices.  Thankfully, Amazon accepted the return at no charge to me.

Bought this for my son's Toyota Matrix.  I added cruise control and this aux input and he says it's like having a new car....haha.  Seriously, it was really easy to install.  I just drilled a hole in a convenient place in the dash, routed the wires to the head unit, and plugged it into an adapter that plugged into the CD changer port.  All he has to do is press the CD button 2x and it displays "Aux" on the screen and his phone's music plays throught the head unit.

I didn't buy these for my kids' first sax and clarinet mouthpieces, but when I recently replaced their mouthpieces, I decided to try these.  They work really well, are barely visible, and as woodwind player myself since 6th grade, I can barely tell they're even there.  Honestly, the only way I can tell is that it is softer on the teeth because they're rubbery feeling.  I never really liked seeing the black ones on other people's instruments, but these are very unobtrusive and do help your teeth as well as protect the mouthpiece.  Easy to install and easy to remove.

This is the second one of these that I've purchased for my middle school band student.  The first one that I purchased to replace the rather crappy one that came with his sax got a small chip in it (from when I dropped it while cleaning it .... oops!).  It still seemed to play fine, but you just never know, so I bought another one and moved the chipped one to being a "backup".This mouthpiece with a Bari Star (medium) synthetic reed and a Vandoren LC57DP ligature has proven to be a perfect combination.  My son gets excellent sound and is always being complimented by his band director as well as judges at solo and ensemble competition.  They're always surprised to find out he's using a synthetic reed, but I think it's the combination of the three that makes all the difference.

This is an excellent mouthpiece, so I felt the need to give it five stars, but I hope that others will read this review above and beyond the star rating, because my son has had a lot of difficulty playing with this mouthpiece versus the one that came with his clarinet.  First of all, the cork on this one made for a very tight fit on my son's clarinet.  I actually expected this, as all of the corks on his clarinet were VERY tight when first purchased, and this was easily remedied with some sanding and cork grease.  However, for some reason he just has a lot of difficulty getting a good sound with this mouthpiece compared to the one that came with his clarinet.  Even using the same reed and ligature.  I also played the clarinet since 6th grade, and I don't have a problem with this mouthpiece at all, but I'm sure my son won't be the only one.  I purchased this mouthpiece because his original one has a tiny chip on one corner of the mouthpiece, so I thought it would be a good idea to replace it before it became a problem.  He's back to using his old mouthpiece, but I decided to keep this one in case the old one eventually gives up the ghost completely.  Hopefully he can learn how to play on it should he ever need to.My other son plays sax and I bought him a Yamaha 4C mouthpiece for it and he loves it and plays it much better than the mouthpiece that came with his sax.Overall, I highly recommend this mouthpiece, but don't be surprised if your young band member doesn't like it so much.

This is an excellent neck strap.  I've been having trouble finding a replacement strap for my the one that came with my son's sax.  His original strap is starting to show some wear, and I didn't want him to be without one should it eventually decide to give up the ghost.  All the other straps I've looked at aren't as comfortable or they clips are plastic or the design uses a plastic swivel, etc.  This clip and swivel are metal, the padded neck is definitely leather, and the whole thing is easily adjustable.  Very nice design and craftsmanship.  I'm glad I bought this size versus the other bigger one, as this proved to be a perfect length for my son and he's even tall for his age.

Love these cards.  I've now bought 4 of the orange/white 32GB cards, and 3 of these 64GB cards.  Two of the 64GB cards are being used in my wife and son's Samsung Galaxy Tab S tablets, and the performance for movies, music, recording video/pics is excellent. I'm using the third 64GB card in my Samsung Galaxy Camera 2, and the video and photo performance in this camera with that card is superb. I'm also using one of the 32GB models in my Galaxy Note 10.1 2014 Edition tablet, as well as one in my Galaxy Note 2 phone, and another two (I rotate them) in my GoPro camera.I've never had a single problem with any of these cards, and they have all been very reliable.  For some reason the orange/white cards are significantly cheaper than the black cards of the same brand, capacity, and specs.  Not sure what the reason is for that, but I'll happily tolerate the brighter colors for the $ savings.
Seems to be legitimate OEM, and works as well as the one it replaced (that stopped working).

This is the second one of these I've purchased -- and not because something happened to the first one.  It actually works so well that I wanted two.  I'm using one on my Panasonic Lumix FZ200 camera and the second one is for my newly purchased Samsung Galaxy Camera 2.  For the Camera 2 I purchased a flash bracket that I mount the mic to, and then I had to purchase an adapter to plug the mic into the combo headphone/mic jack.  Basically, any adapter that works for the iPad will also work for the Camera 2.  I also had to buy an adapter for the Panasonic FZ200 as it uses the smaller size jack.  This mic works great on both cameras, and both cameras shoot excellent 1080p video.  With this mic the dual footage from both of these cameras results in a really nice verging on pro level production.If whatever device you're using for video offers a mic jack, I'd highly recommend buying this mic and using it.  Most devices that offer 1080p video do a good job, but the built-in mics are usually the main drawback.  This will definitely improve your videos.

Exactly what I was looking for -- an extra quick release plate for my new tripod.  Works perfectly and the priced nicely.  I don't buy really high end tripods, but my tripods are still really nice.  However, it is usually rather difficult to find an extra quick-release plate for them.  I was surprised and happy to find one for this Dolica travel tripod.

I have mixed feelings about posting this review, because I love this rod and would normally give it 5 stars.  Unfortunately, both times that I tried to buy this rod through Amazon (and/or one of their venders but still shipped by Amazon) the rod has arrived broken, but I decided to to just keep this a review of the product.  My normal source for this rod (a local sporting goods chain) does not stock them anymore.  This is my favorite rod for fishing in-shore saltwater, love the fast action, love the length, pairs perfectly with a Daiwa Crossfire 2000 or 2500 reel, making a really nice under $60 combo.  If you can get the rod locally, I highly recommend buying it, but I cannot recommend ordering it through Amazon.
Nice gloves -- matches the Deluxe Star Lord costume perfectly.  Received them very quickly and the size/fit was exactly as expected.

The batter seems to be legitimate OEM, and the charger works great.  I can't really use the stand because both of my sons' S3's are in thick protective cases, but honestly I didn't buy it for the stand anyway.
Seems to be legitimately OEM Samsung, but only time will really tell.  Charged up fine and seems to last as long as the original did when new.

I really like this bracket and it does exactly what it advertises.  It's perfect for use with my superzoom camera, as well as my DSLR for getting my shotgun mic off the camera to reduce picking up lens, etc. noise on the mic.  I only gave it 4/5 stars purely because of the STENCH.  Both the rubber handle and the baseplate absolutely reek.  I just left it out in the garage for a week, and a lot of the smell dissipated, but it still smells a little and the smell rubs off on your hands during use.  I've tried heavily scented soap, but the smell still comes back.  I'm going to leave it out in the garage until I need to use it next, so hopefully the smell will eventually be gone.

I don't know why this item is titled "Dental Pick" because the two picks included are relatively useless.  The two scrapers are good, the mirror is a mirror, and I'm honestly not sure what the other tool is because I definitely can't find a use for it in my mouth.  The case is poorly constructed and the tools always fall out of the hole that's still there even when the zipper is closed.  Overall, I'm just unimpressed.  I would send it back, but I'm not going to do that when I've already sterilized the tools and had them in my mouth, etc.  I probably just should've gone with my instincts and sent them back as soon as I opened them.

I have very mixed feelings about this repair kit, but I hate it when buyers review things based on principle rather than reviewing the actual product itself, so that's why I gave it 4/5 stars because OVERALL the product worked and was relatively easy to install.Okay, first of all, Kohler...sheesh...really?  Can Kohler make a valve any more different/proprietary than every other company?  Because I seriously doubt it.  Plus, i really don't think this is the best valve design and definitely more prone to leaks.  All that being said, kudos to Amazon for having it for a fraction of the price of the local hardware stores, and it was great that it was a combo instead of having to buy the items separately (yes, they're both needed to repair a leaking shower).I purchased this to repair the six-year-old shower in our six-year-old home, and I'm rather surprised to find it so different from the original part.  Basically, it's rather similar, but there are some significant differences, too.  First of all, I had to install it a complete 180-degrees from the original.  Not sure why they felt the need to do that, but I (of course) didn't notice it until I installed it and tried to test the hot water.  It wasn't that big of a deal, but it was annoying to have to turn off the city water valve AGAIN, and drain all the water our of the system AGAIN, and then reinstall it "upside down".  There is also no way to install the fixture handle perfectly straight, and it has to be a few degrees from vertical when in the off position.  Again, not a huge deal, but I definitely think that was a botched assembly on the valve stem by Kohler.In the end, I'm not watching expensive Florida water steadily drip down the drain anymore, so I'm happy.  Definitely not the worst plumbing repair/install job I've done.  I still think it's an overall bad design, and I find myself wishing that when the house was under construction that we had gone with a different brand to get something with valves and a valve pot that are more standard.

I have had no Roku related problems with this device.  I really like HuluPlus and UFC.TV Fight Pass channels, which pretty much covers everything on TV that I typically watch. Yes, you have to pay around $18 for those two channels combined, but it's a lot cheaper than the $200 I'm currently paying DirecTV.  Plus, despite the negative reviews, there are quite a few truly free channels out there that are real TV channels from cable and satellite TV.I would advise considering the negative reviews that actually had problems with broken or malfunctioning Roku devices, but the hundreds of negative reviews from people in bought the Roku 3 and then tried to use it in a foreign country where it does not work should just be disregarded.  That doesn't work with DVD players, satellite TV services, satellite radio, etc.  I don't know why they would think it would work for internet streaming.The things I like best about the device:1.  It's tiny2.  The headphones port on the remote is incredibly handy3.  Setup was simple, practically instantaneous4.  Good assortment of channels5.  Navigation is very fastNegatives:1  It's a little pricey all things considering, but you can always get a Roku 1 or 2 instead of the 3.2.  It's only as good as your internet connection.  If your internet provider is having trouble, so is your Roku.3.  The remote is a shiny fingerprint/grease magnet.  A glossy remote control is a bad idea.4.  Why does everything Roku have to be purple?5.  Fingerpointing can be a problem when it comes to support.  Roku support will blame the channel/provider, the channel/provider blames Roku, they both blame everything on your internet connection, etc.In summary, I'm very happy with the device, but I'm admittedly a rather techie type of guy who doesn't consider things like this to be even a challenge.  I can see by the reviews that there are some people who are confused by just the HDMI connection.  Is it the device for you?  If you're not at least a little bit techie, probably not.

I have this trolley on both my canoe and kayak, and love it.  The pulleys alone are woth the price, but the whole kit installs easily and works really well.  I did use the zigzag cleat on my canoe, but not on my kayak.  I had to use rivets on my kayak due to accessiblity, and they're holding just as well as the screws/bolts I used on my canoe.  I have zero complaints and highly recommend this trolley.
Does what it's supposed to, but don't listen to the various YouTube how-to's on getting around HDCP (like for recording game consoles) because this device will no longer do that.

I really like this chest harness a lot more than the headband.  I think it's a lot more conservative and not quite so awkward of a "hey, look, I have a camera on my head!"  Also theme parks and other places are more likely to allow you to wear your camera on this harness than they would be with a headband.  I'm a rather big guy -- 6'3", 240lbs, and this fits fine.  I actually have to tighten it down a little.  It's also easy to put on and take off quickly, and of course it's also easy to just remove the camera.

I really didn't expect anything stellar (no pun intended), but this is a rather inferior telescope.  I think it is a decent terrestrial spotting scope.  However, honestly, if you already have a superzoom camera you probably already have the range of this scope and pretty much can guarantee you'll have better quality with the camera.  I also purchased an accessory kit that included a barlow lens, a couple more eyepieces, and filters.  These accessories were for the most part unusable on this scope because in the end all you're doing is increasing the magnification of an already poor image so you're just getting a larger bad image.  I also got a T-adapter for my Pentax DSLR, but the pics were horrible, and I can get vastly better shots with my longest Pentax lens.Specifically with regard to any astronomy use, if you're planning on looking at the moon, you'll do okay.  If you're wanting to do anything else with this don't waste your time.  The description talks about seeing Saturn's rings and Jupiter's moons -- there's simply no way.  I even used my $400 tripod and there's simply no way.  I highly suspect that this description has been mixed up with another Celestron product, because there's no way you're seeing the moons of Jupiter with this scope.

Excellent case solution for the Galaxy Camera 2.  I found the fit to be perfect for the Camera 2 and definitely not too tight.  There's only one real design problem and that's with the hole position for the wrist strap -- it's right in the middle of the top flap, when it's attached off-center on the camera.  I could see it eventually stretching or ripping the hole if you use the strap to carry the camera while in its case.  Other than that, it's perfect.  Love the magnetic closure -- I hate velcro noise.  The lower price of the brown is hard to beat, and I bought the brown even though I own a black Camera 2.

I've had this for about a month now and love it.  I do a lot of photo and video editing, and was getting really tired of losing work during minor storms which seem to always blip the power around here enough to reboot my PC.  This was really easy to install, the software is nice, powers and protects my server class desktop PC just fine. Was rather interesting to find out that the home laser printer I have installed in the same room (but not plugged into the UPS) reduces the voltage on this circuit in my home so much that it trips this UPS into thinking there's been a power loss.  Never realized laser printers were such power drains.  I will probably buy a couple more smaller versions of this for use with my childrens' video game consoles and our DirecTV DVRs, neither of which react very well to the frequent power blips we get around here.

I never have any problems applying screen protectors to my phones, but this was even easier than usual.  It is nice that the Camera 2 doesn't have any buttons on the screen that you have to work around, properly align, etc.  This particular screen protector greatly reduces finger smudges on the screen, but I feel like it has a tiny effect on the clarity of the screen after it's applied because of that anti-smudge feature.  It's still worth it to me, and still warrants 5 stars.  Excellent product and nice protection for that big touch screen.

First off, I have to say that I'm very impressed with the case.  I think that it's the best thing going in affordable underwater housings for camera -- definitely wins the "best bang for the buck" category.  Unfortunately, that's where the positive part of this review begins and ends.The negatives include me first purchasing the wrong case per the recommendation from the Dicapac website.  They recommended the WP-S3  case for my Panasonic FZ200, and there is no way that the FZ200 can fit in there.  Ironically, they made that recommendation because the WP-S3 is also recommended for the Panasonic FZ70, which is the same superzoom formfactor of the FZ200, but the FZ70 is actually slightly larger all over.  So, don't rely on the Dicapac.com "Fitment Guide", as it could steer you very wrong.So after seeing how tiny the WP-S3 was, I decided to jump two size up (skipping the WP-S5) and got the WP-S10.  It was a little big for the relatively compact FZ200 "body", but the lens extension was a nice fit.  Again, not sure why they would ever recommend the comparatively tiny WP-S3 for this camera.  The bulkiness of the case is significantly reduced by just squeezing most of the air out of it before closing.There is, of course, vignetting (black circle around the image) when shooting at full wideangle, but that's to be expected with this type of case, and most people are going to be shooting at full zoom anyway.  The lens extension on the case is somewhat collapsible, so if you really wanted a wideangle shot, you could get it without vignetting by simply pulling the lens extension in toward the body of the case.  It's a clumsy solution, but it would work.  My smaller diameter lens on the FZ200 is somewhat "lost" in the rather wide lens extension of the WP-S10, but this is the only case that will work because of the length of the FZ200's lens when zoomed.Another caveat of this case is if your camera has one or more roller style controls.  You will not be able to adjust these at all.  On my cameras the aperture is controlled by a roller, so if you're shooting in shallow water where the light is brighter, you're going to have trouble controlling highlights, and then again have trouble in deeper, darker water when you can't open up the aperture.  Limited access to controls with this case definitely dictates that you put your typically high end camera in a very automatic point-n-shoot mode, which somewhat defeats the purpose of the whole endeavor of getting an underwater housing for your high end camera instead of just using a $150 waterproof point-n-shoot.The deal ender for me was that in testing the camera/casing combo, all of my pictures were turning out very soft if not actually blurry/out of focus.  My camera has one of the best, fastest, reliable auto focus features available, but I kept getting very soft pics, even in bright light, even on land (as in not underwater).  So I theorized that it might be the autofocus system of my camera not liking being behind a the lens cover of the case.  My camera does fine with filters on the lens, but the lens cover on this case is about 1" from the end of the camera so I thought that could be the problem.  So, I got out my Pentax K-X DSLR, tried several different lenses on it, and same softness/slight blur.  So I removed the lens cover from the case (it screws on/off), focused a shot with my FZ200 completely out of the case, and then put the removed lens cover from the case in front of the FZ200 lens -- instant blurring visible from the viewfinder and LCD.  The lens cover on this case is not optically correct!  With that issue, it would be better to simply use my Pentax WG-2 waterproof camera or even my GoPro, because although those pics are not as nice quality as pics from the FZ200 or my Pentax K-X, you can easily tweak quality in post-processing, but you can't fix such significant blur.Coming to this conclusion was very disappointing, as I was really looking forward to better waterproof photography.  I frequently fish from a kayak, and participate in Heroes on the Water events (where we take war veterans kayak fishing), and I was going to use this to get better photos of the veterans out on the water, especially from a distance (I can't be up close for everyone all the time).  It's bummer that it's no longer an option.  I'm not sure why Dicapac wouldn't use an optical quality lens cover.  No, it's not because it's supposed to counter any distortion from shooting under water because that's not needed for underwater shooting and even that would just be a magnification adjustment not focus.Unless you like soft, unsharp photos from your high end camera, I just cannot recommend this product.

The head is acceptable quality and the particular shape and style of this Frontier Hawk is my favorite of all the various types.  I favor this shape because it has a nice wedge from the blade to the eye, and does not have any excess weight for a hammer, pipe bowl, or spike.  The Norse Hawk looks good in side profile, but instead of a wedge to the eye, it has a sharper curve.The handles on these Tomahawks are made both incorrectly and carelessly.  The taper on the handles is not gradual, but instead there is a sharp knob on the last inch of the handle, and a set screw the compensate for the incorrect handle shape.  Historical examples of tomahawk certainly did not use set screws, not only because the machine work would have been inaccessible, but the screw itself would easily be lost and irreplaceable in the field.  A proper friction fit is better than a set screw that only damages the handle.  But to achieve a good friction fit, the contour of the handle must match the taper of the head.  Cold Steel's handle has parallel sides and then a rapid taper in the last inch.  This results in only the top sixteenth of an inch of the head bearing on the handle.
