Although the handle can be re-profiled, there is barely enough material left create the correct thickness at the base of the head's taper.The grain orientation of the handle is often wrong, which is simply carelessness that results in an inferior product.

This is a carbon steel chain that is nickel and chrome-plated.  It is not stainless steel.  H-S makes stainless steel collars, but they are about twice the price and have a small tag on one of the round end links identifying that their stainless even from a distance.  You will not find a stainless H-S chain like this for less than twenty dollars new.  They're typically about twenty-eight dollars lately.Here's the advantage of chrome-plated steel: it is much glossier and shinier than stainless steel.  H-S highly polishes the nickle plating before they chrome-plate the chains.  They have a mirror-like finish.  Stainless steel, on the other hand, is a bit duller even after polishing, and then when it wears it turns a duller grey. As already mentioned, the chrome-plated steel can be had for less than half the cost of the stainless.The stainless steel HS uses has a higher tensile strength than their chrome plated collars, and it is lighter weight for the same thickness.  If you want a stronger, lighter chain that won't ever rust, but will stay a sort of bright-grey, dull mirror finish, then get the stainless.The chrome-plated steel chains are not weak by any means.  They will not wear from abrasion the way the brass ones will, and they are more than strong enough to hold any dog.  The strength is slightly less than the stainless chains, but mostly insignificant since both are far stronger than needed for the purpose.  The difference in weight is more significant.  The chrome-plated steel chains do weigh significantly more than the stainless ones, and this could matter depending on the size of chain and dog.  The other disadvantage of the chrome-plated steel is they could rust if the chrome plating is worn off and if the chain is neglected such as being left in the yard, or stored outdoors or in a wet location.

The narration is entertaining if not overly simplified, and it too frequently is dubbed over scenes of the rich men sipping whiskey in their office.  While the narration is slightly deeper, the pictures suggest these guys built empires by brooding greedily over glasses of liquor instead of actually doing any work.  While they may not have literally broken their backs the way some of their workers did, I'm pretty sure they were busy, stressed, and totally consumed by running their empires and not just engaged in the kind of solitary brooding the episodes depict.  Admittedly it would take a great deal more effort to re-enact the hectic daily life of these men, but the images often serve merely as a back drop to the narration.  It would have been better had photographs or paintings of the actual men and sites been used instead, but understandably, this was from an era before photography was especially extensive.  By way of comparison, Ken Burns documentary on Prohibition has a lot of original photographs, but is admittedly from an era slightly later.The reason I still appreciate this pseudo documentary is because it was able to hold the attention of my kids (7 and 8) who probably would not have been able to follow one more concerned with accuracy, detail, and authenticity.  I believe they learned something about this significant era in American history that they'll be able to build on later as they get older.  We used this as part of a study on the reconstruction following our study of the civil war.  We followed it with a study of WWI and then the Prohibition era.

These are inexpensive and more durable than hard plastic, but not especially durable for use with cars (driver training).  I didn't want to spend twenty bucks per cone for really thick soft vinyl traffic cones, and these are working great as long as we don't hit them too often.  Obviously they're tough enough for ball games.
leaked, only slightly but not worth the risk for boating
These are better than the plain cords that come with devices.  They are so much better that it is well worth replacing the plain cords.
son's bike has these and they're great, so when the cork grips on my bike failed, I got more of these.  They work great with terrific grip and they're tough enough to survive many drops
pricey, but I like it; part of my EDC, it clips on my whistle lanyard in my pocket
replaced some rusty old wheels with cracked tires; these look and work great

Super loud.  You really have to learn to modulate this or cover your ears if you don't want to lose your hearing.  My kids carry them outdoors, and I have one for EDC now myself.  I use it primarily to recall my dog when my lips alone won't work for whatever reason.

The trigger is awful.  Considering this is a spring operated pistol, there's really not much justifying the cost if the barrel isn't accurate and the trigger isn't good.  The barrel is accurate enough, but the trigger is horrible.  My double-action airsoft revolver has a better trigger.  This gun is single action and should be short and crisp.  It's long and mushy.
I stuffed these in the nose of my kid's kayaks for extra buoyancy.  In swamp tests, they do help, and they're totally durable.
fit on Lifetime youth kayak paddles and they work
great for disarm practice; less expensive and I believe more durable than Blue guns

very nice targets that are easy to set up.  I use scotch tape and green paint to repair them if the shots are wild (kids and beginners) and they can be repaired with regular scrap 8.5x11" paper if the shots are in the center.  They work great for bb, air-soft, pellets, rimfire and centerfire, and can work well for arrows as well with an arrow stop behind them (I use straw bales).
This is a very fine re-issue.  The sheath is not especially good for regular use, but it is an accurate re-issue.

Beautiful, but very small.  If it were just half an inch or more bigger it would be big enough to fit between the distal transverse and thenar and it would be a favorite.  As it is, it just fits under the knuckle of my index finger which really limits the power I can push it with.
Pricey, but these do seem to last forever.  The wool is very nice.
Very nice.  It doesn't lock, but it is much better looking than a Buck 110.

Does not fit the Galaxy S6.  The glass it cut about half a millimeter to narrow so the edge cuts through the image on the whole side of the screen.  I carefully adjusted it so that the left side did not overlap, but the right side still comes up short.I do not have the S6 Edge.
fits kids (under 5') well, has a nice efficient shape, seems durable, and pleasing to use

Awesome.These are nicely molded polyetheylene kayaks.  They're light (because they're small), durable, and super easy to paddle.These are easy even for kids to paddle.  Although they're best for just having fun, we've gone distances with them too.  My 8 year old can keep up with my canoe paddling a mile.  I tow my 7 year old some of the time.  After the first mile, I've towed both (as a train).Flotation is good, especially since they have foam in both ends.  They're not easy to swamp, but they certainly won't sink.  They are not easy to re-enter, but this is something that takes skill with any boat.  My boys have been successful re-entering several times, but it can be difficult and there has been times they failed without help.  Always wear a life jacket, and never go alone.It comes with a styrofoam billet in the front which adds extra flotation.  It's a good idea, but not durable as kids will kick it with their feet down there and it will come apart (it's just white styrofoam).  I removed the billets (from two kayaks) and replaced them with Polyform A-0 buoys secured to an eyebolt.  I replaced the lag screw that holds the billets in with an eyebolt.  The foam in the stern is unreachable and unlikely to be damaged.  I wonder if it could hold muck in there, but haven't had an issue so far.My wife at 5'1" and 100 pounds fits these nicely but a boat with slightly more leg room would be a little better.  They easily hold her weight though.  Even I fit them at 5'8" and 140 pounds, but I am really too big to fit the short length.  I can fully straighten my legs, but my feet are all the way to narrow part of the bow.  My weight causes the bow to ride too low in the water.  Old Towne limits them to 100 to 115 pounds, which is about right.  I would also put the height limit at 5 feet, but a heavier and taller person can fit in a pinch.Because I have paddled these myself, I can say they are a delight to paddle.  They're very fast and efficient, and they turn well.  Of course they're very short and narrow for my size, so that is not surprising.  However, I would not want a wider, longer boat for my boys as it would be harder to paddle and harder to turn.They're expensive compared to cheaper two-piece or sit-on-top kayaks carried by stores that sell lots of cheap imports.  I think they're worth it, especially if you have the opportunity to do a significant amount of paddling with your kids.  They're probably too expensive for a beach toy that you use for a once a year trip.  We've been paddling with them at least 7 times in the last two months since we got them, and will probably go another 7 times in the next two months before winter.I paddle a canoe myself so I can fit my wife and I and our dog, plus any cargo we want.  The canoe is a lot of fun too but has tradeoffs.  It is harder to paddle. It is much more affected by wind.  It is a beast to carry (it's an Old Towne and polyethylene also, about 80 pounds).  Even though it is a smaller canoe (14'7") I could fit my family of four, our big dog, and some cargo in it.  Even so, I think it was well worth it to get the kids their own boats.  They have far more fun and its more motivating for them to go.

I replaced a Schlage keyed deadbolt with this combination item.  It works very well.A combination lock allows my kids to open the door without having to keep a key.  While I used to be "latch key kid" myself, my own kids are never home alone.  Nevertheless, I might send them to the door with bags/groceries etc. while I'm still at the car.  When we come back from walking the dog, they can open the door for me.  I have confidence knowing they'll never be locked out.A combination lock means my wife and I don't have to carry keys.  My wife has an electronic fob for her car, and my car uses a switch and starter button (old school).  Eliminating the house key means no more keys at all.Brass metal keys, including Schlage and Kwikset have too much toxic lead in them.  So much that they've been sued by State's governments but they are unlikely to change.  Not having to handle a key reduces exposure to lead.The lock functions well.  It was easy to install (to replace existing deadbolt) and the result was the cylinder turns easily, it fits properly, and works smoothly.  Locking and unlocking from inside is just a turn of the large lever.  Locking from outside involves pushing the top "Schlage" button and turning the knob to lock the deadbolt.  Unlocking from outside, you can either enter the 4 digit combo into the keypad and turn the knob, or you can press the Schlage button to illuminate the keypad and then enter the combo and turn the knob.A 4 digit combo is quick and secure enough for the level of security this whole product is intended for.  It provides for more than 3000 possible combinations, so a brute force attack on the combination is not as likely as a brute force attack on the door jamb or window.  This is not a high security product, as it is intended for doors that can be kicked in, breached with a ram, or bypassed.  The buttons appear to be durable and not likely to soon reveal discrepancies in use, but the combination can be changed easily to level the use of different buttons.  The lock also supports multiple combinations, and therefore temporary combinations.I looked at alternatives, but determined this simple option is best.  I imagine future cars (and houses) will have two-factor authentication to use -- you'll need to have something (probably a digital certificate with private key on your smartphone device) and to know something (a PIN), but you'll probably have an (slightly less secure) option to pre-enter or save the PIN so that you'll be able to open the door or use the car just by being near it.  This combination lock won't unlock just because you're nearby, but it is a pretty easy PIN to enter.  I looked at alternatives that include Bluetooth or Wifi connectivity, but they all involved a proprietary service with subscription or a device that was too expensive and unproven.I don't have long term results for this product yet, but expect it will fair well for several years to come.  The brushed nickel finish on my Schlage door set failed with peeling varnish after about 5 years.  I would have thought it would be nickel plated, but apparently they coat it in some kind of plastic varnish and it comes off.  Because of that, I also doubt this combo deadbolt product is really brushed nickel, but instead it is probably the same fake painted-on finish.
not responding to claimUpdate: Smart Guard did ultimately respond to the claim and repaired the item according to the agreement.  No further issues

Perfect for whip cream or to foam egg whites.  I bought this to replace a Cuisinart immersion blender that I only ever used with the poorly-made whisk attachment.  I expect this beater to last longer.  It's also nice because it has variable speed, whereas the more costly stick blender was only high-speed and would be sure to splatter.  The only disadvantage with this manual beater is that it requires two hands to operate, so it is not practical to hold, tip or manipulate the bowl while beating.

My previous toaster lasted over 40 years, and still works.  This one lasted 2 years before one of the internal slice lifting arms dropped and an internal fuse or circuit breaker blew resulting in no power.  Because the unit is sealed with security screws and plastic seals over the housing screws, it is impractical to repair it other than to send it back to Breville for out-of-warranty repair at eighty dollars.While this toaster worked well while it worked, I feel the electronic gadgetry has been mis-applied to make something that should be simple, very complex, expensive, and prone to failure, whereas the same result can be achieved with a much simpler appliance.  You cannot taste the difference.I can think of a more innovative design for a toaster, that instead of using complex lifting motors and electronics just for show.  It would come apart into two modules so that one could be put in the dishwasher and the separate electrical module and heating elements would include a self-clean feature like ovens.  For the price, this Breville unit adds nothing of value compared to a plain electric toaster with a mechanical spring lift.

Awesome pen, but the clip was so tight it ripped my shirt.  Not only is the clip too tight, it also has sharp metal edges folded under the clip.  Too bad they do not make it with a usable clip, otherwise this would definitely be my EDC pen.

Small, light and even after 4 years it performed in training the way I would expect.  Despite its small size and light weight, there's enough spray in there to be effective even if have difficulty hitting the target.  Before training, I was concerned I would run out with this size can.  After training, I'm convinced this is enough for a single attacker.  I still prefer to carry a 2 ounce can on my belt but for my wife and other women in my family this is a size they're more likely to carry.I recently bought one of these keychain units with an additional inert trainer on Amazon for under ten bucks.  That is a good value.
I love this series.  I've been through 1, 2, and 3 with my boys.  The methodology is balanced and easy to follow.

The main functional difference between this and a Welch Allyn is this Dr Mom scope has the LED emitter obscuring the view inside the lens.  When you look through the lens, you would see a circle-shaped view down through the specula, except that from the bottom edge of the circle the led housing protrudes through and that part of the image is obscured and blurry.  The Welch Allyn uses fiber optics to direct the light into a circular cone around the circumference of the specula.  There is no obstruction of the view.The lens, magnification, and brightness on this Dr Mom is acceptable.The price is much more practical for a non-professional.
works great for fungus gnats in house plants; and I am confident to use it on food (ie tomatoes and vegetables started indoors)

Best hoses I've ever used.  I have three now.  I would just as soon throw away everything else I've ever bought or used.  The only thing these don't do is flow a lot of water.  For that, I have a 3/4" hose, but that thing is a beast to wrestle.
great stuff; the FDA might not allow labeling the purpose for pine tar because it hasn't proven in trial to be effective for enough people, but it definitely works for me; will buy again and again.

The whisk has the wires held in place in the head by white plastic.  The plastic degrades, deforms as the wire flexes, and then the plastic crumbles and the wires come out.  If their hand whisks were made like this, All Clad would be tossed on the heap with the junk they sell at the All-China-marts.This is another piece of junk from All Clad.  I hope they don't continue to ruin their name the way Kitchen Aide did their's.

This is the best portable target I have found for youth and traditional archery without heavy draw bows.  I bought this to put in the 4x4 so my sons and I could should a target in the bush without breaking or losing a lot of arrows.  The target face is much nicer than a bag target (a coffee sack stuffed with blankets and wrapping materials).  It stops arrows from my adult draw-length long bow which is about 35#.  I love shooting a bow with a low draw weight and learning instinctive archery.  I used to hunt and draw a 60# bow with a peep sight and pin, and was plenty accurate enough with it, but the lightweight bow is much more fun.  This is the right portable target for it and my kid's bows (ages 7 and 8) which must be about 10#.  At home we use straw bales which give a bigger target area for a lot less money.  We just spray paint a target on three or more bales. But that is too hard to take into the field.  This foam block is perfect to throw in the car.

This is a helpful introduction, but focuses on the basics of one fairly unpopular method.  The bulk of the book is dedicated to teaching the hand stitch or saddle stitch.  Stohlman teaches what could be described as Western stitching, with straight stitches, marked with an overstitch wheel in a groove.  European-style saddle stitching using a pricking iron, diamond awl and laying the stitches at an oblique angle seems to be far more popular with leather craftspeople and consumers of high-end leather goods.  Although the technique varies only slightly, browsing leather working forums, one will quickly realize many people have some difficulty with the European style stitching that is so sought-after.  This book doesn't help with those subtle issues.
The rough hand may be an acquired taste but the blanket is great quality.

While it may make more sense to just have the pulse oximeter as a micro-USB probe and all the software on a phone/tablet, this device does it all with a nice display and flash memory for a fraction of what probe-only devices cost.  I installed the software on a PC and uploaded the data to view a graph without any problems.  The software isn't beautiful, but it is functional.  I also understand that the data can be manipulated into 3rd party software (a previous version was integrated with Sleepy Head).The clip with display is a bit bulky for long-term recording.  I secured it with vet-wrap, careful not to make it too tight, but it was still uncomfortable after several hours.  I got good data though.This device is really most amazing for its price.  Because it is so inexpensive, I could purchase it when I was only slightly curious to record SpO2 levels over several hours.  Had I a more pressing need, I would want something more robust in features and software integration, but would have to expect to pay five times as much.

These are cheaper than a happy meal toy and probably almost as toxic as the meal.  I bought one set as giveaways for 6 to 9 year olds.  I would not give these to smaller kids as I don't trust the PVC or the paint/dye safety.  I was very disappointed in the poor quality of the items when I received them and was going to return them, but considering the price, I decided to just give them away as planned.  They are definitely not anything like Schleich, and not even the kind of quality I would expect to find at Wlmrt or Trgt stores.  I've got to commend their maker for finding a cheaper, lower quality way of making something I thought was already really cheap (plastic animals).The most disappointing thing about them from a play perspective is they are hollow and have a huge seam where they split apart.  The two halves snap together, but fairly poorly and the gap is big is some places.

This is a nice mirror.  The one shortcoming is the steel cover that fits over the studs on the wall mount plate and to which the arm is attached is made of stamped sheet metal rather than a sturdy casting.  As a result, the mounting cover flexes and the mirror bounces.  If a casting or a part machined from bar were used, the mount would be much sturdier.  I did not find any other mirror like this, and don't expect to for the price.

Dim - 39 Watts and 50 too few lumen instead of 50W and at least 550 lumen.  Look, 39 watts are fine if my lighting was specified for 39 watt fixtures, and therefore had at least 25% more lamps in the lighted area, but they were specified for 50W, which means I need 550 lumen or more and this does not deliver.  It seems every time I go to buy light bulbs, I have to decipher all the things printed on the box that are false, not true, exaggerated, or just a lie.

Dim - 53 Watts and 920 lumen instead of 75W and 1100+ lumen.  Look, 53 watts are fine if my lighting was specified for 53 watt fixtures, and therefore had 50% more lamps in the lighted area, but they were specified for 75W, which means I need 1100 lumen and this does not deliver.  It seems everytime I go to buy light bulbs, I have to decipher all the things printed on the box that are false, not true, exaggerated, or just a lie.

Dim - 53 Watts and 920 lumen instead of 75W and 1100+ lumen.  Look, 53 watts are fine if my lighting was specified for 53 watt fixtures, and therefore had 50% more lamps in the lighted area, but they were specified for 75W, which means I need 1100 lumen and this does not deliver.  It seems everytime I go to buy light bulbs, I have to decipher all the things printed on the box that are false, not true, exaggerated, or just a lie.

I love the idea, but it's nowhere near deep and loud enough.  I bought the ED-55 which is the same as this ED-50 but also features three-dog sounds, a chime, and alarm sound.  I was sorely disappointed when I plugged it in, and cranked the volume up to max.  It was distorted and I could tell it was not loud enough.  I tested it at my home's entry which has a double-pane glass window, masonite on stud wall, and a masonite/foam-core door.  The motion sensor activated just fine, but from outside the dog sounds seemed like they were very far away, like the dogs were on the other side of the house.For the sake of this review I decided to use an SPL meter to measure sound pressure levels and compare the fake dog to my real dog.  My SPL meter's microphone is not calibrated so the measurements may not be perfectly accurate, but I think they are a fair comparison since I used the same meter for both sounds.  At 1 meter, the fake dog was as much as 100 to 104 decibels (A-weighted or dBA).  At the same distance, my real dog was also about 100 to 104 dBA.  The A-weighting on the sound meter favors the high-pitched sounds the ED-55 can reproduce.  Without any obstacles in the way, the piercing sound of the ED-55 is fairly loud, but only at the higher frequencies.I also tried stepping outside my home's entry to see how well the different sounds penetrated.  The real dog is able to produce much more sound pressure at low frequencies (bass) compared to the mini-amplifier and very small driver in the ED-55 which struggles with bass.  At the highest volume level, the distortion on the ED-55 is bad.  Just like a small radio on an alarm clock, there is much less distortion if you don't crank the volume all the way up, but I still used maximum volume for all the tests.  Outside, the ED-55 produces barking sounds that only registered as high as 68 dBA, but no higher.  My dog was consistently around 85 dBA when measured through the door and wall.  Decibels are on a logarithmic scale, so that is more than four times louder than the fake dog.  For the test, I had my dog bark on command.  I think he could get even louder if he sensed a real intruder or was actually mad.When my dog is home, I don't need Rex.  But I often take my dog with me when I leave.  I was hoping to leave Rex home, but if I did, people who approach my home would probably think I've acquired a little chihuahua or that the dog is locked in a crate in the bedroom closet with the door shut.The ED-50 and ED-55 are priced well beyond simpler gadgets like the Fake-TV or a fake camera, but an ineffective product is worthless.  I would be willing to pay twice as much for a product that was twice as loud and did not have excessive distortion in the low frequencies.  But as it is, the ED-50/55 is useless.  I think it could be modified with a more powerful amplifier and a larger, perhaps six to eight inch woofer.  I may do that myself, but for most customers, I cannot recommend the fake dog.

I love the idea, but it's nowhere near deep and loud enough.  I bought the ED-55 which is the same as this ED-50 but also features three-dog sounds, a chime, and alarm sound.  I was sorely disappointed when I plugged it in, and cranked the volume up to max.  It was distorted and I could tell it was not loud enough.  I tested it at my home's entry which has a double-pane glass window, masonite on stud wall, and a masonite/foam-core door.  The motion sensor activated just fine, but from outside the dog sounds seemed like they were very far away, like the dogs were on the other side of the house.For the sake of this review I decided to use an SPL meter to measure sound pressure levels and compare the fake dog to my real dog.  My SPL meter's microphone is not calibrated so the measurements may not be perfectly accurate, but I think they are a fair comparison since I used the same meter for both sounds.  At 1 meter, the fake dog was as much as 100 to 104 decibels (A-weighted or dBA).  At the same distance, my real dog was also about 100 to 104 dBA.  The A-weighting on the sound meter favors the high-pitched sounds the ED-55 can reproduce.  Without any obstacles in the way, the piercing sound of the ED-55 is fairly loud, but only at the higher frequencies.I also tried stepping outside my home's entry to see how well the different sounds penetrated.  The real dog is able to produce much more sound pressure at low frequencies (bass) compared to the mini-amplifier and very small driver in the ED-55 which struggles with bass.  At the highest volume level, the distortion on the ED-55 is bad.  Just like a small radio on an alarm clock, there is much less distortion if you don't crank the volume all the way up, but I still used maximum volume for all the tests.  Outside, the ED-55 produces barking sounds that only registered as high as 68 dBA, but no higher.  My dog was consistently around 85 dBA when measured through the door and wall.  Decibels are on a logarithmic scale, so that is more than four times louder than the fake dog.  For the test, I had my dog bark on command.  I think he could get even louder if he sensed a real intruder or was actually mad.When my dog is home, I don't need Rex.  But I often take my dog with me when I leave. I would be willing to pay twice as much for a product that was twice as loud and did not have excessive distortion in the low frequencies.  But as it is, the ED-50/55 is useless.  I think it could be modified with a more powerful amplifier and a larger, perhaps six to eight inch woofer.  I may do that myself, but for most customers, I cannot recommend the fake dog.

A century of dog training has been built primarily on what is explained in this book.  While more recent training theory and methods may build on Most's methods with some improvements, little, if anything has refuted their validity or made them obsolete.Some critics may be suspicious that his methods were harsh, but they have obviously not read the book.  In his own words, his theory and practice is congruent with any modern method that conscientiously acknowledges the use of aversives like a harsh word ("Bah!") or the use of leash and collar which Most explains as contrasting "agreeable" and "disagreeable" experiences for the dog.  For example, walking in the heel position, the dog sustains an agreeable experience, whereas if it forges, lags or walks away out of the heel position, the leash results in a disagreeable experience.  Ironically, Most himself laments the "old days" when less sensitive methods were harsh.  As far as I know, we simply do not have a written record of those methods.  Besides this 1910 book from Most that primarily advocates inducing the dog's instincts and using positive reinforcement, earlier records include Stephen Hammond's 1882 book Practical Training that advocated positive reinforcement through praise and meat, and W. N. Hutchinson's 1848 book "Dog Breaking" which also promotes reward-based training and criticizes lack of kindness, patience, and hard punishments.My conclusion is that sum total of historical literature we have on dog training theory and practice advocates reward-based training, instinctive-inducement and positive reinforcement, and that if harsh, insensitive methods and brute force are used now or in the past*, it was due to ignorance.  Reading this book will not somehow contribute further to that ignorance, but rather serve to dispel it.One might consider Koehler's books from the 1950's as opposed to positive/reward-based training, but if that is so, then they were a contemporary departure from the 100+ years of training literature that preceded them.
not nickel at all, but paintedvery cheap

Review after 9 months:- Constant print alignment problems- Smearing- Skipped lines- Heavy color ink usage even though I almost never print color or pictures- Black ink runs out fast even though I use the faded-grey draft mode for more than half my printsThe quality problems are so persistent and grievous that I can't imagine using this for business.  I use it primarily to print worksheets for my two kids, and UPS return labels.  Every time I try to use it for something where quality matters, it disappoints.If this was truly low-initial-cost printer (40 dollar job), then I would accept getting what I paid for.  While this is still an inexpensive printer, the ink costs add up quickly and I will have to consider dumping this since it cannot print anything decently and is too costly to print casually.Note: The printer will not print black if I select black-only if even one color cartridge is reported empty.  I'm disappointed that the Epson is deliberately set up to stop printing black just because a color cartridge is out and did not allow a workaround to print black only. Shame.I've found the scanner produces poor image quality.  I would like to scan my children's artwork on paper, but I get better results taking a picture of it with a camera.  I suppose the scanner function works adequately if you're just using it to replace fax.Printing can be good quality if the right "inkjet" paper is used so it doesn't bleed too much.  I think this is the first inkjet I've had where I won't regret having it instead of a laser printer, but I also wouldn't replace the lasers at the office with anything like this.  It's definitely a home, personal or small office, low-productivity printer, and it has limited page sizes.  Personally, the thing I miss the most is double-sided 11x17, but admittedly that is another category/price-range.I have done some photo prints on this, which I would not plan to do regularly.  This is not a photo printer.  I used photo paper to print some proof-of-concepts for an offset print project.  The print quality was quite good, but the printer left roller marks with many tiny pin prick dents on the paper.  There may be an adjustment for this, but it's not worth it to me to figure out.  It was awkward enough just changing paper sizes and orientation with the poor user interface.  For photo printing, I still prefer a laser-exposure mini-lab type system (Fuji Frontier etc.) - In other words, I send it out to a service.I frequently have alignment problems with the printer.  I get places on the page where the image is shifted left or right.  I've run the print head alignment utility several times but it still has alignment problems on occasion.

I keep one in my daypack all the time (I hike in the Sierra Nevada and the Great Basin year round), and I wear the other one most of the winter.  I'd like to buy several more.  I prefer this fabric to the Icebreaker I also have.

This is on the thin side for a cap, but it's useful and I bought it to keep in my daypack as an extra so I appreciate the low bulk.  I love the Minus33 fabric, and prefer the several garmets made of it to the ones from Icebreaker that I also have.

This is a great bag.  I use the x-small one to keep extra clothes in my day pack.  It easily holds extra pants, shirt, socks, hat, sweater, and could hold a thin windbreaker as well.  I'm not planning on backpacking this next year, but when I do, I would definitely consider using this bag in other sizes for other compressible items.

I love the My First Tri-Writes, and these are a great intermediate size.  I'm using them with seven and eight year olds primarily for printing.  We'll probably still be using these when we start writing in cursive too.  I sharpen them with an X-Acto Ranger 55 mounted on the wall.

The book covers the basics of several types of ciphers as well as the basics of steganography.  It's a great introduction at the middle school level.  Younger kids could learn plenty from this but may need someone adept at explaining things from the material in the book.

This mix appears to have plenty of carbs for energy, but doesn't make water as easy to drink as Gatorade or Cytomax.  This Roctane is definitely less sweet, which I prefer, but also not as smooth.  I will use this Roctane when I really need power and endurance for athletic activities, but for simply staying hydrated I prefer something else.

It was a bit difficult to fit two very small/short, kids bikes with 16 inch wheels, but it could be done.  My wife's hybrid with the fat aluminum mixte-style frame also fit poorly since it had a very wide top tube and widely-spaced seat stays.  It still works.  My 80's Schwinn 10 speed with thin, chromo, horizontal top-tube fit perfectly.  If you had 4 bikes like that with plain diamond frames and skinny, level top tubes, this rack would be a breeze to load.  As it is, I do not think you could expect to load 4 bikes of various shapes and sizes and not expect some scuffs and minor damage from the bikes rubbing against each other.  I suppose if you have very valuable bicycles, you probably transport them on a rack in a van or truck, well-spaced apart.Threading the bolt to lock the swing-away carrier is a bit tedious.  It could be faster and easier if it was some sort of cam-lock device.  The bolt is at least safe in that it is unlikely to come undone and is backed up by the pin.

Great candy for gifts, but much of it is broken.  I've only tried a few flavors which were ok, but the candy is colorful and the tin handsome.  It's made in Mexico (along with practically all candy canes on US markets).

I could not find a dark brown in the regular consumer vinyl dyes (VHT, Duplicolor etc.).  This can of SEM is about twice the price, but still far less than re-upholstering, and for many hard vinyl or plastic items, a spary like this is really the only practical option.  I got outstanding results with the SEM product on plastic, hard vinyl, and soft vinyl.  My only complaint is the gloss is a little too much on soft vinyl.  The level of gloss was oem-like on the plastic and hard vinyl.  I prefer very low gloss, flat, matte finish.  I see SEM has clear coat products for satin or gloss finishes.  I did not want to spend on an additional product to see if that would improve the finish.

I use them in the tool box, to magnetize tools, on oil filters, oil and transmission pans, differential housings, to test rock samples for magnetite, to hold a can of extra Zippo fluid in my 4x4, and would use them to hold items on clothing instead of pins, etc.  They work great and are super strong.

Worked very well with a serial port (not a USB adapter) and a TH-K20A for use with MCP-5 (free download on Kenwood's site).  I previously ordered the PG-4Y cable that comes with a Proficy USB serial adapter and could not make that work on XP, Win7, or Win8.1 with several different versions of the driver.  I could get the driver to be correct in device manager, but MCP-5 would never read or write to the radio.  This DB-9 serial port cable worked perfectly the first time with no driver installation at all.

This is a 100% wool sweater, which will perform far better than cotton or acrylic (like the Alpha version) neither of which I would ever even bother with.  The wool is not lambswool or Merino or like any of the delicate gift sweaters you'd find at Macy's.  This is fairly tough wool from around the sheep's bottom somewhere in India.  It's made in India on a machine.It fits tight, but I am content with my regular size and would only consider one size up - my size is on the small end and I'm thin.  The sleeves are extra long because they're designed to be rolled back at the cuff.  The sweater has good elasticity so it has stayed tight and not stretched out after several years of occasional use.The sweater is fairly thick and bulky which keeps it warm even in a little breeze.  The wind blows right through my Pendleton Shetland sweater, but this Rothco is quite a bit more substantial.  I can imagine a Lanolin-rich hand-knit Aran jumper being a little tougher and warmer, but not much in this price range.

Been using Dromedary and Dromedary Lite's for 20 years - totally came to trust them on many expeditions (PCT, JMT, 14er's, and winter alpine treks) - bought 2 of these and they both leak.  MSR changed the caps or cap supplier and the new caps are defective.  I screwed on one of the caps from a Dromedary Lite I purchased 15 years ago, and it would not leak.  The old caps, which have been supplied as recently as a year ago, have "wash and dry after each use" molded on them.  The new caps do not and are thicker on the edges and have sharper grip teeth.  Fix the caps and I will change the rating.  In the mean time, I will probably have to buy Nalgene caps or something to replace the junk MSR is selling.The design is top-notch.  The fact that the caps are interchangeable with Nalgene, fit water filters, and the nylon bags are tougher than plastic are all a testament to the fact these bags can be the best.  They're the only bag I trust to fill with hot water and slip in my sleeping bag in the winter.  They're awesome, 5-star products if they're made correctly.I have a hydromedary kit I used on the bigger bags (6L) for at least 15 years.  I replaced the hose before with regular vinyl tubing from the hardware store.  The tubing on this hydromedary is smaller in diameter but still looks like standard vinyl tubing and could easily be replaced.

This is a very nice pressure gage.  I bought it specifically for the fill port it has on the side although I would have to modify it for my use.  The only let-down on this EZ Air is the clip on the end of the hose.  It slips off too easily.  I replaced it with a "CTA Tools 1930 Straight Lock-On Air Chuck."  The two chucks look nearly identical, but the Accu-Gage one works poorly and the CTA one works perfectly.My 4x4's onboard air compressor is tankless so the Schrader valve fill port isn't ideal because an air chuck on the end of my fill hose would cause pressure to build in the hose -- pressure that would normally be stored in a tank with a pressure regulator.  I don't have space for that, and don't desire the cost and complexity of tanks, regulators and cutoff switches.  Therefore I pulled the valve core, installed an adapter to 1/4" NPT and then a quick-disconnect.  The open port is on the fill hose-end and the brass disconnect is on the gage-side where it hold pressure when disconnected so I can get an accurate pressure reading.  While it's connected, I can monitor pressure in the line, but I have to estimate the corresponding pressure in the tire.  It's usually 20 to 30 psi less than the line pressure, and that's enough for me to see when the tire has aired up.

I loved this, until it died.  Now it won't turn on.  I've replaced the batteries, verified they're in correctly, and it does light dimly for a second and then fades out and won't turn on anymore.  I suspect something failed in the dimming circuit.  It's apparently under the lifetime warranty, but I'd rather that it just work -- it's just a flashlight, and it's reasonable to expect that it turns on.Other than the failure, I greatly preferred this to a mini-Maglite.  Because I liked the E21 so much, I bought a Fenix LD01 which has become my EDC torch -- an incredible, awesome tool.

This is an outstanding snow melter and water boiler.  It is very fast and very efficient and it is also reasonably lightweight and compact for the capacity.  The tradeoff's are it does not scale down well for solo use, it does not work well for cooking or simmering, and the pot/cookware is specific.  It may be possible but not practical to use with a regular pot.I use mine to boil water to reconstitute dehydrated food for a family of four people.  I typically only boil 1 liter of water, but the extra capacity is useful and will be used more as my children grow to eat more in a meal.  I understand the 1 liter size does not pack as well as this 1.7L.

It worked pretty good as a portable for a couple of years of regular use for airing up after offroading.  I could fill my 33" radials from 12 to 35 psi in about 18 minutes.  I would have liked a faster fill, but even the larger compressors like the 400 are only a little bit faster.  After mounting it under my hood, it overheats and barely fills the tires.  It really only worked well as a portable.This compressor fills tires up, but it takes a while.  For a really fast fill, the best option is a CO2 or nitrogen tank but they're pricey, bulky and they cost to fill up.  The next best option is to have two compressors.  Even having an air tank doesn't speed fill ups unless it's a very large tank.  Once you empty the relatively low pressure (120 psi) air tank, your compressor now has to fill the tires and the tank.  I just don't have room for a tank large enough to fill my tires.  I don't even have room for two compressors.  So I decided to be content with the 300P.Then I decided I could save some time by mounting it onboard without a tank.  I mounted it under the hood with a hose to an open port at the front grill and wired it with a fuse, relay and switch.  I would save time by not having to un-bag it, pop the hood, connect the leads, or put it all away.  Now I just need to plug the hose, hit the switch, and air up.The problem is the compressor gets preheated to about 140 F under the hood.  I have it mounted above the fender well and tire on the passenger side.  I can fill my 33's from 14 psi to 35 psi and then the compressor shuts off because it gets too hot.  If I make a mistake or want more pressure, I could be waiting a long time for it to cool off.The 400C is a little faster and might fill up my tires before it overheats, but it's also a 33% duty cycle compressor and I don't expect it to run much longer than the 300.  Viair offers the 450C, for continuous duty.  I expect it would continue to run even when it gets hot, but it's even slower than the 300 -- and since it's about three inches longer, it doesn't fit my spot.

I bought this as an art table for two kids, 6 and 7.  Because it tilts down from the center, with the legs in the lowest position, the height at a fairly steep incline is quite low -- about 20 inches from the floor to the front-bottom edge of the table surface.  I use it with their 12 inch seat-height chairs.  The stool is high and mostly useless for my purposes.The table and chair appear to be made out of rubberwood.  I would have preferred maple but rubberwood is slightly better than particleboard or MDF.The screws split the stretchers on the stool in three places.  The table went together without mishap, but one of the holes for the pencil tray appears to have bulged the desk surface.  There's a strange lump there like it may have been repaired at the factory with putty before being finished.The defects are altogether unsatisfactory, but nothing that a second order can't rectify.  The price is low and I hope the utility proves to be more than worth it.

These are fine in mud, but the soles are very hard plastic and they have no traction at all on ice or on the rocks in the river or creek bottom -- I mean they are really slick.  I had Bogs before or cheap PVC boots from the hardware store.  Either of those were far better.  While I don't mind the Wetland boots in light snow, soft dirt, and moderate mud, I primarily wear a tall boot like this to cross the river when its low or creeks, and in snow that's no more than knee-deep, which is usually what it is around the streets and sidewalks -- but these are dangerous to wear in those situations.  I can skate in them.  My dog could easily flip me on my backside.  Last season I used yak trax on them, but lost one in the winter parade.  Now I'm shopping for a better alternative.

There's been many good things written about this pen, and I found most to be true.  Ultimately I was disappointed with the Fine nib.  I found what I wanted with the 1.1mm Italic nib.  Even though changing the nib is as easy and flicking off with a fingernail and sliding another on, I could not find the nibs for sale from Amazon -- only from 3rd parties that charge a lot for shipping.  I ended up buying a Joy pen because I could get the whole pen with a usable section, feed, and cartridge as well as the nib for only a few dollars more than a nib and shipping.  I would appreciate it more if I were able to buy nibs for a reasonable price.The nibs are a bit scratchy and slow.  Maybe a gold nib would be a bit smoother.  I imagine finding a fast italic nib would be a bit tricky, but the Fine that comes with this Safari isn't much faster and doesn't look anywhere near as good.I've used the cartridge and the converter with Noodler's Black and found both to be satisfactory.The only other suggestion I have to make this pen better would be to provide a tactical barrel and cap.  The Al Star might work better than this plastic Safari, but neither is really designed with tactical needs in mind.

I bought this just for the nib.  I wish Lamy and Amazon made the nibs available for a better price, but as it was I could get the whole pen for just a little more than the nib and shipping.  Amazon was not and still is not today selling the nibs, so Prime or Super Saver shipping isn't available.Rather than changing the nib on my Safari, which I could just push off with my fingernail, I just swapped the barrel and cap.  The long barrel on the Joy is impractical, but I do prefer the smooth black section and feed to the Safari's coarse textured grey one.  I don't care for the red clip on the Joy's cap, but again, I bought it for the nib.The nib is decent, I suppose for the price.  The 1.1 italic nib gives me exactly what I was looking for whereas the fine nib on the Safari was a big disappointment.  The 1.1 nib is a bit scratchy, but it writes beautifully.  I think the tines may be a bit too tight as no light passes between them, and I can barely force a piece of fine paper between them.Together, the Joy and Safari are decent pens and they've helped me figure out what I care for in a pen without costing me a fortune.  I continue to use the Safari barrel and cap with the Joy's section, feed, and nib, along with a converter and Noodler's black ink for every day carry.  I don't think I'll ever become a collector or desire to own luxury pens.  I'll admire them, but I only want a pen for EDC that's like the one I have.  It could be better if the nibs were smoother, and the different nibs had better availability.

The front placket with buttons and holes are sewn over a non-woven backing.  It bunched up the first time I put it in the dryer and will require ironing after each wash or the placket will be scrunched up with gaps between the buttons.
I have to send this back just because it didn't come with a low profile bracket.  It probably would have worked had the seven cent bracket been included.

I read the label, and decided to try them based on the big claims.  Immediately I was overwhelmed with disappointment.  Their label claims had really raised my expectations.  I took out a BIC Cristal and compared how each writes.  I was impressed that the InkJoys actually faired well compared to "the" ball point pen.  I was hoping for so much more, but considering that the overwhelming portion of the pen population can't even function half as well as a Cristal, I decided not the throw them away.  After a while, I've come to appreciate the colors.  While they're not as versatile as the Flair, they certainly offer more than boring black and blue.  I use them for the daily math worksheets I write for my students.  They could be used to write a note, but some of the colors are a bit effeminate for a man.  I bought a Le Pen 12 color set for my niece, but wasn't able to compare them.  I hope they were a bit nicer than these Inkjoys.

I've been reading this to my boys.  I started it when we visited Canada and rode the train.  We're not finished yet, that is with the book, but honestly I'm not sure we ever will be.  It's a slow starter, difficult to understand, even a little difficult to read with fluency because the language is poor.  The story may end up being a reasonably good one after we get past the first third, but already the author's skill is quite apparently lacking.  It may very well be a bestseller in the here-today, gone-tomorrow market, but it hardly compares to great children's literature.Update:It took us a while, but we did finish it.  The story picked up a bit about half-way through, but it also continued to demand further stretches of the reader's credulity.  While I didn't find anything offensive, the story just alternated between boring and uninspiring.  It wasn't the worst thing I've read at all.  I'd liken it to a popular action movie -- shallow and unbelievable, but entertaining enough to sell widely.I'd just switched to Boundless after reading a string of Newberry honor books and the original, uncensored Hardy Boys.  I read aloud to a six and seven year old.  Compared to boundless, the Hardy boys have far more lucid action even if it does get a bit predictable after a few volumes.

This is the nicest quick connect I've bought so far.  I usually stand by the US-made, solid brass Dramm connects, but I was so pleased with Water Right's hoses that I thought I'd try this connect.  It's similar to the Dramm, but with chrome plating.  These are so much better than the anodized aluminum or partially-plastic ones that sell for a little less.

I was buying Lands' End, which is the other popular school uniform supplier, but I was totally dismayed with defects in the shirts.  The collars were the worst, but there were numerous problems.These French Toast shirts are less expensive.  In the smaller sizes they cost less every day than LE clearance items.  In the larger sizes they're about the same price as Lands' End when LE has one of their frequent 30% off sales.The French Toast shirts are made with a Cotton/Polyester blend.  The look and feel is similar to cotton, but I'm hoping for more durability.  My kids tend to outgrow their shirts before they wear them out.  But I also wear boys size 20 myself.

This is the second Mystery of History book I've taught from.  I also use the _Story_of_the_World_ series to which I can compare this.  Mystery of History includes a great deal of biblical history, and it is evident the author has tried to make it Christ-centered.  In many places it is written by the author in first-person, which is a little unorthodox for a history text book.  Nevertheless, I think the subject demands a good teacher to keep the subject lively, fun, and engaging for many students.  Story of the World, by comparison contains slightly more brief accounts of many of the same subjects, but doesn't include as much bible history (in volume I), or as much in the way of teaching aides, lesson plans, advice etc.  I still use both and will continue to do so.  I've also been using video from New Dimension Media (available on Amazon Prime Instant Video), Schlessinger Media (old VHS and some DVD from the library), and occasionally some Youtube content.  I think this has sufficed so far for my 6 and 7 year olds, but as they get older I would like to find something that takes a little more critical look at history.

This is like an electronic version of the mechanical Mickey Mouse clock I've got that must be 40 years old and functions but won't keep time reliably.  I am sure that one needs new springs. Internally, this Hito is all electronic -- a quartz movement and electronically controlled alarm, but the alarm sounds electro-mechanically, so you get the sound of the hammer striking the bells instead of some beeping sound from a vibrating diaphragm (speaker).  The style and finish are very clean.  It keeps time quite accurately.  It was just a few seconds fast over several weeks time compared to another clock I have that is corrected by an atomic clock.  It's not silent, but it is much quieter than most quartz clocks in this price range.  I can only hear it if it's within a few inches of my ear.  The noise is a ticking sound of a higher frequency than is typical of many quartz movements.  It may still be quieter than a lot of AC-powered electronic clocks that have cheap transformers.  I noticed the Hito is offered in a few different colors and designs.  I like it.  I think these would make fine gifts too.

These are very stiff and the sole does not flex.  I have worn through quite a few pairs of the original desert boots and appreciate them for what they are.  I thought I would try these with the alternative sole material.  Presumably they will last longer, although I have not found that to be a serious concern about the Desert boots.  Unfortunately, I found the soles on the Bushacre do not flex at all.  This lack of flex introduces a problem while not solving a significant one in the tradeoff.The original desert boot has a flexible upper, the suede ones are breathable, and the soles flex well, and there's not too much toe-spring, but the crepe rubber soles are somewhat heavy and the heel pad results in significant drop.  I recommend trying the Vivobarefoot Gobi II alongside the desert or bushacre boots.  For me, the difference in comfort is stark.  I thought the desert boots were comfortable, having come from highly-structured boots, but the Vivo's are even better, especially with the insole removed.  They're listed on Amazon as Vivobarefoot Men's 300041 Walking Shoe and ship with Free Returns so there's nothing to lose.

When this was released in 2004 by Rhino Handmade, it was an excellent overview of this band.However, the new 2015 "The Ides of March: Last Band Standing" 5-disc box set provides the most comprehensive release to date, including a live DVD.As of this writing, the new set is available for FAR less than even the used copies of this OOP release, to say nothing of the ridiculous prices the last few factory-sealed copies are going for here.  So, get FAR more, pay WAY less.

I'm not impressed with this unit.The marketing ka-ka above which proclaims "the bay provides excellent heat dissipation with a built-in fan and slotted aluminum enclosure" is hilariously funny in post-purchase retrospect, because the fan is a joke, and overall, there is VERY little cooling for any 3.5 HDD under load.  With both slots populated (in my PC, with my SSD primary and the lower slot for a backup HDD), the HDD not only gets unacceptably hot, but it directly transfers heat to the SSD and absolutely cooks it, too.The ejection mechanism on the upper 2.5 slot is goofy, and this is a little difficult to describe: On other backplane products I've used or evaluated (including another Startech double 2.5 unit), you must first insert the 2.5 drive into the slot, then the door must be closed to complete the insertion and marry the drive to the internal connectors.  In other words, you HAVE to use the door, you cannot complete the insertion without, because the door will try to close on your finger if you keep pushing the drive in.On this unit, however, you can slide the drive all the way in and connect it without the use of the door.  BUT, if you do that, the ejection lever doesn't engage, and the drive is now stuck in the slot.  You have to remove anything you have installed in the lower tray, slide your hand inside the unit, and pull the 2.5 drive out, which also puts unwanted force on the 2.5 connector.  Really uncool.As others have noted here, the doors and handles are very flimsy.  You have to be REALLY careful or they indeed are going to break.I bought this so I could change out a series of backup HDD's directly to the mobo and get superior transfer speeds.  However, I guess I'm going back to doing those backups over my external Startech dock at the nearly twice as slow USB3.0.  That much larger fan keeps an HDD COMPLETELY cool to the touch, even under the largest of data transfers.Also, when I compare the design and build quality of this unit against other excellent Startech products I've owned, I can't believe it came  from the same company.  Really disappointed with this.

After sitting on the fence for several months with this item in my Amazon Wishlist, an Amazon Seller called River Oak Group listed this cabinet for the lowest price I had seen, $199 shipped.  With some trepidation over the transit of a 115lb. package consisting primarily of glass from Florida to Los Angeles, I pulled the trigger.  There was also a post-sale issue which ROG responded to quickly and professionally, so kudos to them.The cabinet arrived via UPS glass-intact, which is a minor miracle, considering UPS is a BRUTAL environment for any package.  Ironically, by a label on the bottom of this unit, the U.S. distributor for this Taiwanese-built cabinet is only 40 miles away from us, but ROG is in Florida, so the cabinet went all the way from California to Florida to ROG, then all the way BACK again to us.  The "global economy", sigh.The following is our experience in unpacking and assembling this cabinet.  We offer it as some do's, definitely some don't's, and some off-the-cuff ideas for getting this thing assembled and installed in your home.First of all, you ABSOLUTELY, POSITIVELY, do not want to open this package inside your house.  There was a mountain of of styro-detritus inside this package which came flying out once it was opened.  We unpacked ours on our front porch (see photo), and had to use a Shop-Vac after we were done to get all the tiny bits and pieces of styrofoam cleaned up.  If you have animals, you definitely want to make sure none of these bits ends up where they could consume them, as the ingested styro could block their intestines and potentially harm or kill the animal.As to the design and construction of the cabinet itself, surprisingly, the exterior rigidity of the cabinet comes primarily from the glass sides and rear.  Those four black wooden struts you see in the stock photo are primarily there to hold the shelf clips, and provide only minor structural support.About those struts: There is a recessed metal insert in each end which is threaded for included allen-headed screws.  These became a major problem: As the screws were tightened, several of the inserts began to back themselves out of the strut end.  We had to carefully thread the inserts back into the strut after coating the exterior of each with Gorilla Glue to anchor them (WARNING: you DO NOT want to get any glue inside the insert itself).  Also, on two ends, the wood had not been drilled deep enough for the screw length, so we had to drill those out AFTER the insert was reinserted and the glue had dried, carefully making sure the drill bit did not ruin the inner threads of the insert.  This was NOT fun.The struts themselves want to turn off-center as the screws on both the top and bottom plate are tightened.  We had to use a paper notepad, inserted between the glass and the strut, to keep the strut in the correct orientation during this part of the assembly.Once we got past those obstacles, it was time to insert the glass.  The instructions sequence is the rear panel first, which is inserted in a groove in the base, then the installation of two plastic pieces (that run hte entire length of the glass) that have channels for both the rear glass panels and the sides.  This was pretty nerve wracking, as the glass is not only difficult to get into the groove in the plastic, it made a continual snapping noise that sounded like the glass was cracking.  Getting the plastic channel to seat on the glass edge was NOT easy.After this comes the installation of the shelf clips.  The clips themselves are made of a soft rubbery plastic material that are a molded single unit combination of a barrel and suction cup, and a 2" screw which inserts in the barrel and then is screwed into metal threaded inserts in the struts.  Caution needs to be observed when tightening each shelf clip, because the soft plastic will compress and possibly crack/break if over-tightened.  It is also not exactly easy to operate a screwdriver on each of these, as they are nearly up against the glass.  You want to put a towel in the bottom of the case while you're doing this, because if you slip and drop the screwdriver, you're going to most likely going visibly gouge/damage the finish. Again, surprisingly, the shelves themselves float independently inside the cabinet entirely on the suction cups, and provide no additional structural support to the cabinet itself.The door installation was pretty straghtforward.  Start (from unpacking) to finish (doors on and glass wiped down from installation fingerprints), it took us around 3 hours, due to all the above-described custom fixes we had to engineer.  We've given this unit a four-star rating, but if half stars were possible, we'd give it 3-1/2: It was definitely a more difficult and trying assembly than we would have liked.A final word: This unit sat in my Amazon Wishlist for several months while I monitored the price.  It ranged from low 300's to $245, then suddenly, for just a few days in July '15, ROG listed it for the $199 price.  As of this writing, ROG doesn't have any listed, and the price has risen back to $245.  So, you may want to be patient, drop this into your Wishlist and monitor it.  After everything we went thru to assemble this thing, if we had overpaid $50 -$100 for it, we'd REALLY be unhappy.  As is, we're semi-OK with the entire transaction and the finished product.

This set is being reissued in 2015, with an additional 1000 copies pressed, to mark the release of a new Millennium Volume 2 set. So, don't needlessly spend big bucks for this original release.Update: The reissue is now available on Amazon: Millennium, along with Volume Two.

This set is being reissued in 2015, with an additional 1000 copies pressed, along with the release of a new Volume 2 set.  So, don't lay out huge bucks for the original releases.Update: The reissue is now available on Amazon: Millennium, along with Volume Two.

Pleasantly surprised to get excellent soundboard quality and, as always for this period, a great performance.  I docked only one star because at 50 minutes, this wasn't obviously the entire show (it was a King Biscuit Flower Hour broadcast), and there may also have been some futzing with artifical crowd applause in between songs.  Overall, though, really enjoyed this, and would recommend it to anyone interested in the mid-70's Santana/Tom Coster lineup.

Rats laugh at these; they just trip them and then enjoy the peanut butter out of the reservoir.  I bought three from Home Depot, deployed two in the attic and one on the patio, all three failed to kill.  Completely useless.

I bought three of these at Home Depot for use in an attic and on a patio.  The rats just tripped them and then ate the peanut butter out of the reservoir.  These are a complete joke.  Don't waste your money.

This drink is manufactured with a sugar substitute, Splenda (sucralose), an artificial chemical sweetener that is a competitor to NutraSweet (aspartame).  There is plenty on the internet about the lack of testing of long-term use of this product.  The parent company advertised Splenda as "Made from sugar, so it tastes like sugar", and got sued.  Now, their slogan is  "It starts with sugar. It tastes like sugar. But it's not sugar." Before consuming this product, educate yourself on Sucralose (did you know it contains chlorine?).

This is a compilation of previously released tracks, mostly from the long-OOP album "See My Way" (which, according to Amazon, is due for re-release in early 2015). The excellent audio sounds identical to that release, although "Long Gone" sounds much better than on the original "All Said & Done" album.  This is another great little primer from Secret Records, although at less than 42 minutes, had a lot more room for more great MA tracks.  At the low price from UK-based amazon Sellers, it's definitely an enjoyable bargain, though.

The Space Oddity "rare version" discussed in another review here is most likely a demo or rehearsal take; it does not have multi-track production, and sounds like a rough mix done in single take.  Wakeman's Mellotron is certainly not present, although someone is playing an organ.  All of the other track on this disc are available on other compilations and Japan mini-sleeve editions, so you REALLY have to be a Bowie completist to buy this disc for this one track.

I'm not here to review Dylan (does anybody REALLY need to?).  The audio is fabulous, as the box supplies the '03, '05 & '09 remasters, along with 14 additional newly re-vamped titles, so from an audiophile standpoint, it's the ***t.  However, I'd still give this set a 4-3/4 star rating, the missing 1/4-star due to a couple of weird decisions regarding content and construction.When I was reviewing the tracklist for the "Side Tracks" set, something was tugging at my memory, until finally it dawned on me: On "Biograph", there were 18 unreleased tracks: 17 of them are on the ST set, which you would think would more or less obsolete Biograph in our collections.  However, the '97 remastered Biograph was processed with Sony's Super Bit Mapping, and some of the same tracks on ST don't sound quite as good.  So, don't part with your Biograph set just yet (and Dylan's per-song recollections in the Biograph booklet are pretty kewl).The other CACV1 decision that threw me for a loop was the inclusion of the original mix of Street Legal.  That mix sounded terrible on its original vinyl and CD.  However, when Sony unexpectedly popped up with a fabulous new Street Legal remix/remaster in the 2003 SACD hybrid Dylan releases, it was truly a revelation.  I was never sure what Dylan was trying to accomplish on that album, but I always liked it.  Not including that version in this set is really an injustice, because once you have compared the two, the original becomes unlistenable.The last thing: Sony has been parading out these great catalog box sets for the last few years.  The one negative constant that runs thru them all, however, are the cheap album sleeve cover replicas.  What makes this especially annoying for long time Japan mini-sleeve collectors, like myself, is that mini-sleeves are 135MM-square, where the sleeves for Sony's domestic box sets are 125MM.  The difference? A mini-sleeve CD slides easily out of it's cardboard album jacket, but getting the discs out of these smaller sleeves without getting your fingerprints on the data side is a challenge... with practice, you can do it, but it ain't easy, these smaller sleeves are just too tight around the disc.What's frustrating is: ALL of the 135MM mini-sleeve-sized print-ready artwork masters for ALL of these titles already exist at Sony Japan, because almost all of these box set titles have previously been released as mini-sleeves over the past 20 years... Why not just get that art and print properly-sized sleeves where you don't have to fight to remove a disc?  I've never understood that.  Even more maddeningly: Sony DID use 135MM sleeves in the U.S. Mono Box!All in all, these are minor nits, and this is truly an awesome set.

This CD was originally only available in the early 90's limited edition wooden box set of MMEB's Cohesion remasters.  It contains a comprehensive 1992 49-minute interview with MM that is informative and interesting for any fan.  Also, there are two music tracks, "Joybringer" and "The Runner".
