On the other hand, I might just be over-thinking this whole thing and it's simply a very well-written romance novel.3.5

Ishmael Jones is someone who lives his life on the dark side of the road. He works for the enigmatic Colonel and together they work to uncover the secrets and horrors that lurk in this dark.  Thing is, Ishmael has secrets of his own that must be kept buried which means he tries to remain unseen and unknown. But when he receives a strange invitation from the Colonel to join him and his family for Christmas at their remote mansion, he doesn't hesitate because there must be something terribly wrong for the Colonel to summon him. Despite a raging snowstorm, he rushes to the manse but when he arrives, the Colonel has disappeared.  As the storm worsens preventing anyone from leaving, it becomes clear that there is someone or something trapped here with them and it's very very hungry.The Dark Side of the Road is the latest by author Simon R Green and introduces his new character Ishmael Jones. It has been compared to Agatha Christie's very British closed room country tea cosies but with supernatural elements. This comparison is, in many ways, a fair one what with the setting in a remote country manor; a dinner party among the gentry; everyone trapped inside by a snowstorm; a rising body count; the fact that Ishmael is not a native of Britain albeit from a bit further than Belgium; and the gathering of suspects in the drawing room to unmask the evil-doer; well, and there's that subtitle, A country house murder mystery with a supernatural twist which, if you'll pardon the pun, is kind of a dead give-away.Despite the `whodunnit' quality, Dark Side is pure Simon R Green. The tale is told by Jones in a first person narrative and, because of his need for secrecy, the reader can't always be sure he's reliable.  Nor is he much of a detective, depending more on an extremely good sense of smell, strength and hearing rather than any `little grey cells'. He is, however, like all of Green's heroes, wittily sardonic, making this a whole lot of fun to read. Definitely for fans of Green's other series or urban fantasies in general.3.5

The Skull Throne is the fourth installment in The Demon Cycle series by Peter V Brett and it takes up where The Daylight War stopped with the battle between Arlen and Ahmann which ended abruptly when they threw themselves off the cliff leaving the world without a Deliverer and the Skull Throne without an occupant.  The struggle for control of the throne pits Ahmann's sons against each other. In her attempt to prevent chaos, Inevera uses the dice to convince Jayan, her first-born son to lead an invasion against Docktown, an event that will have far-reaching consequences.Meanwhile, Leesha and Rojer are in the Hollow with both of his wives. Leesha's relationship with Thamos has developed into love and she is fearful of what will happen when her baby is born and it becomes clear that it isn't Thamos'.  Rojer has problems of his own when Jasin, the man who killed his mentor and left him for dead, arrives to summon Leesha and her people to Angiers, a summons fraught with danger for everyone.Okay, I know that all of this may not sound terribly interesting but I'm trying to avoid spoilers here and it's hard to talk about this book without giving too much away. But trust me, if you've been following this series, you are really going to enjoy this installment. I even found the relationship parts interesting and I usually skip over them. My one criticism: there is very little about Arlen here and his presence is missed. Still, there is so much else going on that this was just a tiny irritation.For me, The Demon Cycle by Brett had started out brilliantly with the first book, The Warded Man but lost some of its lustre with the following two books. Don't get me wrong - I still loved the series as evidenced by the fact I continued to read it - it's just that the first book was so dang good, it eclipsed the following two books. The Skull Throne brings back a great deal of the shine - it is chock-full of twists and intrigues and I am really looking forward to the next book in the series.

When Thomas Pitt is ordered to protect Sofia Delacruz, an ex-pat returned to London from Spain to preach her own brand of religion, he is less than enthusiastic. He considers it a job for the police, not Special Branch. But her preaching has gained her as many enemies as followers and, with the political situation somewhat heated between England and Spain, it could cause an international incident should anything untoward happen to her.Thomas takes the job reluctantly but, when she and two of her followers disappear and then the two followers are found brutally murdered, he must rush against time to discover what has happened to them. Soon, he finds himself entangled in a web of plots, schemes, and lies with implications that could bring down the British economy.The Angel Court Affair is not perfect. At times it felt rushed and it was very clear who dunnit if not why they dunnit it rather quickly. However, having said that, I can also say I enjoyed this novel a lot. To be honest, I don't read Perry for her plots or, for that matter, the mystery. I read them for the characters and for the sense of passion and empathy she always imparts to them. They are flawed but in ways we can relate to. And I read her for the portrait she draws of the period about which she is writing. She understands the mores and morals of the era and she rarely deviates from them. She has a deep understanding of the people and the roles they play in society whether by choice or by situation. Most of all, I read her because her stories are always well-written and never fail to keep the reader engaged and entertained and The Angel Court Affair is no exception to this rule.

It is 1944 and two British pilots, James and Bryan, are on a reconnaissance mission over Germany when they are shot down. To escape capture they jump aboard a train that turns out to be carrying wounded SS officers. The pair take the place of two of the officers hoping for a chance to escape unnoticed later. Unfortunately, the chance doesn't come and they have to act as if they have had some sort of mental breakdown. Their act is so convincing that they are taken to The Alphabet House so named because of the Nazis' penchant for bookkeeping, giving everything including different types of psychogenic ailments like those suffered by the inhabitants of The Alphabet House an alphabetical and numerical designation.  The two continue to feign mental illness, an act that is aided by drugs, and electric shock. Soon, though, they discover that they are not the only malingerers and these others are not above murder to protect themselves from discovery.Eventually, Bryan escapes alone. The story then switches to 1972. Bryan is a successful doctor and businessman. He had spent years searching for James after the war but eventually gave up. However, when he meets a man who is from the area of The Alphabet House, he hires him to find any information he can about any survivors. With his information, Bryan is on the trail again but rather than James, he finds the other malingerers who benefitted financially from the war and are determined to stop anyone from uncovering their crimes.This is the first book I have read by author Jussi Adler-Olsen and, as it turns out, it was the first book he wrote; it is, however, the first time it's been released in North America so firsts all around. Despite its setting, The Alphabet House is not, according to Adler-Olsen, a war story. It's also not a perfect book. At times, it strains credulity almost to the breaking point and it says a great deal about the writing and the sheer adrenaline rush of the story that, despite the occasional `huh', it never interferes with the enjoyment of the book.  This is one edge-of-your-seat, nail-bitingly intense, unputdownable and a whole lot of other adjectives and adverbs that can be used to describe one hell of a psychological thriller. In other words, I liked it a lot.  This may have been my first book by Adler-Olsen but it will definitely not be my last.

Justis Fearsson is a private investigator. He is also a weremyste with some fairly formidable magical abilities. Unfortunately, these abilities come with some fairly nasty side effects like he tends to lose his mind during a full moon, a problem which led to him having to leave the police force and which will likely become permanent.When he is hired to look into the death of the daughter of a prominent politician, he begins to see similarities to an unsolved case from his time on the force, the Blind Angel murders. But the deeper he digs, it becomes apparent that the perpetrator has his own magical abilities and they put Justis' to shame. Worse, the perp always seems to be one step ahead and is willing to kill anyone who gets in his way and that includes Justis.Spell Blind by author David Coe is a pretty decent urban fantasy. It starts out a bit slow and I found the romance part somewhat distracting- I mean, will someone explain to me the whole `we just met so I think I love you' thing because it seems to be a requisite part of way too many urban fantasies - but that's just me and I tend to be a bit of a curmudgeon. Anyway, put that aside and once I got into the book, I quite enjoyed it. It has a good storyline, an interesting magic system, and Justis is a likeable character. If you're a fan of Jim Butcher or if you like Coe's other fantasy books, this one should be right up your alley.

Simlar to this author's PAINT app, this simple, yet effective graphic app delivers as outlined. It's free and fun to play with but it also provides a means to create some simple graphics I can use elsewhere... "A picture's worth a thousand words". It's installed and runs well on my Kindle Fire. Would be 5 stars if not for the ads.

Agreeing with so many other posted reviews... disappointing if not irritating. Mediocre graphics, time-wasting gameplay, ever-annoying ads ending with my removing it. Much better available, even for free.

A nice but simple little game installed and running on a Kindle Fire. This game is yet another version of the "Atari 2D game field" genre. It has some interesting variation like changing speed and time constraints but ultimately it joins the ranks of "player at the bottom... objects scroll from the top" - capture or avoid sprites. I've qualified for this kind of gameplay long ago with no desire to replay.

Installed & running on my Kindle Fire, this game has excellent graphics, good 3D dynamics and very good performance. Game play is interesting if not a little predictable, perhaps worthy of a better platform than a Kindle. That it's "free", is also a very nice feature... one that I suspect will change as play progresses. Until then... bravo.
Plays, pauses and saves frames of animated gifs. Easy, fast and stable on my Kindle Fire. No hassles, good quality and free. What's not to like?

Has a learning curve that requires some practice. Installed on a Kindle Fire. Performance is better when controls are set to LESS sensitive. Object seems to be flying an inside obstacle course... that's it. No other challenge that I can detect. That's both entertaining and short lived. I've played worse. (Not all games need be a manic kill-fest to succeed.) There is some relaxation to it.

Whatever this is supposed to be, it's a well-kept secret. Press button... roll. Press button... erect. Press button... launch. Watch trajectory rise up...  I win!  (How? Why?) Hot dang... wow!! A real blast for the brain-dead.  GAME DELE__

Installs, runs & delivers as described, this is a lot of app for a Kindle Fire. I've used it to combine audio files creating custom ring-tones and alerts. Because of Kindles limitations, I wouldn't attempt any big music files... just too slow and cumbersome to be effective on the Kindle. Other than that, it performs nicely and remains in my stable of programs.

Mixed opinion here. It delivers as it describes, but the Kindle Fire is probably not the device to be measuring angles given it doesn't have an edge the holds it up. So it works fine, but not a good marriage with the Kindle.
It runs. It works. It displays its ads. The display is small. Other than that, it's a clock.There's better to be had without the intrusion of ads or the complicated restrictions.

Installed & runs on Kindle Fire HD successfully. I say "seems excellent" only because with this kind of app, I don't really know what's happening in the background. Running 1st time found virus no other package detected. Operation is smooth, comprehensive & intuitive... and it's free. At that price & performance, what's not to like?

Installed and runs well on my Kindle Fire HD. No bugs that I can tell though I can't seem to find the hi-res fly-bys in the promo.Beyond the initial presentation of the solar system, there isn't enough substance for practical application. I suspect even the young will quickly grow bored with it.This seems typical of most UNITY apps, that is, great start followed by benign fizzle.

Installed on my Kindle Fire HD just fine. Unfortunately, it doesn't play. It would seem control is linked to device position & movement but there's no calibration and they simply don't work. There's no instruction or tutorial that might help. The action is impossible to play.Based on another DeckEleven game (a very good one), I expected better. There was 1 update. It didn't help. This app is broken... at least for the Kindle.

Started out thinking good quality on my Kindle Fire but it wasn't until I started getting junk email that wouldn't "unsubscribe" that I realized what the this app's primary purpose is. Additionally, this app tries too hard to quess  my musical tastes, guesses wrong and repeatedly displays the same limited selections. That app is gone. I wish I could say the same for the emails.

Installed on my Kindle Fire HD, it's stable, easy, delivers as promised and free. Like its "paint" counterpart, this app is one of the best. Having searched for a drawing program to quickly serve a number of purposes on the run, this app fills every need without going overboard. Controls are direct, simple and effective. The "animation" feature is interesting but without real purpose. With the possible exception of maybe some additional features like "shapes", most any other criticism would be nit-picking. Bottom line... it's a "keeper".
Installed and works on my Kindle Fire. Between the ads and menu blind allies, there's better and easier to be had for the same price.

Installs, runs & works well enough on a Kindle Fire HD. However, since the Kindle does not have GPS or magnetic sensors, automated features and set up doesn't occur. To complicate set up, manual location doesn't recognize west longitude.Overall, presentation is lacking as navigational markings and lines are not clear or obvious. There is a learning curve required as operation isn't very intuitive. Were this the only sky map available, it might be considered quite good but given the number of celestial navigation aids available, there's certainly better to be had, even for free.

With an ambiance that's left of center, this game has the look and feel of a sports arena on some alien planet. It's all too engrossing and a smoothly seductive. Love the music that helps create the mood and the physics work just fine. One thing... I can't help but feel real $$$ is going to be required in short order. The banner shows 1,998 users downloaded this app and not very many complaints. That's gotta say something.

Unfortunately the Kindle Fire HD does not have all the sensors needed to take full advantage of all the features in this app.Having said that, in the manual mode, this app provides an absolutely great interactive map of the night sky. What I found missing that would be useful with the other sky metrics, is a projection of the Celestial Equator labeled with the sidereal time & scaled for the given latitude. This would certainly help in planning a night of observation. It would also compliment the use of RA & Decl coordinates.However, with all the other features and a price that can't be beat... this is a really, really valued app - great graphics and rendering, useful and well presented data, intuitive control & stable operation... very well done !

Nice tool but the Kindle Fire HD does not have magnetic or gyroscopic sensors. Unfortunately, that renders a couple of features inoperable forcing less than a 5-star rating, not for the app as much as the Kindle. The remaining features that do work on a Kindle are quite nice.

Installed and runs well on my Kindle Fire. However, unless there's something more to this app than I'm aware, I find it quite boring, even with its "hanger" options. Clearly this app is intended for a simpler audience. Since I'm significantly older than 5, it's on its way to being uninstalled.

Given the number of people who downloaded this game, I'm presuming it's liked a lot by a lot of users. I find the game's access to my contacts data base disquieting.Why does this game need to use the people who I email or talk to? Why does it need to know a number of highly personal info tables stated in the permissions?While this "free" game may be way cool, it's not going to run on this Kindle.

Installed & runs on a Kindle Fire with no problems. Plays well. A brain teaser, challenging and fun for a while but as with most games of this genre, it becomes a matter of how fast and repetitive action occurs. The game strategy finally defeats the player by overwhelming the board with more and more targets so there's no chance of actually accomplishing or "winning", save just accumulating tokens to buy different screens. The same challenges & strategy remains. Regardless of acquired skill, defeat is inevitable. Collecting coins is the goal.

Installed & played on my Kindle Fire HD with no problems thus far. Early evaluation doesn't lend itself to comprehensive application. Regardless, the game delivers as promised. Graphics are good. Game play moves as expected but controls are a little flaky. It plays like all 1st-person shooters, perhaps better than most, same weapons array, commentary, selections, missions, etc. Yet more sanitized violence. The aerial view reduces 3D rendering so the game acts more responsive than most of this genre.I'm a little wary of the permissions. Since there's no team play, they seem a bit excessive. Bottom line... very good for being "free".

Installed & runs on my  Kindle Fire w/ no problems. Simple graphics, easy controls, straightforward objectives, it's both fun and challenging. But as with most games of this genre, after a relatively short while, it gets boring or frustrating as the player gets overwhelmed.

Wow... does what it says and does it well. One more thing... It's free.Installed on my Kindle Fire HD, I've waded through hundreds of promising apps with only few that actually deliver, don't crash, needs $$$ to continue or floods my screen with ads. This app delivers without fail. Simple, stable, dependable, easy to install, setup and use, I'm impressed but mostly just plain pleased at being able to print from my Kindle directly to my wifi printer so easily and without... "THE CLOUD", though it does offer that feature. Quite simply, I haven't seen anything this useful that's better. One question... What's the button on the document for? It doesn't seem to do anything I can see.

Nice unit for general application. No performance issues that I can tell. Used w/ T3i.  However, EXTREMELY POOR user guide, almost unintelligible for definition, grammar and sentence contruction - written by a stoned Yoda. I didn't know the head swivels or uses NiMh batteries 'till I researched on line. I can't figure out how external power is applied in the user manual which makes me wonder what else isn't being relayed. "Warnings" don't make sense. While the hardware seems quite satisfactory, instructions on how to use with available features and application fail in generating good consumer confidence.

Like all other free games using this theme, it's not really free. The game stops abruptly to require real money. So ends the "free" status. As a game, it's not bad. It belongs to the "adventure" RPG genre but much is dedicated to ads and sale tactics. It's not as bad as some others but by no means does that make it "good". Novel to start with, it grows cumbersome quickly.

Like all other free games using this theme, it's not really free. The game stops abruptly to require real money. So ends the "free" status. As a game, it's not bad. It belongs to the "adventure" RPG genre but much is dedicated to ads and sale tactics. It's not as bad as some others but by no means does that make it "good". Novel to start with, it grows cumbersome quickly.

Like all other free games using this theme, it's not really free. The game stops abruptly to require real money. So ends the "free" status. As a game, it's not bad. It belongs to the "adventure" RPG genre but much is dedicated to ads and sale tactics. It's not as bad as some others but by no means does that make it "good". Novel to start with, it grows cumbersome quickly.

Installed on a Kindle Fire, this is an aim and shoot game with some interesting twists. Even with the ability to create my own "games", I found I grew bored with it quickly. The graphics are very good. Gameplay is right on. The "gyroscopic" feature makes for an interesting variation though I'd recommend not using it in public lest they send for the men in white coats. There's little strategy (that I can see) to keep interests up. Under different circumstances, this is a carnival "shoot the target" app where occasionally the target shoots back. Perhaps I found it a little disappointing as I expected more from the developers of their other incredibly well done sims.

I have F18 CL1 as well. This version II is visually more impressive than the 1st, but at a performance price. Installed on my Kindle Fire HD, control response is sluggish. Loading a scenario or environment takes a while longer as well.  It takes some adjustment over the previous version. I suspect the much enhanced graphics is at root cause, something that's not going to improve until the Kindle's performance improves.  A big plus is in the flap control. It's been move from its original location, under the Kindle's menu tab. What was a major problem is now fixed. However, the sluggish response applies to touch recognition as well. Again, once I knew that, I adapted.Regardless, the app remains awesome and the standard by which all other flight simulations can be judged. I've search and tried numerous others and can find nothing equal let alone better. My compliments to the developers.

Installed on my Kindle Fire HD, we got off to a very bad start. After crashing and locking up my Kindle, it crashed a couple more times immediately after being installed. Normally I would have uninstalled it there and then.Once getting past this initial impression, I have found its operations and presentation very satisfactory and thorough... actually,  quite impressive. The extra features are definitely an added value.Other reviewers have pointed out that this app is a clone of some on-line mapping services and I would agree. However, the convenience of a rapid and direct interface from the Kindle without the extra steps through an inet nav tool like Silk has a definite advantage. However, with no screen capture, off-line storage and wi-fi requirement, the benefits are greatly restricted by radio connectivity.I use some other stand-alone map apps and while they have the advantage of working without the connectivity problem, this app delivers a far superior result even with its limitations. Bottom line - it's a keeper.

Installed on a Kindle Fire HD, I found the "maps" old and crude. The charts are cluttered and difficult to read looking like someone scanned in old USGS survey charts. In looking for a wildlife reservation, none was listed for an area I know is already established. Given no storage capacity and wi-fi requirements, this is not an app I can take to the field (or road). As a navigation tool, I'm less than impressed.

More arcade than sim, the app takes forever to load (set up) on my Kindle Fire. While the graphics are very nice, the object is to fly and therein lies the rub. Control is rough and sluggish. Calibration is a necessity. Flight dynamics are primitive. "Free" or not, there's better to be had at the same price. In this developer's stable of flight sims, I'd say this is the best of the lot. Regardless of its flaws, it's still fun... for a while.

A fast moving, action shoot-em-up. Simple but fun. Roll around the environment, find the enemy, shoot the enemy, roll into icons to refuel and get more ammo & repairs. Brain power not required. Good reflexes and rifle experience helpful. Lead your moving target and have fun.

Remember Atari Asteroids? Simple, but fun. Same here. Not a mega graphic 3D shooter, but an arcade action game with some strategy involved. Choose a difficulty level. I chose baby girly-boy and enjoyed myself immensely. Fun & free. But there's a reason I don't play Asteroids anymore. And neither do you. You know why. Other than that, I can't think of anything negative about this app.

It says it's a flight simulator. NOT! I don't know what it thinks it is but this app is definitely no flight simulator on a Kindle Fire. It connects me to YouTube. It display some portrait mode pattern. Why is Tetris here? The developer must have been in some altered state when seated at the keyboard. App gone. Bye.

I thought the original F18 Landing was great. F18-II knocks my socks off.  Rortos fixed the "flap control" problem that plagued the Kindle Fire menu tab in the original. The new graphics are simply awesome. I spent quite a few hours on the original app. I look forward to spending even more on this one.In the simulator mode, the flight dynamics are superb. I love the full control of sim over arcade simple. They give game play a dimension of quality. Not having ever  flown this craft for real, I imagine a certain amount of reality given my time in a real cockpit.My compliments to the developers. Great job! (And it's free!)

Like its mate simulator "Sea Plane City", both try to be flight simulators but just quite can't seem to get there. Installed on my Kindle Fire, flight dynamics are good in so much as they can be controlled - and that's 1 of the problems. Controls are a bit primitive.Graphics too are "ok" but lack the ability to display the environment in a more useful manner. As a pilot, I'd like to see more of my surroundings than the instrumentation panel. Different camera angles supply perspectives that hinder rather than help navigation. Taking off from the runway INTO buildings and down narrow avenues just doesn't reflect a real world airport.The environments are interesting enough, but there are no "objectives". Flying around is nice but a flight plan would be nicer. Bottom line... a nice toy but one that'll rapidly get boring.

Graphics are very good. Game play is a bit slow. From a shooter perspective this looks and feels more like an arcade challenge than sim. Still, for being free, this app is quite a value. I like it, however, I did think I might have been able to drive through and over more of the scenery. After all, I am driving a tank!

As a flight sim, it's not bad, not great, but not bad. The scenery is a bit primitive which tends to diminish the simulation experience a bit - more like arcade than sim but the flight dynamics are pretty true. That being said, I've enjoyed flying about but given the limits of the scenery, I can see boredom setting in soon. I will say, the different camera angles gives the game play a nice boost. Bottom line... It's a "keeper".

Working on a Kindle Fire HD, the graphics are good enough to be interesting for a while but I can see this wearing thin in a relatively short time. I suppose that's what induces the $$$ purchases. Still, for being free, not bad. Not bad at all.

Useless on a Kindle Fire HD. The "play" screen came up. No explanation of controls. 2 on-screen "paddles" display. One makes the copter rise. The other does nothing. Suddenly it locked up my Kindle Fire - twice with a graphic of a padlock on screen. Graphics are poor. There was no game play. This certainly is no sim. Given the quality of other free sims out there right now, this app is a 5-star waste of time.

Interesting 3D graphics populates the screen but I couldn't figure out if it was an animation or game. I'm REALLY tired of seeing "Insurance Flo" everywhere these days but the d**ned ads take up a significant part of the Kindle screen & there's that obnoxious smiling face in her white apron.Game controls are primitive (and half hidden behind the ads). Goals are vague. Gameplay is crude. "For kids" is a nice way of saying teens and adults shouldn't bother & I would agree. The space men are obscured behind and between the landscape. I think even "kids" would find that irritating. After initial loading, the app updated twice. If this is the "updated" version... nice try but no cigar.

This app lists/catalogues YouTube movies. It's a nice feature but...Collecting movie titles from YouTube is a mediocre exercise - titles range from old to lame to foreign to "I just don't care". YouTube is not exactly a rich & fertile resource for any real movie fan. This app collects those titles into a catalogue. Nice work but they're still YouTube movies, many of which won't play on a Kindle or are otherwise restricted.The app is good in its ability to list and sort but the titles are hardly interesting. Seaching YouTube directly provides me with more interesting results and YouTube's standard list of "also available" titles. That makes this app pretty much superfluous. YouTube is not the place to find many good and playable movies.

Yes, it's free. Image quality seems good. Operating on a Kindle Fire HD, it occasionally crashes. Movie selections are very limited. Most titles I'd browsed are pretty lame. There is no title search method so browsing lists or icons is required. Once again commercials abound. Streaming programs only... don't touch the screen during a commercial - you'll be transferred to the website with no return to the program exit point possible.Bottom line, it's a stream of commercials interrupted by your lame title of choice... It's television. Disappointing.

It installs & runs on my Kindle Fire HD, however... As described, it does LIST many movies. "Searching" invokes Google search, producing a Google list to wade through - not a true title search. What is presented by the app isn't worth the effort... not to me. Once again, here's another app rendering what can be found on YouTube without all the ads and overhead.Note to developers... Apps are supposed to make effort easier, faster & effective. This applications does none of this. It makes lists and adds unnecessary complications. It gets 2 stars 'cause it installs & runs without crashing and it doesmakelists... lots and lots of lists.

Installed well, runs on Kindle Fire HD just fine. That's the good news and the reason I give it 3 stars instead of a low 2.The bad news - Presents a fixed, limited and unsearchable list of movies, most circa 1950 and older. Few contemporary movies and those that are listed are not exactly block-busters. 1937, Laurel & Hardy, really?  "The Brain From Space"...  not your average George Lucas / Steve Spielberg spell binder.I've found more and better titles at my local library - free. Looking for a limited list of ancient B-grade productions? This is your app. Uninstalling and the search continues.

On the Kindle Fire, it's not quite a game and not quite a sim. As a game, it gets boring quickly. It requires added $$$ to open variations. Graphic quality is "medium" for the Kindle Fire HD. I expected better considering.As a simulator it has little value. Aerodynamics are strictly game quality with no option for gear, flaps, brakes, stall, etc. Go from point A to B. That's it.A nice app, but "nice" is as far as it goes. The long download presumably facilitates a large data base and graphic map. It's admirable but wasted on a too simple exercise. Too bad. It has potential but there are many better flight sims and games available for free.

Well this book is certainly a whirlwind, I don't think the main character managed to stop and have a break for even a minute. It was non-stop fast-paced action. Faster than Chance's usual pace that's for sure. She usually gives us some drawn out moments of passion or touchy feely scenes.If you have been following the life and troubles of Cassie Palmer since the beginning then you will understand the difference between the two of them when you read this book and this Cassie, as opposed to the Cassie of the first book.Chance has kicked up the erotic scenes a notch. Easing slowly towards a romantic relationship between Pritkin and Cassie. She spends a lot of time reflecting upon the why of her relationship with Mircea. Is it love, is it lust or is it just compulsion? If so, has she possibly been ignoring a real connection between her and Pritkin all this time?It seems as if Cassie spends all her time in the buff, in a towel or in general with no clothes in her general vicinity. She also seems to have an unfortunate amount of bathroom, shower and bedroom incidents. Old Cassie used to do all her stunts and crazy missions with clothes on, she also never used to spend half her time playing hole in one with her flavour of the month.It is almost as if Chance is bowing down to the pressure of appealing to a mass audience and using the quick thrills to keep them captivated, instead of sticking to her unique style of writing and creativity.In my opinion Chance is still quite underrated as an Urban Fantasy writer. She certainly deserves more recognition than she gets, especially for her Dorina Basarab series. She spins the worlds of vamps, fey, shifters and magic together like a well-constructed spider's web, and combines all of it with her feisty characters and charming wit.I received a copy of this book via NetGalley, courtesy of Penguin Berkley/Signet.

This is the second book in the Stephens and Mephisto series. The combination of police inspector and magician/actor is unusual, although to be honest I don't think Mephisto really carries his half of the detective work.Two children have gone missing and the hope to find them unharmed is dwindling fast. There seem to suspects galore and plenty of strange connections to nefarious scenarios.Annie has an obsession with the real origin of fairy-tales. The dark murderous side of old children's tales. Is that where the truth lies? Is the person who took them connected to her obsession or is the truth hidden in the world of magic and theatre.Griffiths mixes the pain of the World Wars with the close knitted community of theatre performers. Actors and magicians with their secrets, mysteries and quirks.The story is set in the 1950's, before crime scene technology was available and police had to rely on proof other than DNA. Each lead is followed no matter how bizarre or outlandish it may seem.The beginning was good, but I think Griffiths could have done with making the plot a little tighter towards the end. Incorporating the folk tale and darker side of fairy-tales with the dysfunctional dynamics of family and reality was very interesting.Overall a pleasant read.I received a free copy of this book via NetGalley.

Fascinating premise and perhaps not quite as unrealistic as one might think. Given the power of social media and how vulnerable and easily influenced young people are, it isn't really that far-fetched.Imagine a social media site that will fulfil any need you might have. Not your wants or your wishes, but your needs. An Ipad, a phone, a trip to Disneyland or perhaps you need a car.It all starts out with simple invitations and the fledgling members have the ability to invite a specific number of other users. (Reminds me of the way the social media platform Ello started out, and how coveted the invitations were at the beginning.)Each user has to request a need, which is then submitted only when invites have been sent out. At least that's the way it starts out. All innocence and fun until the Need site starts asking their members for more than just extra members.Things quickly become insidious and dangerous. Teenagers are manipulated into doing seemingly innocent deeds, all of which are connected in some way.In the midst of all this is Kaylee, a young girl living with the an enormous burden on her shoulders. She has been looking for a solution to her problems and has lied, stolen and deceived to do it. Her mother no longer trusts her and everyone else thinks she is desperate and crazy.Charbonneau has a fresh voice with innovative ideas. I think she let the story run away with her a little towards the end, because it wasn't as tight as in the beginning, but other than that it was an interesting idea and read.I received a copy of thisbook via NetGalley.

1:41 Mins To show you how much room you have in this bag I have used a thinner yoga mat and then a thicker yoga mat.The bag has an adjustable shoulder strap , so you can carry it or store your yoga mat in it. It has an outside pocket with a zipper. large enough for a wallet, phone or keys.I have quite a few yoga bags, they aren't really that well known or used that often here in the UK yet. Now I can't imagine not having one. It is an excellent way of keeping the mat stored and clean. It also means I don't have to take an extra bag for a towel ect. I like the basic colours of the YogaAddict bags, because they can be used for other activities, for instance for camping mats and sleeping bags. My older children have been using them for overnight stays, camping at festivals and carrying sleeping mats.It is made of a durable, washable material. It is quite thick, so no flimsy material. Reminds me of rucksack material.As always the product is great quality.Included in the bag are the details for the Yoga-addict website to access the VIP membership.*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

2:59 Mins I know a lot of people mistakenly think the infuser is supposed to make your drink taste like a fruit juice. It just makes gives your water a slighty fruity taste. If you make it and let it stand in the fridge for an hour or so you will be able to taste it. It is refreshing and it has the added benefit of not having any artificial fruit flavours and sweeteners in it. my personal favourite are the lime and lemon based infusers. In the video I am trying out a strawberry and lime combo, which is my daughter's favourite water-based drink.Will there be condensation if you cool the bottle to the point of ice cold. Yes. I think the no-sweat bag is supposed to be used to ensure the condensation is on the inside of the the bag and not on your hands, as opposed to people thinking there will be no condensation at all.It is fairly straightforward to use the bottle. Unscrew the top and lift out the infuser, which has a separate lid. Fill the infuser with fruit. Add water to the bottle before inserting the fruit infuser again, then screw the lid back on.Pros- holds a lot of water- the no-sweat bag will keep it cooler for a longer period of time- rubber grip on side makes it easy to hold- the infuser is easy to insert and take outCons-You have to fill the water to the highest level to get complete benefit from the infuser- have to fill with water before inserting the fruit infuser- The no sweat bag is a tight fit, sometimes a struggle to get it on- it is a bulky bottle, perhaps less suitable for a gym environmentThe bottle is well made and easy to use.*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

4:17 Mins The most important thing you need to know is that fits Ipad 2/3/4. I have an Ipad Air 2 and an Ipad mini 2, it doesn't fit either of those. I have used the Ipad mini to demonstrate how to use it.Insert size 7in x 9.5in or 24cm x 18cm.I have had Cooper Cases before and their cases made for children (and the elderly) or the more accident prone amongst us are very good.The case is made of a sturdy bendy plastic. Looks foamy but isn't. It has a handy grip on the top to carry it around, a bit like a small bag or ghetto blaster. Cooper have made these in bright vibrant colours to make sure you always know where it is and the kids enjoy the fun vibrant element of it. Also easy to identify if you have multiple devices around the house.To connect via bluetooth you have to turn the bluetooth on on your device and switch the case from on. Make sure the TF/FM button on the case is on the bluetooth TF setting. It will show on your device as a Headset or 808. Connect and start listening via the speakers incorporated in the case. I find as I am getting older that either people on TV are mumbling more or I need to turn up my device, so I often use headphones or connect an external speaker. This is why this case is also an alternative for the elderly and not just for children who want to listen to Frozen at full volume.The back of the case also has a slot for a TF or microSD card and input for the charging cable. Just above those buttons are pause/play and volume buttons.When you insert your tablet in the case you have the perfect display and stand for your tablet. It stands secure on a 8.5cm wide base, so no danger of it just toppling over and even if it does the rim around the tablet is raised slightly to keep it from smashing straight onto the front of the tablet.It's interesting to note that although the colour is quite bright it is barely noticeable and certainly doesn't distract from the image on screen, when a tablet is put inside it. It is easy to carry and use, and suitable for both young and old.*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

1:47 Mins It is better suited for the shredding of leafy herbs, as opposed to fine grinding a herb, so it is more of a shredder than a grinder.The top opens to reveal a both halves of the grinder, the middle gives access to the sieve and the bottom half of the grinder and the bottom opens up to the sieve and the result of the grinding. The bottom compartment also has a very small plastic scraping tool/spatula to clean the sieve and the bottom half of the grinder. I already managed to misplace it before my review, because it is quite small.It is well-designed, unobtrusive and can be put or stored anywhere. The design also makes it an item you can pop in your glove compartment or bag, although I am pretty sure only the grinders of certain 'herbs' would need to do that. It is a little on the heavy side, a bit like carrying  a small ice hockey puck around.I have to admit to not knowing this also being used for grinding weed, despite it being in the description. So when my 22 year old walked in and asked why I had one, I was sort of 'What on earth are you talking about? How do you know that is what it is?' Well, now I know, and I also know that my kid knows for some inexplicable reason.I would like to see the company design a grinder for larger items, such as coffee beans or peppercorns. It is definitely something I would buy as a gift.*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

0:34 Mins I have started buying generic Lightning cables, because quite frankly it is getting quite expensive to replace faulty Apple ones with original products. If the are in use often they tend to fry at the end of the cable, which could damage your device as well.Frieq makes quality products. Their braided or clothed cables are especially sturdy, durable and they don't tangle.This particular Lightning cable is 1.2 meters in length, which makes it longer than the Apple Lightning cable. The extra length makes it easier to load your devices.It is MFI certified and it syncs without any problem with my Ipad Air, my Ipad mini and my daughter's Iphone 5. (She needs an endless supply of Lightning cables).The Frieq products always come in minimal and recyclable materials. You can also use these boxes to store your product in when the product isn't in use.*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

2:23 Mins In a day and age of reckless driving, road rage nuts and the roads that are filled with more traffic than ever before, it has almost become a necessity to have a dashcam on board when you drive anywhere.As you can see in the video, the camera records with the same standard and quality regardless of whether it is night or day.We have edited the sound out of the video, because my daughter was chatting with a friend in the car, but I can assure you that the audio picks up everything.The camera records in 3min intervals or clips, which makes it easier to find footage I suppose. You can play back any of the recorded video on the camera display.The dashcam set comes with a camera, cables, charging cable,16GB SDcard and instructions ( unfortunately the instructions could do with an update, because they don't really have all the possible functions listed. I found most of them by scrolling through the menu.) I liked the fact I didn't have to go out of my way to buy an SD cad for this and was able to use it straight away.One of the handy functions for long journeys is the lane drift warning system (LDWS). Really excellent function for when you're on the motorway. The camera also has a front collision (FCWS) warning system, which is useful when you get to close to the driver in front of you.I would have liked to have tested the G-sensor (such an unfortunate name for it), which detects a crash and stores any video recorded during such an event, but I didn't feel like jinxing my luck. It also has an SOS function, for such incidents as rowdy road ragers, you just have to press the lock button and it will record. (Always handy in emergencies). The camera also has a motion sensor, so it turns on automatically when it detects any vibration. If I take our street for instance, we have quite a lot of people who think nothing of scratching bumpers and car doors, then they just drive off.The camera has a 2.7in display and the camera itself isn't very big, so it doesn't obstruct the view when you have it stuck to the front or the back of the car. It is also really simple to transfer the footage from the camera to the computer or laptop.* I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

1:39 Mins The speaker has a clock and alarm feature.The alarm clock sound cannot be replaced by music, so if you want to be woken by the soft tones of your favourite singers you will have to buy a different device. What it does do is play the music of your choice when you connect a bluetooth device. In the video I have connected my laptop. You can then use the buttons on the speaker to skip a track, pause ect. To connect to bluetooth you switch the speaker on via the on/off button on the bottom of the speaker then press the call button on the front. A 'BT' will appear on the screen to indicate that the bluetooth is on. You also turn on the bluetooth on the second device and the speaker will come up as Lightspeaker1.I like the fact the light feature can be set from soft to hard lighting. you can do that by using the touch feature on the top of the speaker or by pressing the light button on the front of the speaker.When you are connecting you might want to make sure you don't have multiple bluetooth devices on, because the speaker sometimes has difficulty connecting if that is the case.You can also insert an SD card into the back of the speaker to listen to pre-chosen tracks.The speaker comes with a USB charging cable, which you insert into the back of the speaker.*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

Mudder really needs to invest some money in a translator for their products, because the one they have is abysmal. I couldn't make hide nor hair out of the instructions, which is quite unfortunate when the device your dealing with is supposed to make you aware of a fire.The battery is included in the device and supposed to last 10 years, so I assume that is a generous estimate.It comes with screws to hang it up on the wall, but I just popped it onto an existing nail.It is important to note where not to install the smoke alarm.On the front of the alarm is a test button, and an LED light flashes every minute or so to indicate the device is actually in working order.If the device malfunctions it is set to give off an alarm in short intervals.*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

The Ripper Gene has quite a fascinating premise, perhaps not really as far-fetched as it may seem. We live in an era of technology and amazing advancements in medicine and genetics. Now in the 21st century parents can dictate the gender of their child, filter out hereditary diseases or extra chromosomes. Designer babies in a world of commercialism.So, let's say scientists made it possible, in the near future, to not only discover whether someone has the so-called warrior gene, but also find out if they are a psychopath or sociopath. Then taking it one step further being able to discover the genetic footprint of their possible heinous crimes,  and how they will perpetrate them.The ability to recognize and perhaps even track specific individuals, who are predetermined to commit horrific crimes. Not quite a simple as that is it? First of all there is simply no way to determine whether they will actually kill or which external factors they will be influenced by. Would you want to know if you have a gene like that or whether one of your loved ones could possibly be a serial killer in the making?Even with all of the information on the Ripper Gene, Dr Lucas Madden still can't manage to keep up with a vicious serial killer. Always one step and one body ahead of the police, the murderous monster is playing cat and mouse games with Lucas.When events take a personal turn Lucas finds himself in the middle of a dangerous triangle of lies, death and false memories. He suddenly comprehends that although he thinks he is in control of the situation and his analysis of the Ripper Gene in the killer, he is actually just a pawn in a violent killing spree.The Ripper Gene is an intriguing blend of science, crime and psychological thriller. It grips you and draws you in from the first few pages. Ransom knows how to combine the science and fictional elements without losing the attention of the reader. For a debut novel it is a very strong start.I received a free copy of this book, courtesy of the publisher, for purposes of review.

2:22 Mins On the bottom there are three inputs. (Usually they are colour coded, because the ground cable is put in the middle/COM. The earth/ground  COM input is always black to distinguish it from the other two.) Left to right; Amps Max 10A/250V, COM is earth/ground negative, Voltage Max 600V. Usually you have a fourth input for mA, but they have combined it with the Voltage inut instead. (Max 200mA/250V)The big button in the middle is to select and  switch between voltage, direct current DC, alternating current AC, resistor, diode test,combined with circuit test, frequency Hz, microAmps, mA milliAmps, A Amps ( all the Amps are available in DC and Ac, if you push the Function button on the top left of the meter. The basic setting is DC if you want AC yo have to push the Function button.On the select button diode option, diode is the basic setting and  to use the circuit test and connectivity option you have to push the function button.You have an OFF position in both directions of the select button.On the outer side of the display it clearly shows which function you have chosen.As a  safety suggestion  for the digital meter it is advisable to always pick the 10A input and the Amps setting to find out the Max Amps of the device your checking. Never choose the milliAmps mA. ( Just as a hint, it will save you having to buy fuses, because if it is bigger than 200 millAmps it will blow the fuse in the meter straight away and you won't be able to measure anything at all)Buttons at the top of the Meter, function button is explained aboveHold button: If you want to remember your measurement you have to measure and then push the hold button , whilst still measuring. It will stay on the display until you press Hold again or move the select button in any direction. The Hold button works on every option.Max Button: When you are measuring , for example measuring Voltage on a car battery which is 12V and the Max is 14.5 when the is car is running, the meter will remember the highest point of measurement. You can use this on all options of  the meter.Back-light button: Which most meters do not have, so a plus. To get the back-light on you have to hold the button for a second for it to turn on and it stays on for about 10 seconds, then turns itself off automatically ( or move select button to off position)It is a full range digital multimeter. You don't need to select the minimum or maximum Voltage or whatever you want to measure, because it does it automatically. It is very easy to measure any resistor.The meter comes with two test leads. One black/negative and one red/positive.It needs a 9 Volt block battery ( Not included in the set).You can attach the test leads to the holder in the back of the meter. (Quite nifty)I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.

0:47 Mins There are no buttons you need to find in the dark. You just simply pull the top of the lantern upwards and the light turns on.It is LED, so obviously the light is quite bright. Exactly what you need when you are camping, have an emergency (car or at home) and you can also use it in your workspace area (garage, workshop).It is quite lightweight and is compact enough to just slide into a corner. You can keep it in the boot of your car (changing tires ect) or next to your bed (power outage, zombie apocalypse). Personally I think it would be a bit bright for using it as a reading lamp.The lantern has practical metal rectangle shaped handles at the side, which can be moved upwards to become carrying handles, and then moved back down when you are finished.If you are worried whether the light is still on and using batteries when the lantern has been slid down and closed, you can see in the video how the light shuts off automatically, as soon as the light is slid down to a certain point.Batteries are not included, so you will need 3 x AA batteries.My daughter is looking forward to trying this out on her next road trip aka camping trip.I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.

This is the third part in the Puffin Island trilogy. First time in Forever introduces us to Emily and Ryan, Some Kind of Wonderful is about Zach and Brittany, and Christmas Ever After features Skylar and Alec.Sarah Morgan is a literary wizard when it comes to creating romance. Reading one of her books is often like eating a deliciously frosted cupcake with sprinkles on top. She will make your heart sob, fuel your ire and then make you feel all fluffy and warm inside.An excellent choice if you are looking for a sometimes complicated, but ultimately happy read. Not everyone wants to finish a last page and feel distraught. Some readers just want a chance to relax and feel like a unicorn has marched in with a years supply of cotton candy and marshmallows.When you read a Morgan you need to make some room for the unicorn happy, the feeling that everything is right in the world at this moment in time, and the feeling of being content. You disappear inside the pages of a book, and for a few hours you are transported into another world.In Christmas Ever After the two people from the Puffin Island group, who were voted most likely to never get along with each other, end up getting to know more about each other than they ever wanted to know.Skylar and Alec come from completely different families. Skylar is used to doing whatever pleases her parents and being subjected to their disappointment when she doesn't. In the midst of a family full of status seeking power-hungry individuals, Skylar is a creative free spirit with a mind of her own. She doesn't quite fit. They see Christmas as business opportunity, as a great time to make business and social connections.Alec comes from an open fun-loving family, who embrace each person as an individual and try to support their choices in life. Christmas is a time of loving and giving to them. They are warm-hearted, funny and they clearly love Alec very much.When Skylar ends up in a spot of trouble she discovers another side to Alec, an unexpected soft and understanding side. She isn't just completely thrown by this, Skylar also finds it oddly attractive. The two of them find themselves in a strange predicament of mutual irritation and attraction. This whirlwind of emotions comes to a head on the infamous Puffin Island.If this your first Sarah Morgan then I also recommend her Snow Crystal series.I received a free copy of this book, courtesy of Mira Uk and Harlequin UK, for purposes of review.

My review is based on a testing period of over 10 weeks.I think they are more suitable for the occasional outbreak of zits, pimples or spots. They are not the suitable solution for full blown acne, which needs treatment from a dermatologist.They are simple to apply. Just wash or cleanse the area you intend to apply the patch/dot to, peel off, place over the spot and leave on overnight.The biggest plus of these dots is that the urge to scratch, pop, press and touch the spot, becomes a secondary thought.They reduce the redness and inflammation. It is not a miracle cure, the spots do not disappear, but the patches do help to reduce swelling.*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.

1:45 Mins As you can see in the video it is well made, brightly coloured and and great way of teaching your child sounds and musical notes.The xylophone has a string attached, so the child can pull the xylophone truck along behind them.The xylophone comes with two sticks ( so you can play on it obviously) and a pamphlet with songs.I think the company could improve the included music pamphlet by including English song titles and a few more more songs.A little warning in advance though, if your child likes this toy they are likely to drive you completely bananas when they bang on it all the time. Even my 10 year old decided to show me how you can play the Stars Wars and Jurassic Park theme song on the xylophone. 'Sigh.' (There was a lot of humming involved)*I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

2:18 Mins If your child tends to stick things in their mouth, ear , nose or any other handy place then please be aware that the plastic snowflake shaped puzzle pieces are small enough to fit in certain places. The age recommended is 3 plus, but I would always suggest adult supervision if you are intending to buy this for younger children.The writing on the box and on the instruction manuals is in Chinese with an English translation underneath. They are non-toxic and environmentally friendly, however I still wouldn't suggest leaving a child alone with this toy if they still like to discover their world with their by taste.The plastic pieces are about 3 cms wide.Their is a small manual with suggestions of designs and pictures, but I am sure no child will have any problem making up their own snowflake pictures and animals.It is an excellent toy to improve hand to eye coordination and fine motor skills. Children can work on their colour skills and it will certainly get their creative juices flowing.If you are a parent with smaller and older children buying this for the older child I can only repeat the above warning of bits of pretty plastic in curious hands. Please be aware of the potential danger with younger children.Aside from that the puzzle pieces come in a practical bucket (cardboard), which means you can clean them up and keep them stored, when your child has finished playing with them.*I received a free copy of this item, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.*

It is a quick read, kind of a penny novel crime with the focus on con-men and scams instead. White Collar set-up and as fast-paced as the A-Team on a role.It is a light-hearted read with two flamboyant main characters. It doesn't have a lot of substance or depth, which is fair enough if you really are just looking for flighty venture into the world of con and crime.Nick and Kate have plenty of sexual tension between them, and the majority of their dialogues are innuendo. Nick is Bomer's Neal Caffrey and Kate is DeKay's Peter Burke.Can he be trusted or not? Will Nick always choose the con instead of the straight and narrow path? Where does Kate crossing the boundaries become too much? Fox and O'Hare meander into the world of hardened criminals and ruthless scam artists. They just happen to be just as good as the real criminals are.I received a copy of this book via NetGalley.

I have allergies and I am highly sensitive to smells. Certain smells can bring on migraine attacks, especially perfume and products with a strong smell. This is why I don't allow air fresheners in any of our cars. It also means other than opening the window everyone has to put up with any odours or smells in the car.Opening the window means being subjected to pollen in certain seasons, so I look forward to trying it out in high season.The interior of the car feels fresher and the it seems to be less dusty. When you plug it into the lighter port there will be an LED light to indicate that it is on.The only real downside is that in an era of technology you will already have some kind of charger plugged into that particular port.I received a copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.

They come in a smart looking hard-case, which you can use to store the earphones when not in use.You will get between 5 and 6 hours use after a full charge. It does not keep external noise out, you will have to put the volume up if  you are in a noisy environment, but then that is the case for most earphones.They come with 3 pairs of earbuds in different sizes, an instruction manual and a USB charging cable.They fit quite securely in the ears.On the right earphone you can find the USB port, the volume button and the power button. The power button is used to connect with bluetooth and your device (phone, tablet, laptop) and also to accept phone calls.I received a copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.

This stand can be used in combination with both Apple and Android products. In the photos you can see a Samsung 4 charging. My Samsung 5 has a small cover over the USB port, so charging it didn't work in combo with this stand.It is very lightweight, easy on the eye and is designed to look like a sleek stand that showcases your devices.It is also angled in a way that you can watch your devices whilst they are charging.it is small and easy to move from room to room.I received a copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.

0:39 Mins If you want something a little different to put your phone then this might be right up your alley.It is like miniature clutch handbag in black quilted material. It has a wrist strap if you want to carry it around, but personally I like putting it in my handbag. You can also remove the wrist strap.It definitely keeps your phone protected when it is in the clutch case.I have a Samsung 5, which is quite a large phone, it fits comfortably. It is just over 5 inches in length and a little over 3 inches wide.When you open it up on the right side you have three horizontal pockets for cards and one larger vertical pocket. 1:29 Mins You can pop this beauty device into your handbag it is literally only 11cm or a little over 4 inches long and about 2cms wide. It fits easily into the palm of your hand. The gold metallic colouring gives it the appearance of a perfume bottle, so it will fit well in any handbag.Apparently the nano ionic mist improves the absorption of the water into the skin.You can barely feel the mist on your face. It is like a cool layer of wind blowing lightly upon your skin. It doesn't leave the skin moist or wet, because the skin absorbs it so quickly.The sprayer comes in a smart-looking hard-case lined with a satiny material. Included in the set is also a pipette to use when you fill the sprayer up and the USB cable to charge the device. You can keep the device, the pipette and the USB cable in the case when you aren't using it. If you decide to buy this as a gift then the recipient will love the quality of the product and the packaging.It doesn't need a lot of water and do not overfill. You can use distilled or regular water and even add a little facial toner to the water. Do not add lotion ect because the nozzle will clog.On the back of the device there are two vertical windows that show you how much water is left in the device. When you slide the window panel upwards you can fill up the water tank.To use just hold the sprayer about 30cms away from your face, slide the bottom front panel downwards and a 1 minute mist stream will begin. If the device is empty and you try to use it, the device will emit a high pitched tone to signal the need to fill it up. (Unfortunately it is so high I can't hear it)It comes with a 1 month free trial and 2 years Warranty.This is quite an innovative beauty must-have for the skin conscious.I received a copy of this product, courtesy of the company, for purposes of review.

Derek Landy is also the author of the incredibly popular Skulduggery Pleasant series. His stories, and that includes Demon Road, have a subtle layer of wit running throughout them.In this new venture Landy introduces a tough teenage girl, who is faced with a certain death sentence and changing her already sealed fate.She learns to accept her inner beauty and outer strength.Poor Amber, imagine finding out you're not only a monster, but you're also the next full course meal for your parents and their friends. Luckily for her she has someone on the inside on her side, and that person leads her to Milo.Milo is the dark horse, I hope we get to know him a lot better in a possible sequel. He starts out as the untrustworthy stranger and slowly becomes Amber's new family.Everyone seems to spend all their time trying to outsmart the boss demon, which tends to end up complicating matters. Amber seems to be particularly talented at making bad situations even worse.Will we see Glen again in the next book? There was a slight or suggestion that we might not have seen the last of him. I hope so , because he was quite funny.It is a fast paced supernatural demonic extravaganza with witty dialogues and strong memorable characters. Oh, and kudos to Landry for making a point of calling out the cat-callers of our society.I received a  free copy of this book via Netgalley.

Robotham manages to draw you in with his strangely compelling main character. As a reader you're not sure whether he is the good or the bad guy. Is he a criminal intent on revenge and profit or is he a good guy who made the wrong choices?It is a mystery to everyone one around him, what exactly has kept Audie alive and fighting for the last ten years? No matter how vicious the fights or how audacious the murder attempts, he just keeps getting back up again for another round.It doesn't become clear until well into the book why Audie escapes the day before his release and you wonder if it was so easy why didn't he do it sooner?I enjoyed the kind of abstract way Robotham went about it. The plot really does revolve around just the one person the entire time and everyone else is secondary. It is done in a way that draws you in, You need to know the why, when, who and how.The suspense is layered and spread in a way that keeps the tension the alive, well and kicking until the end.I received a free copy of this book via NetGalley.

I think I figured it out somewhere in the middle of the book. It was something that was said or perhaps just a specific gesture and I suddenly had this whole scenario in my head, but I thought it might be a little outlandish.I have to give it to Cohen, it was certainly a really interesting plot and ending.I'm not sure whether Megan's Angels is just a morbid extension of the extreme events. Is it really helping the parents or just making them tread water?Much like the family liaison officers, who are assigned to each of the families. They are like odd family member nobody wants to see. It is their job to inform the families of new developments or in this case another murder. Of course then the families have to go through the whole events over and over again, which means they can't move on.Not that you ever really move on from the death of a child, especially when it involves abduction and homicide. In this particular scenario questions of guilt are bounced around and suspicions grow where certain family members are concerned.To complicate matters Leanne has let her personal life interfere with her professional one. I found her actions quite unprofessional and hard to swallow. Not only does she ignore vital evidence she also crosses the line of ethical behaviour.Talking about unethical, Cohen really sheds a light on the behaviour of the press and media in these tragic situations. Reporters are willing to blackmail, lie, steal and betray anyone for a good story. They have no respect for the victims or those left behind.If you're looking for a crime with a bit of a twist then this certainly delivers a big one.I received a copy of this book via NetGalley.

This is a story about the clashes of culture in countries colonized by the British. Native traditions and myths mixed with the stiff upper lip attitude of the British.I wandered between feeling frustrated about Gwen's apathy, anger at her silence, and feeling sympathy for her plight. I can imagine her fictional story coming quite close to reality for many families living in the colonies.Dark secrets hidden in the folds of genealogy, secret children abandoned and forgotten or even disposed of in a more permanent manner. All because their skin isn't or wasn't the quite the right shade of colour.The timid English wife grows with the years. It might be the pain and distress or possibly the guilt she carries with her. Perhaps she toughens up, because she is sick of the lies and the games. Regardless of the why, the fact is somewhere along the line Gwen finally finds a voice.Jefferies pays tribute to the location and surroundings of her story in the form of beautiful descriptive prose, which makes up for the sometimes disjointed flow.Overall Jefferies delivers drama, sorrow, anger and guilt, all wrapped up in the marriage and romance of young woman and her husband, who brings a lifetime of baggage with him.I received a free copy of this book via NetGalley.

This is a gorgeous set. It includes Hematite Buddha Bracelet, one antique Silver-Tone Charm Thong Pendant. All the items came in little drawstring gift bags, so you can gift them or keep them safe.The Hematite bracelet has a Buddha head in silver-tone on it. You can feel the weight of the stone, but it is very comfortable. Some bracelets can catch the small hairs on your arm and wrist, but this doesn't.The Pendant necklace has a leathery strap instead of a chain. It looks and feels much more aesthetic that way.Hematite is called the Stone for the Mind or Blood Stone. It is used to ground or stabilize and for protection. It is a stone often used for anxiety.Earth Therapy is family run UK business. Their business is focused on products that promote wellness and health. They have a great range of magnetic copper therapy bracelets I also highly recommend. In fact my husband, who refuses to wear anything but his wedding ring, has actually started wearing one of their copper bracelets for his joint pains.I particularly like the buddha bracelet in this set. I cannot tell you how comfortable it is to wear and it looks fantastic.I received a free copy of this product, courtesy of Earth Therapy, for purposes of review.

The Waist Trainer Cincher in the pictures is an L-36 and the girl wearing it is a size 10.So if you are ordering smaller than L you need to take that into consideration.In the picture it is on the smallest and second smallest setting.
