About the same time I retired I discovered the In Death series by J. D. Robb (Nora Roberts). Eventually I went overboard in my enthusiasm and collected a copy of every In Death novel and novella. So I own all these weird paranormal romance novella collections with a Robb novella and some novellas by the other authors. Out of all of these collections, the novella I loved the best and remember the best is the one by Patricia Gaffney in this collection. The old man who calls the psychic hotline is adorable. His son is grumpy and protective. The woman answering the psychic hot line has her life in a mess and is lonely and kind and sweet. Her aunt is spunky. It is a funny light hearted story with a happy ending. When I get tired of Robb and decided to sell all her books to the Recycled Bookstore, I am keeping this one just for the Gaffney story.

My old kindle fire says the battery is drained but it is not. It is obviously charged but kindle does not know. I bought this hoping it would work better than the kindle settings feature and tell me what was going on with my battery. Does not do so. It also says it is drained even though it is not. Too bad my battery is pretending to be drained because this looks like a good tool for battery charge management.I guess I will have to live in ignorance of how much charge my kindle fire has left when unplugged.

Honestly, I only bought this for the beautiful cover of fern fiddleheads.I already knew the contents were going to be standard UBF fare, promoting preaching and recruiting for UBF-- not a member of UBF and do not intend to become one.

This Bible is the size of a pew Bible but thinner and nicer looking. I like it. Lighter to hold. Nice duo tone cover. I keep it by my bed to read at night. A good very basic Bible, not for skipping around, but for straight reading through for long periods. No tabs. No words of Jesus in red. No ribbon bookmark. No maps. No index. Has sewn binding. Has presentation page. Has table of contents. Has alphabetical order of books page. Has preface on history of NIV translation. Has some footnotes. Has table of weights and measures at the back. Cover brown with nice border on front cover only. Cover feels like it would be gently washable.

I was hoping for a Bible study or meditations addressed to the ordinary member of a Christian congregation. This is more of a set of prolonged pep talks for would be street preachers. Since the organization that issued this booklet is one whose members are always recruiting on campuses that makes sense for them, but not for ordinary Christians. Personally, I think the Christians sects are overabundantly supplied with preachers and would be preachers. What Christian sects need are better listeners who apply Jesus's message of love for God and especially love for others in every ordinary moment of their lives. Churches should put signs out front say "Good listeners needed!"

I have a lot of clutter in my house, paper clutter. Mail, catalogs, newspapers, magazines, greeting cards, and thousands of books. I went to kindle to reduce the number of incoming physical books; my bookshelves are full and there is no more space for more bookshelves. And I have gone to kindle magazine subscriptions. This is my most expensive subscription. It is worth it for me. And I have just found out the New Yorker posts other articles on their web site daily, things that are even more interesting than the articles in the kindle issue, that I can easily access from my kindle issue by clicking on the New Yorker dot com link inside the kindle issue without having to logon the web site. It has everything in the issue and much more! I feel like saying "duh"  for not realizing this months ago.As far as complaints about print size, no sympathy from me. My father had type 2 diabetic retinopathy. Yet he managed to read fine print until he died using a high powered magnifying glass. It looks like, despite a good Hb A1c value, I too may develop retinopathy. I intend to follow my father's behavior and take it well and use a high powered magnifying glass, if it happens, for reading and other sight based hobbies. (I always thought the artist Titian's work was more interesting when his sight was failing than his younger works.) Just keep writing the magazine, not Amazon, about your gripes until the magazine responds in a positive way. Always be sure to address your questions and complaints to the right source--it works so much better.

Although I have not used these beads in my bracelet making hobby yet, I am very pleased with them. Because they have an antique patina, they are less silvery than other silver spacers beads. I was looking for some less flowery metal spacers for the less flowery and more geometric style bracelets I sometimes make.

I wish I had paid attention to the reviews. A non-political, non-religious story does not get so many negative reviews for nothing. What basically bothers me is the triumph of evil over good. There is no justice in this story.
This works fablously. I love it! No more struggling with split rings and tearing up my fingernails. This is my precious.

I liked this one very much. Bess is at an aid station near the front lines.  An orderly reports something strange to her. She notices something odd. Before she can report either to her supervisor, she falls deathly ill with the Spanish influenza. It is a long time before she gets better. It is a long time before she remembers what the orderly told and showed her and the other odd thing she had noticed. And she is stuck in Britain due to having been so ill, so it is very hard for her to investigate a terrible killer that no one suspects. With Simon's help, and her own sheer persistence, justice is found for the killer's victims. Extremely enjoyable! I wish I was as courageous as Bess.

Love this colorful case that will protect my kindle fire when I throw it in my purse from all the other grubby stuff in the purse. Wish I had bought a larger size so I could put my kindle keyboard in it too (both fire and keyboard at the same time).

I have insomnia. These gel capsules of Melatonin and L-theanine work better than Melatonin alone.Of course, there is nothing that sells over the counter that works all of the time (every night), but when you have such stubborn insomnia as I do and hate chamomile tea, you settle for something that works most of the time.

These burn pads are wonderful for small 1st degree (redness) or 2nd degree (a blister) kitchen burns. If you have any concerns about the severity of your burn or the size of your burn, you should go to urgent care instead. Do not self treat unless your burn is small and you are certain it is 1st or 2nd degree only!When you put one of these pads on your burn, you should cover with a sterile bandage of larger size taped into place. Replace when all of the fluid in the burn pad has been absorbed by skin (at least once a day). It feels like the burn is soaking in cool water and does not hurt. The burn heals up with very little scarring.They are also good for treating friction burns, such as foot blisters from poor fitting shoes. To prevent friction burns, if you insist on wearing shoes that cause them, use moleskin instead.

Love this shampoo and it is gentle enough that it does not cause me contact dermatitis rashes on face, ears, or hands.Leaves a little itty bit of highlighting color on your hair which looks nice on brown hair.Could not find this in my local store anymore so I went online to order it.

My cat chewed through the cord on my original Samsung charger set. She really dislikes cell phones.So I ordered a whole new set (this way I have an extra charger plug, one for home and one for travel).This set is the real thing, exactly what my Samsung Galaxy S4 came with originally.
Not as good as the Birzzle app for cell phones. In fact, I love the other and hate this one.

Not everyone will agree with the author of this short book but the author reviewed the tape of Zimmerman's reenactment of the shooting for the police. By comparing Zimmerman's hand gestures to what Zimmerman was saying the author posits that Zimmerman was sometimes lying, verbally, while he was unconsciously revealing the truth via hand gestures.You can make up your own mind about this author. I found his explanations interesting.

I love the zany ear pieces on this pair of reading classes.A little tight around the bridge of the nose, but my bridge is a little wider than it used to be ever since I broke my nose on my cedar chest.
light weight glasses, comfortable for larger/wider heads.

Even thought these don't say it, they are scented. I am very sensitive to perfumes and smelled it immediately. Why in the world do they companies insist on scenting EVERYTHING. I will never buy this brand again.

Purchased as part of the NOVUS 1-2-3 plastic polish kit. Number 3 is for removing scratches. Number 2 polishes out the fine scratches left by number 3. This is a spray, and has absolutely no additional effect. Does not continue the process started by number 3 and number 2 at all. You might as well stop at number 2 because this does nothing. Unless all you want to do is use it to dust with it, just skip this, it has no polishing effect.

I have been buying these for several years for shipping small items. Because I can print directly on the envelopes these save me time.However with the latest batch the seal is cheaper! The actual length of the seal area is shorter and does not stretch across the entire flap. I am not confident in this new seal and now I have to add tape to make sure it stays closed.Not Happy. I may have to look elsewhere.

This appears to be a direct knockoff of the Canon 2.0x III Extender which costs 2.5x as much. I tested this against the Kenko 2x Pro 300 teleconverter (which is one of the best) and by comparison this has better corner sharpness and much reduced chromatic aberrations. In fact it basically eliminates the CA near the edge of the frame that you get with most teleconverters.I can't say for sure that this is as good as the genuine Canon version but it is darn good. If I ever get my hands on the Canon I'll update my review but I see no reason to--this TC is that good.Just like the Canon 2.0x III Extender, this lens is only compatible with the longer Canon L lenses (135mm and up). You can't use it with the 100mm 2.8 Macro L for instance. That's because of the protruding optic that will not allow you to mount this on anything but the longer L lenses.Keep an eye on this company, they've got a number of canon compatible lighting accessories, and even a straight knockoff of the Canon 50mm F/1.8 nifty-fifty.Note: On some lower-end camera bodies this will only auto-focus with f/2.8 or better lenses but on the Canon 5D Mark III it does focus on f/4 lenses but not always reliably.

It's just OK. I heard one of his tunes on Pandora, and it was a soulful R&B number with horns. Unfortunately that tune wasn't on this release, and these are pretty much just basic blues tunes. There's nothing groundbreaking here, just good basic blues, if that's your cup of tea you might like it but I prefer more soulful adventurous music.

The technology of this device is called Cranial Electrical Stimulation, or CES and is referred to in these books: MegaBrain Power by Michael Hutchison; SuperLearning 2000 by Sheila Ostrander and Lynn Schroeder; and Hooked? NET: The new approach to drug cure by Meg Patterson.The Unit:There are two electrodes that clip to the ears and deliver an electrical impulse of multiple frequencies which are supposed to be beneficial for the brain. There are six settings for the frequency which is Pulse-Width Selectable (550uS [modes 1-3] and 220uS [modes 4-6). It can be set for continuous output (modes 1 and 4), One second on/one second off (modes 2 and 5) and 7.83 Hz Schumann (Earth Frequency) modulated (modes 3 and 6). Unfortunately the manufacturer provides no information as to the effects of each setting so the user is left on her own to experiment. Some of the supposed benefits are: Improved mood, better sleep, improved memory, creativity, learning, and intelligence. Some people supposedly report lucid dreaming and old memories resurfacing.The Experience:The device is easy enough to use and the mild electrical impulse is felt on the earlobes where the electrodes are attached. I usually turn it up to where the tingling can be felt quite a bit and then turn it down slightly. The unit can be easily slipped into a pocket so you can move about during the session. It has a timer so it goes into sleep mode after 20 minutes. Two twenty minute sessions are suggested per day over a period of 30 days. I guess it is recommended to vary the settings from time to time but again the manufacturer provides little to no guidance.The Results:The device did not seem to induce any immediate change in mood, consciousness, or awareness. Subjectively there seems to be a slight relaxation response during use but this could be the placebo effect. I used the device nightly for several weeks and the only real thing I noticed was a single resurfaced memory. No long-term benefits were apparent. Perhaps I was expecting too much from this device but I would have to say that I am disappointed that there was not a more obvious mood lifting effect. I really wanted to be excited over this technology but I'm sorry to say I really can't recommend this over simpler techniques such as yoga, qigong, meditation, or basic aerobic exercise to lift the mood. I would like to have more information about what the different modes of this device are for. Too bad, but there has really been nothing to write home about.

I've worked with and written about many many lenses including Zeiss, Canon, Tamron and Sigma, but I have to say that no lens released in recent memory excites me as much as this one. That's because I've never encountered an f/1.4 lens that begs to be shot wide open, all the time. Until now shooting at f/1.4 has always been a compromise in image quality. At this focal length the only lens that has come anywhere near to this one in edge-to-edge clarity and color rendition is the Zeiss 50mm f/2.0 Makro Planar lens, and that is a lens that costs $300 more, only goes to f/2, and doesn't have auto focus. Even the Zeiss 55mm f/1.4 Otus Distagon T* Lens, which costs about $3000 more than this lens and is out of reach of most photographers including myself, does not offer auto-focus, and in this day and age, auto-focus is nearly a must-have option in a modern high-cost lens.I have the Canon f/1.4 lens, and while that's a good lens, lighter and more compact, the image quality wide open leaves a lot to be desired. There is a spot of decent sharpness in the center, but as you move out to the outer edges of the frame, there's a lot of blurriness and the overall color rendition is kind of flat. It's a fine lens when stopped down smaller than f/2.8, but the whole reason to own a fast lens is to be able to use it wide open with confidence.This Sigma beauty finally changes all that. In my first outing I shot over 100 images at a party gathering with only incandescent available light, every one of them at f/1.4, and the shots are all gorgeous. Not only is the whole image sharp across the frame (when objects are in the plane of focus), but the out-of-focus areas are also rendered in a quite pleasing way. The colors are rich with a lot of depth, and the whole impression is one of lovely portraiture. (50mm is a good focal length for group portraiture, for head shots 135mm is best.) As good as this lens is wide open, it's even better just one stop down at f/2. But unlike every other 50mm f/1.4 SLR lens ever made, you don't HAVE to stop it down to achieve remarkable image quality.The build on this lens is remarkable. It is extremely solid while at the same time quite elegant in design. It exudes luxury.In real-world use, the auto focus is pretty responsive. In low light, I never had a problem with it hunting or failing to find focus--as long as I didn't point it at a blank wall! My copy does not back-focus or front-focus. It just works.All in all, I can't recommend this lens enough. It's a masterpiece, both technically and subjectively from viewing the images it produces. It's certainly not an all-in-one solution to all your photography needs, but for existing light situations, this is by far the best lens I have ever used.

I've shot with Nikon, Canon, Panasonic, and now Sony SLRs and Mirrorless camera.. My favorite camera is and will remain the Canon 5D Mark III. I've owned and used the famed Nikon 14-24mm f/2.8G, and a number of Canon ultra wide angle lenses. But this lens is hands down the best ultra wide angle zoom I've ever used. The clarity, color, and sharpness are beyond any offers from Nikon or Canon.I got a Sony A99 just so that I could shoot with these incredible Zeiss autofocus lenses. There are only a handful of them. The Sony/Zeiss 135mm f/1.8 Carl Zeiss Sonnar T was the first one I shot with. It's hands down the best portrait lens I've ever used.This lens doesn't go as wide as the Nikon 14-24mm f/2.8G, but it goes to 35mm on the long end. And it's more compact than that Nikon beast. For me the 25-35mm range is so much more useful than the 14-15mm I'm not getting on the wide end. This is a matter of style, taste, and choice, but for me personally, 16mm is plenty wide enough for just about any landscape shot.  I don't like the perspective distortion you get at wider angles, unless you can display the image on a large wall--then they look really cool, but the perspective distortion at normal print sizes or on the computer screen just isn't very pleasing.The corners are pretty sharp wide open and you don't get the smearing that you get with most UWA lenses. Very sharp as you get to the long end.The only shame is that this lens isn't made in Canon or Nikon mounts, or in the new Sony E-mount. The A-mount is being surpassed by the E-mount, and you have to use an expensive adapter to use this lens on an E-mount camera. I'm not sold on the E-mount system, as the native zoom lenses are mostly F4 or smaller aperture. I like having the F2.8.These are just first impressions. I'll update the review as I have more time with this gem.

Bought for use as a combination mash/lauter tun for brewing beer. It's even more insulated than the standard industrial version.The nice thing about it is you don't have to drill out or alter the hole for the spigot, so if I want I can put back the Igloo spigot and convert it back for use with cold beverages.Five gallons won't be enough if you want to brew a really big beer (over 1.060 OG) but it's large enough for me as I can just scale back the recipe to 3 or 4 gallons if I want to do that.  Who needs 5 gallons of barleywine?For reference, this will hold up to 12 lbs of grain at 1.25 qt/lb or 14 lbs at a thicker mash density of 1.1 qt/lb. Simply scale your recipe accordingly.
High quality filament, didn't experience any warping compared to the "silver" (gray) that they sell.

I was forced to replace my old Panasonic KX-P7100 because there are no Windows 7 drivers for it. Planned obsolescence. I did a ton of research before setting on this model (M401dn). The D stands for Duplexing and the N stands for Networking. There is a DW version which is for Wireless.If cost was not a factor, I would have opted for the DW (wireless) version. But there are so many deals on this model and the price difference just to get wireless was over $200. You have to ask yourself if you really need "wireless": after all, you can just as easily network this model with an Ethernet cable to your router, or you can use a USB cable and simply share the printer with the other computers over your wireless network. Either way you get the same functionality of the wireless model, the ability to print over a WiFi network; the only difference is a single cable.I was sad to give up my still functioning Panasonic but I have to admit this is a nice upgrade from that old printer. The main difference is the speed--there is zero warmup time, and the pages literally fly out of the machine. There is little to no cool-down period either, unless you print a big job, then a fan kicks in for a bit. Other than that, this printer is virtually silent.I got an amazing open box deal (may still be available from the "Other Sellers" link). This can sometimes mean signs of use and/or missing components but mine came looking like new in the HP box with a power cable, and yes, a USB printer cable. There was no setup disk but I was able to download the drivers and printer software from HP in a matter of minutes. Installation was ridiculously fast and user-friendly, they held my hand through the short process.In no time I was printing, not only from my main computer but also from the other computers on my WiFi network (after reading a short tutorial online about how to do printer sharing in Windows 7). Luckily it was NOT the hair-pulling experience I was afraid it was going to be!Another thing I like about this model is the paper handling. I print a lot of shipping labels and the 50-sheet multipurpose tray is perfect for that and way better than the old single page feed slot of my Panasonic, where I had to sit there feeding labels in one at a time. I now get things done quicker.The output--it's top notch. The font clarity is typeset quality. That is one of the main reasons I went with HP. Yes you can pick up a wireless model from Brother or Oki for around the same or lower price but the print quality may not be as superb. This is more solidly built as well, a real workhorse that should last for years.

I ordered these from two different suppliers. What you actually get may vary somewhat because of the age and condition. Even if they have not been worn before, these have been in storage and will have aged.The fit is strange because of the extra trigger finger. In normal use like shoveling snow you will want to use them as mittens and that extra trigger finger hangs off like an appendage.These issues could be expected however there is one issue that was not expected that I really don't like. That is that the suede-like yellow surface on the inside of the palm side of the mittens constantly sloughs off as lint. The reason this is a problem is that these are intended to be used with glove liners and whatever you use a glove liners will constantly be contaminated by the yellow dust that sloughs off the inside. I tried turning them inside out and vacuuming them, and using a lint roller to remove the yellow dust but it still accumulates on any gloves that I use as liners on the inside of these.So if you're planning on using them, make sure you use glove liners that you don't care about, since these military mittens have aged and dried out.

This thing clears a wide path through snows of 2-4" or less. There are several issues, however. First of all it fills up quickly and gets too heavy to push. Secondly, much of the snow just gets pushed off the sides and you still have to go back and clear it with multiple passes. If you haven't had much snow already, then you can wheel the load onto your lawn and dump it. However, if you've already had considerable snow then there is no way to wheel it over an embankment. You can sort of tip it and fling the snow using your feet but it's not ideal.This scoop fills in the gaps when there's not enough snow to bother with a snow-thrower. In light snow, several passes and you're done. It's practically useless in deep snow as there is no way to lift and throw the snow. All you can do is tip it off to the side. And you may end up getting a shovel out anyway to lift some of the snow up onto the embankment.
This set is much better than the one I got at my local science surplus store. It's all stainless and the borer sizes go much larger. Highly recommended!

Effective hand soap with no chemical ingredients and I like the grapefruit smell. I am VERY sensitive to fragrances but the odor doesn't bother me. I put it on my recurring deliveries schedule but Amazon keeps delaying it because it's not in stock. I'm out of it and may have to find another supplier.
It's thinner and more delicate than it looks in the picture. I was going to use this to ferment beer in because of the conical shape, but it's just too fragile. I sent it back.
Glad to see that Amazon has these for a good price and that they are using environmentally-friendly no frustration packaging.

These are nice thick wool mittens. The fit is a little odd, though, The cuff is tight while the hand portion is long and boxy. I was going to wear them either over some other gloves or under some military mittens. It's a little hard to do either. The hand part is too large to fit under the military mittens and the cuff is too tight to fit over my other gloves.I was able to fit them over a pair of old thinsulate gloves, but hard to get the second one on.

I had hip pain, which I had treated by my chiropractor. I also ordered these and have been taking them daily.The hip pain has not returned. This was a scary piercing pain right in the joint when I put significant weight on it. It was real pain that I was getting worried was becoming chronic. You can't get rid of that kind of paid with a placebo.At times, my chiropractor can be a real healer. In this instance his treatment really worked. In the past, however, that pain has returned after a time. This time it has not. I cannot definitely attribute that to these pills, but the fact remains that my hip pain has not returned while on them. I would recommend giving these a try.

First of all, this is NOT soap, people. I don't know why they put "Soap" in the title. What this is is a solid bar of salt, intended to be rubbed on your underarms after showering, as a deodorant. Others found it rough, I did not have that problem, however I have gotten zero, zip, nada deodorizing protection from this.Let me save you the time and money spent on this---it's just salt, and your perspiration already contains salt. This does NOTHING to control body odor in any shape or form.

These work great to monitor the temps of your fermenting vat. You can peel off the protective layer and stick them on for a permanent solution, or you can leave the protective layer on and just tape them on to using masking tape. That way you don't need one for every container. The price is right too.

I wanted to use these for a ramp that I was setting over the steps to my basement to transport a very heavy item. These were unusable as they are only for a single set ramp angle. Only OK if you have the room for a long ramp. Also they don't tell you that these are supposed to be anchored to the top, so you would end up putting holes in your bumper if used that way.
When I received these one of the colors had developed a leak and there was ink all in the plastic bag. Luckily the bag was still sealed or I would have had a horrible mess on my hands.
This is thinner than the Paula Dean one I had before. I dropped the lid and the ceramic chipped off. Cheaply made.

These gloves look good and the construction is decent, but they're not as warm as hoped. After fifteen minutes outside shoveling in ten degree temperature, my fingers and thumbs started getting quite cold. Although they are listed as "Down" gloves, the fill is actually 70% goose down and 30% waterfowl feathers.That was NOT as advertised in the description: "full of soft insulating down ...  dry 600 fill down insulation"Nowhere does it say 30% waterfowl feathers. I wouldn't care if they kept my fingers warm but certainly not below 20 degrees F.This is not the solution to cold weather shoveling I had hoped for. They are no better than the thinsulate gloves I was already using which were also not as warm as hoped. I got better protection with a pair of old gloves covered by wool mittens, but hard to get all that on and loss of dexterity.Still searching for one pair of gloves that actually keep you warm in frigid temps.

This guide purports to tell you how to brew an authentic Altbier ("Old Beer"). The vast majority of beers brewed in Germany are Lagers. Altbier is one of the few German ales that still exists, but is only brewed in a small area in and around Dusseldorf. The style is pretty rare. I don't think you can get authentic German Altbier in the United States, so you have to brew it. I am a home brewer and have brewed this beer.The book gives an interesting history of Altbier, description of the style, ingredients, equipment and methods of brewing. Altbier is an ale that is mashed using a 3 to as much as 5 step temperature mash, fermented at moderately low temperature (60-62F), and conditioned at lagering temperatures.With most homebrewing books you can skip right to the recipes. Unfortunately, the recipes here are not fully developed. Instead of complete recipes the author calls them "guidelines". They are basically just ingredients and specifications. You must refer back to the text for specifics on mash schedule, boil time, hops addition timing, fermentation procedure, and conditioning instructions, as these are not included in the recipes. The author could have made it lot easier for the reader by simply including these in each recipe as most home brewing books do.There are some inconsistencies in the book. For instance, under mashing the author states that "Total mash times for alt vary from a low of 150 to a high of 170 minutes." However, when he details the mash procedure, the mash times total no higher than 100 minutes, and the specific procedure he recommends for the home brewer is only 60 minutes total.The biggest flaw is that most of the recipes include ingredients that would NOT be included in an authentic Altbier. In an effort to make things easier for the American home brewer, the author formulated the recipes using ingredients he thought would be easily accessible, rather than purely authentic. As a result, the recipes are a re-creation or simulation of an Altbier, but are not 100% true to the style. In particular, the majority of the recipes contain American crystal malt, primarily for color. However there is NO crystal malt used in an authentic Altbier.The author revealed in an email that the color in the darker Dusseldorf Altbiers comes not from crystal but from the addition of a malt-essence coloring agent called SINAMAR, an extract made by the Weyermann Malting Company of Bamberg. It was invented in 1903. SINAMAR is made from dehusked Weyermann Carafa malt. Because the grain base of this product is dehusked, there is no bitterness associated with this liquid, just dark concentrated color.When the author wrote the manuscript for the Alt book in 1997/8, SINAMAR was not available in North America, so he never mentioned it. He fudged and resorted to crystal malt for color in the book. To avoid roasty notes, he kept the color value to no more than 60 Lovibond. The results are simulations of Altbier but if you are a purist you should know that the addition of crystal malt is inaccurate. Now, SINAMAR is available in the United States, where it is imported and distributed by Crosby & Baker. Unfortunately the book never mentions it so we have to do our own formulating. As a guideline, 4 oz. will add 16 SRM units to 5 gallons. SINAMAR is used to add color only, it does not effect flavor or add roasted notes. If you are not a stickler for authenticity, go ahead and use the crystal. I used Weyermann Caramunich and Carafa malts to darken my altbier instead of American crystal malt, because these are German products and I believe truer to style. Another alternative might be to use a tiny amount of debittered black malt for color, or just leave out the crystal altogether.The one completely authentic recipe in the book is the "Enderlein's Alt".  This is actually a clone of Schumacher Alt, still brewed in the oldest altbier brewpub in Dusseldorf (and thus probably the world). It uses only one type of grain, a two-row Pils malt kilned to a pale Munich color rating of 6.5. It uses only German Hallertau hops. Any darkness in the color comes strictly from the Malliard Reaction that occurs in the long boiling time (up to 120 minutes). The formulation was supplied by Mr. Herbert Enderlein, the brewmaster at Brauerei Ferdinand Schumacher so this is the real deal.Altbier is nearly a lost art and is mostly off the radar of today's hop-heavy craft beer seekers. Pick this book up if you want to explore some beer making history and try your hand at brewing a very traditional style with noble hops and a classic Old World taste.

This is a good brand. It is increasingly hard to find herbal teas that don't have added flavors. The addition of concentrated flavors is rampant in the food industry, to constantly overstimulate and excite our taste buds. This is totally unnecessary and is their way of getting us to just consume and consume more. Natural, fresh herbs, dried fruits and spices have their own delicate flavors to appreciate. We don't need all the added flavors.I'm really grateful that Rishi is sticking to all natural, whole ingredients. Please vote with your wallet.

It's a very good value for the money. Costs much less than anything I could find locally. You might find a higher quality stand for more, but this suits me fine. Makes a perfect stand for guitar amp or bass drum.

Just what they say they are. Five pounds is not as many as you might think. Keep that in mind if you need a lot of them. I had a specific application and it was almost enough, I could have used more. The quality is just fine, so five stars.

This baby rocks, it's more substantial than the Milwaukee brand that I bought and returned at the big box home improvement store. I haven't tested it at the full 275 lb capacity, but beware that the capacity ratings on these are probably only for the weight on the bottom plate. The other brand I returned because it broke on the vertical side when I set it down on the back side. I think it's only fair that these should be rated to hold their weight no matter which way you set it down... but I will be more careful with this one.
It's big. It's tough. And it's manly. It really hangs down to the ground. Be sure you want a really loooong apron, 'cause if you do, then this is the one for you!

This is a thorough compendium of herbal ingredients that can and have been used in place of or in addition to hops. The author is particularly prejudiced against using hops, as he explains at length, claiming that government mandating of the use of sedating hops over other more energetic bittering agents was an early "drug law". While I appreciate what he is trying to accomplish in that regard, the reality is that centuries of use have proven hops to be the best and most flavorful all-around bittering agent for beer.Another reason the author is adverse to using hops is his claim that they have estrogen-mimicking compounds that he claims may cause impotence in men. I don't believe this claim has been proven. Regardless, most commercial American beers contain very little hops, and I have seen no scientific evidence that hops are either an anaphrodisiac (dulling the sex drive) or cause impotence in men.Now on to the content of the book: A lot of ground is covered in terms of flavoring and bittering agents that can be used instead of hops. There are tons of recipes that can be used as a springboard to start your own investigation of gruit and other non-hopped ales. The recipes themselves are often VERY basic, using nothing more than brown sugar or molasses as the carbohydrate source. This will not produce a very high quality beer, however. I would recommend that you have a solid brewing foundation and a comfort level with building your own recipes before embarking on this path.Some of the background information, while interesting, is a bit sketchy. There are repeated accounts of folk tales and origin myths about where plants came from, usually involving some allegorical fairy tale from indigenous mythology, none of which held my interest for long. Don't get me wrong, I have respect for the ways and teachings of indigenous peoples, and I think it is important to preserve their cultures and traditions, but I just don't think that many brewers are going to want to wade through page after page of origin mythology to get to the simple recipes that follow. The message here is that that every single plant, seed, foodstuff, or fermentation vat ever used was "sacred" to some tribe or another. I get it, if your life depends on corn, then corn is "sacred". If you don't know about yeast, then the spontaneous fermentation process seems wondrous and "from the gods". But we understand these things now, so I could have done without all the repetitive "sacredness" of virtually every ingredient.The descriptions of the mind-altering properties of the various herbs are also quite unfocused. My main problem is that the author simply attributes nonspecific "narcotic properties" to a great number of herbs. Some of these herbs may have some mild psychoactive effects, but the author makes no effort to distinguish between them or describe what the psychoactive properties actually are. He also makes no reference to studies or even anecdotal reports of their psychoactive effects or names the active compound in most cases. How about some "trip reports"?To simply ascribe the vague term "narcotic effects" is utterly meaningless in this context. First of all, the author claims that most of these herbs are stimulating as opposed to the supposed "sedating" effects of hops. But "narcotic" means "sleep inducing" and is usually a term used to describe opiates or other addictive pain relievers. But none of these herbs resemble opiates in any way, and "stimulating" and "narcotic" are a contradiction in terms. So the reader is left with very few clues as to how these herbs actually effect the mind, if they indeed have any psychoactive properties at all. From the few accounts I have read from brewers who have made gruit and other non-hopped beers, any mind-altering effects from the herbs were either extremely subtle or unnoticeable.Then there are the many accounts of the alleged healing effects of the various herbs. These often read like a laundry list of conditions that the herbs were traditional used to treat or cure. Again, there are no references to any studies that validate any of the claims of the healing effects of these herbs on particular diseases, and some of these claims seem quite dubious. There are also no dosages given, and if you are serious about treating an ailment with herbs, this information is essential. I am in favor of using alternative medicine such as vitamins, herbs, massage therapy, acupuncture etc. in preference to or in conjunction with western medicine. But I also have a science background and there is no reason we should settle for folk tales as evidence of the efficacy of these herbs when we have modern science at our disposal to verify that they actually work.Some of the other negative reviews have focused on the inclusion of potentially poisonous herbs such as henbane and jimson weed in a couple recipes. While these plants should be treated with utmost respect, I actually appreciated the fact that he included these powerful "witches brews" in the book for completeness. Don't try these at home unless you are an experienced plant psychonaut; for me it is sufficient just to read about them.Ultimately the book was an easy and enjoyable read, although I had to skip through much of the origin myth stories. I plan on brewing my first ales flavored with yarrow, sweet gale, mugwort, heather, other herbs discussed. This will be a starting point for further investigation and for that I am grateful. I just wish that the author hadn't been so heavy-handed and had more accurately described the psychoactive properties of these herbs in any other terms besides "narcotic properties".UPDATE APRIL 2013: I brewed my first batch of Gruit, the main "sacred" brew described in this book, and the results were somewhat disappointing. The flavor leaves a lot to be desired, and now I understand why hops rose to be the primary flavoring component of beer and have held that position for the past 6-7 centuries. Gruit tastes very earthy and primaeval, it does not have the refined taste qualities of beer. Unfortunately Gruit is a bit "yucky" and isn't going to win a lot of converts. As for "stimulating" or "inebriating" properties from the herbs, don't expect anything to write home about. The main psychoactive ingredient remains the alcohol, and any specific mind-altering properties contributed by the herbs is subtle, difficult to discern and not worth putting up with the somewhat nasty flavor.Now that I have actually brewed Gruit and tasted the results, I have had to downgrade my review of this book from 3 to 2 stars. Anyone want some yarrow?

It's rated for 150 lbs but that's apparently only for the bottom platform. I moved a 150 lb piece of equipment with it just fine, until I set it down on the handle area. Then it immediately cracked in three places. If they're going to rate something it should be able to handle that weight on all sides. I tried to epoxy the cracked plastic with JB Weld but it didn't hold. I've got to say I'm really disappointed. Wasted of $25. Maybe the Home Despot will take it back. :(

There are several of these listed for sale and I took a chance on this one even though the others had more reviews. Glad I did. Best deal and it does a fantastic job of shredding cabbage for sauerkraut. Very thin slices. Just be sure to only use your hands on the outside of the wooded frame, don't get your hands anywhere near these sharp blades. Read the instructions.

This stuff contains toluene and other organic solvents that are known to be toxic when inhaled. Do not spray indoors.I sprayed two coats on some inkjet beer bottle labels. When the labels got wet, the ink still bled. So much for waterproof.

I was led to believe that these would work well as beer bottle labels because there would be no bleeding when wet. Beer bottles are subject to moisture from condensation and from ice in coolers. These labels are NOT weatherproof and the ink does bleed. If you're just looking to cover up something underneath the label then they work as advertized. Just don't go by the review that states there is no bleeding, even when there was condensation on the bottle.I still haven't found any weatherproof inkjet labels on Amazon and have had to source them from a specialty site for more money.

Elvis Presley, Michael Jackson, Prince... they all got their inspiration from the Source, Jackie Wilson. With a multi-octave operatic vocal range that he mastered with amazing command, plus one of the most emotional deliveries ever, Jackie Wilson has few peers in the pop vocal world. Unfortunately his talent was often masked with sub-par material, syrupy string arrangements and lily white vocal choruses. Even so, when he sang a song like "Danny Boy", there was never a dry eye in the house.Jackie's albums meandered from doo-wop to early R&B to jazz standards to operatic arias to funk to Northern Soul... and everything in between... including Al Jolsen! But even when he was given the most sappy pablum, Jackie always rose above the material, and that soaring Voice always rang true.Luckily on these two offerings the arrangements have a bit more grit and soul than the usual stuff that was thrown at him. Other than "Baby Workout" there are no recognizable hits here, and many of the tunes are derivative of some of his earlier hits, such as "Say You Will", which anyone will immediately recognize as a direct knock-off of "Lonely Teardrops". But there are hidden gems in this collection too, like "You Only Live Once", "Big Boss Line", "Deep Down Love", and a number of others, including one of my favorite overlooked Jackie tunes, "Take One Step (And I'll Take Two)".For years the only way to get these albums was to dig through dusty record bins or bid on eBay for old, worn, scratchy copies. Sadly, these Edsel paired CD reissues are long out of print, but at least you can still find some for sale.Tragically, while performing the song "Lonely Teardrops" in a Dick Clark oldies review show in 1976, Jackie Wilson suffered a major heart attack and fall on stage. With the saddest of irony, it was while singing the line "my heart is crying, crying", that he clutched his chest and hit his head, incurring permanent brain damage that left him in a semi-vegetative coma for eight long years, until he finally succumbed in 1984.Jackie Wilson was and always will be truly a singer's singer.

I purchased these for beer tasting glasses but they could be used as a small juice glass. They are simple, elegant, and identical. No flaws, no variation, no frills, just a perfect little glass. Love 'em.

While the product is effective, and essentially the same as the Preparation H product it is NOT "flushable". These cloth-like wipes do not disintegrate in your sewer pipes or in the municipal sewage system. After some years of use, they clogged my sewer main, causing a backup that required multiple passes of a main line snake to remove, which took many hours of labor. The wipes were entangled on the snake and had to be unwound and cut off, a tedious, disgusting job. The wipes get snagged on roots or other obstructions in the line, and remain there for years if not dealt with.Even if the wipes make it past your sewer line, municipal sewer systems are having problems with these clogging up their sewage treatment pumps. There are a number of articles about this on the web, and several municipalities have sent out "No wipes in the pipes" flyers to residents to urge them to stop flushing the products.It's interesting that the Preparation H brand is still advertised as "flushable" but for this generic Walgreens version, they quietly removed the word "flushable" from the packaging after 2010. Of course most people still assume they are flushable.Only human waste and toilet paper should go in the sewer. If you use these, you should throw them in the trash and NOT down the toilet.

My title is not hyperbole. This is optically the best SLR zoom lens ever made to date, by any manufacturer. The sharpness, resolving power, and color rendition of this lens is equal to or even BETTER than most prime lenses that fall within this focal range of 70-200mm. Not only that, but the ergonomics of this lens are par none. Having both internal focus and internal zoom means that the lens never extends, nor does the front element ever rotate. It's S-M-O-O-T-H. This lens performs especially well at the long end of 200mm, which is where you will probably end up using it most of the time if you're shooting wildlife or sports from a distance. The latest Image Stabilization is also phenomenal, giving you about 4 extra stops of hand-holding ability, with little noise. Yes all of the accolades that have been bestowed on this lens are well deserved. If you can afford it and you need f/2.8, then absolutely get it.That said, before you jump in to this beast you should seriously consider its little brother, the Canon EF 70-200mm f/4 L IS USM Lens for Canon Digital SLR Cameras.The f/4 version isn't as highly touted as this lens, but it's (nearly) every bit as good optically and way better ergonomically. The f/4 version is not only about half the weight, it's about half the size and more importantly, about half the price too. Lugging around the f/2.8 all day is a chore, and draws attention; the f/4 version is a breeze and a joy to use by comparison. In daylight and shooting at the lens' optimum f-stops between f/5.6 - f/8, you will not notice any difference in optical quality between the two lenses. At f/4 the f/4 version will exhibit more vignetting however. Apart from the one stop, that's the main difference optically.If you absolutely need f/2.8, then this is the lens to get. It's great for portraits wide open. If you're shooting in good light and want to carry the lens all day, consider the f/4 version instead. If you're shooting small subjects like flowers and especially insects, then neither of these lenses will get you close enough. Get yourself a good macro lens like either of the Canon 100mm macros, or my current favorite, the excellent Tamron AFF004C700 SP 90MM F/2.8 DI MACRO 1:1 VC Macro Lens for Canon EF Cameras.Happy shooting!

These bars have little flavor and the consistency is dry and gritty. I tried several times to enjoy these and each time the same reaction -- boring and unsatisfying. Plus these raw bars cost twice as much as other raw bars that I actually like, such as Pure Bar and Raw Revolution brands. Do you like the (awful) taste of hemp protein powder? If you do you might like these. Otherwise save your money. Good intentions, bad product.

Based on a friend raving about these on Facebook I bought the big bag at my local big box club membership store. I wasn't actually sure what to do with them so this evening I soaked some in water until they gelled up per the instructions. I then consumed them and I have to say that the taste and consistency is pretty unappealing. The best way to describe it is gritty slime that tastes like dirt.I know that a lot of people say to put them in smoothies. I've gone through periods where I make a lot of smoothies but not so often these days. And I don't bake at all. So I'm afraid that I'm going to be sitting on this bag for a long time because the yukky taste and consistency are not going to have me running back to eat these again right away. And I am very much a natural foods kind of person (vegetarian, raw foods, no refined foods) but these were just not a pleasant experience for me.I did feel a bit of an energy buzz for a little while and I'm hoping they're good for my digestion. Just not appealing, and I think that food should taste good otherwise what is the point.I guess I should know better than to take recommendations off of Facebook, no disrespect to my friends on there. :)

I purchased this based on a recommendation from another reviewer that said they taste better than the Raw Revolution Spirulina Dream bars. Since these cost nearly twice as much I was expecting something REALLY special. Well the taste is unappealing and the texture is too dense and sticks in your teeth. If you've ever tasted hemp protein powder the you know it can be pretty hard to stomach and you can really taste it the hemp. I can't find anything good to say about these. I should have known better but I wanted to give hemp powder another chance since I was a fan of hemp in my younger days. Never again. The Raw Revolution Spirulina bars are like nirvana compared to these.

I bought a big bag at (a big-box club store). I soaked some and consumed them per the instructions. The taste and consistency is not the least bit appealing.Kind of slimy and gritty at the same time and nothing at all good to be said about the flavor. Worse than bland / sort of yukky. I can't say that I have any incentive to repeat the experience based how unenjoyable it is to eat it. Good food should taste good too.

I got a sample tube of this with something else that I bought. It contains a petroleum product (petrolatum). I won't use products that contain petroleum products. I only use natural products that contain plant oils or beeswax. It also contains artificial fragrance. I cannot come near anything with added fragrance.In addition, the Environmental Working Group Skin Deep website gives this product a score of 6 out of 10 (1 being the best, 10 the worst for your health).Here are just some of the ingredients and the health concerns about them:FRAGRANCE Ecotoxicology, Allergies/immunotoxicity, Irritation (skin, eyes, or lungs), Miscellaneous, Organ system toxicity (non-reproductive)PROPYLPARABEN Developmental/reproductive toxicity, Ecotoxicology, Endocrine disruption, Allergies/immunotoxicity, Use restrictionsPETROLATUM Contamination concerns (PAHS), Organ system toxicity (non-reproductive), Use restrictionsDIAZOLIDINYL UREA Allergies/immunotoxicity, Contamination concerns (FORMALDEHYDE), Use restrictionsMETHYLPARABEN Biochemical or cellular level changes, Endocrine disruption, Allergies/immunotoxicity, Use restrictionsPOLYSORBATE-60 Contamination concerns (ETHYLENE OXIDE, 1,4-DIOXANE), Organ system toxicity (non-reproductive)TOCOPHERYL ACETATE Cancer, Ecotoxicology, Allergies/immunotoxicity, Contamination concerns (HYDROQUINONE)

Yes, this is a top-end flash, but Canon sure makes it difficult to use on all but their standard macro lens. I was coming from an Opteka RL-600 E-TTL II Macro Twin Ring Lite Flash, and the transition was frustrating. First of all, the Opteka starts out to fit any 77mm filter size and provides adapters for smaller lenses. With step-down adapters, the Opteka will fit virtually any lens. This Canon starts out at only a 58mm filter size, which means that larger lenses will be blocked by the ring, and that's a really poor design choice. This rig could double as a fill flash on many lenses, not just macro, if only the design allowed for it.Knowing that going in, I assumed that this would still fit any lens with a 58mm filter size. Not so. It only fits the original, non-L, non-IS 100mm macro lens. (In order to fit the "L" macro lens you are asked to buy a $40 adapter which is little more than a step-up ring which should only cost about $5.) I had assumed it would fit the new Tamron 90mmm Macro VC lens, because that lens has the same 58mm filter size as the original Canon 100mm macro. But no, the clamps on this ring are designed ONLY to fit the Canon. I had to buy a different $15 adapter which then allows this to fit any lens with a 58mm filter.Once I had that annoyance straightened out, it's down to the performance of the unit itself. There are two main modes, an ETTL mode which sets the brightness of the flash automatically, and a manual mode which allows you to set the brightness. The ETTL mode is easier to start with because you can adjust the flash compensation in your camera. Still, getting the right balance of flash and background light is difficult. You will need to experiment, and should be comfortable using the M (for Manual) mode on your camera.The main problem with macro flash is that the light drop-off is very dramatic and at the default settings you will get a well-lit subject with a very dark or even completely black background. This may be what you want for some photos but you will quickly tire of this look as it is not natural looking at all. This combines with the fact that the light from the flashes is too harsh and what you end up with is a very sharp but very artificial looking photograph.There are two ways to improve upon this and achieve more pleasing, natural-looking photos. The first is to use a diffuser to soften the light. I got some custom-built ones from the UK on the auction site. Secondly, you have to find a way to light your background. There are several ways to do this. You can remove one of the flashes and manually aim it at the background. This is difficult to do with only two hands. You can utilize sunlight, a slave flash or a light on a stand to light the background. You can use a slower shutter speed to capture more background light. You can turn up the ISO and turn down the flash compensation. You can also add some fill light in post. Or you can use a combination of these. There are all techniques that you will need to explore on your own to achieve the look that you're after.This is a well-built but overpriced unit that is capable of very good lighting of macro subjects, but only if you are willing to take the time to do some customization, manual exposure adjustments, and background lighting. I don't like the fact that Canon forces you to very limited choices of lenses, but now that the Opteka RL-600 is no longer available this is essentially the only twin light true flash rig available for Canon.

This is probably the most reliable full frame digital camera Nikon has produced to date. No flaky left side AF problems like the D800 and no oil/dirt on the sensor problems like the D600. It doesn't do video like either of those cameras, only has 12 megapixels, and doesn't have as much dynamic range, but apparently remains the camera of choice for many stills-only dedicated pros who don't want any issues and just want to shoot away. I have used it and found it to be a solid performer.But this camera is selling new for $700 more than the D800. That seems crazy, and I don't get it. Why in the world would anyone opt to pay that kind of money for last generation technology when the D800 and D600 are so much more advanced. Buy one used if you're stuck on the D700 or just go for the D800 or D600 and hope that the technical issues have been resolved. The D600 is probably the sweet spot. Thirty six megapixels is overkill and will choke all but the most powerful of computers when trying to process the large files. The 12mp of the D700 is already more than enough to print up to poster size prints with the same amount of discernible detail as the 36mp D800.

The photo doesn't show how much the two valves restrict the water flow. The openings are only about 1/4". I'm going from the spigot to 3/4" hose and this flow restriction totally defeats the purpose of my 3/4" contractor hose. I wish I had known before buying. Now I'll have to return at my cost or just keep it as a spare. Skip this and go for a full flow model if you care about sprinkler performance.

Appears to be a well-built hose. Is reasonably flexible and seems to resist kinking. Only time will tell whether it doesn't kink, and more importantly, if the ends hold up without any leaking. I do wish that the color was more subtle, like black or a darker green.

Albert Hoffman is of course the famous Swiss scientist who synthesized LSD in 1938 and discovered its intense psychedelic effects in 1943 after accidentally absorbing a tiny bit of the powerful substance in the lab and went on to take the famous bike ride which would go down in history as the first acid trip. Dr. Hoffman passed away at the advanced age of 102 in 2008.This "book" is subtitled "The Final Thoughts and Reflections of Albert Hoffman" but that phrase is woefully misleading. It's not even a book; it consists entirely of four short manuscripts of lectures from 1979, 1987, 1989 and 1997, plus a few pages of forward and afterward material by others -- that's it. Only about 100 pages and large type at that. This content can hardly in any way be construed as "final thoughts and reflections" on this great man's life, since this material dates from 29 to 11 years prior to his death, and there is nothing at all that is revelatory. The lectures cover 1) planning vs. chance discovery in pharmacological research, 2) how scientific insight reveals truths about nature and reality, 3) a meditation on the search for happiness, and 4) the use of psychedelics in patients transitioning to death.Unfortunately there is almost nothing here that has not already been touched upon in the highly superior LSD My Problem Child: Reflections on Sacred Drugs, Mysticism and Science which is an actual, fully developed book by Hoffman wherein he discusses at length the discovery of LSD, the consciousness-changing effect it had on the world and its aftermath, both positive and negative. I am sorely disappointed in the brevity and blatant false advertising used to capitalize on Hoffman's passing. I feel cheated and am utterly disappointed. The best thing about this "book" is the cover art. The publishers are really reaching here to dig up something worthwhile penned by Hoffman that hasn't been seen before. Were he alive today I very much doubt he would have allowed the publication of these four dated lectures under the guise of a new book with his authorship on the cover.Shameful!!

I got this unit because the diverter my rain barrel came with is cheap with a tiny hose. I choose this model because of the filter, and the larger hose. Installation was fairly easy if you're handy. I'm somewhat disappointed with the performance though,  because a high percentage of the water is lost, particularly in light rain, when you want to capture as much of the flow as possible. The problem is that the water clings to the sides of the unit and much of it ends up dribbling along the edges and right down the gutter rather than through the slots of the filter. And when it rains really hard the unit is overwhelmed and a lot of water just overflows into the gutterDuring a medium to heavy rain where there is consistent flow more is captured. I got maybe about 15 - 20 gallons during a moderate rain storm (0.3") over an afternoon/evening. But my barrel is 85 gallons and it should be filling faster. I like that you can look inside and see the action and easily clean the screen, but the capture is rather haphazard -- there is a lot of splashing around in there that misses the intended mark. I wish I could modify this so that more of the rain is contained towards the back... like a flap in the front or a small water dam to prevent leakage along the edges.  If I have any success in that area I will update my review.

The planter I received is different than the one in the picture and description. Sandstone color, it's 20 inches across the widest part (top) but it's 10 inches high, not 6 inches. That's a big difference -- I really wanted the 6 inch height, after all the title is "low bowl". It's 15 inches across the bottom. Also there are 3 ridges shown in the photo and the one I received has only one large ridge. The style I received is like the large picture under "Akro Mils VIB20000E35 Villa Low Bowl, Clay Color, 20-Inch". I'm not happy with the switch to the higher bowl.

I got this as an emergency pump during the recent torrential rain event that we had. I only used it once, and by the next day it was already showing areas of rust on the base, connecting rods, and inside surfaces. A submersible pump SHOULD NOT RUST. Also, apparently the Rigid warranty is not worth the paper it's printed on. I have read dozens of reviews now where the company failed to honor their warranty because the part that failed, such as the switch is not covered and is considered a ""maintenance" item that needs to be replaced every two years! These pumps are also falling apart due to the rust.A sump pump should deliver a good ten years of maintenance-free, worry-free, rust-free service. A "full warranty" should be just that, and cover every part. This is going back to the big box home improvement store I got it from.

The description states: - Passes solids to 1.38" - 2377 gallons per hour - Total head lift: 19.7 ft. - Drains to 1" of surfaceHowever I just received it and the specs on the box are different: - Passes solids to 1/2" - 2110 gallons per hour - Total head lift: 16 ft. - Drains to 2-1/2" of surfaceAlso the float switch cord is shorter than pictured.I purchased this to pump out my catch basin which accumulates a lot of solids like leaves and debris, and I wanted to pump it down as far as possible. This is a major disappointment that the specs are different than advertized. I got the pump from another tools site but they had the same wrong specs listed as Amazon.There is another one listed by C.M.T. Industrial 1/2 Hp Dirty Water Submersible Pump with Float Switch with a max particle size of  1-3/16" that I could have purchased and saved money on, but I bought this one based on the better specs which turned out to be false.I will probably keep it instead of the hassle of returning and buying the other one at this point but I wish I had known beforehand, I would have just purchased the C.M.T. Industrial pump in the first place. Grrr.

You often see many allegations made about this or that lens being the "sharpest lens made", but this is the one lens that actually lives up to that claim. Certainly at f/2 it exceeds the resolution of the Canon 135mm f/2 and matches or exceeds that of the $6,000 Canon 200mm f/2 IS. It has a solid precision not found in any other consumer or professional grade lens, and like most of the other Zeiss ZE lenses, it's in a class by itself. The Mercedes-Benz of lenses.You can use this lens without hesitation wide open at f/2 and get images with excellent clarity in the center and very good into the far corners. There is quite a bit of light fall-off at that aperture though, but it's about the same as most 100mm lenses at f/2.8 and when you stop this one down to f/2.8 the vignetting is mostly gone, and completely gone at f/4. Understanding the limitations of this lens, that it only delivers macro to 1:2 and is a manual focus lens, there is very little to complain about. If I want to nit-pick, there is a small amount of red fringing at the wider apertures near the corners, but I was able to completely correct this in ACR by using a "defringe purple" of 7.This lens has that icy cool, hard edged Zeiss image quality, which exudes technical perfection in contrast to the warmer tones of Canon lenses.Although all the superlatives that can be heaped on this lens apply, it will most likely not be the first choice for dedicated macro shooters. There is a large field of macro lenses to choose from at or near this 100mm focal length from Canon, Sigma, Tamron, and Tokina that deliver true 1:1 macro magnification and autofocus. You might start with the non-L version of the Canon 100/2.8 macro which is well built, reasonably priced, and shoots superb macro images. Or you might move up to the L version, the Cadillac of macro lenses, which adds image stabilization, weather sealing, and slightly better image quality; although IS is somewhat ineffective at macro magnification it is still very useful at all other distances.If the Zeiss is the Mercedes-Benz and the Canon L is the Caddy, then the new Tamron AFF004C700 SP 90MM F/2.8 DI MACRO 1:1 VC Macro Lens for Canon EF Cameras could be the Lexus. It's actually my current favorite and you can read my review of it to get an in-depth comparison of all these lenses.Back to the Zeiss: this lens is not for everyone. It's heavy, extends quite a bit when focusing close, and the lack of autofocus plus the premium price are going to scare away most lookers. You need to slow down and take more time with this lens. Only you can decide if it's worth it, but I've laid out your options.

I purchased the Nikon mount version of this lens, primarily for product photography in a tight space. It works really well for that, as it focuses seamlessly from infinity down to 1:1 macro magnification with no breaks, or gaps in the field of view, that you might get using a macro ring. And it doesn't make you switch to a special "macro mode" as some zoom "macro" lenses do. This lens simply allows you the freedom to shoot at literally any distance you want. It uses a somewhat old fashioned design where the lens gets longer as you focus, and it nearly doubles in length when focused down to 1:1 macro. This isn't necessary a problem but most newer macro lenses such as my current favorite, the Tamron AF 90mm f/2.8 Di SP AF/MF 1:1 Macro Lens for Nikon Digital SLR Cameras, offer the preferred internal focus design. It also has a funky screw-on hood which is totally old school, which is kind of why I like it! It has a focus limiter which will keep the lens between 18 inches and infinity; this is quite useful to prevent the lens from hunting in the extremely long throw between 18 inches and "macro". AF is accurate but not as fast or quiet as newer designs.This is a good focal length for product photography of medium size objects (around the classic "breadbox" size). I have a room that doubles as a product storage "warehouse" and product photography studio, and this lens allows me to photograph most products in that tight space without the frustration of running up against the minimum focus distance of standard lenses (which can be up to five feet with some zooms!).I am using this with a "full frame" sensor D600 camera so it gives a classic 70mm field of view; on a Nikon crop sensor it would deliver an equivalent focal length of 105mm, which is also very useful for products, flowers, and even portraits. And WOW, wide open this lens is amazingly sharp, from center frame all the way into the corners. It must be well corrected for a flat, zero field curvature focus because when I snapped a photo of a wall chart it remained sharp from corner to corner. There is a bit of vignetting in the corners at f/2.8, but this disappears already at f/4. Sharpness is excellent from f/2.8 to f/8 and remains very good to f/16.I'm really impressed with the optics, and the only reason I'm giving it four stars instead of five is that at 1:1 "true macro" magnification, the lens front is only three inches from the subject. This makes shooting skittish insects virtually impossible, and even for stationary objects it poses a very difficult lighting problem: at only three inches away, the lens casts a shadow on the subject unless you have diffuse lighting from several angles. A ring flash may work but you would probably have to reduce its output at such a close distance.There are much better choices for dedicated macro work. I wasn't all that impressed with the Sigma 105mm f/2.8 macro, but I really like the Sigma 150mm f/2.8 Macro OS or the aforementioned Tamron 90mm f/2.8 VC Macro. Therefore this is a somewhat limited use lens and if you already have 70mm on a fast zoom this may be redundant for you, unless you need to get up close and personal.

This product is an enzyme/bacteria mixture that works over time to "eat" and dissolve built-up sludge in your drains and even the main line. Supposedly. The important thing is you have to remember to use it regularly as maintenance. Which you probably won't do because you don't think about your drains when they're working. And once you have a fully clogged drain or backed up sewer, it's too late, you will NEED to resort to lye type drain openers.Having said that, here's my real problem with it: this product is WAY too expensive!! This is basically the same as either Enforcer EDC16 Build-up Remover Enforcer EDC16 Build-up Remover, 18 oz. or Zep Drain Care Drain Care (18 oz / 510 g).You pay 32% more per treatment for Bio-Clean (see in the comments how I arrived at this figure). Bio-Clean should be priced more competitively$40 or less. If they drop the price to a more reasonable figure, I'll up my rating.

This product is an enzyme/bacteria mixture that works over time to "eat" and dissolve built-up sludge in your drains and even the main line. The important thing is to remember to use it regularly as maintenance. Once you have a fully clogged drain or backed up sewer, it's too late.This is essentially the same as Bio-Clean but costs MUCH less! The Bio-Clean is about $50 for 2 pounds, whereas this is less than $11 for slightly over half that. So the Bio-Clean costs two and a half times as much. Just get two of these and save a lot of money.

This is a discontinued lens but can still be found new for a VERY good price, and used for even less. The reason I purchased it was because it is one of the few 70-300mm lenses that offers a close focusing distance. In macro mode it can magnify to 1:2, which is really good for any zoom lens. The image quality is decent and meets or exceeds that of the consumer-grade 70-300mm lenses from Nikon and Canon, with only better optical quality found in the Canon L version, which sells for five times the price.I purchased this (Nikon mount version) thinking I could use it for product photography in my cramped photo studio/storage room because of the short minimum focus distance. Most 70-300mm lenses have a minimum focus distance of 1.5 meters or 59 inches (about 5 feet), but this lens will focus as close as 37.4 inches in macro mode. However, and here is the caveat: the macro mode is only available in the range from 180mm to 300mm. So, you cannot do any close range work between 70mm and 179mm. As a consequence of this it is not very useful for what I intended, because product photography is normally done in the range of about 70mm to 120mm. I wasn't aware of this limitation when I bought it, and as I found out, even 37.4 inches sometimes is not close enough for my needs--so I picked up the Sigma 70mm F/2.8 EX DG Macro Lens found here: Sigma 70mm F/2.8 EX DG Macro Lens for Nikon Digital SLR CamerasWhat this lens is really good for is macro photography at a distance. At 300mm and 1:2 magnification, you get a very large working distance of over three feet. There are very few 1:2 macro lenses that give you that kind of working distance--the only other one I know about is the very similar Sigma 70-300mm f/4-5.6 DG Macro lens, which judging by review sites is not as good optically. The other thing this lens excels at is sharpness at the "short" end--amazingly, at 70mm, it is as sharp if not sharper than the Canon L, and only slightly less so through 200mm. It is at 300mm that the Canon L kicks this lens's butt.This lens has no image stabilization; the current lens that Tamron replaced it with has image stabilization, but they dropped the macro function and made no improvements to the optics, so I don't find that new lens very compelling. I would rather save up for a Canon L or a fast Nikon lens.Technical details: This lens performs extremely well at 70mm, giving excellent sharpness across the entire frame from f/5.6 to f/11 and low chromatic aberration. As expected, the image quality softens as you zoom to the telephoto end, but still yields "good" sharpness from f/8 to f/16 at 300mm. Chromatic aberration, light falloff, and pincushion distortion are also worse at the long end, but shouldn't cause too many problems and are correctable with most image editing software.In conclusion, this is an interesting lens that offers a large, lightweight walkabout telephoto range plus good macro capabilities with a very large macro working range. The real selling point is the price, which is less than half of what the new VC version without macro costs. This lens will cover wildlife from the very small insects at your feet to large animals in the distance. It's almost worth owning just to have as a backup in case you want to go somewhere where you don't want to bring your more expensive gear.

I am reviewing the Canon version of the Sigma 105mm f/2.8 Macro OS lens.There are probably more macro lenses at or near the focal length of 100mm than at any other focal length. If this were the only macro lens around 100mm, I would consider it a good lens worth having. It has pretty good image quality and a solid build. Unfortunately for Sigma, "pretty good" isn't good enough in a crowded field of ~100mm macros that include the Canon 100mm f/2.8, the Canon 100mm f/2.8L IS, the Tamron 90mm f/2.8, the Tamron 90mm f.2.8 VC, the Tokina AT-X 100mm f/2.8 PRO D Macro and the Zeiss 100mm F/2 Makro Planar ZE. I have had a chance to test and work with all of these except the Tokina.Among the lenses I've tested, the Zeiss ranks highest in terms of image quality, but is a rather specialized, expensive f/2 manual focus lens that does not have 1:1 macro capabilities, auto focus or image stabilization. That rules it out for a lot of folks. Among the autofocus 1:1 macro lenses, the Canon f/2.8L IS takes the top spot for image quality, with the new Tamron 90mm VC coming in a very close second and the non-L, non-IS Canon 100mm and non-VC Tamron 90mm not at all far behind. In fact in the real world you're not going to see much difference in IQ between any of these four lenses, they're all that good.The Sigma 105, on the other hand, while a good performer by most standards, has a hard time competing with any of the aforementioned primo lenses. It's just not as sharp and contrasty, the autofocus isn't as fast and hunts in low light, and it's too heavy. Why settle for a compromise when there are all those other great macros to choose from? Actually I really like and much prefer Sigma's 150mm macro, which is even heavier, but the image quality is superb, and that's really the main criteria I have for keeping a lens.My favorite pick among all of these: The new Tamron 90mm VC released in early 2013. It has everything I want in a macro lens: super sharp, snappy focus, light weight, reasonably compact, and has impressive, nearly silent image stabilization. I never thought I'd say this, but I now prefer the Tamron 90mm VC over the Canon 100mm L.Sorry, Sigma, you didn't make the cut this time. I've been holding off on writing this review until I sold the copy I had. It's gone and I won't be purchasing it again. Next.

These Eye-Fi cards are unbelievably handy timesavers. No more running back and forth from computer to camera, looking for a card reader, the hassle of copying files and misplacing SD cards. Once it's set up, the card acts as a Network adapter, stays in your camera and automatically downloads images as they are taken into your computer sorted by date or any criteria you wish.File copying is just one tedious step that has been eliminated from my workflow. Now, I just take photos, and whenever I want to edit them, they're right there on my computer in an easy place to find. The Eye-Fi card has made my product photography more streamlined and fun. Plus, if you ever need to use their tech support, it's easy to get a support staff person on the line and they're very friendly and helpful.I rarely get a chance to say this, but: Great company!

Flouride-free toothpaste is difficult, if not impossible to find at the standard drug stores. Walgreens and CVS have started to carry brands like Toms, but for some reason only the varieties that contain flouride and the standard mint flavor. This Tom's Fennel and Propolis is far and away superior to their mint flavor, and the only toothpaste I like. Luckily Amazon hooked me up with this on their Subscribe & Save program so now I'll never run out!

This is a decent introduction to fermentation, and covers the basics, however the recipes are too general and vague. For instance, for the recipe for Sauerrben (fermented turnips), the author states:"My fellow communards have rarely been as enthusiastic about any of my ferments as they were the night I first served sauerrben. They went on about it as if it were a rich chocolate dessert."Great, so what is the exact recipe for this particular delicacy? In step 3:"As with sauerkraut, add any other vegetables, herbs, or spices you like. Or don't, and enjoy the strong flavor of the turnips unadulterated."So, I guess we don't get the details on the specific recipe that his friends went on and on about. Is it so good that he's keeping it a secret all to himself? I guess we'll never know.Some of the other recipes are more specific, but others, like "Spontaneous Cider" are even cruder and could well lead to nasty results. I have a degree in microbiology, and while I have no objection to the use of wild organisms as a starter culture in some fermentations, I believe that if you are going to lead the novice fermenter down this path the least you should do is provide more precise instructions than this book offers.

This is it. The One. This is the magical "just right" wide angle lens that every serious 35mm landscape photographer *must* have in his or her kit. It's not so crazy wide that it reduces everything way down in the far horizon, capturing mostly massive sky and foreground, but wide enough that it surpasses the typical 24mm wide angle lens by quite a bit. But the real beauty with this lens lies in the gorgeous color rendition, edge to edge clarity, and lack of chromatic aberration or distortion.
