A little heavy and bulky, but we'll made.  The last slot is a bit of a stretch for the iPad, seems to want to skip out of the slot.  I do recommend it.

These work great if you are careful.  Have the following items ready for a solid outcome:1. Have clean hands.2. Have a clean toothpick handy to position the patch.3. Have a sharpie handy to mark the puncture area.4. Have alcohol ready to clean the area.StepsA. Identify the puncture by using air in the tube.B. Use a Sharpie to mark the puncture using a 2" diameter circle.C. Sand the area within the circle using the enclosed sand paper.D. Clean the area with alcohol.E. Inflate the tube slightly so that it is about the size it will be when it is inflated inside the tire. This minimizes the need for the patch to stretch or shrink thus increasing the odds of long-term success.F. With clean hands, remove the wax backing from the patch minimizing your contact with the sticky side (grab by the corner tip).G. Place the patch on the tip of a clean toothpick and use the toothpick to position the patch into place.H. Press the patch into place, reinstall the tube, and you should be good to go.

I wouldn't throw out your wingnuts just yet, but, there are situations where these can be quite handy.  Case in point, I had a contractor that cut into a 2" X 12" base plate to install a dryer vent.  Long after he had gone, I realized a circuit was dead.  After suspecting & finding the cause (yes, he cut the circuit in the wall), I was able to use a set of these connectors to splice the circuit within the wall.  It was a challenge performing the "surgery" within the wall with one hand (meaning cutting back the sheathing).  However, without this connector, the alternative would have been to open up the wall and use conventional wire nuts.There are other situations when installing a new switch or fixture that uses stranded wire where these connectors won't work.  It appears to be based on the thickness of the strands; thinner strands just won't push in and in those cases, the trusty ole wire nuts continue to be your best friend.Regardless, the Wago connector is a good product to add to your electrical assortment.
Does not fit athletic men well.  But good quality suit.

Excellent bulbs that provide 60w light equivalent.  A test of this bulb yields a 6.2w rating, well within the seller's 6w claim.There are sellers on eBay that are selling similar looking bulbs that have the same rating.  However, the Lightstory version has 8 filaments, the recent eBay similar bulbs have only 6 filaments.  The Lightstory bulbs measure 6.2w and cast light that to the eye appears equivalent to a 60w incandescent bulb.  While the eBay version measures about 4w (even though they claim to be 6w) and casts light that appears closer to a 40w equivalent incandescent bulb.  Except for the number of filaments, the bulb quality appears to be identical between the two.You pay a few dollars more per bulb here, but, you are also paying for the integrity of the seller not to over-state the bulb's capacity.

There are four bolts that anchor the tub to the frame.  The tub broke at the two bolts closest to the handles.  Large washers were used to resecure the tub to the frame, but, this is a temporary fix.  There are better barrows out there for less money.

Does the job but two annoyances:1. Case Missing - just a PIA to have a wad of probes/wires just sitting there.2. Poor Probe Connectivity - a simple Continuity Test using only the Probes provides a disappointing experience.  Multimeters that I've had for 30 years produce a very clear audible sound when touching the probes against one another.  Not this unit.  You have to "scrape" the probes together to get a good enough connection to hear an audible sound indicating no resistance.Otherwise, it does the job and the wrist/forearm strap can be somewhat useful.  It just is not as refined as other competitors.  Fix the two annoyances and you have a near 5 star product.

1. The unit does not go into sleep mode when the clamshell is completely closed.  Therefore, the iPad and keyboard batteries continually drain while the clamshell is in the closed state.  I suspect my unit is defective because if the clamshell is opened by about 1/4" (6mm), the iPad goes into sleep mode.2. This unit is charged using an old MINI-usb (not a far more common micro-usb) connector.3. This unit does NOT come with a power supply (only the MINI-usb cable).4. The keys have an ultra cheap feel to them.  Compared to a similar device made by DeviceWear (http://www.devicewear.com/360-rotating-keyboard-case-with-stylus-for-ipad-air-by-kingrain/) for the iPad Air, they are night and day different.5. This device will add noticeable weight to your iPad, however, it has to because the keyboard needs to be heavy enough to counter-balance the weight of the iPad itself.The seller of this unit provided a note within the package to contact them in the event of a problem.  My contact to them was ignored.  I am returning this item.

I've used many bluetooth headsets.  Although there are features about the M50 that are appealing, overall it is quirkie when paired to my Samsung Galaxy Note 3.Pros:- connects quickly- persons on the other end of the call say I sound clear- fairly comfortable once positionedCons:- sound quality (at least on my unit) is poor- sound volume is low compared to competitors- bluetooth range is very limited compared to competitors- Google Now integration when button is depressed is hit or miss and flawed- music quality is very poor- situating it on the ear takes some practice and not nearly as easy as Motorola's H730When compared to the Motorola H730, the M50 just doesn't cut it.  The two negatives re the H730 is that it uses the older BT 2.0 technology (so no music audio; not a big deal to me) and the H730 is quite fragile (don't drop it).  Otherwise, the H730 is a slam dunk winner over the M50.  If you don't mind an earmuff style headset, the Knivo BT240 is fantastic for around the house (not recommended for driving).

I thought an LED light was supposed to be cool to the touch.  Not this one, it's scorching hot.  I'm not sure how this can use only 6 watts when it generates that much heat.  With this level of heat being emitted, the longevity of the bulb comes into question and is it really saving energy?  Time will tell.

I love the unit.  Solid and lightweight.  The problem identified on new units that some have complained about is apparently associated to the O-ring within the regulator.  I suspect the reconditioned units have fixed this design.  For others having this problem, the solution is to purchase a 2-211 sized O-ring from your hardware store and replace the regulator O ring.According to someone who posted instructions for this:- remove upper plastic housing- unscrew the pressure relief valve (this will give you enough room to get a wrench around the pressure adjust unit)- unscrew the regulator adjust knob- remove the white disc with the crappy grooved O-ring- discard the grooved O-ring and replace with the 2-211 sized O-ring- reassemble and you should be back in business

It appears to hold a charge better than my now 1.5 yrs old the Samsung Note 3 OEM battery.  I would say it is as good as a new, fresh OEM battery.  Since it is LI-ON 3200mAh battery, it is what it is.  Hopefully, the next technology of batteries will provide even greater range.  For now, the Anker seems to do the job and I'm satisfied thus far.

First, Home Depot carries this exact product under a different name for slightly less money.  It is referred to as a "boiler valve" and will fit many Laundry Room washing machine water supply fixtures.  For the price, convenience, and peace of mind to easily shut off the water supply to your washing machine while not in use, this is a no-brainer.The change out is easy, but, may be time-consuming depending on the clearance you have within the Laundry Room water supply housing.  You'll need a pair of channel locks to remove the valve and either a pipe wrench or a large pair of channel locks to secure the female base pipe.  It is critical that you not allow the female end of the base pipe to twist or you may damage the pipe within the wall.  Of course, before starting anything, be sure to shut off the main water supply to the house and allow a lower faucet to drain the lines before performing the change out.  Be sure to use Teflon tape on the pipe threads to create a good seal.  It may take an hour to do the job, but, if it prevents a flood, you'll have saved countless days dealing with that. It's a good insurance policy in addition to changing your washer hoses every 5 years.If you're not sure how to perform the change out, search YouTube for a how-to video (this is a good instructional: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2grrmHVDsCA ).  This 1/4 turn valve works very nicely and is of excellent quality.

The hose ends seem well constructed with nice washers.  The stainless steel braid seems nicely finished.  My concern is with the unexposed hose hidden by the stainless sheathing.  The hose weight indicates it's not substantial.  Is it plastic or rubber?  Will it last?  Time will tell.I'm tempted to cut the hose to find out the composition and how it's fastened to the end pieces.By the way, the hose orifice appears smaller than other washer hoses I've had in the past.
A solid replacement for a 28 year old Kiddie model that was damaged by water.

Little to no mess, easy to use, and seems well made for the price.  Have used it to secure shoe soles, felt furniture foot pads, and a few other odds & ends.  Certainly much better than Pop's old red glue gun.

I have had the Hoover Linx for over a year and like it very much.  For hardwood & engineered floors as we use it on, it is very good.  I bought the Bolt for Mom.  After trying it out, it seemed clumsy and I sent it back.  Here's why:- The Bolt's steering is too radical, there's no need to flex and turn to the degree it does; it seems somewhat unstable.- About 50% of the time, the unit falls over when parked in the upright position.  It appears the locking mechanism is defective.- The attachments seem like a nice touch.  But, the pieces don't fit well together, just not refined.- The attachments have no place to be docked. Putting them on the body would add weight, but, Bissel could have provided an organizer to keep them together.- The detachable dust buster is a great idea, but, the execution is clumsy.  You are forced to yank it and push it back into place.  Seems like an unnecessary struggle that engineers could have improved.- The 18v motor in this unit takes about 4 seconds to reach its maximum RPM.  That may not seem like much, but, I found it annoying to have to wait for the motor to get up to speed.- The battery is not removable.  Not a big deal unless you store you vac in a closet.  In that case, you'll need a 120v outlet in the closet to charge it.Final thoughts:I use a 18" soft bristle push broom on the hardwood floor and use the Link to suck up the pile. That's what works best for me.  In that case, the Link is perfect.  It's fast, light, and easy to grab.  It has a removable battery that slides on the unit, unlike the Bissel which has a non-removeable battery.If Bissel can improve on the issues mentioned above, they may have a decent product.  Both the Bolt and Linx seem to have nearly the same suction power with a possible edge to the Bolt.  I was unfortunately fooled by the wonderful reviews that turned out to be done by people who received the product for free.  If I had received it for free, I would have rated it 5 Stars.Amazon's reviews have always been the most trusted in the industry.  The latest trend of allowing reviews from free product recipients diminishes Amazon's integrity and profits.  Nobody wins when products are returned unnecessarily.Mom is getting the Hoover Linx.

The product is good.  HOWEVER, the Bon taping knives come with an impossible to remove sticker on the blade.  I spent an hour trying to remove the sticker with everything imaginable, including Goo Gone.  Nothing worked.Why do companys make good products only to allow a staff slacker to make bone-headed decisions to afix such a sticker to their product?  It's like a taking a hammer to a mirror just before shipment.

Bought two cans.  Can #1 worked until 50% of the can was empty and then would no longer spray.  Can #2 worked all of less than 2 seconds of spraying before it no longer worked either.  Neither was caused by a clogged tip.

SpoofCard enables Sick-Os who want to harass others (see www.SpoofCard.com to see how it works).  Simply put, SpoofCard allows someone to 1. enter the phone # they wish to call and, 2. enter the phone # they wish to appear on a caller-ID display (this could be the # from the White House).  This is illegal in the United States.The makers of SpoofCard also sell TrapCall; allowing recipients of the prank calls to determine the origin of the caller.Analogous to breaking the very windshields they are called upon to repair.  By the way, we have been victims of SpoofCard Sick-Os and are surprised Amazon supports this behavior.

I unfortunately had to send my bag back.  As another reviewer reported, the smell was overwhelming and despite trying to let it air out for a day in the garage, it didn't subside.  My bag also had a scrape at the top and appeared to have been a repackaged item.  I also measured the bag in a straight line at 22" from East to West.  I guess they must measure diagonally when indicating that it's a 25" bag.

Excellent product and does as is intended.  I use these for securing my bike onto the bed of my truck.  Open the straps using the cambuckle button, secure the hooks, and remove the slack by pulling on the strap.  These are not going to provide the same level of tension as ratchet straps, but, are quick and easy to work with.  These should handle the weight of an ATV or motorcycle.  They are lightweight, gray in color, and the hooks are straight/parallel S hooks (not wide mouth S hooks that tend to slip).  They arrived in horrible condition despite being Shipped and Sold by Amazon (that was reported on the shipping feedback).  Once cleaned up, the product has performed well.

FIVE STAR PRODUCT - I have several of these lights from different sellers.  I like the One Mode version (this product) better than the Multi Mode version.  The zoom on these flashlights do not provide the sense of a presision feature, but, it's quite functional.  When in full zoom, the image the flashlight casts appears to be a somewhat odd computer chip image. But, they all do this and it does what is intended, throwing focused light in a concentrated area.ONE STAR SHIPPING - My order on this particular flashlight took nearly a month to fulfill.  It came straight from China with Custom papers enclosed.  It arrived fine, but, if you're in a hurry, check with a different vendor.

When you need it, the tool pays for itself.  It works well and here are two suggestions to make it even better:1. There is no need for the turn knob to be threaded onto the stem.  If you have a stubborn valve core, the knob simply becomes loose and useless in the operation of removing the old valve core.  If I didn't have a manual valve core removal tool to loosen the old core before using this tool, I would have been stuck.  At a minimum, locktite should be applied on the threads from the factory.2. The seating of the new valve core on this tool's stem is a bit shaky.  If there's a way to better secure the new valve core onto the stem when installing, that would be a plus.  Perhaps a rubberized catch within the stem to better grab the valve core pin.  During the removal process, it took about 5 tries before the stem was able to "grab" the old valve core pinhead and I was able to slide it out with the stem.  Although a bit shaky, installing the new stem worked on the first try.  It is possible that I received a defective tool since it was obvious the one I received had been used before.  If someone can take a close-up pic of the stem that grabs the valve core, that would be great.Notes:  In case anyone is wondering, the removal of the old valve core requires counter-clockwise turning as you would expect.  My application was on the low side of a 2005 Toyota Tacoma 6 Cyl and access was easy.All-in-all, an ingenious tool that does what is intended; replacing a valve core on the low side without the need to lose refrigerant.  The designer of this tool should be smiling ear-to-ear; nicely done.  This is a well made, mostly brass piece.  It's heavy as you would want and produces no leaks during use.  As others have reported, during the operation, there will be resistance on the stem as the refrigerant attempts to escape.  Stick with it and be patient.  It may take a few tries, but, the old valve core will come out.A 5-star tool when you need it that gets dinged a star for the minor improvements it can use.  If you have a leaking low side valve core, don't hesitate to get this tool.

I like the single mode switch as opposed to the dim-bright-strobe 3 mode version (that I have as well).  The silver Cree that I received has a faulty zoom in that it will not stay in the full zoom position once you let the barrel go (it backs off due to resistance).  Also, the zoom on all of these torch adjustable lights are a little funky in that it projects the image of a computer-like chip on the subject being illuminated.  It doesn't hurt anything, it just appears odd.That said, it does it's job, is fairly bright, and small enough to carry just about anywhere.  The fact that it uses a single AA battery is a plus.  The switch is a little suspect in that it is sensitive to the touch.  But, so far after two weeks, it has not failed.

The hose, like most garden hoses, does it job and it looks fairly nice.  Unfortunately, mine does not recoil well on the hose hangout.  I had a 50 ft garden hose for 27 years that coiled very nicely before it finally developed a leak.  I wish I knew who manufactured it.I personally would rather have a hose that coils without curling than have a never-kink hose that is too stiff.  A balance for me is preferred.UPDATE: I was hoping the summer hot weather would relax the hose yielding a tamer, more compliant re-coiling profile.  Didn't happen.  I did find that allowing the hose to bake for about 30 min with full water pressure helps.  But, the hose eventually goes back to it's original form factor and becomes unwieldy on the hose hangout.I don't like the hose at all and would return it if it hadn't been so long.

It will accomodate any 3.5mm headphone/microphone device and allow you to connect it to a PC or laptop that has separate headphone/microphone jacks.  Just be sure to insert the jacks all the way in.  Otherwise, it may appear to not be working.Tip: Use Skype's Call Testing Service to test this adapter.

Other than a bluetooth connection problem that I eventually over came, no problems.  I do find Simvalley a bit shady since they refuse to provide a customer support phone number.  If they became a little more legit, I'd give this item a 5-star rating based on the initial experience.  Time will tell how it holds up.By the way, I bought a second competitor's unit from DBPOWER for around $8 that looks similar on the pics, but, Simvalley's unit seemed a little better refined based on esthetics alone.  Both seem to work the same.Publish your phone number, Simvalley.  It's a good business practice that will pay off in the long run if you want to grow your business.

I have used it once for hammer drilling eight 1/2" holes in concrete blocks.  I obviously am not providing a review on its ability to endure daily use, but, the unit did it's job as expected.  Others who use it more frequently should be able to provide a better idea of it's long-term capabilities.I have most of PCs 18v tools and have been pleased with most.  The batteries have held up well and I hope they don't give up on the 18v line up and continue to make more products that work on this battery platform such as a leaf blower for light-duty garage sweeping.UPDATE (Dec 2013): I used the drill for making holes in ceramic tile and the unit worked beautifully. Porter Cable deserves a good deal of credit for this line of tools. They work well and are reasonably priced (except the batteries).  As mentioned above, I sure wish they would continue to add other devices like a sweeper/blower.

I like the concept, it looks nice, but, the execution can use improving.The concept of having a lid that can stay closed when on the shelf is appealing and works well.  The unit comes with 3 different sifters; one is seated on the main body secured by the black screw-on retaining ring while the other two are conveniently stored in the cap.  I use it for flour so I use the sifter with the largest holes (as shown in the product picture).  The problem is that the sifter does not seat properly onto the main body and the black retaining ring does not screw down snuggly onto the sifter to hold it securely in place.  Subsequently, the sifter on mine is loose and sloppy.  Maybe I received a defective unit.  If not, this is certainly an area of improvement for this product.  Otherwise, it is nicely done and a great concept.

UPDATE: I reported the bluetooth issue below and after diagnosing the issue with Alpatronix Support, it turned out to be a defective unit and they are taking care of replacing it.  Alpatronix was also receptive to my suggestion of improving the touch panel as mentioned in the last para below.THIS TURNED OUT TO BE A DEFECTIVE UNIT THAT ALPATRONIX IS REPLACING: <<Orignal Post: While charging and the speaker switch is turned to the OFF position, the AX400's Bluetooth receiver is activated.  This means when your AX400 is charging, your phone will be paired and connected to the AX400 speaker even when the speaker is turned OFF.  Therefore, all phone sounds will be routed through the speaker and not your phone. A problem if, say, the speaker is charging downstairs and you're upstairs.  It also means you won't be able to pair your phone with a bluetooth headset unless you unplug your AX400 speaker (and the switch is in the OFF position).  This is a major logic flaw.  Given that no one else has reported this, it makes me wonder if I received a defective unit.>>With the exception of the Bluetooth issue when charging, the AX400 has excellent build quality and the sound is fine for a speaker of this size.  If your current phone uses a micro USB charging port, the AX400 cooperates nicely by using the same (although they mounted the port upside down for some reason).  I have a Samsung Note2 Android phone and the AX400 works nicely with it when that is the intention.The AX400 has a touch sensor on the top of the unit that controls the Volume and Next/Previous song selections.  The controls work well with Pandora and Google's Play Music apps, however, the backlight is quite dim and difficult to see.  I suggest providing raised or braille-like controls with brighter backlighting.

The overall build quality is excellent and the case is a nice plus.Although my unit was wrap-sealed, I deducted two stars because:(a) the head unit appeared used with grime on the Hi/Lo shutoff valves;(b) the head unit was marred (not a big deal, but, unexpected on a new product);(c) whoever was in charge of applying the "H" & "L" stickers to the Hi/Lo shutoff valves didn't bother to place them on the 12 o'clock position while the valves were closed, placed them on crooked, and placed them on grimy knobs (I doubt the "H" & "L" stickers will stay on very long).  The sticker on the case was rather sloppily applied as well.Taking off two stars is a little harsh, but, I hope to get the attention of the seller to pay attention to quality control.  Otherwise, the rest of the hardware is nothing short of outstanding and well done.  Too bad the easiest touches of the product were a let-down.

If you have recessed light bulbs that are difficult to reach because of height AND the bulbs screw in and out easily, this is a good product.  However, like many recessed lights, if the bulbs are difficult to remove from their sockets, this product will not have enough friction on the bulb to turn it.One idea is to coat the socket and bulb "threads" with a silicon spray.  This should make the bulbs easier to insert and remove making a product like this worthwhile. Just be sure not to spray silicon directly into the socket or on the bottom tip of the bulb; you don't want to impede the contact surface, and, direct spray into the socket could wind up with a mild electrical shock if your switch is accidentally in the ON position).Another idea to consider: I have my device mounted on a Shur-Line 06570L Easy Reach Extension Pole that allows rapid extension from 4-9 ft.  Nice product.

I've had two of these units and both went bad; the first after just a few months.  The second unit lasted about a year and the LED display blacked out and the CD component no longer works.  The radio sometimes works, but, reception is so bad that you may only get a station or two.JVC used to make decent products and this one looks nice.  However, JVC's quality has become significantly sub-par.  For the money I spent on these two units, I should have spent a little more and purchased from a manufacturer that has a better reputation.

Comparing the Motorola HX550 with the Motorola H730: After a few years of experience with the Motorola H730, my opinion remains that it's a 5 Star product. I recently bought the newer Motorola HX550 thinking maybe it would be an upgrade; it's not. The H730 is better in every way including:- wearing comfort,- slipping on and off the ear,- call quality for me wearing the H730,- call quality for the person I am talking to (yes, I have compared both units with multiple people on the other end; the H730 was preferred each time), and- button controls (the vol buttons are better on the HX550 but the large command button most used is superior on the H730).I have had plenty of bluetooth headsets and the H730 as of March 2013 is still the best I have tried and I have tried units that cost nearly $200.So, if you're considering the HX550 (which is not bad), you may want to consider the H730 as well.

When I first bought the set, I thought I was buying two of the same thing.  I thought I could store one in my toolbox-to-go and the other in my electrical drawer.  I wasn't very observant of the product description and/or pic.For most others that are far more observant than me, they already know that one pair will strip 10 thru 22 gauge wire.  While the other pair handles 20 thru 30 gauge wire.  Both will strip 20 and 22 gauge wire.5 star quality.

It's not the prettiest angle grinder available, but, it does the job when you need it.I had been a Hitachi cordless tool guy, but, Hitachi doesn't seem to have a master plan; meaning they don't have a line of tools that fit a particular battery (it seems hit or miss), and, they are expensive.  Porter Cable, on the other hand, has nicely created an 18v battery system that can be used on multiple tools (their website lists them all and Lowes carries most of their line).  I have nearly all of their cordless tools in this line and they are competent.  I would rate the overall quality of their entire tool line a 4 out of 5 and the value a 5+.  Excellent for the Harry Homeowner that doesn't want to break the bank for occasional use of these tools when needed.  I also suspect they'd hold their own to the pro that uses them daily as well.By the way, Porter Cable's customer service is very good.  I had a battery issue that seemingly wouldn't charge.  They replaced it with no questions asked.  For what it's worth, I later discovered the battery may not have been bad after all.  As it turns out, if you attempt to charge a COLD battery (as in left in cold garage during the winter months), the charger will indicate that the battery is defective.  Solution: let it sit inside until it reaches room temperature and then try charging.  A minor quirk but it hasn't been an issue for me since I now just keep the batteries inside (where they should be anyway to prevent premature discharge).

The Jabra Clipper (clip part) seems solid and does what it intends to do.  The color coordinated headset is simply cheap and the cords are too short.  The length of the cords, which are quite thin, appear to be designed to only be used as a belt or lapel clip.  While watching TV (the way I use it), I want to hold it in my hand.  In my case, you'll tug the short side (yes, the wires are of different length) right of out your ear.Msg to Jabra: You have a good product.  If you need to cut a corner, ditch the micro USB charger (most of us have them) and provide a decent headset.

If you plan to use this for view TV, the audio lipsync delay is too great for use (I have this Transmitter paired with the Jabra Clipper ). I have another bluetooth headset that I bought several years ago from Costco that has zero lipsync issues.  So, the issue appears to be with the TT-BA01 transmitter.  Based on comments by at least one other that indicated no lipsync/audio delay issues, I attempted to contact the manufacturer to see if maybe I had an older version.  The manufacturer, apparently located in China, did not respond.One other minor irritation: the bluetooth light on the device blinks like a slow strobe light in dark room situations.  I suggest the manufacturer make this less pronounced.  Finally, the question of whether it works while being charge that several have asked about, my unit does transmit and operate normally even when charging.

I was a software developer once upon a time in my career.  So, I was not intimidated by having to program a remote.  Well, after buying the R50. I was so frustrated that I threw it in the drawer and forgot about it.  Then, 6 months later, I saw some pretty good Amazon reviews on this remote and decided to give it another chance.  Glad I did.  Once you get the hang of it, the remote is actually pretty good.  The instructions that come with the remote are skimpy.  After mastering this remote through trial and error, here are some tips that I really think will help you get through:Primer- there are two levels of remote commands:1. Main level2. Sub level (or referenced as "inside device" by the remote instructions)Tips:1. Write down all of your devices on a piece of paper such as Samsung HDTV, Sony Blu-ray Player, Panasonic VCR, ...2. For each device in #1 above, search the URC database for the "best" code set.  The code sets are stored in the remote.  So, if you have a newer device, there may not be a code set perfect match.  Store the device code set on the "last page" of the devices.  So, when adding your Samsumg HDTV, code set "0656" may be the best match (only way to find out is to test the buttons which is the most frustrating part). Then label the device, in this case "HDTV" and again put it on the last page.3. After you test the device buttons, you may need to supplement the device buttons with LEARNED commands.  The R50 learning mode is very effective.  So, for example, if your 0656 code set for your HDTV does not include a mute command, add a MUTE command inside the HDTV device you set up above using your Samsung factory remote to learn from.4. Repeat steps 2 & 3 above for each device.5. Now, you're ready to do some damage.  Your friend on this device are the MACROS.  Now that you have taken the steps above, you can create macros for just about anything you'd like.  So, here's what my remote opening Page looks like:- Top Left "Cable"- Top Right "Air TV"- Mid Left "Apple TV"- Mid Right "BlueRay"- Bot Left "NetFlix"- Bot Right "Pandora"So, to program the Cable button, create a button labeled "Cable" and assign a macro to the button (on the Main level). Once the recording starts, HDTV codes > HDMI-2 code > DONE.To program the Air TV, in my case, HDTV codes > AirTV code > MAIN > DONE.Reading this cold will likely not make sense.  But, I think the tips above will help you if you take your time.

This little guy works with Linux Mint 14 (likely previous versions of Ubuntu and Linux Mint as well).Although others have indicated this is plug and play, here is how I got it to work on Linux Mint 14:  1. plug it into your USB port (nothing happened for me)  2. connect an ethernet cable to your PC  3. Start your Update Manager and let it find the software it needs  4. Go into your Network Manager.  It should detect your wireless adapter.  Configure your wireless security and you should be good to go.For anyone wondering, this USB wireless adapter works flawlessly with LM14 including being able to wake up normally from suspend mode.  My only concern is the week signal it shows (80%) when the PC is within 5 feet of an Asus N Router.  Hopefully, it will behave normally once I move the PC 35 ft away.

No kickback when the trigger is pulled and surprising power.  Remember to use 30 weight oil (chain oil is too thick and not recommended by the mfgr).  My only complaint is that the oil reservoir leaks during storage.  If this could be addresses, I cannot think of any other improvements that it requires.  Still, a 5 Star product in my opinion.

I've had it now for a few years.  I have never replaced the batteries.  It just works when you need it.  I recently used it to diagnose a trailer axle bearing problem by measuring the temp of the drums after a long trip.  Excellent for detecting where you need weather stripping or insulation during extreme weather conditions.  I've been very pleased with the product.
I like these a lot.  The quality control of the tips coming together is not perfect, but, pretty close.  Still, a nice plier.

This motherboard has served me well since upgrading to the latest version of the firmware.  Prior to that, I had sporadic trouble with the BIOS posting correctly.  Nice board for my needs.  Here's my build:Corsair Graphite Series 600T Mid-Tower Gaming Computer Case with Mesh Side Panel CC600TMCorsair Enthusiast Series 750-Watt 80 Plus Bronze Certified Power Supply CMPSU-750TXV2Gigabyte Intel Z68 ATX DDR3 2133 LGA 1155 Motherboards GA-Z68X-UD3H-B3Intel Core i7-2600 Processor 3.4GHz 8 MB Cache Socket LGA1155Corsair Vengeance Blue 16 GB PC3-12800 1600mHz DDR3 240-Pin SDRAM CMZ16GX3M4A1600C9BCrucial 256GB m4 SSD 2.5" SATA III CT256M4SSD2LG Electronics WH12LS30 12X Blu-ray SATA Writer Drive - WH12LS30KAsus DRW-24B1ST 24xDVDRW Drive DVD-RAM/R/RW 24x8x16x(DVD) 48x32x48x(CD) Serial ATA Internal10 in One Card ReaderI am running Linux Mint 12 as the host OS and running Windows 7 as a virtual OS.

This is yet another very good tool in Porter Cable's line of 18v cordless tools.  I had been an 18v Hitachi fan until they simply could not demonstrate that they cared about their customers by offering few accessories to their 18v line-up.  Porter Cable, on the other hand, listens.  I called to suggest an 18v leaf blower and they appeared quite eager and hungry to please.  They offer an impressive line-up of tools that appear to be very good.As for this jigsaw, I have only one complaint; the safety switch is a pain (it should have been made like the safety lock PC placed on their reciprocating saw).  I therefore removed the safety switch since I don't have kids to worry about (at least not right now).  If you decide to try removing the safety switch, here's how:  1. remove the blade  2. remove the sole plate by completely loosening the finger screw and slide the plate back & off.  3. remove all of the phillips screws on the casing.  Note, all screws are the same size & length except for one long screw closest to where the battery reads "18v".  4. carefully remove one side of the saw's casing. Pay attention to the blade mechanism and take a picture of it before proceeding.  If the blade mechanism falls out (easy for it to happen, you can refer back to the pic).  5. remove the safety switch.  6. align the case, fasten the screws, re-attach sole plate, and test.If you have a situation where minors or less experienced people have access to your jigsaw, it is recommend that you do NOT modify the tool.  Of course, modifying the tool will likely void the warranty as well.

I'm pleased with the jacket and actually bought two.  The quality is very good, typical of Columbia wear.  If you can be patient, the price seems to fluctuate frequently.  I found it less here on Amamzon than at the Columbia store.
There's little to say, it's an inner tube that appears to work fine.  Time will tell how it holds up, but, based on visual inspection there's no reason to doubt this product.

Exceeded my expectations in every way. Excellent fit, finish, and materials. Smooth operation.The latch piece in particular is a delight - - simple and rugged (it's NOT going to bend), with a very secure set screw that appears will never loosen.Locks work perfectly (all keys alike), and the rain-covers are also included.I'm not a gushy reviewer, quite the opposite in fact. But this one is worth six stars.
Big, beasty rings - - I'm going to be using these for vehicle-recovery shackles on my 4x4.Very substantial and well-made. No finish so they will rust unless painted.

Pretty nice knob, very solid and rich looking - - but it cracked in the desert dryness. It's still serviceable, and I guess you could say it's now got "character", but the wood just couldn't tolerate the lower humidity and heat.UPDATE: after I posted the initial review, the seller offered a refund - - this is simply outstanding support, the kind that we all wish more vendors would copy. This level of customer service, in league with the general excellent quality of the knob, prompted a bump to 4 star rating.

Although it says "all Coleman 2 and 3 burner stoves", it is NOT a great fit on the compact that I own. Yes, you can kind of jam it into place, but it won't be stable, and the wind-breaks don't fit.After looking at it for a while, I decided to make some minor modifications. I ground off about 1/8" of each outside foot tab on the griddle, and it now fits down inside the frame of the stove as it should (little too wide before). I also used a nibbler to trim a notch into each windbreak panel, so they'll fit around the corners of the griddle and tuck into their retention slots.With those mods, the griddle works like a charm, and my first set of steaks came out great (thumbs-up from the wife and grandkids). As other reviewers have noted, the non-stick makes for easy clean up (even better with grill spray before cooking. After some experimentation, I found that about 3/4 heat on my little stove is the best for meats. This equates to about 10,000 BTU.

I bought this bag because I fell in love with the looks, and I was not disappointed. Real leather and real canvas, but not too heavy (about 14 ounces more than my nylon day-pack). Worth noting is that it is SO NOT waterproof. The canvas soaks up water like blotter paper. I bought an inexpensive rain-cover which I'll keep in the bottom for soggy days. I'm also experimenting with a spray-on water-repellency treatment which (first coat) is only mildly effective -- but still better than untreated.There is a nylon liner in all compartments, the zippers are first-quality, and the side pockets are correctly sized for my favorite water bottles (bicycle bottles). All in all, very happy with it, especially the more "gentile" look as opposed to the hitch-hiking hippie look of nylon backpacks.

Exactly what I needed for a lower-power (branch circuit). This 15A unit defaults (no shore power) to the inverter input. If shore power (or generator power) is activated, the internal relay switches over to that source.It's small and light weight too, and was easy to install in an empty space underneath a set of drawers, right next to my shore-power breaker bank.

Big, beautiful, solidly made faucet. However, the installation instructions specifically identify that it is not recommended for RO use. Since I bought it for my reverse-osmosis system, I called tech support for more info. Turns out, an RO system will deteriorate a non-stainless faucet and erode it. Nobody seems to know how quickly this will happen, however.Since this is a BN model (brass/nickel), I'm not sure of its longevity.

These are fantastic, the first wire-rope clamp I've found besides aluminum ferrules which doesn't need special tooling and still looks great. These are MUCH better than the u-bolt type clamps (for appearance).They are a little finicky to put together - - seems to take three hands sometimes, but after a couple of tries you get the hang of it.Just like all wire-rope clamps, don't forget to tape or RTV the bare end of the cable, to prevent getting poked.

For some peculiar reason, I couldn't find this stuff ANYWHERE in a brick/mortar store, so I had to order it. Not the best choice for making a color match to my other metal trim.Fortunately, it was a great match, a good deep brass/anodize color. Material is excellent, and packaged in a huge long box so it came, miraculously undamaged. Not that I needed a piece 8 feet long, but that was the only length.It also came with screws (not nails), also brass-colored, but perhaps a bit long for my application at about 1" length. I may have to buy some shorter screws, no big deal.

I kind of liked this unit at first, but it definitely did NOT grow on me.What I liked:Small, light, convenient, nearly instant warm-up.Easy to manage water tank.What I will throw it away because of:Watery coffee - - I have to remember to shut it off mid-brew, or it puts in too much water even on "small" setting.Buttons have no feedback and have to be pushed multiple times.Actually TOO light, it moves around the counter just by using it. Won't stay put.The lid-puncture spike is too small to pierce the top of the biodegradable K-cups (the ones with the paper bottom). I have to manually punch a hole in these cups or they won't work.All in all, a big disappointment. Can't recommend it unless you like weak coffee and use only the all-plastic cups.

If you live in the Arctic, this might work. Otherwise, it's going to be too warm. It's thick and furry and insulated, and my face started to sweat before I finished adjusting the strap.Otherwise, good quality and well made.
These things will save you an expensive water-heater replacement (and maybe even a nasty RV leaking experience). Mine gets chewed up and wasted away about every 6 months or so.

I like these a lot, and they are a great addition to lava-rock fireplaces or campfires. That said, the kit has some flaws.Too many dumb-looking pine conesToo many duplicate logsFlat areas on most logs (can't turn them over)Despite the flaws, I found that they created a more pleasant fake-campfire experience. Expensive too, but I still recommend them.

Absolutely superb quality and sharpness. I'd give them 5 stars except the loops are so small, I really have to concentrate to keep my fingers properly in them. For slender-fingered people, these will be a wonderful tool. For sausage-fingered dudes like me, they are worth buying but a little finicky to use.

All three worked well as-received. My experience with all such lighters is poor, they just don't seem to keep working for very long even though they obviously still have butane in them. If these keep going for more than a year, I'll upgrade them to a 5-star rating.

Fits great, does the proper job of sealing my Warn hubs to my wheel hubs. I give it 4 stars because it's ridiculously high-priced. I also noted that this "universal" kit has two large O-rings that don't fit anywhere in my hubs, so off they go to my spare O-ring kit.

For what these are -- stick-on emblems -- they are superb. They have a thick, rich, clear top-coat that makes them look like a heavy glass or plastic emblem. But they are a supple, conformal plastic that easily fits to flat or curved surfaces. The adhesive is super-tacky and looks like it will stick great and last a long time.I only needed one, so even if it only lasts a couple of years, I have another to replace it with. Not bad for seven bucks.

This is a plastic, but sturdy, replacement faucet for my RV. I like the big base for the outlet, which can be pulled on without breaking (unlike the old shower-type faucet that came in my RV). Unfortunately, the base is a straight-thread fitting that can't be found in my local hardware stores, so I had to buy the quick-release mate to this female fitting. This increases the effective price -- but I needed a quick-release for my hose anyway.
Just the thing for disconnecting propane appliances -- these things are super-safe and never leak. I've got them everywhere in my house and RV.

What a great hose for my RV. It's delightfully slender and light, coils up really compact, and has a very decent flow rate. I keep it squirreled away for various tasks that I wouldn't want to use my clean tidy white fresh-water hose for.
This book is even better than the Dick, Jane, and Sally picture books that came out in the 1960s. The stories are really fun short stories, instead of all that "Look look, see Spot run" stuff.

Let me be clear by what I mean with this five-star rating. I don't mean that this device is a top-of-the-line tablet. It isn't. But for the price it's a great value, and it's good enough for what I wanted to do with it, which is to serve as an interface for e-books between an SD card and my Kindle Paperwhite, a situation made necessary by the fact that the PW doesn't have a memory expansion slot for a microSD card.

The Turner Diaries is a short novel of speculative fiction.  It's a military fantasy about a time when the U.S. government finally got too big for its britches and had to be called to heel by an Organization that, unlike the government itself, truly worked on behalf of the majority of its citizenswhite Americans.As fiction, the story is of high quality, which is astounding when you appreciate that Dr. William Pierce was not a frequent fantasy author.  He was a former physics professor who abandoned that career to become a real-life revolutionist.  The novel itself is short, but the story it tells is self-contained.It would, in fact, be difficult to imagine a sequel, unless it had to do with extraterrestrial aliens trying to take over the world with guile here, bribes there, stealthy assassinations, and, rarely, with overt force; i.e., the aliens in such a sequel would have to play the part that the Jews played in The Turner Diaries.The Turner Diaries has been blamed for inspiring Timothy McVeigh to bomb the Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City in 1995.  It's a lie.  Although McVeigh had read The Turner Diaries and had recommended that others read it, his motivation for bombing the Federal Building was watching the U.S. government murder 83 Christian men, women and children inside their church compound near Waco, Texas, on 19 April 1993.  McVeigh testified at his trial that he had been convinced that the U.S. government was too authoritarian, that it was disregarding the Constitution, and that it was time somebody took it down a peg.  He wanted to show the government that there were still Americans who can and will fight against totalitarianism.  McVeigh didn't need to read The Turner Diaries to get the basic idea of bombing: he had been a soldier, a combat engineer, in the U.S. Armed Forces for several yearshe already knew about bombs and their uses.There are lots of examples of military fiction in the world.  In most of them, a building or a bridge gets blown up at some point in the story.  So why do people, such as the Anti-Defamation League, blame The Turner Diaries in particular for violence? Why don't they blame other authors for including similar scenes in their fiction stories?It's simple.  The criticism is a smear job intended to foster a widespread prejudice against the book and anyone associated with it.  The Turner Diaries portrays Jews as agents and sponsors of oppression.  The complainers, who are mostly Jews themselves, don't like being so portrayed.  Even the Jews who run Wall Street and Hollywoodmocking white men and women in movies, in TV sitcoms, and in advertisingwon't admit that maybe some turnabout is fair play.  Worse (to them), it shows determined and competent white people winning a race war against all comers.  They don't want whites to get the idea that they could actually win such a war, because one day white people might have plenty of reasons to fightwhen there are no more places for them to escape minority crime and alien culture.It is from such political motives that the ADL and similar organizations bad-mouth The Turner Diaries.  Every pretext they use when making this criticism is a deception of one kind or another.  In reality, it's a good story.  If you aren't white, then you can use a magic marker on your copy to cover up every instance of the word "white" and write in its place whatever other word you'd rather were there.

I must say, when these cards are selling for under $14 each, they are just about the best value around. I've had problems with SAMSUNG Chromebooks, and I've heard from people who have had trouble with SAMSUNG smartphones, but I've never heard anyone complain about SAMSUNG SD cards. Apparently, SD cards are something that SAMSUNG actually knows how to make right.
Handy little memory cards. Not the fastest, but you don't need speed for everything.

Savitri Devi makes you think. I've always regarded the intensity and longevity of the anti-Nazi hate phenomenon as something suspicious. Most alleged or ostensible villains fade into "history" (textbook narratives) within a few decades. But the animus against Hitler and the Nazis has been kept alive and, if not fresh, at least vigorous. One would be right to wonder why that is so.It turns out that the Jews have been profiting from Holocaust propaganda, probably far more than they should have profited. It might also be the case that Hitler was the good guy in the Second World War, and that if England and America had been wisely and honestly led, they would have joined forces with Germany to put an end to Communism, rather than take sides with the USSR to put an end to National Socialism. That might have led to a global cultural renewal of humanity, instead of its taking a downward cultural trend toward degeneracy, as actually did happen.
Just as I remember from all those years ago. About 50 years ago, in fact.

The battery in the keyboard has low capacity. You need to charge it back up frequently, or else just leave it connected to a battery pack. Also, the space bar key is sometimes difficult to press-to-click. You have to press on it in just the right way, either left side or right side, but not in the middle. Also, some of the keys return the incorrect characters. The ampersand key on mine returns the symbol for the British pound (money), and the backslash returns the # symbol. Although most of the characters (including all the letters and numbers) do return the correct character, the ones that don't can be a nuisance. This keyboard does work with my Raspberry Pi, though. If it didn't, I'd be one-starring it now.
The percentage of remaining charge digital indicator runs quickly down from 100% to 82%, and then the rate of decline in the percentage slows down a lot.
It worked. That's what it was supposed to do. And it had Python 3 built in, so I didn't have to download it separately.
It has been working very well with my Raspberry Pi (HDMI feed) so far.
Quinoa is my favorite grain. I especially enjoy buying quinoa when the price is low. That's because then I can afford to get more of it.

The Saga of the Renunciates is politically the nastiest series that I've ever read. The nastiness takes the form of extreme reverse sexism: the attitude toward men taken by a female fiction author. The Shattered Chain, Thendara House, and City of Sorcery are books in which to be male is, generally speaking, to be evil. Most of the the men are evil to some degree, except the homosexuals and men who allows themselves to be guided by the innately superior wisdom of women. All the women are good, except for the villainesses. And the villainesses are supremely capable enemies, unlike the male antagonists whom the all-female cast of Good-Persons mow down with ease. The women who are not heroines nonetheless commonly speak with wisdom and/or with virtuous circumspection. The men are mostly loud, rude, stupid, braggarts who hold power that they do not deserve and jobs that most anyone female could do better. (This rule does not, of course, apply to male homosexuals, who are such a noble bunch.) And so on. There's more, but now you have the stink in your nostrils. If this is your thing, then buy this book. If not, then avoid irritating yourself and skip it.

It was a good game for its time. An upgraded version with better graphics would sell today, I think. The music is quite good, especially the tune heard in the Spitting Lion Inn and the Shady Vale Inn. If I could play the game on the computer I have now, I'd buy it again just to lift the music off with Total Recorder.
This same model of calculator served me well in the 1980s. It's good for everything from keeping track of your shopping bill at the grocery store to trigonometry in high school.

The good side of the Kindle Fire 6 HD is that it is well made, without the cheap feel of most cheap tablets. It radiates competence for doing what it was designed to do.The bad side is that it wasn't designed to do enough.Most buyers will find the basic 8gb storage inadequate, as the OS will eat up a lot of it. Knowing this, I paid extra for the 16gb version, and I'm still likely to be pressed before long. In other words, a memory extension slot for swappable 32gb microSD cards would have been a big help. That particular feature is USUALLY a big help, which makes it something of a mystery why Amazon didn't put one in the Fire.(One imagines that this was discussed among the directors in the boardroom, with them weighing customer satisfaction against their own, with predictable results.)At the moment, I'm using my Kindle Fire 6 HD as a combination music player and backup library. It will let me store and enjoy local tunes and ebooks that I downloaded with my PC and hopped over via USB card. However, it won't let me do the same thing with my videos until the Fire can make connection with the internet. And therein is a major problem.The fault might be with my router. Although my PC connection to the internet is clear, obviously, or you wouldn't be reading this, the router apparently doesn't hear my Kindle Fire. I'm not sure why that is, but it is annoying.So for now my Fire is an alternative ebook reader that can play music.I'd like a programmable calculator app, too, but I don't see one. It would be sort of like a simulated TI-89 or Casio fx-9860gii, with a calculator style BASIC syntax language, suitable for making all the usual code structures that college sophomores get taught in computer science classes. For-next loops, while-endwhile, repeat-until, subroutines, defined functions, global and local variables with alphanumeric names, callable external subroutines, quadruple precision and integer variable types, lists, matrices, and all the usual functions you get with high-end graphing calculators, with the whole screen being available for readout. Maybe the screen can be partitioned so that the NE third of it shows the code, the NW third shows the command line and the output, and the southern third shows the virtual keyboard user interface.A platform like the Kindle Fire could put all existing graphing calculators to shame, if the appropriate apps were written. Again, it is something of a mystery why this has not already been done.

When you marry him, tell him that he was The Prince. Crossing your fingers crossed behind your back is the customary non-verbal apology to God for telling a small lie. And, if you aren't an insufferable nag, he'll probably even improve with age to near-Prince status.The only book on gender politics that I like more than this one is John Gordon's "The Myth of the Monstrous Male."

I bought a Kobo Aura for $122 elsewhere. The price here on Amazon is too high. Although both Kobo Aura and Kindle Paperwhite are very good eReaders, there are reasons for why someone might prefer the Kobo Aura.1. Aura's CPU runs at 1 GHz. Paperwhite runs only at 800 MHz.2. Aura has 4 Gb of RAM. Paperwhite has only 2 Gb of RAM.3. Aura has 4 Gb of disk space. Paperwhite has only 2 Gb of disk space.^4. Aura needs page refresh less often than Paperwhite does.5. Aura has memory expansion slot for 32 Gb microSD card. Paperwhite does not.6. Aura will display both epub and mobi ebooks. Kindle will not display epub books.7. Aura has better multi-touch functionality than Kindle does (e.g. control of light, etc.)*In 2014, the Kindle Paperwhite was upgraded to 4 Gb of disk space.The biggest advantage of Kobo Aura over Kindle Paperwhite is, in my opinion, #5. The lack of a microSD memory expansion slot limits the Kindle to only 1000 books or so, whereas you can pile more than 30,000 books on the Aura with a 32 Gb card installed. The Amazon Kindle Paperwhite (2013) is a four-star eReader. The Kobo Aura is a five-star one.Edit, 17 Jan 2014. A disadvantage of the Kobo Aura is the relatively low contrast of the etext. Apparently, in order to reduce the screen refresh rate, Kobo decided to make the Aura's e-ink print in dark grey. Whereas this is readable, it's a slight strain on the eyes. A really black text is preferable to text that is merely dark grey. You can improve things a bit by increasing the font weight, but in my opinion the Aura's tradeoff between text darkness and refresh rate wasn't worthwhile.Edit, 24 Jan 2014. Another disadvantage has been spotted! Despite its (allegedly) fast CPU, the Kobo Aura slows down quite a lot as you manage your collections if you have a lot of collections. I have 148 collections, and it can be a long wait between touch-triggered actions. Even the NOOK Simple Touch, with its slower processor, is faster than the Kobo Aura while managing collections, given same number of collections on each device. With this fault, I am downgrading the Aura from a 5-star eReader to four stars.Edit, 25 June 2014. Another disadvantage! Either the KOBO Aura or the epub book format that it uses does not render much of the Unicode character set. The Amazon Kindle Paperwhite with the mobi format does a much better job with math expressions that use weird symbols, exponents, subscripts, and such. KOBO's eReaders usually substitute a default meaningless character to substitute for any Unicode symbols that it doesn't know how to display. It makes following the math almost impossible.

I own the Sper Scientific 810035, 810036, 810047, and 810048. This one, the 810035, is the most basic. It is easiest to read, but it has the fewest features. But most of the time, you only need the time and the chronometer, and that's what this watch has. So I use this model more than the others.

Is there anyone you despise, but feel you must buy a holiday gift for anyway? This book will be perfect. It will be a square-filler, so the recipient can't complain that you didn't give him anything, but it won't bring him any joy. He'll feel as if he has wasted his time by reading as much of it as he could stomach.

I use my Kindle Paperwhite as my main e-reader. I also own a Kobo and an inexpensive tablet PC (AllDayMall), each with 32 Gb memory expansion microSD cards, as back-ups and as safe storage for my ebooks. But the Kindle PW is the one I use for actually reading ebooks, as it seems the friendliest to my hand. I have acquired four extra Kindle PW batteries from a medical supply website, which are in nested static protection bags (proof against nuclear EMP and remote activation hazards) along with my other e-readers.My main gripes about the Kindle PW is the smallness of the internal memory (only 1.3 GB usable) and the lack of a memory card expansion slot. A place to insert a 32 GB microSD card would just about double the item's value.Another possible improvement to the Kindle PW is the marketing of an optional, separately sold, external rechargeable battery pack with 20,000 mAh capacity. If the claims about the Kindle's energy efficiency are correct, such an external pack would run the device for over 400 hours continuously. (I dislike the way Amazon promotes the "8-weeks of battery life" idea based on 30-minutes use per day, with wi-fi off and light turned down low. It works out to only 28 hours of continuous runtime. It would be much more informative for Amazon to tell us this, instead, and let the customer figure out how many days he can make that much time stretch into.)Still, the Kindle Paperwhite is pretty good. I don't know why the obvious ways to make it even better weren't pursued, but I'm sure that it must have something to do with Amazon's profits.Edit, added 29 December 2013. Altered 24 January 2014. Despite my dissatisfaction with the fact that the 2nd-generation Kindle Paperwhite doesn't have a microSD memory expansion slot, I bought one anyway. Then I wished that I hadn't because I saw that the Kobo Aura has 4 gig of built-in disk space (3.3 gig usable), while the Kindle has only 2 gig of disk space (1.3 gig usable) AND has NO microSD card slot! Even the basic Barnes & Noble NOOK Simple Touch has a microSD card slot for holding up to 30000 more books. For what insane reason did Amazon decide to cut the Kindle Paperwhite off short in this way? With a microSD slot, Kindle PW would lead the pack, both in absolute terms and in cost-benefit terms. Without such a slot, Kindle Paperwhite is merely "okay."Edit, added 25 June 2014. A bit of extra praise is in order for the Kindle Paperwhite. I have discovered that it will render a fair proportion of Unicode characters, doing a much better job of it than the KOBO eReaders do. If you use an eReader for textbooks that contain math equations with lots of exponents, subscripts, and weird symbols, then you'll probably be able to read them easier with a Kindle PW than with a KOBO reader.

Pretty standard quality for the 500-(haha)"800" mAh 9V li-ion battery type. You know most of these batteries are hollow inside and contain the electrolyte in plastic pouches? I took apart a "780" (actually more like 600) mAh LightLong battery and examined the innerds. The pouches are smaller than they need to be, so, just guessing, the manufacturers could easily make genuine over 1000 mAh 9V batteries, but they don't. Anyway, these batteries here are about as good as most of the others. They aren't the lowest performers in the bunch, either. But they probably aren't as great as they could be.

The hero came over here and did some wonderful things, and then he went over there and did more wonderful things. After that, he went down yonder and started doing wonderful things, but he made a mistake, and bad things started happening. But the hero remembered his old teacher, an ancient sage, telling him how to fix the bad things, and he applied that wisdom, and the situation abruptly became better. The hero just kept striding around, righting wrongs and spreading his excellence, until all were satisfied. The end.

I bought one of these 7" Alldaymall tablets to keep back-up copies of my ebooks. I separately bought and installed a 32 GB microSD card in the memory expansion slot. It looks like this tablet will do what I bought it for. For the price, it has been very worthwhile. Of course, should I encounter problems with it in the future, this review will be revisited and revised accordingly. (I've had a bad experience with a Chromebook that worked OK at first.) But, so far, no complaints.

The Pak-Lite isn't a thrower, not by any means. But it will give you enough light to get around your camp, and you can't beat it for compact size. With a single-use alkaline or a rechargeable 550-600 mAh li-ion battery, expect about 24-40 hours of light on the bright setting, and much more on the dimmer "thief mode" (just bright enough to let a thief see what he's stealing). If you want to make a reading lamp out of it, just tape a piece of white cardboard to one side, so the light going the other way will reflect back on your book.Pak-Lites are quite rugged and will stand up moderately well to prolonged immersion in water. I accidentally left one in the pocket of a pair of pants that I was leaving to soak in water/detergent. When I got it out (after two days), one of the LED's was stuck on "dim" mode until the circuit board dried out. After that it worked fine, although there's a bit of rust on the contacts now.Nearly everybody who has used Pak-Lites likes them. I've bought three of these so far, and I think I'll get another one now. Correction: I -would- have bought another one, but the seller wants $15 shipping, and that killed the deal. Definitely.

The elastic straps on the bottom block access to the USB 2.0 port on the left, and to the power supply port on the right. The tablet I am using is the "Alldaymall A70X 7 Inch Android 4.2 4 GB A20 Dual-Core Tablet PC Capacitive Multi-Touchscreen with Dual Cameras, HDMI (Black)". The size of the case is correct, but the straps interfere with the tablet function too much.

A "9-volt" lithium-ion battery never really reaches nine volts across the poles. The most you can charge it to is about 8.47V, and most of them are full at 8.33V.Maximal Power's 550 mAh li-ion battery ran a Pak-Lite on bright mode for 24 hours, which is about the same runtime that I got from a LightLong 780 mAh and a ONAN 600 mAh battery. The weakling of the bunch that I tested was a Tenergy 500 mAh, which only lasted about 15 or 16 hours.By comprison, Li-ion rechargeable batteries are much better than NiMH ones. The runtime for a Tenergy Centura NiMH 9V battery was only 5 hours with my Pak-Lite set on bright.However, I have discovered an inconsistency in these Maximal Power batteries. I use them to run a Pak-Lite, a snap-on LED cap that works as a weak flashlight. The poles on some of the Maximal Power batteries are too short to snap on the cap securely, causing a poor connection. But some of the batteries have taller poles, which snap on OK.

I recently tested four brands of "9V" lithium-ion batteries. These Tenergy 500mAh batteries were one brand. The others were LightLong 780mAh, Maximal Power 550mAh, and Onan 600mAh. The batteries were drained from about 8.40V to 5.25V by using a Pak-Lite cap set on "bright mode." The same Pak-Lite cap was used for all of the tests.The LightLong, Maximal Power, and Onan batteries all had endurances of about 24 hours. There wasn't much difference between them. LightLong might be puffing its capacity a bit, since you'd expect a 780mAh battery to outlast a 550mAh battery by quite a lot, and it didn't. All three of these brands give about the same performance.Not so the Tenergy 500mAh. Its performance was decidedly inferior, showing a runtime only 2/3 as long as any of the other brands: somewhere between 15 and 16 hours. Sure, they're cheaper. But these are rechargeable batteries, and the difference in cost is spread over all the rechargings, so it really is worthwhile to get the better battery and pay a little more.

No, they aren't glamorous items, but these little prybars for electronic devices do what they're supposed to. They get the back cover off in a jiffy. I used one of them to replace the battery of an old SHARP EL-509D calculator. Worked just fine.

Lithium-ion rechargeable batteries of the "9 volt" size never actually charge to nine volts. The most you can charge them to is about 8.45 volts, and most of them are fully charged at 8.3V.I recently tested four brands of 9V batteries with my Pak-Lite, which is a cap that snaps on to a 9V battery and emits light from a pair of LEDs mounted on the top. The same Pak-Lite was used for all of the tests, and the bright setting was used continuously.Three of the brands, ONAN 600mAh, LightLong 780mAh, and Maximal Power 550mAh had nearly identical runtimes, at 24 hours each. (LightLong might be puffing its capacity just a bit.)The other brand, the Tenergy 500mAh, had the most inferior runtime, at only 16 hours. They're cheaper, but I don't think I'll be buying any more Tenergy 9V li-ion batteries.Maximal Power's 550mAh 9V li-ion battery did as well as any (and better than some) in my endurance tests, and I just now bought four more of them.Edited: One thing that I noticed after posting this review is that not all of my Maximal Power 9v batteries have equally high poles on top of the battery. The poles on some are taller than the poles on others, so either there is a lack of standardization in the manufacturer, or someone else is counterfeiting. The taller poles are better because they can snap on to things that the shorter poles won't make a good connection with.

I paid my $19.99. I waited two days for the game installer to download. I ran the installer, and the Origin interface program works okay. I gave Origin some of my personal data. But MY GAME won't install! I keep getting this error message: "DirectX Setup Error: An Internal Error Occurred." I regret buying this. I want back both my money and MY TIME. Or else I want the game I paid for to WORK, one or the other. I really HATE when this happens, some unforeseen glitch that should not occur, some software error that should have been found and ironed out before trying to do business with it.

Both the Kindle Paperwhite and the Kobo Glo are excellent eReaders. I own both. Compared with the Kindle Paperwhite...Minor points of inferiority:* The Kobo Glo is slightly less responsive to screen touch.* The Kobo Glo's presentation occasionally makes less efficient use of the page.* Kobo Glo takes longer to boot than Kindle Paperwhite does.* Kobo's online store isn't as rich as Amazon is, and you must convert Kindle content to epub with a program such as Calibre (augmented with deDRM tools) before you can read it on the Kobo Glo.* For my devices, the "fuzzy grey bottom" lighting problem is a little more pronounced on the Kobo Glo than on the Kindle Paperwhite.MAJOR point of inferiority:* The battery on the Kobo Glo is "embedded," meaning it isn't intended to be replaceable, unlike the battery on the Kindle Paperwhite, which can be replaced. I'm looking into the possibility of hacking in an improvised replacement, but at present I don't know whether this can be done. The original battery on the Kobo Glo has 1000 mAh capacity at a nominal 3.7 V and a service life of 3 to 5 years. (And THEN they want you to buy ANOTHER ENTIRE DEVICE! Not just a new battery!) It sounds like you could run--extending if necessary--the wires from the Kobo's original battery to an externally mounted 18650 Li-ion battery of the same voltage.Minor points of superiority:* You can turn the Kobo Glo's light completely off.* Kobo Glo uses the epub format, which can be edited with a program such as Sigil to correct typographical errors in a book or other document.* Kobo Glo is somewhat more flexible in the choosing of font size, line spacing, and margin size than is the Kindle Paperwhite.* On the Kobo Glo, you can also change the justification of the text: right (off), full, or left.* The Kobo Glo gives the remaining charge on the battery as a percentage, rather than merely a guestimate bar.* You can play chess on your Kobo Glo, the device being your opponent.MAJOR point of superiority:* You can expand the memory of the Kobo Glo by up to 32 Gb with a micro-SD card.It seems to me, now, that neither Kobo nor Kindle exists in perfected form. The Kindle really ought to have a memory expansion slot. The Kobo really ought to have a replaceable battery. Unless a reader exists that has both of these features, along with a reasonable array of other good e-reader features, then the buyer is advised not to buy either of them and, maybe, just stick with paperback books.I swear, I wish I'd never dumped into these electronic gadgets the $4000 or so that I've spent trying to get a capacious, functional, and reliable electronic library for myself. That's $700 for various electronic gadgets, all of which turned out to have unacceptable flaws or drawbacks, and the rest for the ebooks that, at some point in the future, I won't have any way to read. Don't be a sucker like I was. Forget the ebook reader, unless you're rich and can afford to spend a lot for something that will work only for a little while.

This is a YA novel about the Stone family, whose history looms large in the political history of the Lunar Free State. When the twin teenage boys, Castor and Pollux, try to buy a spaceship, their father intervenes and buys an even better spaceship for the whole family to jump into and go sight-seeing.Interestingly, it appears the Heinlein actually did the math for the transfer orbit from Earth to Mars. I'm a celestial mechanic, and I checked it myself. Yes, he did. (However, his references to a Venus departure are incorrect in regard to timing, and his calculations for a transfer orbit from Mars to a part of the asteroid belt "near Ceres" probably contained an error that would cause the Stone family to end up in a part of Ceres' orbit that is 180 degrees around the sun from Ceres. But hey, the guy was a fiction writer, not a JPL astrodynamicist, so he did pretty good.)

Katharine Kerr should be better-known and read. I've read all 15 book in the Deverry universe, and the first eight are excellent. The latter seven are, if not excellent, still quite good. For me, something went out of the series when Jill died.The story is about a struggle between good and evil, with magic being used on both sides. The Celtic metaphysical paradigm of etheric and astral planes, and out-of-body travel, and shape-changing to animal forms is used quite a lot. Some of the early stories aren't closely associated with each other. Or at least it doesn't seem that way until later books pull the threads together.

Jack Vance could really write. There just isn't anyone quite like him putting out stories today. Madouc is a young princess of faerie heritage who can't help getting into a lot of mischief, despite the cruel punishments that her foster parents (the king and queen) inflict on her for it. If they catch her, that is. Anyway, in the story there's a war, and there's a good-guy hero who eventually meets up with Madouc. And in the end her nasty old foster parents get what's coming to them.

Kindle Paperwhite had the potential to be an excellent ebook reader. Even with the intentional limitations and defects, it's still fairly decent.First, there's no SD card slot for expanding the Kindle's internal memory, which limits the user, per storage space, to about 1000 books, unless he takes extreme measures to remedy this defect. For me, the remedy was to buy a Samsung Chromebook--which has its own issues, by the way--and a small SD card drive with a USB 2.0 connector. The Chromebook will mount the SD card drive and the Kindle, though not both at the same time, which lets me transfer Kindle ebooks to the SD card.While it's true that my desktop computer can do this, too, I was aiming for a book backup system that runs on batteries that can be recharged using a solar energy charging system that I've put together. In case civilization collapses, or something, and there's no electric power from the utility company.Anyway, by spending a hefty amount of money ($249), I got that done.Second, although the Kindle has enough internal storage for, perhaps, 1000 books, its file management system doesn't seem robust enough to handle that many items. I had set out on a major book buying spree, loading up my Kindle with all the books I'd already read in paperback and more books that were judged must-reads by fantasy fans. By the time I had maybe 600 books on my Kindle, it had some sort of nervous breakdown. I got a message on screen that said something like "frame error" and the Kindle rebooted.I did not have any trouble with uneven lighting. From low to high, my Kindle Paperwhite is very close to being evenly lit.My Kindle Paperwhite still lets me read ebooks, but it has become clear that this device won't serve as a portable library as I had hoped it would when I bought it. At least I can still swap books between the Kindle and an SD card by using my Chromebook.Edited (1 September 2013): The Chromebook didn't work out due to its own hardware/software flaws. I've bought a tablet that--I hope--won't be yet another marketing swindle. Also, my Kindle is back up to 574 books, and so far it's working okay with all of them.

Raymond E. Feist's "Magician: Master" delivers a fast pace, action, tension, summary histories of Kelewan and Midkemia, and a very satisfying wrap-up at the end.  In all of these, it excels its prequel (Magician: Apprentice) by a wide margin, but the same characters that starred in the first book (Pug, Tomas, Arutha, Martin) also star in this one, and nearly all of the heroes end up marrying the girl, princess or elf queen of their choice.  They also have grown up and, in one way or another, come into some sort of hard-won maturity and power.The pace of the story is kept rapid, in part, by Feist's leaving out the boring details of days of travel by sea - except when something really exciting happens, like a battle with a warship or a passage through the Straits of Darkness.While "Apprentice" was a good book, "Master" is a better one and would have been truly great if a bit more Midkemian natural philosophy been woven into the story.  Like: "Why are goblins nasty?  Are they born that way, or is it something they learn in Goblin School?"The main irritation of the story turns out to be a necessary part of the plot: when Macros tricks the elves and dwarves into betraying the peace conference with the Tsurani Emperor.The major unresolved plot element involves something known only as the Enemy, a vast and powerful entity capable of destroying an entire universe, from whom mankind fled in ages past to colonize other worlds through ancient rifts in space and time.  Macros instigated the betrayal at the peace conference as a means of closing the rift to Kelewan, in order to preclude the possibility of the Enemy using the rift to find Midkemia.Will the Enemy find Midkemia anyway?  Maybe a future book by Feist will answer that question.

The Spotlight review by Rich Chiavaroli, "A Page Turner", conveys much of what I would confirm.  Raymond E. Feist's book, Magician: Apprentice, is a competently written fantasy story that will hold your interest throughout.  While it is a good book, it is not an great one, and by that I mean there are no moments at which the reader is overwhelmed with passion in sympathy with any of the characters.This is not really a harsh criticism.  Most authors manage it only once in a while.  Piers Anthony, for example, did it only once that I know of: when Mach shouted "Thee...Thee...Thee..." to Fleta after she had jumped from the top of a cliff (at the end of Out Of Phaze).  Many stories don't have these superlatively poignant scenes, yet they are still good stories.Magician: Apprentice has three main characters - Pug, Tomas and Arutha.  Pug is the title character, the Magician's apprentice. Tomas is his friend.  After Pug is captured by the Tsurani (about 3/4 through the book), the viewpoint shifts briefly to Tomas, who has found a magical sword and a suit of magical armor that makes a sword-swinging hero out of him.  Later, though, the action leaves Tomas in Elvandar and joins Arutha as he returns to the keep at Crydee.
