The rest of the book is about how Arutha assumes command of his father's (Duke Borric's) soldiers and fights off the Tsurani invaders by his heroic and inspirational leadership.Several other characters are very important, including Kulgan (the magician to whom Pug is apprenticed), Roland (a friend and rival of Pug's), and Carline (the princess who loves Pug and Roland...both).Martin Longbow and his fellow tracker Garret provide some comedy on the battlefield as they trick one group of enemies into chasing them into another group of enemies, as mutually opposed to each other as either of them is to the Crydee faction.Pug doesn't do much magic in this story.  After he saves the Princess by casting a spell, he's pretty much a spectator until he attacks the Tsurani by the rift and gets himself caught.The story is fast-paced, interesting, and well-told.  But it is obvious that Magician: Apprentice is a set up for the later books in the Riftwar Saga.

The title of my review says it all.  If you're in junior high and have attention deficit disorder, then this book might be for you.If you can't ponder life in all its subtlety, if you will miss anything that is not made obvious, if you can't tell what a story character is thinking unless the narrator supplies his thoughts word-for-word, then you should probably read the Dragonlance Chronicles from start to finish.To be fair, the book has an excellent plot.  If you've read Tolkien's "Lord of the Rings" trilogy, you'll probably recognize it.  An archfiend of some description, while trying to conquer the world and bring it under the shadow of his/her evil, searches for some sort of artifact that can either magnify him if he obtains it, or destroy him if, instead, the heroes of the story get their hands on it and dispose of it properly.In order to carry out their purpose, the heroes have some sort of meeting and at some point there is a big war, which, ultimately, is a distraction from the true quest of finding the magic artifact and disposing of it properly.So, yeh, Dragonlance Chronicles uses basically the same plot as The Lord of the Rings.  But Tolkien did a vastly superior job with the storytelling, and LOTR is part of the finest and most definitive literature of the 20th century.  DL Chronicles is a hack job.  As hack jobs go, it's not too bad.  But the characters have a toy-soldier quality, and the story is told in such a way that you can imagine Margaret Weis pushing the Tanis toy-soldier here and saying "Bang-bang, die you villain" while Tracy Hickman pushes the Kitiara toy-soldier there and saying "Not so fast, bring me the crown."I've heard it said that Dragonlance Chronicles reads as it does because the authors were trying to follow Dungeons & Dragons gaming rules.  If so, then it would appear that there is limited crossover value between games and novels.Readers under age 13 will probably enjoy this series.  The story has a fast pace, lots of (inane) emotion, many (cheap) action thrills, and just enough sex to flatter teenagers into thinking that they're grooving with the grown-ups.  And it's because it DOES have THAT audience that I give this book three stars, rather than one.  But readers over 20 will find their eyes rolling much, and they will soon become impatient with the characters' introspective shallowness, their repetitively knee-jerk hyperemotionalism, with the way the narrative revelations too obviously come from a narrator, and with the frequent shifts in viewpoint.Older fantasy readers will want to avoid Dragonlance and choose Feist's Riftwar Saga, or Modesitt's Saga of Recluce, or George R.R. Martin's Song of Ice and Fire, or David Eddings' Belgariad.

If I could, I'd give a copy of this comic book fantasy to every police officer, sheriff's deputy, and constable in the world.  The story told is that of a Medieval morality play, in which what is right and what is "officially proper" are at odds with each other, as they often have been (and still are) in the real world. The "hedge knight" Duncan the Tall is a symbol for every good man who defies or fights an evil System for a noble cause.  The story offers a reminder that while laws are written by men, morals are not, and that the world is sick when one forbids what the other requires.Seeking fame as a knight, Dunk and his recently acquired young squire go to a tournament.  During the games, one of the king's grandsons, Aerion, takes offense at a puppet show being shown by a young woman puppeteer, so he "arrests" her and begins to beat her, breaking her fingers, while his guards hold off the crowd.  Duncan hears of the trouble, charges through the crowd, tosses the guards every which way, and falls on the princeling in a fury of fists and feet.Knights must protect the weak and defend the innocent, even if the oppressor is someone with rank.The princeling's guards finally subdue Dunk, and the Aerion has threatened to break out all of Duncan's teeth and then disembowel him, when suddenly Duncan's squire appears and orders Aerion's guards to back off.  And they do.  It turns out that the squire, whom Duncan had known as "Egg," is in reality a prince himself, shamed so badly by his brother's degeneracy that he ran away from home to live among the peasants.Duncan is charged with treason and held in a prison cell, not allowed to participate in the tournament games.  Ancient laws give Sir Duncan the choice, either of having a hand and a foot cut off, or to face the prince in single combat.  Duncan chooses the combat.  The same ancient laws, however, give the princeling an option.  Instead of facing Duncan alone, he can insist that he (and his party) fight Dunk (and his) in a sort of collective duel in which seven knights face seven knights in a joust-like battle -- but with real weapons of war, not with tournament mock weapons.  The battle would continue until one side yields or until all the knights on one side are dead.The problem is that Duncan is a "nobody," whereas the princeling can count on the help of several of his royal relatives and can command members of the king's guard to fight on his side.  When Duncan protests that he knows of no one who will take his part, he's told (by Aerion's father) that his failure to come up with six champions to fight beside him, in the single day before the battle is to begin, will prove his guilt - the idea being that the world is full of good men, and good men always fight for a just cause.It is an assumption that is largely false, and the pretense to the contrary is no doubt highly convenient to those in power.  But, nonetheless, Duncan does find six champions, despite the treacherous defection of one who was expected to volunteer.  The last of the champions was Aerion's uncle, Prince Baelor, heir to his father's throne.  Of all the royal characters, Baelor is the only one to concede that Duncan did right to punch Aerion in the face, and he is taking Duncan's side for the same reason that Duncan fought Aerion to save a puppetteer.The best moment of the book, though, is when Duncan enters the field early and is joyously mobbed by affectionate peasants.  Duncan - never the brightest knight in the realm - asks himself out loud why the peasants love him so well: "What am I to them?"His answer is a reply from the armorer who made his shield: "A knight who remembered his vows."

With Dragons of Winter Night, Weis and Hickman continue telling the tale of their heroic adventurers.  I won't detail the story here, since that's been done in other reviews.  I'll just tell you what most of the other reviewers don't.The stylistic flaws that the reader found in Dragons of Autumn Twilight will be noticed also in this book, which is its sequel.  The story has a "not filled in" feel.  The characters seem force-marched through their roles, as the authors sacrifice introspection to gain speed of pace.When a story is told well, a reader can anticipate the feelings of characters a few seconds before reading the narrative that confirms them.  But that's usually not true in this story, just as it wasn't true in its prequel.  Every glance is a jolt.  Every reaction, a surprise.  Well, okay, it isn't quite that bad: but it is almost that bad.The viewpoint jumps around erratically, as the narration informs us of the feelings of this character, and then of the feelings of that character, rather than revealing those feelings more subtly.  The reader thus gets an impression of the narrator's presence as an intruder in the story, which places a burden upon his suspension of disbelief.  You aren't able to "live" in the story because it remains too obvious that you are being "told" the story.In general, readers continually estimate the probable thoughts and choices of a storybook character with remembered reference to that character's past experiences.  In superbly written fantasies, present actions are rooted in, and are naturally developed from, those experiences.  Dragons of Winter Night, however, is not superbly written, though it's probably worth reading if you're in solitary confinement.  The authors have made it a habit to give their characters such knee-jerk reactions that the story seems a bit hokey.Despite all the narrative blather about codes of honor, dignity, or some such thing, which is evidently intended to mitigate the effect of those knee-jerk reactions, the characters have the maturity of easily provoked children.And there are discrepancies in the tale that the writers should have avoided.  For example, while Gilthanas and Silvara are smooching on a rock above a river, Silvara releases her hold on a blanket, which falls into the rapidly flowing water, presumably never to be seen again.  In the next chapter, the party sleeps in their blankets, with no mention that Silvara no longer has one.  Is Silvara carrying a suitcase full of blankets that the authors forgot to mention, or does Silvara have one of those magical, boomerang blankets that keep returning to their owners?Reading Dragons of Winter Night brings to mind the phrases "cardboard mansion" and "genuine quartz."  Still, this second novel in the Dragonlance Chronicles is slightly improved over the first.  The scenes remain rough-hewn, and the feel of the action and dialogue remains shallow, but not quite as much so as in the earlier book.  It's as if Weis and Hickman were (very slowly) adding levels to their Storytelling Skill.We all have to learn our skills at some point, and every author goes through a learning curve.  The Dragonlance Chronicles (or as much of them as I've so far read) aren't too bad, but they certainly do not deserve most of their billing.  They've been much over-touted.  The comparisons with Tolkien's fantasy are ridiculous and insulting to Tolkien's vastly superior craftsmanship.It's difficult to account for this mediocre series' quick rise to eminence in fantasy, and many of the five-star reviews appear to have come from reviewers who, if they aren't shills, may be more responsive to the "bandwagon" effect than to their own judgment, such as that might be.  The Dragonlance Chronicles appear to be aimed at the teenage or preteen audience. The shallowness, the inconsistencies and the viewpoint shifts probably won't bother the bubblegum crowd as much as they do older readers.  If you read and enjoyed this book as a youngster, you might find nostalgia carrying you through a second reading, much later.The most accurate customer reviews of Dragons of Winter Night, other than this one, are these:* great when I was 15 and immature. But now...Reviewer: Erik Vanasch "Spartan Soul" (Folsom, CA)* A seventh-graders dream; an adult's nightmare, March 8, 2000Reviewer: A reader* How old are you?, April 14, 1999Reviewer: A reader* Best of the series, April 24, 2003Reviewer: Joshua Drake (Agoura Hills, CA)* The Second Book, the First Chance to Commit, September 7, 2000Reviewer: David Rudel (Charlottesville, VA)Believe me, the 1-3 star reviews are far more reliable than the 4 and 5 star reviews, at least from a mature reader's perspective.If you'd like to read an author who does well what Weis & Hickman do poorly, read "The Wheel of Time" series by Robert Jordan.  Although Jordon is infamous for the way his WOT plot has gradually thickened in much the same manner that concrete hardens as it sets, he does an incomparably better job at characterization and character interaction than Weis & Hickman do.If you want to read a series that keeps the plot moving along, without the shallowness of the Dragonlance Chronicles, read "The Saga of Recluce" by L.E. Modesitt, Jr.  Modesitt occasionally commits diction blunders, usually a confusion of place-names, noticing which won't delight you as much as finding the eggs on an Easter Sunday, but his characters are deeply introspective, and their actions are well-grounded in their past.  Plus, it's clear in Modesitt's stories which character is the main character, which are the villains, and which secondary characters are of importance to each.  Weis & Hickman tried to execute a "committee of main characters," and this does not seem to work as well.

First, the good points.  The book is fast-paced, has lots of action, and tells an interesting story.  So what's to complain about?  In a word: style.  The pace is fast, but with the speed of the action comes a shallowness, a lack of introspective depth that leaves the mature reader dissatisfied in much the same way that The Hardy Boys series might.  What's great when you're eight isn't as fine when you're thirty-nine.Whether conveying consolation or conviviance, the dialog is often platitudinous.  The authors could have spent a little more time creating dialog that proved that the characters were capable of original and ponderous thinking.Certain details are omitted that should have been included to provide set-up for an important later event.  For example, early in the book Tanis discovers that the door to Tika's cottage is open, despite his conviction that it had been closed and bolted.  Why was Tanis sure of this?  The authors don't say.  The reader, flipping back through the pages, trying vainly to find out who had closed and bolted the door, or who SAID he was going to close and bolt the door, or who had been SUPPOSED to close and bolt the door, finds nothing to justify Tanis' mistaken belief.  The reader thus becomes annoyed for having wasted his time.Emotions oscillate from extreme to extreme, from brotherly love to hatred and back again, with no more provocation than a few careless words.  The main characters often have strong feelings, but they are usually not based on anything that might be reasonably expected to evoke them.  When changes of mood do have a plausible basis for evocation, such as when the heroes entered the ruins of Goldmoon's tribe, their effect on the characters has a cardboard quality.  You are told that the characters feel very badly indeed about the desolation around them, but somehow the reader is not fully convinced.  That might be because Tanis and Riverwind have the emotional complexity of Frank and Joe Hardy; i.e., none to speak of.The "serious" combat scenes are usually implausible and sometimes just plain goofy.  At best, the reader gains the impression that time moves rapidly here, in this paragraph, but much more slowly there, in that paragraph.  At one point, the draconians are skillful and efficient fighters who easily capture the heroes.  A few pages later, these "intelligent" fiends are deceived by a simple trick and set to running hither and yon, screaming in terror, confused and disorganized, and remaining so for long enough that Sturm and Flint could break apart a fake dragon, carry off its wooden head, extract Tas, and hold a lengthy conversation about what they should do next.  This is slapstick, not serious fantasy.(Correction: The lengthy conversation in that particular episode of combat occurred during Tas' rescue from the burning wicker dragon, and not afterward.  I'd misremembered.  However, in this story there are times when it seems that enemies might show up at one of the heroes' planning discussions, expecting to fight, but being told by Caramon, "Go back to freaking out.  We aren't done talking yet."  And the villain does indeed turn around and run away, and apparently none of the other heroes even noticed he was there.)Another conspicuous flaw is the too-rapid shifting of viewpoints, from Tanis, to Flint, to Sturm, back to Tanis, to Raistlin, to Goldmoon, back to Tanis again, to Tasselhof, to Caramon, again to Tanis...  It is possible to have more than one viewpoint character in a book, but the shifts should come less rapidly.  The viewpoint should stay with one character long enough for the reader to fix in his mind how that one character regards each of the others.  Weis & Hickman bounce the viewpoint around as if it were a basketball, with three or four shifts occurring on a single page.Despite these flaws, the story is a good one.  The stylistic awkwardness may be compared with a chair made from good, but unfinished, wood.  Had it been sanded and polished, the chair could have been a work of art; instead it's a merely rugged chair that puts splinters into unwary butts.  In the same way, Dragons of Autumn Twilight could have been a masterpiece, but it was left in a rough state of storytelling with annoying splinters.

The biggest difference in Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11, in contrast with other documentaries, is that it does not bother with the customary phony facade of objectivity. Most documentaries are politically motivated propaganda meant to lead their viewers to false or distorted impressions, by what they emphasize, by what they leave out, by speculation or rumor insinuated to be proven fact, etc. One common trick is to speak the truth as it were through a mouthful of garbage so that it seems to emerge with a stinking odor that causes most listeners to disbelieve it. Or to set up a villain (actually, an actor) who speaks the truth with his tongue obviously in cheek, so that the listener will get the impression that he is being lied to. The producers of "historical" documentaries know a thousand tricks of deception, and outright lying is only one of them. Michael Moore must be aware that the public falls for the slick tricks that are standard fare in other people's documentaries. He simply did not use them. You know right away that he doesn't like the president. Rather than condemn him for "hating" Bush, at least appreciate that he didn't hide his personal opinions, as many other, less honest propagandists, usually do.

This is a fantastic production of Parsifal if you can tolerate modern adaptations. I generally prefer a traditional, as intended, production but there are times when the modern adaptation works. In this case, it works beautifully.Remember, you're reading a skeptic. I almost dreaded seeing what is going to happen to Kaufmann in this opera. Sure enough, they get his shoes and shirt off but the silliness ends there. The acting and singing in this production are pretty close to perfect---again, Kaufmann isn't the greatest actor in the world though he well may be the best tenor. However, acting befuddled and confused suites him perfectly in this role.I don't think he fully assumes the title of keeper of the Grail and Spear collection at the end of the opera. He still doesn't really seem to get it. I give Kaufmann a B+.Pape on the other hand hits it so far out of the park that they'll never find the ball. Acting and singing is perfect. He nails it. A+Katarina Dalayman is really good Kundry. She seems to understand the personal hell that Kundry faces daily. She wants to do good but is owned because of her transgression. This is a tough role very well performed. Solid A for Katarina Dalayman.Peter Mattei is a terrific Amfortas. Man, I feel your pain. A+Maestro Gatti steers the orchestra for 4 1/2 hours of perfection.I cried at the end. It's that powerful. It's that good. Watch an act each night and savor it. This is well worth adding to your collection. It's a beautiful work of art.The staging? I thought it was rather interesting. It delivers the right message at the proper time. No, you don't get people in knight costumes running around a castle and you get a meadow scene with blooming flowers---well, sort of. You do get a good feel for what Wagner was trying to say...Don't let the bad reviews scare you off. It's wonderful. And I'm very critical.

It could be worse. If this boxed set cost a penny more, it wouldn't be worth buying. At this price it's marginal. I can't recommend this after forcing myself through the awful Don Giovanni. The Don's man, his PA looks like a bum. I doubt nobility would have that seedy character around. This guy does the leg work (recruiting) and keeps the books for the Don and yet looks like a crack head from the streets?The sets look like they simply decided to save money and not use sets. The opening act is almost funny as our Don gets tangled up in the curtain while making the kill.Then you get your ears pierced by that screechy voice of Bartoli. I don't know if she's straining or if she's trying to shatter the screen but her singing is awful. (Disclaimer: I really can't stand her voice. It is a piercing quality that I've never liked so your mileage may vary)  Gilfrey delivers some solid singing despite the awful, dark, spartan sets. However, the extreme close-ups of his sweat dripping face detract a bit from the mood.I wouldn't recommend this set.

Wow! I was looking for a "no special occasion gift" and came across these. My expectations were exceeded! I mean, at first, I thought, maybe they sent the wrong ones. These are too nice---wait! Nope, they are the right ones.These are not only beautiful earrings, they are very well made. I wanted several to give as gifts and picked up an assortment---these may just be my favorite of the selection.Guys, you can't go wrong with these. Be a hero! Stock up before they raise the price and save them for that emergency---"I didn't forget our special day, see!" Smart guys always keep a few back-up gifts on hand...and these are sure to be a hit.Seriously, they are very attractive and well made. You can't go wrong.

These earrings are beautiful and well made. Here's the thing. You can't make a delicate looking earring that can withstand the abuse of a 10 year old. These are serious earrings for grown-ups.I like the quality. The build is solid---much better than you would expect from jewelry at this price. You can't make a delicate piece and then add enough solder to make them able to lift a bowling ball. They aren't fishing lures except that maybe the smart guy who buys these for a gift is going to make a nice catch.You just can't beat these for the money. They were a huge with the recipient of my generosity...I highly recommend you give this collection a try. The biggest problem will be deciding which one you want! I decided on several. So far, so good. ;)

These are fantastic earrings at a fantastic price. I decided to try several of these to give as gifts---occasions that come up throughout the year. These earrings have proven themselves with the test: Yes, wife approved and certified. I'm no earring expert but I've been told that construction of the clasp is one of the most important things to look for.I'm pleased to report that these are well made and cleanly soldered. You're getting a great value in these earrings as the workmanship is excellent. There's a guy's point of view---nice and sturdy! Well, my wife loves the appearance of these earrings and agrees that they are well designed and made. So there you have it.Guys, here's your chance to score a great gift that won't break the bank.I can highly recommend these earrings. Simply beautiful.

This is a bit dated and often comes off as corny. I like that it is a traditional presentation---no space aliens or trapeze artists. Making an opera movie versus taping a live performance is going to be a little different and they can do things you can't do on stage. That's great and does add to the experience. However, it's easy to go overboard when short scenes or shots can be staged.There are some extreme closeups that are almost comical. There are a few shots of Pavarotti which reminded me of one of those "Guys Night in Las Vegas" movies.You've got a great cast and very good performances. I however found the more recent stage performances better than this. It's hard not to award 5 stars to anything with Pavarotti but as mentioned, the "movie" aspect is often excessive. I really liked this one better and it's a great deal:"An exhilarating live recording from the Opernhaus Zurich stars acclaimed baritone Leo Nucci as the namesake of the opera, alongside the inimitable Elena Mosuc as his daughter Gilda, Piotr Beczala as the Duke of Mantua, and Lazslo Polgar as Sparafucile."What are your thoughts?

This is a beautifully staged and well-sung opera. I wouldn't call it minimalist as some have said. While the stage is sparse, the entire theater is used. Sometimes, in some productions, that comes off a bit silly but in this production it works. The costumes are lush and interesting. They fit the period. The central characters are the least gussied up and that works well as we focus on their terrific singing rather than on some weird costume. Nobody in sweats an T-shirts. No trapeze acts. No Nazi uniforms. Imagine that. They don't even bother with rivers of fake blood.The acting is better than I'm seeing lately in many 5 star, top of the line, big name productions.The singing is in French but done "Italian Style"? Funny, I have a little coffee business and we sell French Roast, Italian Style. It's a big seller (our best) so I wouldn't be too critical of that! The singing is wonderful. The cast sings their hearts out. I love that feeling when I finish watching a DVD that makes me wish I could personally applaud the cast. There are great productions and there are good productions where the cast connects with the audience and delivers an authentic opera experience. Opera was entertainment for the masses---think about vendors hawking food during an opera. These operas, romances, good guys vs bad guys, sword fights, evil priests, pokes at the nobility---these are great fun. This is the sort of opera that gives us the flavor of an 18th century experience.It's a ball! I wish everyone could see this and enjoy the beautiful sounds of Bel Canto, the fun of a good story done well, and a cast that wants to deliver a good time.Loosen your tie and enjoy this opera.

I enjoyed this DVD very much. It's an interesting opera on a grand scale with lots of good music and some tunes that will make you want to sing along. If you like this opera, you will probably like this production. I love that it's not perverted by some maladjusted director who want the characters as space aliens or cavorting around in sweats. This production gives proper respect to the art of Bellini.On the negative side, the acting is sometimes a little wooden.  Nino Machaidze is the exception. Her acting is really good. There times when the other singers seem disconnected. She's all in, the males characters don't seem so. The big number of the opera lacks punch. I was anxiously awaiting it as I listen to this opera on my MP3 player often. In this production, I nearly missed it because Rival Salvar Tu Dei comes in a bit flat.The costumes are odd---the women look to be wearing metal visors. That's niggly and unimportant.Worth buying? Yes. I'm really glad to have it.

Wait! Hold the presses, the bench presses that is. There is a better jump rope.I need to do some exercise that doesn't involve joining anything or buying special shoes. Jumping rope, even at a moderate pace, is great exercise and shown to improve not only stamina and muscle tone, but also bone density. Our bones want a little impact.So this high tech jump rope shows up and I skeptically open the box. Well, it's certainly minimal packaging. Can you get a decent jump rope into a little plastic bag? Yup. Okay, so this light weight cable won't really be that easy to flip. Wait! It has a nice weight. Unlike cheap and thin ropes, this is easy to flip. It doesn't twist. You get a smooth easy movement. That's pretty cool. I was certain that it wouldn't be long enough. At 6'2", most of these things are too short and I have to bend to clear my head---yes, I've tried jumping rope in the past and have a few that became dog toys.This is not only long enough, it was too long. But that problem is solved but a very clever means of adjustment. But that's not all, the rope (coated cable really) attaches to the handles through gimbals. Really? An engineered jump rope? Indeed! You can jump, twist turn and this rope will never get twisted up. That's pretty amazing.The build quality is excellent too. This is a professional piece of exercise equipment.So after about 5 minutes I was wiped out. But after a couple months I expect to be doing better!The product is excellent. There was a very nice card in the package too. I won't say what it says in case they stop the amazing offer. But I'll say this: Order now before they discontinue that practice---READ THE CARD!Yes! I have to say that I enthusiastically recommend this product. SUPERB.

These ear rings are very attractive and well constructed. I'm not an expert on ear rings but I liked these and gave them as a gift. The recipient raved about them. They look nice---like they are worth a lot more. The main thing about ear rings is the construction. If not well made, they are going to break easily and be lost. These are solidly made without blobs of ugly solder.They arrived in a felt box making a good presentation. At this price, you can't go wrong and with the gold plating, they are sure to look great for a very long time. Worth the money? You bet.

I really like these glasses! They have a great feel in the hand and are very nice looking. At a fraction of the cost of some of the other, similar whiskey glasses, they are a bargain as well. I'm glad I found these as I can use them for a variety of applications.

I was pleased to see this is available for free as a Prime member. So, I added it to my library and started a listen while catching up some work.While I can appreciate talent in old recordings, I don't care to listen to them on a casual basis. The sound quality of this is so bad I stopped it and deleted it from my library after 15 minutes. It sounds like it was recorded on an IPhone at a concert. No, it's not even that good. Awful sound. As the other reviewer says, Amazon may mix up the covers---so I'm not even sure who is performing.
Great product at a great price. You can't beat this. Nice spicey taste! I love to have big quantities so I can use it liberally.
Meh. A basic CD of Wagner overtures. The music is great but there is no sparkle to this recording. The sound has a somewhat muddy quality to it. This is what you'd expect from a $3 CD.
Mom cut light weight rather cheaply made jeans that do the job of being comfortable around the house.

Not sure that the reviews line up with CDs. Often Amazon mixes up which goes to what. My three stars go to the CD pictured here. The sound quality, certainly good for the time, isn't great. The editing is poor and the opera is pretty chopped up.This recording is great example of what people both like and dislike about Callas. Her control is beautiful but her voice is not. That makes this recording worth owning from a "study" point of view but if you have other, more recent, recordings of superior quality, you'll listen to them more often.This is bit like an old Caruso recording. Yes, he's great but you have to in the mood for an old recording. Maybe that is unfair? For me, I prefer other of my I Puritani CDs so this gets fewer stars.

These heat resistant, non-slip gloves are fantastic. Not only are they very convenient, they add a lot of safety around the kitchen. I've used mine to remove a hot cookie sheet (stoneware) from the oven. That's tough to do because stoneware is heavy and it gets very hot. So doubling up the pot holders and one-handing it is tough and dangerous. These gloves border on providing super powers as I can reach in and with BOTH hands lift out a very heavy stoneware bar pan.Ok, so as a pot holder they are great. Have trouble opening a jar because the old wrists just don't have the strength the used to? Glove up! You can twist the top off if it was glued on. Seriously, they make opening a jar much easier and again, they eliminate slippage.Here's a dandy problem. I love those Reynolds Turkey Bags. Turkey comes out great every time. You can overcook it an hour and have a moist, tender turkey. But there's a problem. A 15 pound turkey isn't easy to extract from that bag when done cooking. That's a downright dangerous event because the bag sticks to the bird. So while you're trying with forks and tongs and spears to lift the turkey out of the bag---whoops, the wing splatters hot juices across the room. Oh my, don't drop it or there will be boiling turkey juices everywhere. The bag, the bag! It's stuck to bottom. Harry! Get over here quick, pull that bag away----wait! I need to get it to the plate---no pull the bag, yes I know it's hot. Hurry, I can't...crap.Well, problem solved! Cut away the bag, lift out the turkey and with those super powers just use your red hands (gloves) to pull away the bag without a single plop of boiling juices taking out an eye. Amazing. You can easily get the bag into the trash, pour the juices into a sauce pan and make gravy. While the gravy simmers---hey, keep those gloves on---you can wash the turkey pan even though it's a bit hot you won't get burned and you won't drop it (Mine is Corel giant, deep lasagna pan) and the gloves get cleaned so you can rip the legs off the turkey and GET CAUGHT red handed doing it. Arrange nicely, hold the thing down and carve. No burns.This is a great gift item. Anyone who does anything in the kitchen will use them and think of you every time they do. It's not every day to find an item that is useful and adds safety. And, so many kitchen things are more trouble than they save. Not these. Easy to use, easy to clean.You cannot go wrong.

Sometimes an opera can be pure fun. Here's a great example.This is an older recording so don't expect HD. It's a standard 4:3. The singing is good, not great. There are times the tempi seems rushed. Some of the staging is a bit confusing---the opening scene made me laugh out-loud as this giant....errr, battering ram...heads toward the audience and we're riding it in.All that and 5 stars? You bet! Some operas are just sheer fun. The audience is exuberant and it's contagious. It reminds me of what it must have been like in the 1800s. People applaud and "bravo!" every aria. It's really fun.Il Trovatore is a weird opera anyway but it's packed with great music. Enjoy this "NASCAR" version! Get in there and cheer, boo, hiss and BRAVO!Get the DVD for the sheer pleasure of opera.

This is very decent production of a superb opera. The singing is very good. Behrens is great in the role of Senta and delivers near sacred music in her arias. It's beautiful. Salminen and Grundheber are superb and the lesser parts are excellently presented.The grand party chorus is terrific. Makes you want to jump up and join them---grab a mug and do it!I did find the slow camera tour of the castle during the overture to be annoying. I'd rather just watch the orchestra. There are too many cutaways to the water image. The annoyances are minor.The ending is what cost this DVD a star. The old Dutchman is boarding his ship, Senta is torn, Erik flashes his gun and we fade to a fake water image as Senta walks toward it. It's poorly conceived and misses the impact of her choice.Still, it's Wagner and done well. I would not pay top dollar for this DVD but it's a bargain at current prices. Buy it while you can still get it.

I doubt this would stop a charging dog in spite of the claims herein. I bought it to "stun" ground squirrels caught in a no-kill trap. Then I could transport them to another part of the world and free them...bad me. But this thing not only doesn't stun, they'll fight it, bite it and throw themselves at it. When it contacts fur, it makes a burn. It does not stun. Not to be too graphic but one actually chewed on the end while I was zapping him. This isn't the Spanish Inquisition so I've abandoned this idea which I though would be a humane solution. (When they escape the cage, they are crazed and I though I could slow them down, open it and step back)Also, the strips on the sides charge which could make this dangerous.It works, but not as advertised. Pretty useless really though the snap sound may deter a human.

This is a fantastic item. I love the taste of grapefruit. Add a few drops to a jug of water and you've got a wonderful grapefruit flavored water that is true to the fruit, subtle and in no need of sweetening. It's very, very good. There are no artificial ingredients. Superb.I am ordering other flavors today based on how good this is.

This production has it's quirks but to date is my favorite. Having purchased a handful of Lohengrins, I've decided this one is my favorite. There is a clean mix of the modern with the traditional---the piano scene is a bit weird---but for the most part it stays true to the intent of the composer.I am not too picky about the sound quality of a DVD unless it's very poor. Great sound comes from a studio, not a production of singers bouncing around a stage. That said, the sound is decent. The performances are excellent. I would give the singing a solid B+ and the acting an A. The acting in Lohengrin is very important. I doubt Wagner would tolerate sub-standard performance in any area, music, singing or acting. I do think that bad acting can destroy this opera and the acting here conveys the story's deeper meanings very well.Here's what I mean. Elsa approaches mental imbalance. There is a tension with her character from the beginning.  Is she the virtuous maiden or just a bit nuts? The King's herald is appropriately aloof and sterile. He serves as the referee between myth and reality. The king seems really conflicted. War is breaking out and he's got this divided territory and he must rule on whether Elsa is nuts or Friedrich is working a ploy. We feel the tension. The king looks conflicted unlike in other productions I've seen, this king looks really torn. Then this knight shows up. Is he really a good guy? The king asks that question---and in this production, he has the look of Montezuma.  Is this the return of the god-knight or some evil force? Meanwhile, Ortrud is blowing a gasket and conjuring up anything to help Friedrich prevail. The closing of Act 1 really is a mad house scene. It's beautiful. There is a coming together, an agreement, but it's chaos too as Ortrud shrieks, Friedrich crawls  off, Elsa is smitten, our magic knight croons and the king, at the top of his lungs, is basically singing "Let's get on with things!"The other DVDs seem to dilute this very weird opera. They either stage it so screwy the original philosophy is lost, or it's so bland it ends up a watered down Arthurian story. This is a profound treatise on good, evil, virtue and conflict. In my opinion, the DVD allows those themes to play out. I liked it.

The book is mildly entertaining but reads like one of the Japanese comic books. Here's a story that is about as vibrant a tale as possible with the honor of an entire culture riding on it. This novel fails to develop the characters and fails to convey any of the magnitude of the event.There's a line that just struck me as hilarious. In a bar scene, one of the boys wants to go get a potential traitor right at that moment. The wise Samurai, whoops, ex Samurai cum Ronin, says, "Do not go off half cocked". Picture the deep voice, maybe add a grunt, oh! No half cock grasshopper. The expression, half cocked, has to do with the readiness of a gun. These guys didn't have guns. No, Samurai sons [sic] do not go nuclear. I just found this book to be borderline silly.There has to be a better account somewhere. I gave it 2 stars because, based on the really ridiculous trailer I saw, this book has to be better than the movie which look like a stars wars goes to 18th century Tokyo.

I bought this CD in error while searching for a Rossini opera. Shopping on a tablet is sometimes confusing---I viewed this, somehow bought it and yuck, cannot stand it. There are many detractors of this woman's voice and I could never understand that until now. I have another CD of hers that I received as a gift. I didn't care for it and it's been on the shelf after a single listen years ago. This CD is like nails on a chalkboard. Awful screechy warbly noise.I can't understand what the other reviewers found so wonderful about this CD of ear piercing coloratorture.

This is an odd production of an odd opera. Still, it's enjoyable and I'm glad to have it in my collection. The singing is good, the acting is very good, the staging is about as good as it gets for this opera short of doing a high budget movie version.The story is strange but it is almost a modern update or parody of Die Meistersinger. You have groups---which I suppose represent the unwashed masses of opera attendees---crying for more comedy! Make us laugh! Other groups call for drama. So the opera is trying to please these clamoring masses while delivering artistic excellence. Operas are somewhat known for nearly corny plots so Prokofiev takes that to extremes and still stays just inside of coherent. That's actually pretty masterful.I won't say that I was engrossed by this opera so I'll give it 4 stars. But I have mixed feelings about that and perhaps it deserves 5. I struggle because it does brilliantly make the composer's points about much of the absurdity around art and the public's demand for what they want. Again, think about Meistersinger. Wagner makes a similar statement but does so in all seriousness to "preserve the German art form!" Here Prokofiev uses a kingdom run by a clown king who hires a real clown to cure the heir of hypochondria who then falls in love with three oranges, one of which turns into a princess. The prince is cured and the kingdom saved. In the end, the crowds are pleased. Hum?Give it a chance. It's worth a venture out to something very different. I would sure appreciate your comments.

Here is a nearly perfect production of a very difficult opera. Get it while you can. It's a treasure.The opera itself has a very convoluted plot. It can be difficult to follow the motivations of the characters, This staging is very quick paced which helps build continuity between the scenes. The set is a little bit strange---very dark. I wondered if it was meant to be a church or a torture chamber at times. The Count's headquarters are like an emergency exit from a factory. None of these minor criticisms detract enough from the performance to matter.The performances of all the singers are superb. Some of the arias are simply spell-binding. Verdi is about the music and this is a singers production. The orchestra does the job and is never in the way. This is one of the best operas on DVD for pure singing that I have seen. Every part is excellent and will have you holding your breath on some of the most beautiful long notes, diminutive expressions and leaps into high territory.When I ordered, I made an error and added this to my cart twice. It was a large order and the DVD was pretty inexpensive so I didn't notice. Now I'm glad to have a spare to loan to friends. It's that good.

This book lays bare the mythology we have bought for years about our glorious nation under god. Turns out there's a reason we believe we're special---part of the trappings of power. I agree.Every American should read this book and learn. Learn that neither party has the honesty market cornered. Nope, you can't even say that one party is a little better than the other party. The lies both parties have told us have cost thousands of American lives and trillions of dollars in treasure. From Johnson to Obama, we haven't had a truly honest man in the White House.We're not talking about little lies either. Big stuff.Please give this book a read. Then buy a few copies and give them as gifts---or curses. It's pretty rough to face the myths we believe in.

Well, here's an interesting dilemma. I generally prefer a traditional production over a modernized one. Oddly, in this case, I'm giving my preference to the 'other' Faust starring Kaufmann and Pape.This production is good, and Terfel is superb. The production is excellent though Faust (Alagna) is not, in my opinion, well acted. This has the ballet---good---and lots of interesting dance numbers. Terfel in a dress is certainly decadent and devilish but maybe too much.Gheorghiu is good in the roll though perhaps a bit past the age prime to be the enchantress. That's horribly sexist but the role is about seduction and frankly she ain't got that.I love this opera and the music is excellent. This production is very, very good. The Kaufmann production at the Met is, in my opinion, better.Now, can someone answer a question? When the devil sings the 'ring' aria he says that Catherine shouldn't let anyone in without putting a ring on her finger. Who the heck is Catherine?I'd enjoy your thoughts on this opera. You have mine.

Before you use it for this purpose, consult with your doctor.I use my MP3 player CONSTANTLY. I'm an audio book fan---long listens---and an opera fanatic---long listens. I have 'beater' MP3 players with audio books that I take to bed and often fall asleep listening. So what? Well, I developed this fierce ear itch. I know, too much information. My doctor told me to rinse the ease with some peroxide and then a drop of mineral oil. That helped but didn't clear it up---now, I'm talking about a maddening itch.I thought this is probably yeast---a little water in the ear, little air circulation because of the ear buds and presto, yeast. So I tried applying a little of this stuff into each each 3 times a day. After a week, all clear, no more itch.I give the product and the company an A+

I want to start with a few statements about my own taste in opera. First, I confess to being a rather new consumer of the art having taken a few classes and listened to opera daily for a few years. I own many DVDs. My taste is in traditional staging over modernized productions. I love Wagner's operas. I enjoy Verdi. (There seems to be Wagner/Verdi camps)With that, how could I possibly give 5 stars to a modernized staging of this opera? The staging, while modernized, is not "bare bones" as some have said here. It's modernistic, not spartan. For comparison, I recently reviewed an extremely silly production of Parsifal that takes place with the singers dressed in leaves climbing around in bushes with lighting so poor you can hardly see them. That is modernized staging that goes to the awful. This isn't whacky. It's updated.That updating gives me an initial pause. When I see these modernized sets, the production needs to prove itself to me. This production had me within 10 minutes. The performances are rare captures. The entire cast delivers a magnificent performance. This will be the gold standard for Faust [performances] in the future. The singing and acting are so good, it's hard to focus on the set. It's there, it adds to mood, but doesn't intrude. If you allow your mind to wonder about what they are trying to say with the bomb and war and nuclear labs, well, you'll miss a great opera.To be clear, the performances are excellent. The acting is moving. The staging is unobtrusive---not in the way of this superb production.So, if there is criticism, it can possibly be traced to the opera itself. Why does Faust leave the girl of his dreams in the first place? That's a big hole to leave unfilled in the story. Can't blame the setting for what isn't in the script. Gounod gives us beautiful music but as is the case with many operas, the 'plot' is a bit convoluted and the storyline is certainly flawed. Don't blame the production. When a novel becomes a movie, the producers take great liberties with the story. That can't be done with opera. Remember that.This is a wonderful opera and I highly recommend it to anyone. And, if you are relatively new to opera and want to try a modern production that is as enjoyable as a traditional staging, try this. You'll be happy with it.Last comment. The between scenes interviews are interesting but demeaning. I haven't explored the DVD to see if those corny interviews can be shut off. These "half time reports" give the opera a sporting event feel. The questions are stupid---asking Pape if he mixes up the role from day to day as in evil one day, mysterious the next, etc., is absurd. His answer is fitting. Of course he doesn't change the role from day to day, there are other singers who must respond to his part---it would be nuts to be changing it up. So please Met, stop this opera for the masses nonsense. The masses can rise. Don't stoop.Thank you for reading this. I'd like your comments.

I purchased this viewer to replace an old brass viewer in my front door when I changed the hardware to a modern, satin-nickel finish.  The old viewer required a hole 1 1/8" in diameter, and finding another door viewer that would fit that hole was definitely a challenge.  In fact, this particular viewer is the ONLY viewer I found to fit that space perfectly.I'm very happy to report that the optics in this viewer are excellent, and far surpass those of the old viewer.  I can definitely see a wide angle through the peephole, and the view is clear and crisp.  Sadly, too many viewers distort the view or are unfocused, which negates the benefits of using such a viewer.The finish on this product is smooth and works with the satin nickel color scheme.  Installation was as easy as fitting the two pieces together through the hole in the door and screwing them together.  It took minutes to complete, and looks great.

I'm a huge fan of using "green" products when possible, not only to save energy, but to reduce my personal expenses.  I ordered this 1320 lumen PAR R40 bulb in Daylight to use in a ceiling fixture in my kitchen's dining area.  I have 18 other PAR 38 65-watt equivalent LED bulbs in use in my kitchen, which uses a total of 171 watts of power.  If I used traditional filament bulbs for this purpose, I'd be using  1,170 watts of power... this is a HUGE savings as these lights are on most all day every day.This particular Satco bulb lives up to its description in every way.  It provides a bright light in the proper color tone (Daylight, in this case.)  The design of the bulb ensures that the lighting dispersal pattern is wide and truly floods the area.  Too many LED lights work more like a spot light, providing light only on the area directly beneath the bulb.I use the bulb with an electronic dimmer, and the bulb definitely dims properly according to the specifications of the dimmer.  At no time do I experience any flickering or buzzing... I suspect that those experiencing these issues may have problems related to the type of dimmer that's in use.I use Daylight equivalent lighting exclusively throughout my home... Cool White is simply too yellow for me and changes the color of my decor in an unflattering fashion.  We find the Daylight tone to be bright, cheerful and excellent for lighting task areas.  Finding bulbs in the Daylight tone can be difficult at times, as Cool White seems to pervade the market.Time will tell how well this particular bulb lasts, but my experience with similar bulbs has been excellent.  I've yet to have a bulb fail, and my home uses LED lighting for almost every fixture at this point.  The product works perfectly for my purposes, and based upon my experience thus far, I recommend it without reservation.

As a past customer of Hydracentials products, I received the Kids Insulated Resuable Lunch Bag to test in exchange for an honest review.  My opinions are my own and represent my experience with this and similar products as a consumer.While not a "kid" by any means, I use the insulated lunch bag to tote my own lunch items to work.  When I received the product, I was surprised at the quality of it's design and construction.  The bag is heavily stitched at all seams, and the handles and zipper are very durable and should hold up to a lot of abuse.  The interior of the bag is lined to prevent leaks and to ensure easy cleanup should any spillage occur.  The PEVA insulating layer is dense but not overly thick and keeps food items (warm or cold) for plenty of time for my purposes.  The bag is definitely large enough to carry adult portions of food with room to spare.I purchased a similar product from a company called Thirty-One a few years ago.  For the price I paid, I was surprised at how cheaply the product was made.  Also, it was not very effective at keeping products warm or cold.  There's no comparison between these two products except for the color and intended use... the design, construction and usability of the Hydracentials product is outstanding in every way, and the price is less than half of the price of the Thirty-One product.  For anyone looking for a quality lunch tote, I recommend this product without reservation.

I believe this was Christopher's first true foray into the romance novel genre.  I'm an avid reader of anything that Christopher writes, so I picked this up immediately to see how well Christopher could write in this genre.  My review of this work is completely subjective, based upon my own likes and dislikes, and that subjective opinion likely differs for every reader.  The romance genre is not one that I typically follow.The plot for the novella was definitely interesting and fresh.  The supernatural concept embedded in a three-way romance is definitely new, at least as far as I know.  When I picked the novella up, I did not put it down until I was finished.  The relationship of the three focal characters is emotionally charged, intensely erotic and thoroughly documented.  When the story ended, I definitely wanted more, which to me is the mark of excellent writing.

First, let me say that most any review of an author's work is completely subjective.  I can only speak from and report my personal experience of reading the novel, and that experience is likely different in some aspect for every reader.I generally love anything by Christopher Rice, so I stepped "outside the box" so to speak to read this novel.  I did enjoy the read, but couldn't completely engage in the storyline.  Perhaps that's because I seldom read novels in this genre.  It seemed like the characters emotions were somewhat blunted, preventing me from completely emerging myself in the storyline.Overall, I enjoyed the read and will continue to read anything that Christopher deigns to write.

I purchased this music to use as background music for a photo slideshow I created for a friend's memorial service.  She loved everything by Barbra Streisand.The song originates from the musical score for the play "Cats," and I believe the original version was performed by Betty Buckley.  Barbra's version of the song is excellent, although I believe the original version evokes even more emotion, if possible.

I purchased this music to use as background music for a photo slideshow I created for a friend's memorial service.  She loved anything by Barbra Streisand.  This song is a "standard" in the world of music; I think most anyone would recognize it immediately.

I have two large dining room tables that I built specifically to fit our space, so finding a pre-made pad to fit is impossible.  The cut-to-fit intention of this product was exactly what I needed.  I had enough to cover both custom tables, plus enough to use as a cover on a smaller kitchen table as well.  I use the pads all the time and they are very effective at controlling spills and definitely product the surface of the table from nicks and dings.The padding was a bit thinner than I expected, but again, it works.  The coated side of the pad must be placed facing upward to protect against spillage.  As other reviewers have mentioned, it takes some effort to get the creases out of the material.  If you remove the pad from your table, make sure to roll it up rather than folding to prevent creasing.  Someone recommended using a cool iron to help with the creases... I chose to let the pad flatten naturally, as I did not want to run the risk of damaging the waterproof coating.I did find it somewhat difficult to cut the pad to fit.  It cuts fine with some sharp scissors, but cutting it straight can be challenging due to the density of the pad, or at least it was for me.  I definitely recommend measuring and marking the pad to the appropriate size, then cutting on the lines with very sharp scissors.

I bought this to use as a free-standing microphone to use with Microsoft Windows 10.  From the product description, this seemed to be an effective solution for my needs.  It works very well... training Windows 10 to understand my speech took only moments, with no adjustments to recording levels required.  Even with background noise (in my office I have a portable air conditioner that sits less than 3 feet from my desk) the system has no problem extracting the background noise and deciphering my speech.  The microphone is a bit large, but thankfully I have enough room on my desktop.  The cord is long enough for my needs, and the red color is a nice touch in that it helps to make the mic cable stand out from the others dangling in the wiring jumble behind my system.It would be nice if the mic and stand were a bit smaller, but otherwise this was an excellent choice for my needs.  Since the quality of the microphone goes a long way to determine a system's ability to decipher speech, buying a better, full-featured microphone helps to ensure success.  I'm successfully using voice controls and dictation now.

While I haven't delved into testing the read/write timings that other reviewers have reported, I simply inserted the card into my Dell Venue 8 Pro tablet to see how it performed and if it was acceptable for my needs.  I found that the speed was actually better than I expected, as I've used a number of similar cards in the past.  The speed is more than adequate for my needs, and I think it outperforms the built in memory in the device.  Although I come from a technical background, for most users the key questions are 1)  Does the product work? and 2) Does it perform well enough to be effective for my needs?  In my case, the answer is definitely YES for both.

I've used similar dishwasher cleaner products in the past, and I can say that the Finish brand product works the best.  We use the Finish Quantum Power Free packs in our dishwashers (I have two:  A top-of-the-line Samsung Chef's Collection water-wall dishwasher, and a 6 year old top-of-the-line Kitchenaid.)  The dishwasher packs are very convenient and provide everything you need to result in clean, gleaming dishes, but the packaging for the packs melts in during the dishwashing cycle and tends to leave a film on the dishwasher.  I couldn't understand where the film was coming from, and only after quite a bit of research did I find out what was causing the problem.  I also found many recommendations for this product as a means to eliminate the film.  After a single use, the dishwasher was restored to it's original shine and was odor free.To use the product, I simply insert the bottle upside down in the silverware rack and run the otherwise empty dishwasher through a normal wash cycle.  At the end of the cycle, I remove and discard the empty bottle.  What could be easier?I buy these cleaners in a multi-pack through Amazon, and have them set up as a Subscribe and Save item for regular deliveries.  We use the cleaner in each dishwasher once per month to ensure they stay clean and fresh.  It's a great product!

I purchased these for use when replacing the electronic thermostat on my Toyota Prius.  I had three lines that had to be clamped... draining the coolant from the system is easy enough, but would require a two-hour-plus cycle to replace the fluid and to "burp" the system properly.  The repair part was $55, but the dealership estimated charges at over $500 for the repair.  After reading some of the reviews for these clamps, I was concerned as to how well they would work, but I can say that for me they worked perfectly.  They clamped the hoses completely and prevented any coolant loss without damaging the hoses.  My biggest problem was the fact that they are fairly large and I was working in a severely confined space, but they did what I needed.  For other projects where there's more room, they would be perfect.  I'm sure I'll have other uses for these clamps moving forward, but if not they definitely paid for themselves in a single use.

Using microfiber for dishtowels is not a new concept, I've been using similar towels for several years to dry dishes that I've washed by hand or that have come out of the dishwasher damp.  Microfiber towels also leave no lint, ensuring a clean finish.  What sets these towels apart from others that I've used is the fact that they are more absorbent, providing even more drying ability than any other towel I've used.  Perhaps it has something to do with the waffle-like texture of the towel, but they lift the water from the dishes and leave a dry finish in a single swipe.  Additionally, glass and stainless steel items are spot and streak free, leaving gleaming surfaces.Other great uses for these towels include cleaning windows, mirrors, eyeglasses, and any other objects that you want to have a clean, lint-free and streak-free finish.  When cleaning windows, I use a standard window cleaner and paper towel to perform the cleaning function, then use the Microfiber towel for the final drying wipe-down to pickup the remaining moisture and to remove any streaks.One thing that all potential users should note:  make sure that when you wash these towels that you do NOT use fabric softeners in the wash or dryer sheets during their dry cycle, as stated in the accompanying instructions  Fabric softeners impact the absorbency of the towels, which negates the benefit of using the microfiber towels.

This footbath definitely has some high and some low points.  I've not owned a foot spa previously, but I've used others that I will consider in this review.First, the product is exactly as it appears in the photographs associated with the description.  It is indeed tall, sturdy and crafted to last.  The drain tube did drain the spa fairly quickly and completely.  I did not have any problem with the casters... they worked exactly as described, and since this unit holds 20 liters of water, they were greatly appreciated when it came time to drain the spa.PROS:-  This foot spa does maintain a present temperature, and does so very well.  Based upon my research, this is a problem in most foot spas, but this particular unit shines in this purpose.-  The pairs of massaging rollers for each foot are powerful and effective as a tool to massage the base of the feet.-  The unit is tall enough that water does not splash out.  I did not use the cover; doing so would have prevented me from moving my feet to use the massage rollers.-  This unit is HEAVY when filled with water, so having casters and a drain tube is definitely a positive.  I rolled my unit into the shower to drain.-  The water intake into the pump is screened to prevent any additives or debris from getting into the pump.CONS:-  There are no bubbles and the water action is minimal.  There is an intake at the rear of the unit and two "jets" near the front in the center of the toe position.  Water circulates through these "jets", but the force is so delicate that it's hardly noticeable to me, and definitely it does not create a bubble effect that I've experienced with other units, nor the bubble action that I understood in the description.-  The "needled massage" tool is located between the two foot wells, and is a disk with tines that you can rub your feet against for massage purposes.  The piece is stationary and difficult to use... it's useless to me.-  Other than being a deeper unit that allows you to submerge your ankles a couple inches of your lower leg, the unit provides no service for my calves.  Only a person with very short legs could find any leg benefit with this unit.While the overall product didn't meet my expectations or the description, I will keep it as I was desperately in need of a solution, and this unit does perform well as a soak.

I've got a number of wireless devices in my home, and have been using a Buffalo wireless router to service them for some time.  Sadly, hardware/firmware issues with the Buffalo device have forced me to toggle power on the unit at the least opportune times, so I decided that a change for something more reliable was required.  I do not use this for hardcore gaming purposes, so I can't speak to those capabilities.This unit exceeded my expectations.  It was very simple to set up... a few instructions make it easy even for the most novice users.  As an IT expert, this unit also has advanced setup capability to handle almost any user's needs.  My WiFi-dependent devices now all work far better and more reliably.  As a plus, my router sits in the open on a shelf near the center of my home, so this stylish looking device doesn't seem out of place.  The wireless range far exceeds that of the router it replaced.  I'm very happy with this purchase and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to others.

I bought this to use with my Dell XPS 18 tablet.  The tablet doesn't have a wired Ethernet connection, and I've been experiencing problems with the built-in wireless adapter.  I felt it would be helpful to have a means to add a wired connection to the device, and this works perfectly.  In fact, with Windows 8.1, I didn't even have to install a driver.  The additional USB ports are also a bonus in a unit that has only one.  It's worked perfectly for my needs, and it is solidly constructed (per Anker's claims) and is stylish, too.  I would rather have had black and aluminum, but function is the most important factor and every Anker product I've purchased in the past has exceeded my expectations.  This device is no different.  I strongly recommend it to anyone who has similar needs!

After reading tons of reviews, I purchased this unit knowing that other users have experienced minor issues and was prepared for that at first use.  Considering that this isn't something I use every day and it would be stored on an open shelf in my kitchen, I had to make sure that it wasn't as tall as the traditional units, and the stainless steel appearance works perfectly in my space.  It is significantly shorter than most other units, making storage on a shelf or in a cabinet much easier.  It also includes an on/off switch, which was important to me.  Plugging in some other unswitched units causes sparking and can be an issue with GFCI outlets... having a switch avoids these issues.I've not experienced the issues with unpopped kernels that some have reported... I think that may have something to do with the age and quality of the popcorn kernels along with the level of humidity where they're stored... dryer kernels will pop easier and faster.The unit works great... it takes a minute or so for it to heat up, but after that it pops a full half cup of kernels in just a couple of minutes.  The speed of trajectory is sometimes too great, and popped kernels do fly out of the bowl, but I've taken to holding a hand towel in front of the unit to prevent these kernels from flying all over the place.  Cleanup is a snap... the cover lifts off easily for this purpose.I'm a fan of this unit and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to anyone who wants an air popper that's more elegant than a brightly colored plastic unit.  In fact, most who have seen it don't recognize that it's an air popper.

I bought this along with a hot pink Radio Flyer tricycle for my niece who is turning two.  Lilli is a bit larger for her size, and this helmet is a perfect fit.  The construction is very lightweight and the strap is easily adjustable.  After adjustment, the fit is perfect for her, yet there's plenty of room for adjustment as she grows over the next couple of years.  I don't have any idea how well it will perform in an accident, but it seems to me that it would offer a great deal of protection, which is all important with children under 6 years of age.  She loves the "hat," and I think it was a perfect choice for our needs.  I would buy it again.

I abhor carrying a large wallet... I seldom carry cash and I love the concept of a minimalist card case.  This one suits my needs perfectly.  With six card pockets and a larger center pocket, it has the capacity to hold all of the key cards that I used plus my ID and insurance cards.  Naturally, by the time I got all of the necessary cards in place, it is a bit thicker than I would have liked, but there's no fix for that other than to carry fewer cards.Putting the cards in for the first time was trying, and the wallet is quite stiff.  Using the cards for the first few times was also a challenge due to the stiffness and the number of cards I carry (most pockets have 2 cards.)  However, after a week or so I've found that the pockets have stretched a little bit and although the cards are held snugly, they are easy to remove for use.  I looked at virtually every option available, and this seemed to be the perfect fit for my needs.  So far I'm very happy with it and would definitely buy it again.

I received a classic Zippo lighter as a gift, but was having a difficult time finding fluid for it.  While placing some other orders with Amazon, I ran into this and decided to give it a try.  True to the description, this fluid does not have the typical "lighter fluid" odor that I'm accustomed to, and the fluid doesn't leave a taste with that first inhale when you light a cigarette.  While perhaps a bit pricey, eliminating this odor and taste is important for me, I and would not hesitate to buy this again in the future.

I'm always looking for new chew toys for my 100 pound Pitt Bull, and this seemed like it was worth a try.  My guy chews through virtually any toy I give him quickly, and his love for chewing is limited to toys, so I'm happy to keep him supplied.  This particular toy has been in his possession for over a month and is still not falling to pieces, and it is still one of his favorites.  For me, that's the highest kudos I can give.  I do recommend it for those hardy chewers who make mincemeat of most of the other "durable" toys out there... I will be buying more of these in the future!

First of all, let me say that the Pillsbury Cookbook is unparalleled... it's my kitchen Bible, my go-to every time I look for a recipe.  I own the 1986 hardbound version, and my poor copy is falling apart.  I thought I'd try to get another copy, but when I saw that it was out of print and the price for a copy ranged upward to $500, my jaw dropped to the floor!  Needless to say, I'm not going to buy another hardbound copy anytime soon.  When I saw that this paperback version was available, I thought it prudent to get a copy just so I have a backup.My 4-star rating is specific to this paperback version.  First of all, the content is great and contains everything that was in the original.  This book is HUGE.  In order to cram all of that content inside, it's become quite thick and the print is very small.  It's just not reasonable to open up this copy on the counter while you're working, and that impact on usability is why I removed a star.  I still think that as a backup, or for the cook who doesn't have a "kitchen bible," this is a must have and is worth every penny.  The recipes contained within are "real food" made with real ingredients... optimized for taste and quality and not some fanatical health fad or diet.

While I love the Bar Keeper's Friend scouring powder, I didn't find this foam cleanser to be all that exciting.  I've used in on a number of surfaces and I've not found it to be any more effective than any other spray cleaner.  If I need to scrub something, I find myself still pulling out the sponge and the normal BKF to get the job done.  I would not purchase this product again.

I bought this as a replacement for a similar stand I purchased 6 years ago... the old one finally failed.  I love these... we have several trees, and all have rotating stands.  The trees always end up in corners where I live, and this ensures that all of the trees beauty is revealed.  Also, my holiday guests always comment on the rotation... it seems many aren't aware that such stands are readily available.I love my stands and wouldn't hesitate to repurchase when necessary.  These are quiet... I use them on hardwood floors... and they work great.  Just make sure that your tree doesn't get bound against the wall or by gifts under the tree, as that CAN damage the mechanism!

I love this product, and sadly it's becoming VERY hard to find via normal retail channels.  I tend to have a reaction to caustic chemicals, but this stuff cleans great without all of the odor.  When used as directed, it makes quick work of greasy, hard-to-clean pots and pans.  What most people may not realize is that it works great to clean up your oven, or your cooktop.  If someone's car leaks a bit of oil on my concrete driveway, I can spray it with this product and remove most (if not all) of the oil stain.  I understand that mechanics often use it to degrease tools or parts, too.  There are many, many uses for this product, and it does a wonderful job for all.  I cannot understand why such a useful product would disappear from the retail marketplace.This product is the equivalent of the retail version, however it's packaged differently (for industrial use) and is a larger quantity.  I don't care about the packaging, as long as I can get the product!

I bought two of these a few years ago for use in a Synology network attached disk storage device I use in my home to share files, movies, music, etc.  They both worked great, but recently one failed.  Fortunately, Amazon still had them in stock (at a VERY reasonable price, I might add,) so I was able to get another that I could swap into my system.  After a couple of hours, all of my data was synched and stable again.  I also bought a spare to have on hand in case the other original disk fails.  ALL disks fail in time... it's just a matter of when, and you need to be prepared.

I recently upgraded my phone to an iPhone 6plus, and purchased a similar case for it which I absolutely love... it's the best case I've found.  Since I decided to give my iPhone 4S to my partner to use, I added this case and I'm very happy with the result.  The bumper edge on the case does help to protect the phone from minor drops or falls, and the clear backing on the case doesn't cover up the phone.  The front edges do protrude a bit, enough to ensure the face on the phone is not resting on the glass when sitting face down on a table.  I don't know how well this would protect from a 6' drop onto a hard surface floor, but for my everyday use of my phone, this is a great choice.  I recommend it to those looking for a case that offers protection and makes the phone easier to handle without adding bulk.

While I've not yet had a party to use this set, I've tried it out just to see if it will keep ice without melting, and it works great.  This is a great design... nicely contemporary and fits well with the rest of my dcor.  The bucket it large enough to hold a good quantity of ice, and the double wall design definitely helps to maintain the temperature in the bucket while preventing condensation on the outside.  I like the provided scoop, too... tongs are OK, but I particularly like the spoon-shaped design of this scoop and think it will be very useful.  We'll find out on Christmas Eve!

While looking for item #5133502 to complete a set red and green glass set I'd purchased from Mikasa, I found this ornament-shaped candy dish and it was a perfect accompaniment to the versions I'd already ordered.  The dish is perfect for my needs, is relatively heavy and is well made.  I suspect I'll be using these for years to come.  As I mentioned in the review of a similar product, these would make great gift items, too!

This is a cute, useful candy dish that I bought for use during the holidays.  I particularly like the ornament shape and design.  This was a match to a red and green pair that I purchased from Mikasa... this particular design was not available through them, but fortunately Amazon had it available and I was able to complete the set.  The dish isn't as large as one might expect, but it's perfect for my needs.  I bought a few extra to give as gifts this year, as we're making quantities of homemade candies to give to friends for the holidays.  This is a way to turn a simple gift into a more lasting memory that can be used for many seasons.

After upgrading to an iPhone6plus (from an iPhone 4S,) I found myself in need of some extra Lightning to USB cables.  Buying quality cables such as these through most retail channels is quite expensive, and for no clear reason.  This cable met my needs... a longer, 6ft cable to ensure mobility, and a solid, lasting design that wouldn't come apart with wear and tear.  I bought this one as it suited all of my requirements, but couldn't know of the precise quality until I received it.  Upon receipt, I was quite happy that I'd chosen well.  This exactly meets my needs, and was a substantially better buy than similar products.  I wouldn't hesitate to repurchase if/when I need additional cables.

I went to great lengths to find the set of coffee cups that I wanted.  They had to be 16 oz or greater, contemporary in design, solid in color, and easy to hold.  I found these and had to give them a shot... and so far I love them.  The simple grey exterior with a white interior is a perfect fit into my color scheme.  The large loop handles ensure that even my large hands can hold the cups without any concern of dropping them.I ordered 4 mugs of these to try them out, then ordered 8 more the day I received the first 4.  In the second shipment one of the cups was broken, but I was able to get a replacement on the way on the same day... making returns to Amazon is incredibly simple, although I've seldom had to return anything.If you want a classic coffee cup, consider this choice.  My guests and I love them, and I'm sure others will too.  It's comfortable contemporary and stylish, which makes is a perfect fit for my world.

I love my Voyager Legend headset... it's the absolute best headset I've been able to find.  My only real complaint about it is the short, USB charging cable that comes with it.  It's only about 8 inches long, and magnetically attaches to the headset for charging.  I've found it difficult to locate the headset/charger so that it's convenient and out of the way.With this charging stand all of my problems are solved.  It has a lengthy cable, which eliminates part of the problem.  The base is weighted and solid, so it stays where you put it.  Like the cable, it magnetically holds the headset in place during charging, and has a light on the base so that you can see when the headset is charging or fully charged.  For the sake of convenience, for someone who uses and charges their headset daily, this is very much a worthwhile add-on.  I strongly recommend it for Voyager Legend users.
