All of this had me reading just one more chapter.Original/Fresh storyline: From the world to the characters Neill created a world I am anxious to return to. I loved how down to earth and normal Claire was. While the males had alpha tendencies, she added some depth, particularly with Liams backstory. The ending was climatic and had me holding my breath. Neill even managed to surprise me with a little twist and reveal. The threat in this first installment was handled and I appreciated that the ending didnt feel rushed. She has created unlimited storyline possibilities with this motley crew of characters and I am curious as to what will happen next.Copy provided by publisher/original review posted at caffeinated book reviewer.

While the previous books were laden with angst, suspense and danger, Brand of the Pack focused more on shoring up the relationship between Morgan and Greyson as it introduced a new threat. Shanley has created an engaging series and I quickly slip into the story despite wishing for a full length novel. To her credit, she tells a tight tale and I guess one should appreciate being able to slip away for an hour and enjoy a good story.Brand of the Pack wrapped up the romantic aspect of the series but also opened the door to a new threat. I am anxious to learn more about this new danger, and see the White Wolf Clan strengthen. Shanley continued to add depth to her characters while weaving in some sweet moments. While this installment wasnt as action packed as the last few, we did get some battle scenes, a good dose of humor and a little snuggly time. Greyson continues to be his smexy self and is becoming comfortable in his decision to form his own pack.The world building and clan structures are fascinating.  The author continues to strengthen and flesh out this world. Secondary characters add substance and threads like those of a jealous she-wolf have me oh so curious. The bonding ceremony was interesting although not as ritual rich as others I have read. Unlike the previous books which ended with a cliffhanger, Brand of the Pack has more of a closed ending as it hints of what we can expect in the next installment. Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer.

The tale surrounds two thirty-something characters whose upbringing has them swearing off long term relationships. When Victoria Slade, a successful divorce attorney suffers panic attacks after a home invasion, she temporarily moves into a condominium for the summer until her newly purchased condominium is available. A shared bedroom wall and poor sound proofing soon have her exchange banter with smexy, single investigative reporter Ford Dixon. The tale that unfolds had me consuming this in a single evening.Suddenly One Summer is a novel the reader will easily slip into, they will soon find themselves laughing, wiping a tear and  becoming fully invested in this couple. The secondary characters weaved throughout gave this novel a small-town community feel and enhanced the story. The depth of the story from the fleshed out characters to the couch sessions with a therapist both surprised and delighted me.  James weaved in delicious banter, page melting heat, humor and side stories that held weight.Both carries scars from their childhoods but are survivors with successful careers and strong social networks. Victorias personality and her need to be observed as normal by others was one I am sure many women can relate to. There is a story about Fords sister that I found especially touching and I loved the way it caused Ford and Victoria to interact. We do get some miscommunication but it was realistically done and not overly drawn out.If you are looking for a feel good, swoon-worthy summer read with a small-town feel and a little heat then you cannot go wrong with Suddenly One Summer.Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer

First Date: Holly Bell is a  single divorced Mom and has the night off. She decides to take an unauthorized walk into her future home after learning the bank accepted her offer. Holly has big plans for the rundown Craftsman and has spent the last five years saving to realize those dreams. The events that unfold have me giggling and annoyed when we discover Dan Amador has outbid her and now owns the house. These two have chemistry but I would not exactly call it sizzling, unless thoughts of frying up Dan are romantic. I have a feeling we are in for a ride.Second Date: I love this quirky little town.Dan is a bone-headed idiot at the moment, but I have hopes.  The banter between Holly and Dan slowly develops into friendship and more. Saint weaves in wonderful secondary characters from the other Amador brothers to Hollys daughter. We get plenty of banter as Dan makes some assumptions that quickly get him in trouble with folks. It was fun watching him make amends and discover how wrong he was. Holly is a perfumer and I liked her snark and independent streak. Saint does a wonderful job of fleshing out Dan and bringing me around to liking him.Third Date: Growing pains, a little two-step and some ah ha moments had me flipping the pages, swooning a little and losing myself within the story. When I began reading, I did not realize this was the first in a series. In fact, I often felt like I had missed something regarding secondary characters and eventually stopped reading to see if this was perhaps the third book in a series. I was surprised to find it was the first. Secondary characters piqued my interest but felt information was lacking. I enjoyed the romance, which was slow burning and offered passionate kisses and eventually some heat.Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer

The Night We Said Yes is a second chance romance that includes fleshed out secondary characters, and a summer night reliving the night, they said yes. The tale is realistic but be warned it portrays underage drinking and is filled with dorky, sweet moments and friendship.I loved how the tale unfolded using alternate chapters of then and now. The then tells the story of the first night Matt and Ella or El met. Gibaldi shows us those first moments of a budding romance, of the getting to know that special someone. She gives us all a glimpse at the chemistry, that awkwardness and adorableness as it unfolds. We also met Els best friend Meg and her volatile relationship with Jake. The now chapters take place almost a year later. Matt moved away six months early without any closure and has returned hoping for a second chance not just with El but their friends too. He tries to recapture that first night. It was sweet and had me shaking my head, feeling for both of them and laughing aloud.While I certainly cannot condone some of their behavior from trespassing to underage drinking, Gibaldi kept it realistic and still managed to impart common sense such as not drinking and driving or vandalism. It evoked memories of high school years.Matt and Els romance is adorkable and reminded me of first love. I became caught up in wondering whether El would forgive Matt and take chance. Surprisingly mature and low on angst the now chapters filled us in on everything that happen between then and now. We get a secondary romance between Jake and Meg. It is volatile and exposes their rocky relationship.The friendship between Meg and El was perhaps my favorite part of the story from memory bracelets to having each others back it truly captured those magical friendships that are a part of our childhood.Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer

First Date: Hayley introduces us to Lauren Hastings an outspoken, snarky twenty-six year old who is completing her masters degree in psychology. A night out with her best friends lands Lauren in a bit of trouble forcing her to accept a part time job for a doctor at Trinity Hospital. Right away, I like Lauren. She has spunk, a good sense of humor and the events that unfolded have me worried that this girl has the worst luck.Second date: Hello Doctor Yummy. *wipes drool* I mean hello Dr. Scott Jacobs. Scott fast-tracked through college and medical school and has taken over his deceased fathers practice. The man oozes confidence and charm. Sure, he has commitment issues, but I have no problem admiring the view. The sparks are zinging around the office and poor Scott is at a loss for words. The wicked banter and one-line zingers have me eager to see these two tango. An arrangement of sorts develops and while I can see the writing on the wall, I am all in. Hold on to your book dear reader as things are about to get heated.Third date: Despite the intense heat Hayley allows a friendship to grow, pushing both characters past the boundaries they have set. We get to learn about their friends and family giving the story depth. Hayley fleshes out both Scott and Lauren exposing the real reasons behind their commitment issues and allows them to share personal experiences. Their stories were genuine and this late date was filled with a little angst and some of the sweetest, swoon worthy moments. Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer.

I have always found novels set during this era to be fascinating even as I try to wrap my head around the atrocities. Bruce brought us two very interesting characters. She delivered a tale that shares the struggles of individuals while giving us a sense of the war itself and its impact. I appreciated her attention to detail and the way in which she brought these characters to life.Eleana is a Russian widow, who works at the hospital as an aid, but secretly works with the black market. She reads banned American and British literature and believes in God. She finds herself assigned to a hospital near outskirt of the war, and eventually is assigned to the front-line as medic. It seems the fates are against her when she is assigned to be a Night Witch. These female pilots dropped bombs on the Germans forcing them to retreat.For most it was a death sentence flying about in these tin cans.  Eleana is strong, passionate and at times fearless. I found her to be remarkable and Bruce did a wonderful job of allowing me to connect and gain insight into what her life must have been like. Bruces descriptions of her transformation and internal struggles felt genuine.Friedrich is a German professor and architect who covers up his disdain for the Third Reich by becoming a German lieutenant. He works at a concentration camp and gives us a harrowing account before he is assigned to fight with troops invading Russia. Friedrich is not as strong of a character as Eleana.  He does what he must in order to survive. One cannot help but question how we would handle the situation. Is he a coward or survivor?The two accidentally meet and find themselves holding up on a Russian farm during Russias harsh winter. It was fascinating seeing these two enemies relying on each other and discovering how very different the other is from their own preconceived notions and of course, from the propaganda their leaders have fed them. A friendship forms out of necessity and soon they are confessing their sins and darkest fears. The two become lovers and eventually hatch a plan to desert and escape together. Their time on the farm felt very genuine from their distrust to their need to feel safe and loved.Death Steppe: A World War II Novel shares a love story but do not look for happily ever after. Bruce beautifully captures the brutal landscape of war while weaving in the effects upon humanity and individuals. It was sometimes dark, sometimes beautiful, and at times incredibly suspenseful. The words flowed wonderfully allowing me to become completely immersed in their story. While the ending was awash in sadness Bruce also gave us a glimmer of hope befitting such a tale. Copy provided by author, full review at caffeinated book reviewer.

The first in An Ember in the Ashes series, Tahir brings us a roman like world filled with gladiator type military schools, slaves and an oppressed society ruled by violence and fear. The author did an excellent job of bringing the world to life from the impressive academy to the slums.Dual perspectives gave us both sides of the story. Elias is a solider at the academy who dreams of freedom and an escape from the violence that rules his life. He unwittingly finds himself competing to be the next Martial emperor. Laia is a Scholar, living under the control of the emperor, but when her brother is arrested and her grandparents murdered, she soon finds herself working undercover in hopes of freeing her brother. The chapters alternate between the two and I immediately became wrapped up in their stories. Laia is an unlikely hero, in fact if given a choice she would be in hiding, but it is her love for her brother that drives her and her transformation alone was worth the ride.Tahir delivers a dark tale that touches on the darker side of war, and the sacrifices on both sides. The emperor faction is dark and blood thirsty, with political maneuvering and quests for power. Scholars and slaves are treated like commodities in this quest. In the middle of it, all we have a rebel group. The Revolutionist, and we learn that Laia has ties to them; she uses that connection to aid her brother.What strengthened this novel and gave it its heart were the protagonists. Both are struggling and see tremendous growth and enlightenment throughout the story. The tale is surprising romance free although seeds have been planted. I loved these little teasers they gave a little hope to all the darkness. I thought a triangle was in the making, but with one line, Tahir squelched that and I was delighted. An Ember in the Ashes is dark and falls on the higher end of young adult genre making it a great crossover novel.Fiona Hardingham and Steve West did a splendid job with the narration allowing us to feel Laias and Eliass internal struggles, fear and growth. The choice to use two narrators was a good one and I hope these two continue the series. Audio provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer.

Learning your ABCs has never been more fun..from the vivid pictures of bugs to the tongue twisters accompanying each photo in The Alphabet of Bugs. Each page opens with the Letter of the Alphabet on the left side of the page and a tongue twister and on the right side a colorful picture of a BUG! Unusual bugs, dare I say beautiful bugs. They are detailed and quickly caught my granddaughters eye. The bugs are placed on colored backgrounds and the sentences teach not only the bug name, but a unique color as well. For example, Mason Wasp Magnificently mimics Moccasin or Katydid keenly kicks Keppel The book is intended for preschool to kindergarten but will require a parent who is good at pronunciation to read them. My husband and son enjoyed reading this as much as Sophia liked the pictures.

The focus was on Leisel and Evelyn and they had this whole Thelma and Louise vibe about them. Leisel is extremely broken when we first meet her, and I will be the first to claim I wanted to slap her and yell, Snap out of it bitch! She felt more like the first character to be killed in a B-horror movie, but then Alex said something about her strength and I realized he was right. From that moment on, I changed my attitude about her and watched as the authors allowed her to grow and become this little kick-ass. I am woman hear me roar. I loved the transformation. Evelyn, Alex and secondary characters added to the tale and I lost myself listening. At just under 12 hours, I consumed this over a two-day span listening into the wee hours and finding excuses to slip in my earbuds.C. J. Bloom did an excellent job of narrating giving both Leisel and Evelyn clear voices. This was important since the story switches perspectives each chapter. Her male voices were especially pleasant and did not have that gruff weird tone that many female narrators give to male parts.Thicker Than Blood was dark and twisted at times but the gore is rather low making it a listen even non-zombie fans will enjoy. Thicker Than Blood wraps up nicely despite having a slightly open ending. It appears there will be another book and I for one will be snagging it on audio.

Ooo we begin with wicked banter and snark. I am dancing a little I love these hater begins, it leads to heat. Logan is drop dead gorgeous and Ive been waiting for his story. Since I have known him since Echoes of Scotland Street, I am willing to ignore his man-whore ways on our first date. I know what lies beneath and I am not talking about his killer abs. Logan is starting over and life looks good. He has a good paying job, has paid for his mistakes and it totally making up for lost time with all sorts of extracurricular activity. All of which has cast him in a bad light with his sexy, uptight neighbor Grace. Grace is normally soft spoken but her new neighbor has her verbally sparing with him. I am hooked folks. Hooked! These two are destine to dance and it is going to be wicked.Life is about to throw Logan a curve-ball and somehow Grace finds herself assisting him and the more Logan steps up the harder Grace falls. I will not tell you what the curveball is because well, spoilers darling. I will tell you it is sweet, complicated, and wonderful. If I had a soft spot for Logan before I am a puddle on the floor at this point. I love the friendship that begins to develop between Logan and Grace. It feels natural and allows them to really see the other. The complication adds interest, awe moments and stole my heart. We get some heat and it was deliciously hot.Copy provided by publisher. Full review at caffeinated book reviewer

eveneves had a realistic vibe that makes you stand up and take notice. Instead of aliens attacking or a meteor bumping Earth out of orbit, Stephenson created a scenario that felt realistic. Fans of the Martian will enjoy Seveneves although be warned there is a lot of technical jargon. From the characters to the technology Stephenson offered up a suspenseful tale.Get your geek on. I loved all the technical jargon from how they built things to handling resources. It was truly fascinating and I found myself completely caught up. It delves into so many aspects from mining asteroids using tiny robots and housing folks as they build. Then there is the whole process of determining who will be placed on board the ship to ensure humanities survival. The story the governments tell folks sent me chills it was so realistic.The story is broken up into three parts. The first shares the catalyst and humanities plan to preserve the species. The second part focuses on Earths final days and the final section unfolds five thousand years later as the survivors of humankind return to Earth. The action scenes were suspenseful and beautifully described giving me a panoramic view as events unfolded.I was disappointed that the segments werent balanced and that we spent the least amount of time learning about the return. The last two hundred plus pages was intense and some of the strongest writing.Seveneves is massive, and generally, I do not have a problem with that. It is also a standalone, but in this instance, I really would have preferred this to be a trilogy with the three segments being balanced. Who knew I would encourage a trilogy?

We learn about the first time Donovan Pate and Sofie Martin tangoed. Let us just say Donovan didnt make the nice list and it changed both of them.  Now we fast forward to the present and Sofie has created a wonderful business in town.  Donovan has returned after his grandmother passed leaving him her estate. He plans to sell it and learns the house has been contracted out to host a charity event. Um, guess who is handling the event. *hehe* Yep, Sofie and oh how the sparks that fly when these two are in the same room. Right away, I am in lust over Donovan and looking forwarded to seeing these two tango.I love how Lemmon weaves in secondary characters and already I see the promise of another romance with Sofie and Donovans friends. I already love the dance Lemmon is providing in Rescuing the Bad Boy but then she introduces a dog to the mix making me fall further. I loved the old estate and the youth group who is the recipient of the charity event. Friends and banter had me giggling. I laughed so hard at moments and was grinning from ear to ear. Donavon and Sofie cave into their needs and I suggest you get some oven mitts because these are some of the sexiest, hottest scenes. Did I mention Donovan has tats? The story behind them will make you turn to mush, so grab a tissue and truffle.The author does a wonderful job of fleshing out the characters and sharing their backstories particularly Donovan. He may be a bad boy, but it is all a faade and seeing what lies beneath will have you adding him as your latest book boyfriend. I love second chance romances and on this last date, we faced a few bumps as our characters experienced growing pains but Lemmon more than made-up for it with a wonderful epilogue. Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer

Crave is first in the Undone series and I am anxious to learn about all of the characters we met. Layla and Michaels story was bittersweet and I quickly consumed Crave.Layla is a successful business women who once had it all but things fell apart by an unexpected tragedy. In her darkest hours, she craves what she once held dear. Michael is attracted to Layla and knows exactly what she craves. I love how he takes control but allows Layla to feel as if she is taking the lead. The man is hot and his sensitive side is so sweet. Laylas reaction to him felt genuine.This explores the early stages of  a dom/sub relationship and it was beautiful, tender and fresh.  I would hate to classify this as BDSM, since this just dabbles on the fridges and takes a more realistic approach. If you liked the vibe of Bare It All by Lori Foster, you will enjoy Crave. Even though it touches on the subject, the tale is low on heat and details. Instead the author focuses more on the emotional aspect as Layla heals and finds herself.Dawson gives us a full romance, allowing the characters to become friends, trust and find something meaningful. The slow development and delicious tension created as these two tangoed captivate me. Their story felt genuine allowing me to connect. We also meet secondary characters that tickle our interest and whose stories we hope to soon hear.Dawsons grasp of human emotion brings this story unexpected depth. While she brings heat, she also gives us a couple whose passion, pain, love, and emotions we experience first hand. Layla and Michaels romance is one you will remember long after you close the book.If you love Foster, Kaye and Dawsons Something New series youll love Crave and the Undone series. Each book will work as a standalone and feature characters we have met along the way

Bette Lee Crosbys writing: Is magical from her descriptive writing to the easy flow in which her stories unfold. She offers unique characters with depth, lovability and manages to allow me to slip into her stories and lose myself.Memory House Bed and Breakfast: located in Burnsville, just outside Richmond Virginia is a quaint home surrounded by a garden with a sign half hidden. The owner runs an apothecary shop in the front and has two rooms available for guests. The white house is situated at the end of Haber Street and the owner never advertises as folks have a way of finding Memory House when they need it. I love that the house itself is like a character.The Characters: Ophelia Browne is almost ninety years old. She knows her time here on earth is limited but she is spry and intelligent. She tends her garden, mixes herbal remedies and has the ability to read memories in objects. She collects them and keeps them safe. I adored Ophelia and found myself envious of the time Annie spends with her. Her story, gift and presence were delightful. Annie Cross is at a crossroads. She has recently broken up with her boyfriend of seven years and is frustrated with work. She decides to take off for the weekend and soon finds herself at Memory House. We learn about her troubled romance and experience the growing friendship with Ophelia. Ophelia shares her gift with Annie and I loved how their friendship grew and strengthened.Narrative: The tale is delivered mostly in third person with chapters weaved in from Annie and Ophelias perspective. While I enjoyed the tale, I found myself particularly drawn to their first person perspectives as we grew to know them and learned their secrets.Magical Realism: I loved the concept of Memory House. Watching Ophelia share her stories regarding objects and Annies determination to unlock secrets from one object in particular. The tale is sweet, light and perfect for a rainy evening. I truly enjoyed the characters and was sadden when the story came to end. While Crosby chose to leave it open-ended, she gave us enough that creating our own happily ever after was easy. I closed this book with a smile while wishing I had some dandelion tea.Copy provided by author, full review at caffeinated book reviewer

What I liked:London hooks the reader from the opening pages making us very curious about what is happening to Caroline and Jack. I wanted to know who they were, why they were in trouble and what was happening.The story has chapters both in present day and of those in the past. The chapters in the past make up the majority of the tale as we meet Caroline and Jack and witness their romance unfold. In between, we get chapters on what is happening both to Caroline and in the United States. These chapters were suspenseful and oh how I wanted more.The romance is a slow burn with friendship, heat, and growth. London fleshes out the characters taking us into their personal lives as well as their careers in government. I enjoyed both Caroline and Jacks characters. Of the two, we get to understand and identify more with Caroline. She is strong, confident and as a politician, she tends to be bi-partisan and relentlessly stands by her convictions in the all-boys club.From the chapters in the present we know Caroline is injured and have an inkling of where Jack is. It is the why we do not learn about, at least not yet. Caroline is injured and we meet other characters such as doctors who go beyond in their duty to help her. We know there is civil unrest, the government is like a regime and that states are seceding. These chapters held me riveted and I was begging for more.The story has a nice flow and is well written. The reader can easily identify where they are in the story.What I didn'tThe romance between Jack and Caroline is fully fleshed out and developed slowly. Normally this is a good thing and to a point, it was but after a while, I started skimming. I loved that they developed a strong relationship but the getting to know each other slowed down the story. Conversations on books they liked, plays, and movies became overkill. While the synopsis clearly states Dissident focuses mostly on their romance I ultimately ended up skimming through some of their tete-a-tetes . I would have liked the romance slimmed down for more chapters in the present. Maybe in book two I will appreciate the depth but I wanted more action.This is a six-book commitment and the books must be read in order. I am hoping we get more depth from the dystopian angle in future books. As a romance despite some heated moments I am not invested enough. However, the present day situation really drew me in.While the book has been edited, I personally felt the book would have benefited from being more balanced between past and present day. Copy provided by author, full review at caffeinated book reviewer.

Our protagonist, Lila Merriweather is a tough, orphaned thief who makes her home in the basement of a library in a town filled with magic. The story takes place in Cloudburst Falls, West Virginia where tourists come from all around to see pixies, Fae and monsters. Rich families who are constantly feuding run the town. Estep brought the world to life in vivid three-D imagery from the troll on the bridge to the pixies preparing meals.The characters were unique from zany Mo to the cold and manipulative mother of Devon. Lila is a colorful heroine who I quickly warmed up to. Lila is young and has some baggage but she is also street smart and in some ways wise beyond her seventeen years. Fiercely loyal she has several talents. She is content attending high school by day and thieving by night but she unwittingly finds herself involved in protecting one of the royal families sons after intervening in a deadly fight. A certain grumpy pixie about stole my heart and the attention to detail with this secondary character was amazing.The story Estep weaves is magical, filled with action and growth for Lila. I would love to see this made into a Disney movie. I can just see the Sinclair mansion on the big screen. Weapons, spider spun jackets and rare talents amped my enjoyment of the world. I have a feeling with the right narrator this would be an amazing listen on audio. Estep weaves in several storylines from the feuding families to Lilas own past. She satisfied my need to know while leaving room for more details as the story progresses. Villains, a mysterious stranger and betrayal added danger.While there are hints of a budding romance, Estep did not bog this tale down with unnecessary drama, insta-love or triangles. Instead, she hinted at a slow-burning romance.  This added a few swoony moments and left us with the possibility of a future romance. I l found it to be refreshing. The tale wraps up nicely, giving us closure but also an idea of what is to come leaving the reader satisfied. Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer.

Touching, tender and with secrets that could rip them apart I quickly became caught up in their story. Sofia has always been the most fragile of the Santos family and has the deepest scars. I was worried about how Robson would handle the romance between her and Killian.I enjoyed watching this delicate romance with its tender moments unfolded. Their story was not an easy one to share. Killian carries guilt for what happened to Sofia and blames the events on himself. Sofia carries not only the memories of that painful event but also the dark path it led her own.Robson tackles some tough issues including domestic abuse, rape and molestation. She tackles these topics head on and does not gloss over the darkness that grows from them. At its heart, the story is about healing and finding love and forgiveness. Of being ok with the past and moving, forward. She also weaves in secondary stories involving other characters. Wren, Killians sister and Finn both have me curious. Robson even gave us updates on previous couples as we see Mateo and Evie, and heard from Brody and Lety.While I still am not a fan of the angst, miscommunications and volatile relationships typical of the new adult genre, I do love the heart that Cecy Robson brings to these characters and enjoyed Once Pure. I am looking forward to the next books in this series. Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer

N.D. Byma was kind enough to send me a hardcover edition of The Letter and Sophia and I quickly began reading.  The story is beautifully illustrated both inside and out by Amanda Grove. The colors are vivid and the font used for telling the story is cute. Each page offer a few sentences making it easy for early readers to follow along. The story begins with a little girl trying to write a very special letter at the park. Unable to think of the words she sets it on a park bench. Throughout the day folks find the letter and add to it. This was fun, adorable and added a little suspense from things happening to the letter to finding out what it says. Sophia while very little loved the vivid images and of course Nonnas hilarious narration and sound effects. I can definitely see why The Letter is a readers favorite. Its message is sweet and the adventure was fun. The Letter is available in Hardcover and as an eBook.

t is a character reunion! So many characters begin appearing at the convent and it was delightful seeing them and learning new developments. Jones takes secondary characters and gives them pivotal roles for future novels. Folks you will not be able to set this down. Call your boss now. You need a mental health day.For fans, this book might make you pee your pants a little because we get answers. I am talking big answers! Ones that have driven us crazy for example, Who is Mr. Wong? or Who sent the twelve hell hounds? and so much more.Twists, turns and oh baby, Reyes is in trouble! Jones continues to surprise me and it is clear she knows what direction she is taking this story and these characters. It is one hell of ride. While we see some of Charleys wit and sarcasm and get some heated moments with Reyes this story is much more serious. The ending was brutal but it is not a cliffhanger. Jones likes to deliver these zingers and while it is clear where we are heading the last chapter will bring excitement, tears and have you contemplating driving to New Mexico for an advanced copy of Dirt on Ninth Grave. Unless you are up for a road trip and possible jail time, you will just have to wait like the rest of us for January 5, 2016. Copy provided by publisher.

This wonderful, beautifully written story left me with a smile and an empty box of truffles. It had all the feels with realistic issues, fleshed out characters and story that you will want to share with others. If you have abandoned NA or want something refreshing then I encourage you to grab A Shattered Moment. I may have read this by accident, but I fully intend to continue the Fractured Lives series and read more of Tiffany Kings work. Copy provided by publisher, full review at caffeinated book reviewer

I'm a longtime user of a Dove's beauty line because the products usually deliver on their promises. I also love Dove's campaign to help build self confidence and self esteem in young girls and women of all ages. I use Dove's softening body daily but with the colder months around the corner I thought that I would try their Deep Moisture wash. I was not disappointed! This wash is creamy and a little bit goes a long way. My skin felt moisturized and super soft. Certain scents trigger migraines for me but this scent didn't. It smells fresh, clean and lovely but it doesn't linger and overpower my perfume. On another note I really, really like the new bottle with the pump. It is much easier to use than the old bottle. I highly recommend this body wash fir people with normal to dry skin.

My six year old first grader is transitioning from reading children's books to reading chapter books. I selected this book for him because the premise sounded unique and the illustration on the front looked fun. As predicted, this story held his interest from start to finish and he really liked the black and white illustrations (which I also thought were super cute). This story made him laugh and also sparked a new fascination with Yeti folklore. This is an entertaining story that contains thoughtful lessons for younger children that parents will appreciate. 'The Yeti Files' is the first book of a new series that we will follow and I highly recommend it to advanced first grade readers and up or children ages 7-10.

This is one of the best moisturizers I've ever used! It's so rich and creamy and leaves my skin feeling hydrated and soft without any greasiness. I'm a 39 year old female with very sensitive skin. My skin type is normal with an oily T-Zone and I have some redness on my chin and around my nose. This moisturizer not only leaves my skin feeling amazing but it also tones down the redness I have. My 44 year old husband has very sensitive, combination skin with slight rosacea. He's been using this moisturizer for two weeks and he said that this is his new favorite. The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because I don't care for the scent which is very faint but it smells like old lipstick. My skin loves this moisturizer so the scent doesn't bother me enough to stop using this. I highly recommend this to both men and women who have sensitive skin that's prone to redness.

Jack Black is one of my favorite skin care lines because they make high quality products that have always delivered on their promises. Unfortunately this Glycolic cleanser didn't agree with my skin. I'm a 39 year old female with normal skin and an oily T-Zone. My skin is very sensitive and I'm prone to occasional hormonal breakouts. The first time I washed my face with this cleanser, I noticed that my skin felt very dry and tight. I immediately put moisturizer on and although it helped, my skin still felt very irritated. It's been four days since I used this and my skin has reddish dry patches on my cheeks and chin. I realize that this product line is targeted to men but I've been using Jack Black skin care products for years and I've never had a problem until now. I will continue to use my favorite products from this line, I just can't recommend this one to people with sensitive skin

This screen protector was easy to put on my phone. First I cleaned my phone with a microfiber cloth then I aligned the protector holes with the speaker and camera. It wasn't perfectly aligned the first time I tried, so I pulled it off and I got it right the second time. So even if you make a mistake, it comes off easily and is easy to readjust. There are a few bubbles on my screen but they don't bother me and they aren't a distraction. What I like the most about this screen protector is that my makeup smudges wipe off much easier from the protector than they did on the actual screen. This isn't perfect but I like it a lot.

This case is made with nice quality materials that hold my laptop securely and is nicely padded to keep it protected during travel. The strap is sturdy and I trust it to hold my case. It opens easily and my laptop is accessible and easy to use while it's still on the case. I trust this product and I recommend it to others.

My first impression when I felt this lotion was that it's too watery but once I rubbed it into my arms and legs , my skin just soaked it in. My skin felt so soft and not at all greasy like I expected. The scent is a very fresh citrusy scent that is not overwhelming. It very common for scented products to give me a migraine but this one didn't. My husband also uses this lotion and he doesn't have any complaints, which is a good thing because he is a man of few words unless he dislikes something. We both have normal to oily, sensitive skin and neither one of us had any breakouts or issues with this lotion. The fact that this is paraben free, alcohol free and made with organic ingredients are huge pluses! I recommend this to both men and women who like a citrus scented lotion that will make their skin feel incredible.

This toaster oven has been a great way to cook food without heating up our entire home using the full sized oven. With this toaster oven we have the option of baking, broiling or toasting food. So far I've used this to cook everything from pork chops and chicken to corn dogs and taquitos. All of the food has been cooked evenly and thoroughly. This comes with a cooking rack, a baking pan, a crumb tray and tray grabber. The rack and the pan can be positioned in three different slots and the pan is dishwasher safe. This is the first toaster oven I've ever used and I've enjoyed cooking with it. I'm really looking forward to trying different recipes. This is a sleek looking kitchen appliance and the stainless steel will compliment most kitchen decor. When considering the space needed for this, I want to add that this oven needs 6" on each side and 6" from the top for proper air circulation. Dimensions are: Width 19.38" Depth 14.49" Height 11.81"

I'm a fan of Johnny Shaw's first book from his "Jimmy Veeder Fiasco" series, 'Dove Season' and this story is another action packed, violent, exciting adventure involving best friends Jimmy Veeder and Bobby Maves. The fellas go in search of Bobby's fifteen year old daughter after her mother calls asking Bobby for help when the teenager is missing. If you liked 'Dove Season' then you will probably enjoy 'Plaster City'. This story also has an exciting chain of events and the same crude humor that is really just what I consider "guy humor". For readers who have not read Dove Season', this book stands out on its own and it's not necessary to have read the first book. Although that's a really fun and exciting read also and I highly recommend them both. I really got lost in this story and I enjoyed every minute of it.

My 6 year old son is a lanky boy who is 47 inches tall and he weighs 45 lbs and the size small fit him exactly as I hoped it would. It's not skin tight nor is it too baggy. He could easily wear a thermal shirt or pants underneath if it's cold on Halloween and if it's not, he will still look great. The length of the jumpsuit fits him perfectly as well. I deducted one star because the mask is supposed to attach in the back of the child's head with elastic strings and Velcro but the Velcro doesn't stick together. Also one of the lightening bolts was folded over in the package and now it doesn't stick out the way it's suppose to. However, my son LOVES this costume and he runs around the house at super speed every time he wears it. His joy makes this costume worth very penny.

The key feature that attracted me to this coffee maker is the all-in-one grinder and brew basket. The easy to clean basket can be used for whole coffee beans or ground coffee. I've been using whole coffee beans for the last couple of weeks and the basket does a thorough job of grinding the beans and I must add that the smell is intoxicating! There are other great features like the option of selecting brew strength, a programmable timer and one of my favorites, the sneak a cup feature. ln my opinion this is a sophisticated coffee maker with great features that is really easy to use. We really love this coffee maker and we're planning on buying one for my in-laws for Christmas.

This is the most adorable mirror for baby girls that I've ever seen! By gently pushing Cinderella, baby will hear one of five princess phrases. To me the phrases all sound like Cinderella but there are twinkling lights that light up the pictures of Baby Rapunzel, Belle, Snow White and Ariel. There are a few ways to activate the sounds and lights: 1) waving the "magic wand" which is actually a rattle (my favorite) 2) rolling the rollerball 3) moving Cinderella. The set up is super easy. You simply snap the base legs into the mirror and its ready to go. It's no secret that babies love looking at their reflection in mirrors and with the eye catching colors, lights and sounds, this is perfect!

Although this recommended age for this building set is 4-8 years old I ordered it as a project that my three year old daughter and I could do together. This is her second Mega Bloks set, the first one is a Hello Kitty set that she really enjoyed working on and this one brought her just as much enjoyment as the first one. Some of the pieces are very small (as expected) but I was really surprised with how tiny Chelsea and her puppy are. Although my daughter has passed the stage of putting things in her mouth, I would only feel comfortable with her playing with this in my presence. She and I really enjoyed putting this together and I highly recommend it for older girls or as a project for preschoolers to work on with a supervised adult.

My three year old daughter loves this Alexa doll because she is so different from the other dolls that she has in the Barbie line. Alexa sings snippets of two different songs by moving her arm that is holding the wand. Her bodice also lights up when she sings which adds some magical glamour to the brightly colored princess gown. I highly recommend this Alexa doll to Barbie fans because she actually does something other than just look pretty.

When we pulled the package out of the box I immediately felt overwhelmed and in over my head. I asked my husband to help our son put this model kit together and he was very happy to oblige. With 109 small pieces that snap together this is a time consuming project that my boys thoroughly enjoyed working on together. The directions were very detailed and easy to follow but there were still moments of shared frustrations. The recommended age for this is 8 years and up and that is accurate. My son is 6 and he basically worked as my husband's co-pilot on this project but when they were finished they were thrilled. Nice quality model that doesn't need scissors, glue or paint. This would make a great gift for older children and adult collectors.

My three year old daughter, six year old son and I put this set together. My daughter is younger than the recommended age but with our guidance, she was able to help build and she loved every minute of it. My son is a huge fan of Mega Bloks sets (Skylanders in particular) but he didn't mind the Hello Kitty theme because it belongs to his sister and he was able to help build and use his Mega Bloks expertise. Some of the pieces are tiny and some parental help will be needed for the younger children. The finished product is smaller than you would expect but I've noticed this with all the Mega Bloks and Lego sets that we've bought. That being said, this Hello Kitty set is adorable and my daughter loves all the bright girly colors. We are pleased with this Mega Bloks Hello Kitty set and I will be purchasing more to start a collection.

I had forgotten how much fun Twister is until my family and I started playing this recently. My children have so much fun and their big belly laughs are music to my ears. My three year old is a little too young to play without help, however this is a great way to teach her the difference between her left and her right. My six year old son loves playing Twister and this is great way to get the family moving and stretching. There is a reason that Twister has been a fan favorite for so many years and I highly recommend it!

My three year old daughter has had a blast playing this super fun and clever matching game designed to use as a teaching tool. The object of the game is to be the first player to spot a match between two words, two pictures or the word that matches the pictures. Although this is more geared towards teaching older children the beginning stages of reading, my daughter is able to match the pictures with the pictures.These are small round cards that come in a small tin container that can easily be thrown in a purse. This is a really fun way for children to learn word recognition nd I highly recommend it!

This is a really fun, fast paced matching game that is a great teaching tool for young preschoolers. My three year old daughter loves Doc McStuffins, so this is a theme that holds her interest and this game has been very helpful in teaching her to recognize numbers. Even my six year old son enjoys playing this with her. I highly recommend this game along with Spot it! Disney Princesses - Words and Spot it! Frozen - Alphabet to inspire learning in a really fun way for little ones.

This story is so beautifully written that I devoured it in two days and I would have finished sooner if I didn't have to do things like feed my family, shower, sleep etc. ;) This author is a truly gifted story teller and I was completely lost in this story that broke my heart, made me laugh and infuriated me. Maggie is an African-American psychologist who is married to an East Indian man and because of that she is assigned a new patient who is an East Indian woman who had attempted suicide. While trying to figure out why Lakshmi tried to end her life, she realizes that this woman is incredibly lonely, homesick and stuck in a loveless marriage. Maggie and Lakshmi's connection to Indian culture and the fact that they both lost their mothers at a young age bonds them and a friendship is born. Unfortunately, the friendship is unethical and unbalanced. Through the course of their relationship secrets, betrayals and self-revelations are revealed. Ultimately, this is an incredibly captivating story that really hinges on forgiveness. There are small flaws like how unlikable Maggie turned out to be. Her indignant attitude towards her husband and her lack of compassion when Lakshmi confesses her deepest secret were very hard to swallow. Especially given the fact that Maggie held some pretty big secrets of her own. However, what I struggled with the most was the way the story ended. I love this story, I was invested in this story and I cared about these characters (even Maggie) so I felt disappointed with the abrupt ending that left me completely in the dark as to what happened between Maggie and Lakshmi and between Maggie and her husband Sudhir. That being said, I still LOVE this book! I love Thrity Umrigar's style of writing and gift for story telling and I'm looking forward to reading her other novels.

This is a super cute book in a new series about four sister's (Spring, Summer, Autmn and Winter) who are the daughter's of Mother Nature. This book is Winter's story involving themes of friendship, jealousy and feelings of being left out. I read this story to my 6 year old son and 3 year old daughter. My daughter is too young for a chapter book and this didn't quite hold her attention the way it held my son's. He particularly liked Flurry, Winter's best friend who happens to be a polar bear. Even though this book is targeted more towards girls, my son really enjoyed the story. This is a great chapter book for children about age 6 and up. The black and white illustrations are really cute and there are good lessons to be learned in the story.

My three year old daughter was giddy with excitement when I pulled this game out for us to play. Like many little girls, she is Frozen obsessed and that being the theme of this fast paced matching game helped to hold her attention and keep her interest in this game. So far this has been a fun tool to help teach her the letters in the alphabet and I'm positive that in continuing to play, she will recognize all the letters very soon. This game comes in a very small, round tin box that is easy to throw in a purse and travel with. This would also make a great stocking stuffer.

This is the most adorable umbrella and it looks ever better in person! The bright pink and red colors are eye catching and the black details are a nice contrast. My three year old daughter loves the clear "see through window" to see where she's walking and I love that it curves down instead of sticking out and poking people. My daughter can easily open and close this without the worry of her fingers being pinched. This is lightweight enough for a toddler to carry but big enough for an adult to use as well. I highly recommend this umbrella.

This is a very sturdy caddy that fits all of our shower essentials easily. The top shelf has three openings to hold bottles that are upside down, which is a unique feature that I particularly like. I also love that underneath the caddy there is a place to hang two razors. The only suggestion I have to make this even better, is a couple of suction cups to secure the caddy to the shower wall. This is wider than the one we previously had so it holds more products and doesn't stick out as far. This is a great space saver and I highly recommend it.

Elsa is preparing to host a Christmas party in the castle and the other Frozen characters pitch in to help. This story has all the elements that make Christmas fun, decorating, baking, snowball fights etc. The text is simple and easy for my first grader to read but the story is pretty short because the text is a small paragraph on each of the 24 pages. The illustrations are lovely and look exactly like the beloved Frozen characters. Also included are eight paper cutout ornaments. My 3 year old daughter loves this book and hasn't put it down since it arrived. A great book for Frozen fans!

The idea behind this toy is great but the finished product needs some tweaking.1) The web shooter is a loose on my average sized 6 year old son.2) The silly string style "web" clogs and runs out very quickly3) replacement web fluid cans are too I expensive for how quickly they run outWater can be used in place of the web fluid (and it's less messy), but after my son used the web cartridge, water wasn't as much fun. I wouldn't mind purchasing web fluid refills, except that because it clogs easily and runs out fast, I just can't justify the cost. This is an ok toy that has limited features and may lead to children feeling frustrated.

I get so excited whenever I get new kitchen gadgets, utensils and pots/pans, so I've cooked dinner with this pan for the last four nights. I love it! This cast aluminum pan is very lightweight, I can easily hold it with one hand (unlike the much heavier pans that I own). This pan is coated with Ecolan, which is a "professional grad non-stick ceramic coating that uses earth's natural substances" and is free of PFOA. I've cooked chicken breasts, pork chops and steaks without using cooking spray and there weren't any problems with the food sticking. My food cooked evenly and quickly and the pan was easy to clean using a soft sponge and gentle dish soap. This is dishwasher safe but I prefer to wash it by hand. This is a deep pan and at 11 inches it easily fits 4 chicken breasts/pork chops or two large steaks. I'm a new fan and I highly recommend this!

To the public, power couple Eve and Cooper have it all but when Cooper and Eve's sister are in a serious car accident together, secrets and lies are brought to light. I really enjoy this author's style of writing. This story is intriguing, easy to follow and descriptive enough to paint the picture without being overly so. In the beginning, I thought that I had "what really happened" figured out and even though I thought this story was a little predictable, I still continued to enjoy reading it to the very end. As it turned out, my prediction was wrong and I was pleasantly surprised with the ending.

We have Wi-Fi service in our 2300 square foot house and we felt frustrated that there were several places in our home that wouldn't get signal to use the internet. I requested this in hopes that it would solve that problem and because with the internet tv, iPad and laptop often in use at the same time, I understood that this router would create a stronger signal. My brother came and set this up for us and he said it was very easy to do. We've been using this for about a month and our Wi-Fi signal has greatly improved, especially in the dead zones of our home. I'm not a techie but I can say that this router worked for us exactly as we had hoped it would.

I misunderstood what this book was about, I thought it was going to be a self-help sort of book involving the author's trials with cancer. It is more of a coffee table book with lovely pictures (taken by the author) and has one sentence ideas about slowing down and enjoying your life more. Towards the middle of the book she writes about a paragraph on each page and this book ended up being a very quick read. Although I found the photos to be lovely, I didn't feel very inspired by the text. This could very well be a book that will resonate and speak to others, it just didn't to me.

This a very sweet book about a budding artist ,Louise, who is so focused on her art and how to display it that she doesn't notice until it's too late that her little brother has taken her best "piece" and turned into something different. Instead of becoming angry with her little brother (although she's disappointed), she lovingly finds the perfect place to display his new art. The illustrations are adorable and the bold pops of color are stunning. My children (ages 6 and 3) and I really enjoyed this story and the sweet message encourages sibling love, patience and kindness.

The book description given for this (at the time I'm writing my review) is inaccurate. Although, I wasn't sure exactly what to expect because the description was rather vague, I was shocked when a I removed a 3 inch box out of the envelope. The "book" is 3 inches tall and it is not a "16 panel fold-out sheet of images", as described in the book description. It is actually a booklet of only 8 stickers from scenes from the movie that are about 2 1/2 inches tall. The Gizmo is a tiny 3 inch plush toy that looks minuscule even in my three year old daughter's hands (whom this kit was purchased for). This would probably make a cute stocking stuffer but my daughter was disappointed by the the product because she was expecting more. As long as you know exactly what you're going to receive, then you will probably be satisfied with this product.

My son and husband were very eager to put this set together the day that it arrived, unfortunately this ended up being a disappointment to them. The pieces are pretty flimsy, the directions weren't the clearest and the finished product is a clumsy robot that can't stand on its own or be played with because it falls apart easily. I wouldn't recommend this toy for kids who intend on playing with the finished product. However, this maybe something that a collector would appreciate.

This is a wonderful towel for little girls who love princesses. It's super soft, cozy and comfortable. The Aurora graphics look beautiful and the colors look striking and bold. My three year old daughter is 29 lbs. and 37 inches tall and the bottom falls just below her knees. The hole for her head is perfectly sized and is neither too small or too wide. I've washed this in warm water and dried on medium heat without any shrinkage or fading. My daughter also has the Ariel version of this towel and after 6 months, it still looks brand new. Little princesses will love these towels after baths, swimming or at the beach!

My six year old son and his fellow first grade friends have been talking about Minecraft non-stop for awhile now. When I gave him this 6 pack of Minecraft animal toys he was overjoyed and did a very impressive happy dance. He's been playing with them non-stop since he received them and is asking for more figures to add to this collection. These figures have movable parts and are well made  so I feel comfortable recommending them to other Minecrafts fans and collectors. I plan on purchasing other figures for my son as Christmas gifts.

This is a story of a woman's brave escape from her abusive husband that is terrifying, heartwrentching and inspiring. Following in her grandmother Lola's footsteps, pregnant Ellen and her mystical Aunt Ruth, join the very same circus in hopes of escaping a death sentence sure to be carried out by her husband if she doesn't leave. This story is so well written that I could feel the fear and terror that Ellen experienced while in the company of her diabolical husband. I particularly loved the tidbits of information regarding tigers and circus life in general. I deducted one star for being a little predictable at times and I had hoped for a more dynamic ending. However, I would still recommend this story to readers who love a little magic mixed with circus animals and an eclectic group of characters.

There is something to be said for simple, basic products such as this toilet paper. It's strong and does it's job thoroughly. Although it's not the softest toilet paper, it's not rough either. It's certainly gentle enough for private regions, however it's not what I would want to use for a runny nose if I had a bad cold or allergy attack. I like that it's not like the Charming Ultra Soft that is so soft that it sort of sheds and I really like that it's unscented. This is a simple, economical toilet paper that I would purchase in the future.

This adorable doll, Brayden, looks so much better in person than she does online. She's just as cute (if not cuter) than Bratz or Monsters High dolls, minus the risqu outfits. Her metallic tutu dress is accessorized with a shrug and leggings and I truly appreciate that this child's doll isn't dressed like a 21 year old going to the club. Brayden would be the perfect doll for children who love purple (like my daughter) because she has violet eyes, lavender lips and tons of gorgeous dark purple hair that my little girl is completely fascinated with. She is constantly styling and playing with her hair. My daughter takes this doll everywhere with her and she's been asking for the other three dolls in the group. I think they're adorable and I feel comfortable with my daughter having these toys. We plan on purchasing the rest of the collection for Christmas.

I've been using this to organize my son's important school work and other information from his school because the two pocket folders that I've been using just fill up too quickly. This expanding file is much nicer than I expected it to be! It feels very study like it can take the beating that school supplies take during a school year and be just fine. There are seven pockets that are able to hold quite a lot papers and the front cover is clear plastic where it can be customized with a picture, drawing etc. I'm impressed with this and I would love to have several more to stay a little more organized.

My six year old son loves, loves, loves the Ghostbusters movie and he loves dressing up as one everyday after school (his old Halloween costume). Finding Ghostbusters toys has been challenging so he was over the moon when we found this plush collection on Amazon. These toys are really cute (the fellas even have proton packs printed on their backs) but they are not the greatest quality and I'm fairly certain they are from a claw machine game. They probably cannot handle being played with too roughly or they will fall apart. That being said, my son is so stinkin' happy with these toys that they are absolutely worth every penny. I definitely recommend them to little Ghostbusters fans and/or collectors.

My family and I are huge fans of this nacho cheese seasoning! It tastes delicious on popcorn, baked potatoes and French fries. It has the perfect amount of salty flavor without being overly salty like I find the White Cheddar flavor to be. It doesn't contain MSG and it's made in the USA. I prefer these larger size bottles because my family and I go through the smaller size bottles really quickly. I highly recommend this seasoning to cheese lovers!

I've always had the terrible habit of only drinking coffee in the morning and not eating anything until about 10 or 11 in the morning. Now that I'm getting older my metabolism has started slowing down and in an effort to speed it up and lose about 10 lbs., I've started eating one bar for breakfast every morning. My husband and I both find the apple cinnamon flavor to be be quite tasty and these do a good job of filling us up for a few hours. Since trying these I've also purchased the chocolate chunk and peanut butter flavors, both of which we find equally tasty. I recommend these for people who are on the go and need something quick, easy and tasty to put in their stomach as well as people who are trying to lose weight.

Many moons ago when I was in school I only used Mead filler paper because it was well made, sturdy and fit easily into my binders. Now that my son is in school I've noticed that the paper seems a little thinner than I remember, however it meets the basic needs of my soon to be first grader. The huge plus for me is that this product is made in the USA and I will definitely continue to purchase it for my children.

I've tried several of the flavors in this line and the Ranch flavor is my favorite! It has an authentic ranch flavor and it's delicious on popcorn, fries, roasted potatoes and vegetables. The movie theatre that we frequent has this line of seasonings for the popcorn and that is where I first fell in love with these. Perfect way to curb my salty cravings without being overly salty and without the MSG that I find in so many snacks. I highly recommend this!

This nacho cheese seasoning is delicious on popcorn and French fries! It's made from natural ingredients, it doesn't contain MSG (a migraine trigger for me) and it doesn't tasty overly salty. The possibilities are endless for this cheesy deliciousness and I highly recommend it for nacho cheese lovers.

This was a gift for my sister and  she absolutely loves it! This nice quality clip feels sturdy and it easily fits on the visor of her Nissan Altima. She is my younger sister and I feel very protective of her, so I wanted her to have a reminder in her car not to drive too fast and also to avoid using her cellphone while driving. There's nothing like a visual of an Angel looking down on you to serve as a safety reminder. :)

I'm 5'7", weigh 136 lbs. and I typically wear a size 6-8 in clothing and a 34/36A bra. I ordered an XL based on the measurements provided by the seller and this swim dress fits me one size too small. It felt tight going up over my thighs and once on it creates back fat, which I typically don't have unless I'm squeezing myself into something that is too small. If you can find the correct size then you will probably love this swim dress because it's made well and the style and print are absolutely darling! I also want to point out that the bust has thin but awkwardly molded cups that shift. Hope this helps, ladies. :)

My family and I host extended family gatherings regularly and having a crockpot of this size and quality helps tremendously. So far, green chile shredded beef, pot roast and red chile shredded chicken are the main courses that I've made in this slow cooker and I'm incredibly happy with this crock pot! Having the all in one option to brown meat in the ceramic pot is easy and convenient, as is the built in timer. I hand wash the ceramic pot to protect the ceramic coating but the lid is dishwasher safe. This crock pot is high quality and makes cooking for a larger group super easy. I highly recommend this product.

I must admit that when I first tried this curling iron I felt that it was too lightweight to be a quality tool. Also, as others have pointed out, the temperature button is located in an awkward place on the handle where it's very easy to change the temperature without realizing it. However, this curler did a nice job of curling my hair and managed to maintain some shine in my curls. The feature that makes this staying tool different from others that I own is that the barrel is coated with moringa, argan and macadamia oils to protect the hair from heat damage. I must admit that I wonder how long the oils will stay coated on the curling iron, but in the meantime I will continue to use this, as I have received the desired results that I was looking for.

I've been using this battery powered toothbrush with the Truly Radiant toothpaste from the same line and I'm so pleased with the results! My teeth are whiter and they feel cleaner than they normally do when I use a manual brush. The head is not abrasive yet it's effective in thoroughly cleaning my teeth and my mouth feels fresh. I like this toothbrush so much that I purchased one for my husband and he is very pleased with the results as well. I highly recommend this product as well as the Truly Radiant toothpaste.

The story of a young girl in Appalachia, The Killing Tree is written in a lyrical, almost poetic style that one would expect from a novel about this region of the country.  In fact, the thing that most makes this an ok-but-not-great book is that so much if it is expected, even stereotypical almost.But first, let me talk about what I liked.First and foremost was Mercy, the main character.  A lonely orphaned girl raised by her grandparents and starved for a mother's love, she captivates the reader's sympathy almost from the first page.  Even her best friend Della, in spite of her wild and promiscuous ways, captivates the reader as an equally lost and lonely soul.  Although at times a little too heavy on the poetic imagery for my taste, still Keener's writing is strong and skilled, painting a story in vivid pictures.  At times, for instance when Della's boyfriend betrays her, the emotion it evokes is so strong as to be almost painful.  She creates a plot full of conflict and tension that keeps you reading, wanting to know how it's all going to turn out.But there were a couple of things that disappointed me and kept this from being a 5-star book.  One was the way it ended.  I will keep my comments deliberately vague so as to not be a spoiler, but there was a lack of resolution in the story involving two of the main characters that felt very unfinished and left me disappointed.But even more disappointing, I think, is that so much of this book is so expected as to be almost stereotypical.  The young girl raised in Appalachia by a crazy grandmother and a cruel, warped grandfather just seemed so unoriginal.  And the fact that the cruel, warped grandfather is a sin-obsessed deacon in the church was a turn off for me.  Why do so many authors love making their cruelest, most warped characters be a Bible reading churchgoer?  As though church is nothing more than a gathering place of holier than thous, and a spawning place for the worst in society.The book would have been much more enjoyable had the author developed a story more original, instead of using already overused characters and plot elements.

A non-fiction tale of murder, injustice, and freedom come too late, The Innocent Man is the story of Ron Williamson.  It is a sad, tragic tale of a man already spiraling down into depression and mental illness, when a wrongful conviction for murder pushes him further into mental and physical illness and, eventually, premature death.  John Grisham's skilled writing makes this sad, wasted life into a page-turning story.  Craig Wasson is a fine narrator.

The Last Juror is a fictional tale of murder, injustice and revenge set in rural Mississippi in the early 1970s.  Danny Padgitt, of the notorious and powerful Padgitt family who have had Ford County in their iron-fisted control for over 100 years, is found guilty of the rape and murder of a young woman.  No one doubts that he is guilty -- the last words of the dying woman sealed his guilt -- but everyone assumes that the Padgitt clan will pay false witnesses, buy off the judge, whatever it takes to secury a verdict of innocent.  To everyone's surprise the jury finds him guilty, although they deadlock on a death sentence and so he is sent to prison for life, instead.But in 1970s Mississippi a life sentence really only meant about 10 years behind bars.  With the Padgitt influence Danny was set free in even less than that, and as soon as he returned to Ford County the jurors in his trial began one by one to be brutally murdered.This sounds like a chilling tale of suspense; however it is anything but and if that is what you are looking for you will be sorely disappointed.  The Danny Padgitt story occupies the first couple of CDs and the last couple.  All the CDs in between -- the majority of the book -- is a tale of small-town life in 1970s Mississippi.  This is really the story of Willie Traynor a young man from "up north" (Tennessee) who comes to Clanton, buys the town's newspaper, and immerses himself in the life of the small town.  Narrated by him in the first person, it is an engaging story with a cast of whimsical, eccentric and entertaining characters.John Grisham's style is so engaging that it is impossible not to enjoy the story, even if it is not the highly charged suspense tale that the cover blurb makes it sound like.  Michael Beck does a fabulous narration -- his pace and cadence are perfect, and his voice has just enough twang to perfectly fit the story.

Angela Hunt is one of my favorite writers of historical Biblical fiction and, since it's been several years since she's turned out anything historical (I don't at all care for her contemporary books) I started this with eager anticipation.In spite of the fact that Hunt is a gifted writer, whose style is polished and skilled, I found this book somewhat lackluster.  Perhaps this is because it took me 2+ months to read it and so I thereby lost the rhythm of her writing.  Or perhaps the lackluster quality of the book is what caused me to set it aside for weeks at a time - ?All I know is that the story lacked spark.  Hunt's depiction of Esther's life and upbringing prior to the palace was believable, her depiction of Esther's experiences in the palace plausible, but I think the main problem was that too much of the book was focused on events outside of the very exciting plot of the Biblical book of Esther.  Hunt spends most of the book focusing on the king's military activities and the imagined/presumed machinations of the deposed queen Vashti and, while all of this is somewhat interesting, it does nothing to advance the story.  I don't know if Hunt felt that the the biblical account alone was not enough to fill a book and so felt compelled to expand on it - ?  The character of Haman wasn't introduced until three-quarters of the way through the book, and the exciting intrigues and events of the Biblical story were rushed and crammed into the last 80 pages.Nevertheless, I plan to read Hunt's next book in this series -- skilled Christian fiction writers are few and far between and so I am loyal to my favorites and don't give up on them after just one disappointing book.

Set in a small English village in the 19th century, The Return of the Native is the story of crossed affections involving several young adults.  It is a mostly sad tale of irony, misplaced affections and misunderstandings.  Although tragic, the tale never descends into the melancholy or gloomy.  Eustacia Vye is at the center of it all -- a young lady beautiful but vain, selfish and self-centered.  Although she is not all that likeable, she is not totally unsympathetic and there were many points in the tale when I identified with her.This is an elegantly-written classic that I will listen to again.  Simon Vance does an excellent anrration.

This Side of Paradise, F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel, is a semi-autobiographical sketch of a young man in the first decade of the 20th century.  It covers Amory Blaine's years at Princeton, and immediately afterward, aluding to but not detailing his time in-between in the battlefields of WWI.  Although in even this his first novel Fitzgerald demonstrated a skill with language, the lack of plot makes this book a tedious bore to read.  A mix of prose and poetry it reads like a disjointed mix of stories and vignettes written independently and then strung together into a single novel (which is probably exactly what it was).  After a rambling, aimless wander for 6 or 7 discs, the last disc or so descended into philosophical ramble.I find it hugely ironic that when it was published this book became an instant bestseller that catapulted Fitzgerald into fame and fortune.  While the vastly superior The Great Gatsby sold poorly and only achieved popularity and critical acclaim after Fitzgerald's death decades later.The narrator does a good enough job, but I just can't recommend this tediously boring book.

The Black Tulip is a tale of love and intrigue in Renaissance Holland.  Cornelius van Baerle, a wealthy but somewhat native young man, wants nothing more than to grow his tulips in peace, and to become the first to develop a perfectly black tulip.  However, politics is in turmoil as his country struggles for independence, and tulipmania is at a high, and Cornelius finds himself unwittingly embroiled in both.  Will he ever be free from his sentence of life imprisonment for a crime he did not commit?  Will he ever be able to rightfully claim the reward for developing the first perfectly black tulip?This is an enjoyable but unremarkable story, which is no doubt why it isn't one of Dumas' better known books.  However it is difficult for me to objectively rate the quality of the book due to the quality of the narration.A narrator can make or break an audio book, and in this instance the narrator definitely breaks it.  Some months back I purchased several audio books, three of which were narrated by unknown-to-me narrator John Bolen.  As soon as I began the first CD narrated by him, I immediately regretted the money I had wasted on the three books.At the risk of sounding scathing, I have to say that John Bolen is just about the worst audio book narrator I have ever listened to.  His "natural" speaking voice when narrating is so drawling and affected that it is annoying in the extreme.  His cadence when reading dialogue is so off that the dialogue is completely stilted and unnatural.  He manages to make almost all the male characters sound foppish and effeminate, and his narration style is so distracting that it is almost impossible for me to focus on the book.  In fact, I was unable to finish two of the three audio books I purchased that were narrated by him.  I was able to finish this one, although it was made somewhat worse by the poor quality -- it is obvious that the book was not recorded in a studio but at Bolen's home.I will not purchase or listen to any more books narrated by John Bolen.

It's not surprising that Anne Bronte is the least significant writer of the Bronte sisters, and that Agnes Grey is probably her least significant book.  Although it is written with the smooth, elegant language for which the Brontes are known, it is totally lacking in the powerful plot and characters of her sisters' famous works.  It is simply a nice, short little novel about a nice litle governess who has to endure absolutely horrible employers and situations before finding true love and living happily ever after.I think only true Bronte fans would enjoy this one, and even at that I can't see this book being anyone's favorite.  Anne Flosnik does an excellent narration.

Ben Hur is one of my favorite classics, because it has it all:  love, hate, vengeance,adventure, endurance and restoration, all set against the backdrop of 1st century Judea and with the character of Jesus woven throughout.  The one thing Ben Hur is missing is forgiveness; although Judah ben Hur does succeed in avenging the wrong done him and his family, and though he does encounter Jesus and become a follower of him, he doesn't ever come to a place of forgiveness against his enemy Masala, at least it's never expressed in the book.  To me this is a critical omission, and one that would have made the story even greater.That being said, it is still a great story that I have read more than once, will doubtless read again, and would recommend to anybody.  As far as audiobook narrators go, Todd McLaren is ok but not great.  He has a pleasant reading voice that is perfect for narrating the story itself, but his performance is weak on character voices.  Everyone sounded middle-aged or older, and it was especially true of Iris, who did not sound at all like the sultry, young, seductive character she was.A great book suitable for the whole family.  If you listen to this book and like it, then I highly recommend Focus on the Family's dramatized version; it is much more abridged, so much of the story is cut out, but the performance is excellent.

A Room With a View is a well-written and enjoyable novel that blends skilled writing and gentle humor into a comedy of manners set in the very early 1900s (although dates are never referred to in the novel, it seemed to be around the turn of the century).
