It is the story of a young gentlewoman, Lucy Honeychurch, who must choose between two men:  one who is well-connected and well-regarded by her family, and one not of her family's social standing.  Although the outcome is predictable, there was a time near the end when I had some doubt and wondered if the author was going to throw in a real twist.  Alas, he didn't; I say alas, because books with twists and turns and unpredictable outcomes are much more interesting and memorable.Even so this is an enjoyable book, and the frequently recurring theme of views and rooms with views makes it no doubt a favorite of high school English teachers, as well.  Steven Crossley does an excellent narration; his voice is pleasant and with no distinctive qualities that often make narrators' voices distracting and even annoying.This was my first book by E.M. Forster, but I plan to read more.

Focus on the Family does an outstanding job with their Radio Theatre productions, and this one is no exception.  The voice actors and sound effects are top-notch.In this production they turn for their source to the Gospel of Luke.  And I must say that the original title of this series -- The Luke Reports -- is much more appropriate than the title it's been re-issued under, The LIfe of Jesus.  For the focus is much more on the imagined backstory of Luke's writing of his gospel than on the actual life of Jesus.  That isn't necessarily a negative, as Luke's story -- which is the story of the turmoil of Palestine in the time of Nero -- is interesting.  However, if you're looking for a dramatization of the Gospel of Luke then you may be disappointed, as the life of Jesus occurs as just snippets throughout.I have just a few criticisms of this production.  For one, I didn't particularly care for Luke's voice -- which is purely a subjective opinion I realize.  Mary the mother of Jesus was voiced way too young.  The story takes place 30 to 40 years after Jesus' death, which would put her in her 80s.  However, she sounds about 20 years younger than that, and much too vigorous for such an elderly woman. I didn't particularly care for the scene where Jesus scourged the money changers in the temple, as the way they had him growl and roar made him sound almost like an animal.  And I was especially disappointed in the crucifixion scene as most of Jesus' words were omitted -- and thus the power of the moment was omitted, as well.While all of these criticisms are fairly minor, taken all together they make this one 4 stars rather than 5. Another observation -- which has no impact on my rating but is expressed just as a tongue-in-cheek comment -- is that many of the characters had cockney or Irish-sounding accents.  I found the same to be true with the other FOTF production I listened to from this same setting (Ben Hur).  I didn't realize there were cockneys living in 1st century Palestine!All in all an enjoyable listening experience, and one I will definitely listen to again.

Little Women has been one of my favorites since I first read it at about age 9 (a very long time ago).  Although old-fashioned, and sometimes preachy and moralistic, nevertheless it is a comfort read.  Every time I re-read it, which I do every few years, it is like wrapping myself in a warm blanket.  Somehow it manages to touch my heartstrings every time.As always, Focus on the Family does a fine production. Although it is impossible to capture the richness of Little Women in just 4 CDs, they manage to convey much of the book's spirit by hitting the highlights.  My only criticism of their production was that they had different actresses voice Jo's character (a young Jo and an older Jo) but didn't do so for Meg or Amy.  The actress who voiced Meg sounded too old to be a 16 year old girl in the beginning, although she was fine for an older Meg at the end.  Just the opposite was true of Amy -- in the book Amy grows from a spoiled and selfish 12 year old into an elegant, refined and gracious young woman who wins the reader's admiration.  By having the same actress voice her throughout, this production fails to capture the essence of Amy, as she sounds like a 12 year old throughout the entire book.One other disappointment was that many of the scenes in this production failed to capture the depth and poignancy of the book, or at least the way I've always voiced them in my head the many times I've read it.  One example in particular is the scene where Laurie declares his love for Jo and she turns him down - this is truly a heart-wrenching scene in the book that makes me cry every time I read it.  But in this production it didn't touch any heart strings at all.  Perhaps it is simply that an abridged dramatization can never equal the power of the much-loved and much-read original.Nevertheless, this production is highly recommended for enjoyable family listening.  If you truly love Little Women then I recommend the unabridged version produced by Recorded Books and narrated by Barbara Caruso -- it is outstanding.

I bought this audio dramatization solely on the strength of the fact that it was done by Focus on the Family Radio Theatre.  Having listened to several of their productions I know that they are always first-rate.  And in terms of production and performance this one was no exception.The disappointment was in the story itself.  When I opened the package I was a bit dismayed to see it was only one CD -- I guess I should have checked closer before purchasing.  Had I known it was only one CD I probably wouldn't have bought it, knowing that such a short story would necessarily be lacking in development.And so it was.  The story of Billy Budd, a young man apparently without flaw, was not only lacking in development but was pointless.  Pressed into service on a British warship during the Napoleonic wars, Billy endeared himself to almost everyone with his pleasant disposition, honesty and integrity.  There were a few on board, however, who hated him for reasons unknown; he suffered persecution at their hands and ultimately,...... well to say anymore would be a spoiler.Focus on the Family generally chooses stories that are based on issues of right, wrong, injustice, and that have some redemptive quality.  Billy Budd, Sailor was lacking in all of these, in spite of Dave Arnold's attempt at the end of the story to draw parallels between the story of Billy and that of Adam or even Jesus.  I just didn't see the parallel and I think this was a disappointing choice of a book for them to dramatize.

Although I will never be a fan of Jane Austen -- her works are too tedious for my taste -- I have recently enjoyed a couple of them in audio version, this being one of them.Emma is the story of a well-to-do young lady who likes to arrange matches for her friends.  With her mother long deceased, her sister and governess married and in their own households, and living alone with her fussy, silly, doddering old father, there is no one in Emma's life to curb her self-important interference into other people's affairs.  Mr. Knightley, a long-time friend of the family and Emma's brother-in-law, is the only one who will even dare to criticize her, as everyone else in Emma's life thinks she is perfect.  The story centers around Emma's relationship with Harriet Smith, a poor younger woman in unfortunate circumstances, who Emma takes under her wing, convinced that she can improve Harriet and make a perfect match for her.  Alas, every one of Emma's schemes goes awry as she constantly misunderstands and misinterprets the feelings and actions of others, and poor Harriet suffers as a result.It is a credit to Jane Austen's ability to create subtle, nuanced characters that I liked Emma.  She was full of qualities that should make her unlikeable, and yet I liked her in spite of her flaws.  And when she bore Mr. Knightley's somewhat harsh criticism of a particular instance of bad behavior with grace and contrition, I knew my liking of her was justified.All that being said, this book isn't nor ever can be one of my favorites.  It was too long and drawn out -- as Miss Austen's works tend to be -- for my taste.  It took me much longer to finish this book than it should have, simply because I often lost interest and did other things rather than listen to it.  I also don't particularly care for tidy, they-all-lived-happily-ever-after endings such as this book has.The narrator, Nadia May, does a fine job.  Although narrators can make or break any audio book, I find they are particulary crucial to Jane Austen's works.  Her books need more than just a nice, pleasant voice, they need some character and drama to keep them from becoming just so much monotonous background noise.

This brow wax works well enough, only I wish it lasted longer and didn't need to be re-applied during the day.  Perhaps my brows are just extra unruly - ?Best of all, this product works just as well as the more expensive designer brand and is less than half the price.

This brow wax works great, except that I wish it lasted longer and didn't have to be re-applied during the day.  Perhaps my brows are just extra unruly - ?But.... the NYX brand works just as well and is less than half the price.  I suspect they are identical products, but this one has the designer brand label and a higher price.

Ivanhoe is that most quintissential of Medieval adventure stories.  Written in Sir Walter Scott's old-fashioned but easily readible 19th century style, the story captures all that we most associate with chivalry and the Middle Ages.  The large cast of characters spans nearly all of Medieval English society:  Norman knights, Saxon nobles, a hermit, a jester, Knights Templar, Jews, palmers, knights errant, friars, and of course, lovely damsels.  And there are even a few "celebrities" -- King Richard the Lion Hearted, his nefarious brother John and the legendary outlaw Robin Hood and his band.This is a sprawling adventure that covers many facets of Medieval English society:  wandering palmers and knights returning home from Crusade, a noble feast, tournaments, battles, dungeons, all are worked into the story.  It is a story that covers all the color and glory of Medieval society, but much of its treacheries and injustices, too.  Scott's style keeps the story pretty lighthearted, no matter what the scene, so that even the less attractive aspects are told in a way that is never dark or brooding.Although the story is named after Wilfred of Ivanhoe, a young Saxon warrior returning home after being on crusade with King Richard, he is hardly the main character.  The story's focus shifts from one character to another so that it could be said there really isn't any main charcter.This is a story suitable for family listening and will doubltess have special appeal for young boys, since much of the story focuses on tournaments, battles, loyalty and betrayal.  Simon Prebble does an excellent narration

I've never been a fan of Jane Austen's works, having tried to listen to a few of them in audio version and finding them too tedious to even finish.  However, I recently tried another of her books and discovered that a really, really gifted narrator can actually transform her books into a pleasant, even entertaining listening experience.I purchased this copy of Northanger Abbey on the strength of Anna Massey's narration alone; I have another audio book read by her and know that she is a truly gifted narrator.  She definitely didn't disappoint this time, although even her skilled reading couldn't mask or make up for some significant flaws in the book.It is clear from almost the first sentence that Northanger Abbey is a satire of the popular romantic novels of Austen's day.  However, once past the almost-sarcastic beginning, the story settles into a nice tale.  The heroine is Catherine Moreland, a young and innocent girl of a good family who is invited to vacation in Bath with some family friends.  In spite of her naivete and propensity to view everything through the lens of the Gothic romances she loves to read, the reader can't help but like Catherine.  She is not silly, but simply a girl who is lacking in experience but not lacking in good sense.  Although she becomes involved with some people of less than sterling character, her natural intelligence allows her to discern this and the reader can't help cheering for her and hoping that she will come though it unscathed.Then another family invites Catherine to visit their country home Northanger Abbey and here begins the weakest part of the novel.  Catherine's relationships with those around her are suspended as Jane Austen turns the book into a parody of Gothic novels.  Immediately caught up by her overactive, naive imagination, Catherine is sure that the Abbey harbors dark secrets and immediately sets about discovering the truth behind the death of Mrs. Tilney, mother of her friends.  This part of the book is simply ridiculous and silly, with Catherine acting like a 19th century Nancy Drew.  Really, this section could have been (and should have been) completely cut from the book and nothing would have been lost.Finally, Henry Tilney, the young man Catherine loves, becomes aware of her ridiculous quest and firmly makes her aware of the facts behind his mother's death.  With this Catherine is overcome with embarrassment, this silly Goth parody comes to an abrupt end, and the story of Catherine and her society resumes.Besides the silly Gothic parody there are other significant weaknesss.  One is the author's tendency to suddenly turn to the reader as it were and start writing in the first person.  Another major weakness is the character of Captain Tilney; although his reason for suddenly dismissing Catherine and sending her home alone might have worked had it been written with Austen's usual sophisticated style and polish, it wasn't.  So it came across as clunky and even dumb.My conclusion -- this book was badly in need of some editing.  It lacks the polish of Austen's other works -- perhaps  because she died before being able to finish it to her normal standard?  It is not a terrible book but I can't help feeling that money would have been better spent on some other book and I doubt I will ever listen to this one again.  It will probably appeal most to ardent Jane Austen fans.

The Turn of the Screw is quite possibly the stupidest and most pointless story I have ever wasted my time on.  Purportedly a ghost story, the "ghosts" are nothing more than occasional appearances by the former governess and valet, both of whom are now dead.  The reaction of the current governess and housekeeper to these appearances are immediate, irrational and overdone; both are convinced that these ghosts are evil and are controlling the two young children in the governess's charge.  Though just exactly what it is about the "ghosts" that makes them evil, or just what evidence there is that they are controlling the children, is never revealed.  The only thing "bad" that either child does is when 10-year-old Miles is suspended from his private school for -- ok, we are forced to wait until almost the very end of the story to find out just what terrible thing Miles did, so a drumroll is appropriate here -- as he finally confesses to his governess, "saying things."  Seriously?  Yawn.The narrator did nothing to help this gutless and pointless story.  Her pleasant monotone lacked drama and turned into so much dull background noise.  I don't think a better narrator could have rescued this terrible story, but she definitely did nothing to help it.If, after this scathing review, you still feel that you simply must read this story then get it from the library; don't waste your hard-earned money on it.

I have never been able to understand the enduring popularity of Jane Austen's books.  The one I read in print years ago was unmemorable.  The two or three I tried to listen to on audio, and was unable to finish, were monotonous, genteel British chatter that quickly became background noise as my mind wandered.  Thus, I long ago concluded that I simply was not a fane of Jane Austen and never would be.So I'm not sure exactly what made me try another of her books -- but I am glad I did.  Mansfield Park is a Cinderella-type story of Fanny Price, a young girl removed from her poor family and taken in by her more prosperous relatives, ostensibly for her own benefit but really just to satisfy their own proud sense of generosity and magnanimity.  The book covers the next 10 or so years of her life, as she grows from a girl of 9 to a young lady of 19.  It follows her trials as the poor relation who is practically friendless, treated almost as a servant while continually being reminded of how grateful she should be to those who have taken her in.I found myself actually liking Fanny and wondering what would become of her.  Which young man would she ultimately marry -- the cad who pursued her relentlessly, claiming his undying love and that her goodness had reformed him, or the cousin she loved but who himself loved another young woman totally unworthy of him?So what made his book different than the other Jane Austens I have tried?  The narrator:  Frances Barber gives a performance that is nothing short of fabulous.  She breathes color, variety and character into each voice that brings the story to life.  She particularly excelled with the sultry-voiced Mary Crawford and the nasally, odious Aunt Norris.The only thing that keeps this book from being 5 stars is the happily-ever-after ending; a little too flat and pat for my taste.  In fact, the last several chapters were anti-climactic, as Ms. Austen was tying up the loose ends and the drama and action virtually came to an end.  I particularly missed the presence of Aunt Norris; dislikeable as she was, Ms. Barber's rendition of her added a lot of color to the story.Nevertheless, I enjoyed this book so much that I purchased a copy for my own (the one I listened to was from the library) and I will definitely listen to it again when I am in the mood for a cosy, easy story.  And I am now trying out other Jane Austen works on audio, being careful to choose different narrators from those I've tried before.  While a narrator can make or break any audiobook, I find this is especially true of Jane Austen's books.  Her stories need more than just a pleasant voice.  I wish Frances Barber had narrated more of her books; still, I am hopeful that some of the others I will be trying soon will be just as enjoyable.

Robert Louis Stevenson excelled at the short story -- the three in this volume are exquisitely written with the lovely language of the best 19th century writers.  Although these are labeled tales of "terror" there is no terror here, only mild suspense.  "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" is the best-known of the three and is the best story, but the other two are enjoyable.Michael Kitchen is an excellent narrator with a voice well-suited to Stevenson's stories.

Having never read The Prince and the Pauper, I was expecting a lighthearted, funny story in the vein of Mark Twain's other works.  Set 16th century England, the story is about Henry VIII's son Prince Edward and a pauper boy Tom Canti born on the exact same day who also happens to look exactly like the prince.  Their paths happen to cross one day when the prince witnesses the pauper being mistreated and he takes him back to the palace.  Intrigued by the fact that they look so much alike, and thinking that Tom's life sounds like carefree fun, the prince decides they should switch clothes.  They are both amazed by how indistinguishable they are.  Then suddenly the prince decides to punish a servant who has mistreated Tom and runs out of the room still wearing Tom's tattered clothes.  Thus he sets in motion a chain of events that traps each boy into the other's role..The story was as lighthearted as one would expect from Mark Twain, but the adventures each boy faced were more intriguing than I expected and made the story better than I expected.  This is great family entertainment, well-done by the Colonial Radio Players.  I do wish the ending hadn't tied up so nice and pat -- after all the conflicts each boy was entwined in, to have it all end so neatly was somewhat of a letdown.  But that's Twain, I suppose.  And younger listeners should be satisfied with it.

I bought this CD just for the title song, which I had heard on the radio on a visit to the South.  Unfortunately, that is the only song on the CD that I really like.  Most of the rest are mediocre and a couple actually get on my nerves.

Ok, so it's my own fault that this ended up being a waste of money to me.  I'm no fan of horror and this is Dracula after all, right?  I guess I just wasn't prepared for how much different a full-cast dramatization of Bram Stoker's classic would be from a simple narration -- which I listened to several years ago and thought was good but not great.  Hearing the screams, the moans, the whispers, the sounds of someone lapping up blood was just too creepy for my taste.  Although that's probably evidence that BBC Radio has done a successful dramatization of this most classic of vampire tales.  I have several BBC Radio productions and their voice talent and sound effects are always top-notch; this one is no exception.  The only fault I find with this production, performance-wise, is that it constantly changes scenes with no narrator or other method of informing the listener, so that the performance feels very incoherent and disjointed throughout.  Perhaps that is the effect they were trying to achieve, to enhance the eerieness of the tale, but I didn't like it.If you like horror stories then you'll no doubt love this one.  I was truly impressed by the actor who voiced the American character.  I don't know if he is a Brit or not, but if so then he is the first British actor I've ever heard who can do an American accent -- and a southern one at that -- convincingly.I just hope I can sell this on ebay and get a few dollars back for it.

I bought this to replace the blade assembly on my 20+ year old blender that suddenly locked up.  I am very happy that for just a small investment of $5 I was able to save my blender (which is a particular shade of green, thus I don't want to have to get rid of it).  Other reviewers have complained that the part was rusty and didn't work well, but I have used it twice now and had no problems.

I've listened to several productions of The Colonial Radio Theater, and so far this is the best one by far.  The cast is small, with each actor giving an excellent performance.  I've noticed in some of their other productions that some of the actors' performances are a bit stilted, as though they are reading their lines, but there is none of that here.  The sound effects are just right, also -- enough to lend color and atmosphere but with not a single "dead spot" such as is typical of all the other CRT dramatizaitons I've listened to.This is a short performance, at only about an hour and a half, but psychological and atmospheric and excellently done.

Captain, Blood, written in the 1920s and immensely popular in its day, is the quintissential pirate story.  Peter Blood, a soldier turned physician in 17th century England, is accused of treason for treating a wounded rebel during the Monmouth rebellion.  Originally sentenced to hang, his punishment in instead commuted to slavery in the West Indies.  After being purchased by a wealthy and prominent planter in Barbados, his talent for treating the sick is soon discovered and he is granted a large degree of freedom, especially since his medical services are highly regarded by the governor and his wife.However, when he regards the brutality with which his fellow slaves are treated, and when he concludes that he will never win the regard of the young woman he loves or the acceptance of society, but will always be regarded as a convict and slave, he arranges an escape for his friends. They capture a Spanish ship in the harbor and, turning his back on respectable society, Peter Blood becomes Captain Blood, pirate of the Caribbean.Of the several productions I have listened to by The Colonial Radio Players this one is the best; as a whole the actors' performances are better and there aren't quite as many "dead spots" as I've heard in their other productions -- that is, places where there is no dialogue and little sound effects, leaving the listener to wonder what is going on.  There is also a nice musical theme woven throughout.A large part of the story focuses on the sea battles and treachery between Blood and other pirates, both Spanish and French.  While this will certainly appeal to some listeners, particularly male, I found it a bit hard to follow and my attention sometimes strayed.  The story is tied together by a nice romance that is not sugary sweet but believable, although I never could figure out what it was about the self-righteous and obtuse Arabella that would cause two decent men to turn to villainy because of her.  She must have been really beautiful is all I can figure.Although I don't consider the performances of The Colonial Radio Players to be quite up to the level of BBC4 Radio or Focus on the Family Radio Drama, still they do a nice job overall at producing entertaining stories.  This one has a few mild oaths, but should still be suitable for family listening.

Having never read The Legend of Sleepy Hollow I don't know how this audio adaptation compares to the original, so all I can say is it is a somewhat odd story.  Washington Irving's classic tale about an idiosyncratic school teacher and the legendary ghost of a small country village in New York is spooky in a lighthearted, non-creepy way that is appropriate for family listening.  The story starts off somewhat strangely with a montage of soundbites that I assume is supposed to create the feeling of ghosts and haunted woods; once past this the story improves.This is my third audio adaptation my Colonial Radio Theater and I have to say that, for the most part, they do a fine job (not quite as good as the BBC dramatizations, but then that is strictly a matter of opinion).  With a few exceptions their actors are animated, and they use a lot of sound effects which enhance the story; The Legend of Sleepy Hollow even includes a full-cast song.I enjoyed the story enough that I will listen to it again sometime -- it has also sparked my interest in finding out more about and perhaps reading Irving's original.

I've listened to enough of P.D. James' books by now to know she is not a favorite of mine, so why do I keep listening to her books?  I guess because when I'm at the library desperately in need of an audiobook to listen to, hers are one of the few that I know will at least be free of graphic sex, violence and profanity (except for her occasional use of the f-word, more on that below).Admittedly, what makes me continue to pick James' books off the library shelf is her elegant skill as a writer.  She has a gift with words that I find irresistable (since so few modern writers have it) that makes me keep trying her books, hoping that this one will be a 5-star read.Alas, it was not to be with The Private Patient.  In spite of the elegance of the prose, there are many things about this book that keep it from being any more than a 3-star read.  First is that this book, as all of James', is almost completely lacking in anything resembling suspense.  And for a book that touts itself as a murder mystery, that is a death sentence (no pun intended).  After all, what is a mystery without suspense?  A flat story, indeed.  To her credit, this time James did throw in a little twist at the end that gave credibility to the otherwise overly-contrived and unbelieveable motive of the murderer.  However, for some mysterious reason, she never stated it outright but only hinted at it.The second reason why this, as all of James' books, are only mediocre at best is her persistence in throwing in elements that have absolutely nothing to do with the plot of the book and which only serve to sabotage what would otherwise be a lovely, elegant story.  In the case of this book it was the dropping of the f-bomb in the middle (yes, it was only a few times but it was jarring, unnecessary and crude) and the inclusion of characters and a minor side story that, again, had no bearing on the plot (I kept thinking it would) and introduced issues I find distasteful.  I don't know why James persists in throwing such things into her books unless she feels it makes her more "relevant" and attractive to modern, younger readers.  Perhaps it does to some, but for me it degrades her otherwise fine writing.All in all a typical offering by P.D. James -- ok, but not great.  Slow moving with nothing to offer, really, except an interesting insight into modern British life.

Let me start by saying that we are a family of five avid cyclists (with three teenagers). We ride mountain bikes, road bikes, commuter bikes, beach bikes and I restore and ride vintage British bikes.  I almost always like to use my phone for tracking my rides, navigation, etc.  Sometimes my employer needs to be able to reach me quickly.  So taking the phone along is anywhere from a strong desire to a necessity.However - finding a quality and rugged mount for large, late model smartphone has been a challenge.  In the past, I had some very nice mounts but my phones outgrew those.  More recently, I've used a small frame saddle bag to hold the phone, but this is less than ideal.  I keep looking - primarily for a mount that is sturdy and reliable - and that is affordable and can accommodate a late model smartphone in a reasonable case.Now it seems I've finally found it!  This mount from Gear Beast is inexpensive, rugged and reliable.  The handlebar clamp seems to be made of very rugged polymer (possibly fiber filled).  The phone clamp has a gripper cushion for the rear of the phone (or case) and rubber grippers for the side clamps.  And this mount comes with the stretchy (rubber-bandy???) safety harness.  Just a little extra protection for your phone.I believe this is a SOLID 5 star item - especially when considering the low selling price!Note #1:  Just out of an abundance of caution (and I don't want to ruin a $700 phone), I tether the phone clamp portion of this mount to my handlebar with a small camera strap (threaded through the oval hole in the phone clamp portion of this mount).Note #2:  This mount will open wide enough to hold a Galaxy Note or Iphone Plus.

It is easy to call a product "professional grade" or "salon quality", but an entirely different matter to deliver a product that truly is.Our teenage daughters had been wanting a flat iron of their own, so I ordered this unit from Bebella. The Bebella heats up fast, but not as fast as the professional Iron (the professional iron heats to 425 in less than 8 seconds - unbelievable)...it takes about 30 seconds to reach maximum temperature. Also, the surface is well designed for easy gripping - this feature is very well done.Considering the high quality and good performance versus the low selling price (less than a third the price of my wife's professional iron) I consider this unit a solid 5 star value!We were very fortunate to receive a discount on this item in exchange for an honest opinion and unbiased review. Every so often, I run across an item that really surprises me and fully exceeds my expectations - this is truly one of those items! If you are looking for great sound in a rather small enclosure - and for a good price - this is the best I've found for its size (and price range).We are a family of five (three teenagers - woohoo) and we have a number of various Bluetooth speakers, including big brand speakers that cost quite a bit more than this speaker from TaoTronics. This speaker almost outperforms our Sony X33 (which cost us over $100). It does outperform several other models we spent a lot on from Altec Lansing and JBL.The neatly engineered design includes two forward-firing drivers, and an oblong rear-firing passive radiator.  It is a very similar acoustical and driver design to some very expensive Bluetooth speakers out there (some of which sell for crazy high prices).I've tried this speaker with wildly varying genres of music - from classical to 80s rock to bluegrass. It handles all of these with amazing ability - seriously. The sound is very balanced, and does not sound over processed. When you need smooth bass, you get smooth bass (and possibly a lot of it). When you need punch bass you get punchy bass. Enveloping mid-range? Yep. Crystal clear highs? Yep. And it seems to handle all volume levels very well.This speaker is well-constructed and I'm satisfied with the weather-resistant efforts in its design.. I especially like the ruggedized rubber surround and the clip for hanging (like on a backpack).I cannot imagine anyone not being impressed with this speaker considering its size and selling price.  In my opinion, this speaker is a SOLID 5 star item!I was very fortunate to receive a discount on this product for which I provided an honest opinion and unbiased review. I'll  be buying more of these at regular selling price for my nephew's birthdays.. If you have any questions about the product or my review, please post a comment below - I will reply promptly!

As a device-heavy family of five (three teenagers - woohoo) living in a rural area (poor signal strength causes cellular 3G/4G/LTE devices to deplete batteries quickly), we rely a lot on portable battery packs to keep our devices charged. In many ways they are more convenient than other types of chargers.I tested this E-life DuriPower pack utilizing a 1 amp resistive (fan-cooled) load tester - and I tested it for two discharge/recharge cycles. I was able to establish that this pack does almost meet its advertised rating of 10000mAh (raw). I monitored the recharge cycles for amperage demanded by this pack and am very impressed with how it manages incoming amperage to protect and extend the life of the lithium cells.  My actual reading was 9748mAh.  I expect this to get better and actually will probably exceed 10000mAh after a few more cycles.  This has been the case with almost every other lithium pack I've tested.  Most packs to not come this close to the stated/advertised capacity in my testing experience.I was very fortunate to receive a discount on this product in exchange for my honest opinion and unbiased review - and that is exactly what I have provided. If you have any questions about this product or my review, please post a comment below. I will respond promptly.

Let me start by saying that we are a family of five avid cyclists (including three teenagers). We ride mountain bikes, road bikes, commuter bikes, beach bikes and I restore and ride vintage British bikes.  I'm very familiar with the type of gear included in this kit - and have used many similar bags, patches, pumps, tools, etc. for years.This is a good kit with a GREAT pump!The pump is a dual stage pump - which means it delivers air on both strokes.  So when you are pumping, you are increasing the air volume and pressure twice as fast as a traditional single stage pump.  I call this engineering "stroke of genius" (yes, pun intended).  The concept has been around for decades, but this is the first time I've seen it implemented on a small, frame-mountable bike pump.  Awesome!The pump is made from a fiber-filled polymer that looks to be very high quality.  It is very sturdy, yet remains a very lightweight design.  And the mount - which is designed to mount between a bottle cage and the bike frame - is one of the best I've seen.The under saddle bag included with this kit is well made from ballistic nylon.  It is a smaller size bag - large enough for tools and a patch kit along with a road bike tube.  It is not large enough to include a mountain bike tube.The levers are small, fiber-filled polymer - strong and lightweight.  It is nice that three are included rather than the standard count of two.The included patches are the "scab" type stick-on patches.  These are not my favorite, but they can be used quickly and are generally good enough to get you back home.  Sometimes they last much longer.The included tool is the most comprehensive tool I think I've ever seen (except for the possibility of adding a chain break tool).  It has every size of Allen wrench you'll ever see on a bike....along with sockets and a wrench.  It is a bit on the heavy side but very sturdy.Overall, this kit is a super value.  You could really consider that you are buying the pump - and getting all the other stuff for free!I would rate the pump a solid 5 stars - and the other items 4 or 5 stars. This light is outstanding!  But let's just cut right to the Pros and Cons...Pros:Bright - very bright for its compact sizeQuick and easy to install on railQuick and easy to removeVery compactGood fit and finish (I cannot find a single flaw in the finish)Cons:Logo is large and noticeable - would rather have this subdued (user correctable)Silver screws on rear of unit could/should have been black (also user correctable)I tried this installed on a number of different arms. The Sinvitron is a good bit brighter than the TLR-4, so the 180 lumen rating seems very realistic (the TLR-4 is rated at 115 lumens).The two cons I mentioned are really being a bit nit picky.  A small dab of black paint or even a Sharpie marker can correct this issues quickly.I have noticed others complaining about the CR2 battery - but that is really the standard battery for lights (and some lasers) this small (again, like the TLR-4).  I keep a number of CR2s on-hand for my other lights and lasers.  The CR2 is a great lithium cell that has tremendous capacity and shelf life - and not that hard to find.  I wonder what other possible battery they were expecting to find in a very bright light this small (I don't know of another option).I did add a dab of silicone grease to the threads and gasket (I do this will all of my tactical lights).  For the selling price - this light is a bargain!In the photos below, the AR is just for size comparison (obviously a hand would block the output from this light).  It is perfect mounted on the side of the CZ Scorpion EVO.

I would definitely recommend this book to anyone in a sales role, as it will help you to achieve and exceed your goals.

I had little knowledge of peripheral neuropathy until reading this book. I am amazed at the volume of information packed into a short read that will help people to live their lives with this disease. The author uses his firsthand experience with peripheral neuropathy to provide great advice on how to manage this disease including diet options, exercise options, some medications, and being conscious of your body. I'm glad that I learned about this disease and would highly recommend this book

My friend just got laid off from her job and was looking to start her own business making jewelry. I'm glad I found this book because it will be so helpful to her in setting up a small business doing what she loves. From information on different types of jewelry to make and how to market your jewelry, this book has everything you could need to get a small jewelry business going. I will definitely be passing this book on to my friend and would recommend it to anyone creative enough to make their own jewelry.

Anyone starting a new business knows the importance of a good business, unfortunately writing a business plan isn't the easiest thing to do. This book will help with every aspect of writing a successful business plan! With all of the reasons why a business plan is important to step by step instructions on how to write a successful business plan that any investor would love, this book has it all. When I get everything together to get my business started I will definitely be following the advice in this book to be successful!

While the low carb diet has been around for a long time, it really hit the media with a bang when the Adkins diet came about. Since then, you don't hear a lot about low carb diets anymore, but they are still a great weight loss option. This book lays out why low carb is a good way to eat, while providing tips on what foods to eat and what exercise can do to help. Along with all of this great information is a short list of recipes for every meal to get you started. I would highly recommend this book!

More and more people are looking to make money on the internet and one way to do that is by blogging. Blogging can be used for a multitude of things, including of course making money. I have recently considered starting a blog for no other reason than to just write and this book provided helpful information on where to get started, why to do it, and how to maintain it. I definitely recommend this book to anyone looking to start a blog.

Anytime there is information available to help with diseases that dont require relying on medication, Im all for it. This book has great information about what inflammatory diseases are and specific diet changes to make to help. Along with all of the excellent information, there is a great list of recipes for any time of day  breakfast, lunch, or dinner. I will definitely be passing this book on to my friend who suffers from an inflammatory disease and would highly recommend this book.

Since I have never done crochet before, this book is a great option to get me started on my path to crocheting. This book is packed with information on materials to use, how to read a pattern, and even a few easy patterns to follow. It has definitely given me motivation to start crocheting and I would highly recommend this book to anyone looking to get started with crocheting.

Everyone I know loves a good fantasy novel and this one delivers in a big way. From the very first page, you will want to know what is going to happen next and you will have a hard time putting this book down. I can't wait to read the next book in this series and to see more from Ms. Berg. I highly recommend this book.

I'm a big fan of Westerns because I feel like there is truth to how it was in those days in every story, and this book was no exception. Robert Vaughan really makes you feel like you are in the scenes and tells an amazing story. This is a great book for those who love westerns or someone just picking it up on a whim. I definitely recommend this book.

It is becoming more and more popular to work for yourself  from home, and this book is an excellent read to get started. With important information on the advantages, disadvantages, and is it the right choice for you, this book will get you thinking. Along with this great information are over one hundred ideas including popular choices, jobs that provide services, sales, and creating crafts. This book really will answer all of your questions if this the route you want to go.

Ive tried at home yoga before with little success, but with this book I am able to complete basic, beginner poses with very little difficulty. This book gives a great history of where yoga comes from as well as the amazing things it can do for your body  internal and external. Ms. Faye provides excellent instruction for initial beginner poses to get you started at home. I find this beneficial because now I wont feel foolish going to a yoga class. I would recommend this book to anyone looking to get started with yoga.

I have always been very interested in photography and am looking forward to getting started. Mr. Clyde has great advice, tips, and tricks to be a great photographer and take great photos with a digital camera. Like anything, taking the best photos out there will not happen right away, but using the tips provided and practicing regularly will allow you to be the photographer you want to be. I would absolutely recommend this book to anyone wanting to get started in photography and I know I will be keeping this book handy as a resource on my journey.

While I had never heard of the Mediterranean Diet, I am looking to make changes to how I eat and this book caught my eye. This book gave me a lot of great information on the benefits of eating foods from the Mediterranean  fish, lots of vegetables, non-processed foods, and olive oil. It is easy to know what you have to do to start eating better, but harder to take the steps to make those changes. This book will be an excellent guide to make it easy and as painless as possible.

With the most recent outbreak of Ebola, I was concerned about what to look for and how to get treatment if needed. This book has so much fantastic information on what Ebola is, the symptoms, and essential treatments necessary if you have contracted Ebola. With so much media reporting different things, it was nice to find a book that I could truly feel like the information was accurate. I definitely recommend this book.

I am always looking for books by authors I haven't read before and am so glad that I found this book. While this is the second in a series, it has the feel of an independent story that is very easy to follow. Starting off with a plane crash and ending with murder, this book definitely keeps you interested and entertained. I can't wait to read more from Roxy Jewell and highly recommend this book.

Those of who are parents know that it is the hardest job! It's hard to know what to teach them and when is the right time to teach them. This book, while on the lighter, funnier side, has very helpful information on getting our children to toddlerhood and beyond. The basic principle of this book is to let kids explore and learn, while teaching them the right way to do things (or the safe way). I highly recommend this book to any parent or soon to be parent.

I've always wanted to own a rice cooker but have been intimidated that I would mess it up. I've recently considered buying one but wanted to find recipe information first. I'm so glad I chose this book! With recipes for not only rice dishes, but breakfast recipes, recipes including quinoa, lentils, and vegetables, this book has everything that you will need to be successful at using a rice cooker for every meal. I highly recommend this book!

Accelerated learning has been around for a long time but hasn't been utilized to its full potential. This book breaks down what accelerated learning is and how to use it in every aspect of your life. This is a great book for students but also a great guide for those who just need to jump start how they learn and for businesses. I highly recommend this book.

Because I dont tend to spend a lot of time browsing on the internet  I have my specific web sites I go to and thats about it  I wasnt one hundred percent sure what a TED talk was, but I am always looking for ways to tell a better story. This book answered my questions about TED talks and gave me so much more than I was expecting! This book has great advice on connecting with your audience, making eye contact, creating an emotional connection, and ways to share your own story that you cannot go wrong. I highly recommend this book.practice

I have followed Weight Watchers in the past but didnt have enough meal ideas to keep me from getting bored. I am ready to try again and am glad that I found this book. This book has over fifty recipes for meals, snacks, and desserts that it will definitely take me a long time to get bored with what Im eating. I am so glad I found these great recipes and would absolutely recommend this book to anyone  following Weight Watchers or not.

If there is ever a disaster  natural or otherwise  I want to be prepared, which is why I decided to read this book. After reading the reviews, I knew this was the right book for what I was looking for! With chapters on how to protect your house, yourself and family members, and the basic things to do to survive when everything we know and are used to are no longer. I highly recommend this book!

Meditation has always been something Ive been interested in but havent found the time to study it. Now that I have the time, Im so excited I picked this book as my first look into meditation. This book has so many excellent tips on how to get started, what can be used in conjunction with meditation  like music, and yoga. This book really has everything you need to get started on your path to being an expert at meditation and balancing your emotions and life. I definitely recommend this book.

I am a sucker for love stories and am always looking for authors I've never read before. This is the first book I've found from Mr. Gedall and I'm so glad I picked it up. While this story isn't very long, it really tells a well-rounded love story from beginning to end. I can't wait to read more from Mr. Gedall and would recommend this book.

In today's dating world, I think that both men and women could use all the help they can get. I am recently back on the dating market after ten years with someone and it has been extremely challenging, so I am so glad I found this book. This book will give you excellent advice on how to get into the dating world and how to find the right one for you - which I believe there is a right one for all of us. So much great advice is packed into this book that I would highly recommend this to anyone.

While the DASH diet was originally created for people with high blood pressure and bad cardiovascular health, this diet will work for anyone who is looking to lose weight. The basics of the DASH diet increase fats and moderate your protein intake, but this causes your body will start to burn the fat that is stored in your body. This book not only provides a brief history of where the DASH diet comes from to a full menu of what to eat on a regular basis  including great recipes for breakfast, soups, main dishes, snacks, and even dessert. I highly recommend this book.

We've heard for years that low carb is better and there are a multitude of diets out there to follow. I have found that reducing my carb intake has been the most successful for me but I get bored with the same old recipes. I am so glad that I found this book to help me mix up what I've been eating on a regular basis. With step by step instructions and nutritional information this book has it all. I highly recommend this book.

I believe anyone can learn to be a leader but people without the inherent sense of leadership may need more help than others. That is where this book comes into play. This book has so much great advice and tips on how to become an excellent leader and persevere at leadership. I believe this is a great book for anyone to read as everyone can gain some skills to help in every aspect of their lives from this advice.

*Note: you should have read the first part before starting this one. This is a continuation of the same story*Wow this story just gets better and better! Hansel Part 1 leaves off when Hansel/Edgar/Luke kicks the girl he was testing for a sub out then finds out she was actually Leah. This part picks up a few days later and man. I am loving this story. I am so glad I gave it a try. The whole dark erotic fairy tale was kind of an eh idea for me, but man is this good. If you like dark, of you like hot, if you like characters that have issues but use those issue to make the sexy time super intense than this is the story for you.In this chapter you get to see more of Luke's past pre-Hansel. This story is so intense my heart was just pounding from the moment I start reading until I get to the end. I just have to keep going and see what will happen. Luke has not had a good life. He has a pretty messed up childhood and man...no wonder he is the way he is now. He wants Leah, but doesn't think he can have her. He is a monster. She wouldn't want him if she knew everything he did. He can't really deal with his feelings for her. He tries to burry them with alcohol and such, but oh my heart just broke for him.Leah is all set to go back home and try and forget Hansel/Luke, but she still has one more night in town. She goes out and happens to run into Hansel. Oh, Leah is so kind. She cares so much for him. She is wonderful even if he hurts her heart mistakenly at times. They both want the other, but can Luke deal with his past and let Leah take care of him? Can he put aside some of his demons so they can have a future together? Oh this story is amazing. I absolutely love it. Now on to part 3 to see what happens next!This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

Phew. Hansel was...part 1 is kind of amazing. I read the synopsis and thought dark erotic fairy tale? That could be good or it could be a disaster. I will either love it or I will hate it. I hadn't read anything by the author before so I just decided to give it a go. It is a quick read so if it was bad I wouldn't be wasting a lot of my time. Well this was far from bad. I loved this story, at least this first part. It is dark and gritty and everything I wanted. The story is so much better than I thought it would be. If you do not like dark than this is not the story for you. It is kind of an intense read.Hansel and Gretel(Leah) first meet after Leah is kidnapped by Mother Goose. She looks the part of Gretel and Mother has been needing that. She is locked up and her only source of companionship is Hansel on the other side of the wall. He makes a small hole in the wall so they can talk and hold hands. He tries to help Leah as much as he can, and she him. It sounds horrible and you get to see what it was like through some flashback. Man Mother is crazy. Obviously. She would have to be, but I loved how crazy she was. I loved that she was crazy with fairy tales. It was just a really interesting idea. Terrible for the kids, but she was a great villain.The story takes place years after Hansel and Leah escape Mother's house. Leah stumbles upon Hansel again only he is now a famous Dom. He has subs who he uses to try and be with Leah when he knows he can't. It was...oh. It was hot and intense and everything wrapped up in this dark fairy tale. Leah and Hansel obviously both wanted to be with the other, but not sure why they weren't after they got out. You don't get to see much of the in between time yet, but phew! I cannot wait to see what happens! Amazing read so far. Now on to part 2!This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

The best thing about All Your Reasons is that is was a really short, quick read. It doesn't really have much substance to it so it was just blah.Presley is this girl who apparently falls in love with everyone instantly and doesn't make the right choices with men. She is married to a rock star, but has been separated for six months. She just wanted him to put her first instead of his career, which he wouldn't do. Now he wants to come back, after his tour, and be husband and wife again. Apparently she had only known the guy for 4 weeks before they got married and none of her friends liked him even then. She also reveals at one point that she almost married a guy twenty years older than her when she was eighteen. So she seems to just jump right into things without thinking much. The problem with the story was even though I know all this about her I don't really feel like I know Presley. She meets and falls for Jett instantly, but I have no idea why. Because he is good looking? Maybe? I don't know.Jett sleeps with lots of women, but has never found one he would want to settle down with. Until he sees Presley at a club one night and just like that he knows she is different and he wants her. Again not sure why. He mentions at one point that he can talk to her unlike most women he meets. So I guess that is as good a reason to be instantly in love.Now everything in this story happens instantly. They meet and instantly both just want to get out of there and have sex. The sex scenes? Well they are basically just take your clothes off as fast as possible and get to it. Not a lot of working up to it or anything. It was just...it made even the sex scenes not that good as I just couldn't even connect with them being that attracted to each other. They were all over before they started. I didn't buy it so it didn't work. Instead of feeling like they just can't wait, they have to be together, it was awkward. It could have used a bit of development so you could actually get to know the characters some or at least let you feel the attraction between the two. It just wasn't there for me. There is some slight drama with Presley's husband, but not much. It was all just too quick. There is a second book with the rest of their story, but I don't think I will read it. I just found this one to be kind of dull so I don't need to read more.This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

Maybe In Another Life was not quite what I expected. It started off not so good for me, but by the end I was loving it (and I loved where the story ended up). At first I was curious to read it as it reminded me of that movie where the girl gets on the train or she doesn't...sliding doors maybe it was called? I only vaguely remember it and I thought this would be a similar thing. It was surprising and I really liked a lot of the story and the thoughts behind it.At the beginning I really did not like Hannah. I also didn't like the style of writing and it was just something that I put aside to maybe pick up again and finish. The writing was too descriptive at times in a way that I don't like. For example:I don't need to know all of that. It just takes me out of the story as it is unnecessary and kind of bulky and just not for me. Pair that with not liking Hannah, not liking her 'well if I just pretend like I don't know that I am doing something I shouldn't then that is okay and I am a good person' thing. I really just did not like her attitude towards everything. I found her annoying. Then we have the time split. The decision to stay with Ethan her ex or to go home with Gabby her friend. After that I didn't put the book down until I got to the end. After that it was really interesting to read what happened in both timelines. You would get one chapter from one then one chapter from the other timeline. It was fun.I don't want to say too much as I don't want to ruin anything for those who have not read this yet, but if you find it just kind of blah at first keep going. It does get better. I loved all the talk of the one and soul mates and just knowing this person is right for you and so on. I truly believe there is more than one person for everyone. It doesn't make sense to me otherwise. To think in this entire world there is only one person for me and I was lucky enough to find them and live in the same area as them? To me that is crazy. If I hadn't met my husband, if I hadn't gone to college in Washington state, if I hadn't made the decisions I did I am sure I would have found someone else and be equally as happy as I am now. Or be happy by myself. Either way it would have worked out. Or maybe we would have found each other some other way. Who knows. So it was interesting reading a story where the characters talked about that and you see if there really is one person for them. I liked seeing what that one decision would and wouldn't change. If no matter the decisions you would end up in the same place or not.Where everything ends up I really enjoyed. Things happen, you make decision and then you deal with what happens afterwards. Really a great read once I got into the story.This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

Paper Hearts is the story of Mia and Jensen. It is a second chance romance and I really enjoyed it. This was the second book I read this week where the main character had qualities I normally hate, but the story was written in such a way that I really liked them. I always love when that happens.If you have read Torn Hearts, the free prequel to this story, then you know Mia and Jensen were in love. They both thought the other was the one for them, but some bumps int he road tore them apart. Her mom said something in that story about how she was not with Jensen because she didn't like the idea of him being away at school with other women and Mia not being there. That Mia didn't like not having control of the situation. I see that. I see that in her. She just seems to be afraid of everything so much so that she is missing out. If she can control everything then everything will be fine, but if not...When she found out Jensen got some other girl pregnant her thoughts were immediately that she cannot be with him anymore, that should have been her baby even though she says she doesn't want kids, it just completely destroys her.This story starts off with Mia in New York, where Jensen lives, working for the same place Jensen often works. So of course they get thrown together on an assignment. And what does Mia try to do every time? Run. That is what she always does. If things are uncomfortable, if she has to deal with emotions or anything, she runs. She tries to just stay in her safe, controlled little bubble. The problem is that doesn't work. She still loves Jensen even though she won't admit it. And his daughter? Well she doesn't even want to think about her. She is Jensen's with some other woman! Mia is ridiculous, but she is kind of pitiful at the same time. So much so that it is hard to be annoyed with her. I was reading and just thought normally this would be so irritating, but she is so sad I can't be annoyed with her.Through it all Jensen keeps trying to win Mia over. He has never moved on from her. She has always been the one for him, and now that she in in New York for a few months he thinks this is his chance. He writes a column for the newspaper and she is in it a lot (even if she doesn't realize it). It is a long and bumpy road to get Mia to realize that a) she can take a chance with Jensen again and b) what her dreams were might not be her dreams anymore. That maybe she needs to make big changes to get what she really wants. She just seems to put her head in the sand and not know what is actually happening, but I really enjoyed this story. She is so afraid, but she learns to not be so much by the end. It was painful at times, heartbreaking for poor Jensen who kept throwing himself out there, but you do get the happily ever after eventually. Really a great read.This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

Gah - Mia Sheridan really knows how to make you feel the feels. While Greyson's Vow was not as devastating as some of her books (I'm looking at you Kyland) that doesn't mean it wasn't just as amazing. Really I started reading it and loving it, but thought good this is not going to make me an emotional mess before I have to go out and meet my friends. Only by the end it did. I teared up because it was just so beautiful! Oh Mia Sheridan, you get me to feel all the feels for these amazing characters!Kira and Greyson - there are not two people more perfect for each other. I loved them both, loved watching them grow closer and work through things and be better people because they know the other. I just loved them so much! They both get the other person and phew were they hot together!Kira is one of the sweetest, kindest, nicest people. She has such a huge heart that she shares with those who need it. She is always giving, always trying to make things just a little bit better for those who don't have much. She is this ray of sunshine that you can't help but love. Man the things she does to help others, the things she does for those she cares about...absolutely amazing. Yes she has crazy ideas, and they don't always work out the way she planned, but she was so much fun. She has this youthful exuberance that just makes you happy. She has not always had it easy, she has a lot that has happened to her that would have crushed others spirits until they were nothing, but she just picks herself back up, dusts herself off and gets on with it.Greyson has not had the easiest of lives either. Always reminded by his dad and stepmom how he is not wanted, how much they hate him, it was rough. When you learn everything that happened, man I could  just cry for the child he was. He does get in some trouble with the law and ends up doing time. Now the people in his town don't know him, don't want to know him, as he is an ex con. They are so judgemental it is terrible. He really is a good man, but he has a lot of hurt inside. Since he got out he has not really been living, not until his little witch comes into his life.When Kira comes to him with her business proposition to help him save his winery and her to get out from under her fathers thumb it was fun. Greyson makes a lot of assumptions about who Kira is and what she is like. He thinks she is a spoiled little princess and really doesn't want much to do with her, but he is out of options. It was so much fun. I was just waiting for when Greyson would realize that he was being a huge judgemental jerk. I loved it.The best thing about the story is it is kind of fairy tale-ish, but the scaly dragon who breathes fire falls in love with his little witch. I loved that. I loved the imagery and just everything about it. How it started off as a negative, but soon turned into terms on endearment. Really a great read. There are issues and things to overcome, things to work on, to get to the happily every after but it was just beautiful. It was so sweet. It was just a wonderful read. Kira and Greyson are perfect together. It just took them some time to figure that out.This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

*Note: I received a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review*Overall I really enjoyed The Madmen's City. It was a fun noir style book. It is like a dark super hero, Batman type story. I can just see Towton as a similar city to Gotham. I loved that aspect of it.Towton is a dark, gritty, corrupt city. There are two different families ruling different parts of the city. They have their hands in everyones pockets. The cops are corrupt and the ruling families can get away with anything. There are few people who are actively working to try and keep the city safe. Gwen is learning from her father, the vigilante known as Phantom. Phantom also works with Ethos, the other masked vigilante. While Phantom catches the bad guys and turns them over to the cops (only to have them be set free again usually), Phantom kills the bad guys and doesn't think twice about it. After all why capture them to have them be set loose to kill more innocent people? I understand why he does what he does and in his place I might do the same.Everything is going great, Phantom and Ethos sharing patrolling the city. Only one night Phantom gets arrested for murder, a murder Ethos committed. Someone is setting up Phanton and Gwen is determined to figure out who and save her dad.When I started writing this up I re-read the synopsis and thought Gwen is 17? Really? She seems much younger. While reading I kept thinking she should be annoying me, but she was written in a way that was fun instead of annoying. She seems really young and not the smartest person. Well it is that she really just rushes head long into situations without thinking about them too much. She doesn't have a lot of patients and she sees everything in very black and white. She really just acted like a kid who would be upset if she didn't get her own way. Also some of her thought processes I didn't quite get. She doesn't like Ethos/Silas because he kills people. She says at one time that she would never ever kill anyone (so then I kept waiting for that to happen. It was near the beginning of the book that she said that so it was just like yep, that will happen eventually), but she is on board with the death penalty. Apparently she can't kill anyone, but the cops can. I just seemed odd to me especially since a lot of the cops are corrupt so...Anyways in order for Gwen to figure out who is setting up her dad and save him from jail she has to work with Silas. Silas who was so sweet, who obviously likes Gwen, but who would be hurt by her mean words she would spew without thinking. Sometimes I thought I don't even know why he likes her, but I liked him. I got him. He was out doing something and he is good at it. Yes he kills people, but only bad people.He does what he has to to try and keep his city safe. Reading him was heartbreaking at times. Gwen is so mean, cuts him so deep, and she doesn't even realize it. There are also some friends and family to deal with, some good, some bad, and it was just a lot of fun to read.So why is it not rated higher? Well it was a good four plus stars most of the way through until the end. I was reading and thought oh, this must be the first book in what will be a series. I only have a few minutes left and there is no way to wrap everything up in that time. Only that is what the author does. The story gets wrapped up all well, there we go everything is sunshine and rainbows now. It didn't make sense. It didn't work. There is no way what happened in two pages stopped all the badness from happening anymore and made everything great. Also Gwen suddenly likes Silas and that felt like it came out of left field. I didn't see her actually coming around to him that much until the rush at the end to fit it in. So I was loving the story, but the end was way too rushed. Still a good read, but know that the end is a bit rushed.This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

4.5 starsI am so glad Aurora Rose Reynolds started writing these Until series spin off books. I love the original books and it is so much fun getting to see those characters again and seeing them as parents watching their children find their boom. I just love it. And all of the kids are just as amazing as their parents so...I just love the Mayson clan!Until Jax is the story of Cash and Lilly's son Jax. He always heard about the boom - when you see the one for you you just instantly know it. All the kids kind of think it is an old wives tale, but Jax has always kind of wanted it to happen to him. After all he sees how all of the parents are together and he wants that. He wants that one person that he can love and care about with his whole heart. He is a sweetheart.Ellie did not even know what she was getting into when she meets Jax and the Mayson clan. She was just pulled from a horrible situation (if you have read Until July you know a little bit about that) and she has never really had that family that she wants. She has her daughter, Hope, but the rest of her family, at least those who cared about her, are gone. She is not used to trusting people and counting on them for things as she has always had to try and survive by herself. She has always had to provide for Hope by herself. When things go down and Jax knows Ellie is his boom he does whatever he can to move Ellie and Hope to his town. They can even stay with him while she looks for a place to stay. Not that he is going to let them leave...When Jax finds out Ellie has a daughter at first he is shocked, but it doesn't really matter to him. Ellie is who he wants and he will love her daughter as well. When he meets Hope he instantly falls for her as well. Hope is so dang cute! She wraps Jax around her little finger and gets away with everything. It was so sweet.Hope is so adorable! Watching Jax take to her and be this amazing father was so much fun. You can just see how much he cares about both of these ladies and I loved it.Ellie doesn't know how to trust people and she fears if she lets Jax in he will leave and then she will have to try and survive by herself again. She tries not to get her hopes up as everything has been taken away from her in the past, but how can she resist Jax especially when he is so adamant that this is going to happen. That they are going to get to know each other and date and live happily ever after. She still has a hard time really opening up especially when his past keeps trying to ruin things. She is very insecure, but Jax will do whatever he can to reassure her and keep her and Hope safe. He does push her, but she needs it. You can see how much he cares about her and doesn't want her fears to ruin what they have.Ellie, Jax and Hope just make such a cute family. I love that he is just as alpha male as his dad and uncles. I also love that they have such similar situations, but at the same time they are very different. He can relate a lot to what she has gone through and her situation and everything just clicked. It was like these two are meant to be! And Lilly is such a sweetheart with Ellie. I love that Ellie gets this whole other family, the family she has always wanted. These two are just so perfect for each other. They don't always have it easy with Ellie's insecurities and unresolved past, but together they can get through it. If you enjoyed the Until series then you will not want to miss this book. Such a great read.This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

Wow The Air He Breathes was just an incredible read. It is one of those books that just broke me down, but then put me back together in a much better way. One of those books where I care so much for the characters that I feel everything. It has been a long time since I have had a book affect me as much as this one and it was amazing.Elizabeth and Tristan have both suffered loses that neither has really dealt with yet. They are both so broken it is heartbreaking. While Tristan has been pushing everyone away, acting like a super jerk to keep people from getting close, Elizabeth just doesn't have that option. She has her daughter Emma to worry about. She doesn't want to become her mother and force Emma to take care of her. She has to keep it together, at least somewhat, so she will be there for her daughter.Tristan is the town jerk. Everyone thinks he is this horrible human being, maybe on the run from the law or something, and you should watch out. He will get you. Only he really isn't. Elizabeth can see him. She can see that he is hurting just as much as she is. She can see that he is really a kind person behind that gruff facade. She can see what he is hiding because she is doing the same. Ah these two just killed me!"He was hard to look at, because he was so broken, but every scarred part of his existence seemed to draw me in."Elizabeth is such a kind and caring soul. She is having a hard time, but somehow things aren't quite so bad with Tristan around. Even though he doesn't want to be her friend, she knows they need each other. They can help each other try and remember their loses. This book....seriously it made me feel all the feels. There were many times I teared up for these characters. There were times when I was so devastated as I just couldn't see how this wouldn't end in heartbreak for the both of them, they are both just so broken, but it was so beautiful at the same time. Tristan's chapters were particularly hard to read, but particularly beautiful. There was just so much pain in there, but it was beautiful.Elizabeth and Tristan slowly start to become friends and open up to each other. They are heartbreaking to watch, but so wonderful together. And Tristan with Emma? Oh, my heart almost couldn't take how incredibly sweet he is. I am not really a kid person, but Tick and Tock? Oh, my heart was so full watching them together. Tristan really has this incredibly big heart. Once he lets Elizabeth in he is just the sweetest. His kindness to others, people others don't even notice, is incredible. He is a truly a remarkable person touched by lose. I cannot get over how much I loved these characters.Through the book everyone kept warning Elizabeth about Tristan. How she should stay away, how he is bad new, etc. Oh, these townspeople made me angry. I cared so much for these characters that whenever someone would say something bad about one of them I would just get angry. I was very defensive and had to put the book aside a few times and just get my angry rant out so I could go on. It was all very realistic in how the close-minded small town people were. I couldn't live there that is for sure. And the worst offender for me? Faye, Elizabeth's bff. She does provide some comic relief, but I couldn't forgive her for not standing by her friend. For not trusting that her friend knows what she is doing. For not trying to see past the awful rumors that have no basis in fact.This book was just an incredible read. There were times when things were revealed, or something would happen, that would just rip my heart out. There were times when I was just so full of love I was overwhelmed. Times when I was completely devastated, and times that were so hopeful and happy. This book about losing and learning to love again, about the painful process of moving on and letting love in, was simply beautiful. Tristan was so wonderful, such a great person, and even when he ran, when he tried to push Elizabeth away, he never really got far. It was hard at times to see how these two broken people would ever be whole again, but gah! I really loved this story. It made me feel all the feels. I finished reading and just couldn't get the story out of my head. Even now, a few days after finishing, I am still wrapped up in it. Amazing. Beautiful. Just such an incredible story. Definitely give this book a read.This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland

Snapped was another great Tracer series read. I just love these. I love reading how everyone goes about trying to solve the crimes. Even though some of the characters in this story annoyed the bejeezus out of me I still loved reading it.Snapped is the story of Sophie and Jonah. At the end of the last book Sophie had been kidnapped by the killer and was rescued just in the nick of time by Jonah and the cops. There was something between the two of them even then, but with that incident Jonah didn't want to overstep and try to start something when she is still healing.When this story opens Sophie is on her way to the local university to sign up for some classes. She wants to try and get a promotion at work so she is trying to take classes to help her career. Only she never makes it to registration as a gunman opens fire. Three people were killed, multiple injured before the gunman killed himself. Sophie was there watching as a pregnant lady died across from her. So not the best time for Sophie. Just trying to get over her abduction and now this.Jonah is one of the cops that responds to the school shooting and when he sees Sophie there he is worried about her. He likes her, he just might not admit how much even to himself. Now that she is a witness to the shooting he really should stay away. Only he can't.Sophie was annoying in this story. She treated all men like they only want one thing from her - sex. She also keeps trying to throw herself at Jonah and have sex with him as a way to like repay him for stuff. She is all kinds of messed up in the head, but she frustrated me to no end. I just wanted to be like can't you see how amazing Jonah is? He is so nice to you and obviously doesn't just want a one night stand. You keep trying to use sex with him, and he doesn't take you up on it and you still think the only thing he wants is sex. Argh she was frustrating at times. She has a lot going on and when she remembers seeing something that prevents the police from wrapping up this shooting in a nice little bow she gets in even more trouble. Someone is after here and she doesn't make the smartest decisions. You would think almost getting yourself killed multiple times would make you more cautious, but apparently not with her. She is set against doing what Jonah wants her to do to keep herself safe because...well because she just is.Jonah gets frustrated with Sophie just like I did. He would get so angry with her and I loved it.
